洛斯阿拉莫斯的灯光下，巫师们熬夜不眠

（呆在车里，忘记大门）

是拯救世界还是毁灭世界，时间会告诉我们答案

——詹姆斯·梅里尔，

《天秤座之下：重量和尺寸》，

摘自《勇敢面对自然》

Los Alamos’ lights where wizards stay up late

(Stay in the car, forget the gate)

To save the world or end it, time will tell

—James Merrill,

“Under Libra: Weights and Measures,”

from Braving the Elements

序幕

Prologue

1994 年 9 月

September 1994

他们从伦敦和洛杉矶等遥远的地方来到波士顿，几十名中年男子在 1994 年的一个秋季周末相聚，庆祝他们 25 年前的成就。这些科学家和工程师曾设计和建造了 ARPANET，这个计算机网络彻底改变了通讯方式，催生了全球互联网。他们在 20 世纪 60 年代默默无闻地工作；他们中的许多人在为网络做出重大贡献时还只是研究生。其他人曾是导师。他们中的大多数人从未因他们的成就而获得太多认可。

They came to Boston from as far away as London and Los Angeles, several dozen middle-aged men, reuniting for a fall weekend in 1994 to celebrate what they had done twenty-five years earlier. These were the scientists and engineers who had designed and built theARPANET, the computer network that revolutionized communications and gave rise to the global Internet. They had worked in relative obscurity in the 1960s; a number of them had been only graduate students when they made significant contributions to the network. Others had been mentors. Most of them had never gained much recognition for the achievement.

总部位于剑桥的计算机公司 Bolt Beranek and Newman 曾是他们的重心，曾雇佣过他们中的许多人，曾建立并运营最初的 ARPA 网络，但随着互联网像一座围绕其最早社区的繁华城市一样发展，该公司逐渐变得默默无闻。现在，在安装第一个网络节点 25 年后，BBN 邀请了所有 ARPANET 先驱者聚集在一起，希望通过举办盛大的周年庆典来提升自己的知名度。

Bolt Beranek and Newman, a computer company based in Cambridge, had been their center of gravity, had employed many of them, had built and operated the original ARPA network, then slipped into relative obscurity as the Internet grew like a teeming city around its earliest neighborhood. Now, a quarter-century after installing the first network node, BBN had invited all of theARPANETpioneers to come together, hoping to heighten its own profile by throwing a lavish celebration marking the anniversary.

参加聚会的许多人已经多年未见或联系。周五下午，当他们走进科普利广场大厅参加庆祝活动的新闻发布会时，他们环顾房间寻找熟悉的面孔。

Many of those at the reunion hadn’t seen one another or been in touch for years. As they filtered into the lobby of the Copley Plaza for a Friday afternoon press conference kicking off the celebration, they scanned the room for familiar faces.

硅谷一家企业研究机构的主管鲍勃·泰勒 (Bob Taylor) 来参加聚会是为了追忆往昔，但他的个人使命也是纠正一个长期存在的错误说法。多年来一直有传言称，ARPANET 是为了在遭受核攻击时保护国家安全而建立的。这是一个神话，长期以来一直无人质疑，以至于被广泛接受为事实。

Bob Taylor, the director of a corporate research facility in Silicon Valley, had come to the party for old times sake, but he was also on a personal mission to correct an inaccuracy of long standing. Rumors had persisted for years that theARPANEThad been built to protect national security in the face of a nuclear attack. It was a myth that had gone unchallenged long enough to become widely accepted as fact.

泰勒曾是国防部高级研究计划署计算机研究办公室的年轻主任，也是阿帕网的发起人。该项目体现了最和平的意图——将全国各地科学实验室的计算机连接起来，以便研究人员可以共享计算机资源。泰勒知道阿帕网及其后代互联网与支持或生存战争无关——从来都不知道。但他感到自己在掌握这一知识方面相当孤独。

Taylor had been the young director of the office within the Defense Department’s Advanced Research Projects Agency overseeing computer research, and he was the one who had started theARPANET . The project had embodied the most peaceful intentions—to link computers at scientific laboratories across the country so that researchers might share computer resources. Taylor knew theARPANET and its progeny, the Internet, had nothing to do with supporting or surviving war—never did.Yet he felt fairly alone in carrying that knowledge.

最近，主流媒体纷纷报道核辐射生存情景这一可怕神话，并将其作为既定事实加以报道。当《时代》杂志犯下这一错误时，泰勒曾给编辑写过一封信，但该杂志并未刊登。澄清事实的努力无异于追逐风，泰勒开始觉得自己像个怪人。

Lately, the mainstream press had picked up the grim myth of a nuclear survival scenario and had presented it as an established truth. WhenTimemagazine committed the error, Taylor wrote a letter to the editor, but the magazine didn’t print it. The effort to set the record straight was like chasing the wind; Taylor was beginning to feel like a crank.

那天晚上，在科普利酒店吃晚餐时，泰勒在房间的另一边看到了一位身材魁梧、留着浓密小胡子的老人。他立刻认出这个人是唯一能够令人信服地证实他的故事的人。这个人就是他的前老板查理·赫茨菲尔德，泰勒在 ARPA 工作时，赫茨菲尔德曾担任该局局长。两人最后一次见面是在几年前，那时还没有人关心这个网络是如何开始的。现在看到赫茨菲尔德，泰勒很振奋。他又回到了知道真相的人中间。现在他们会把事情理顺的。

Across the room at dinner that night at the Copley, Taylor spotted an elderly, heavyset man with a thick mustache. He recognized him immediately as the one person who could convincingly corroborate his story. It was his old boss, Charlie Herzfeld, who had been the director of ARPA when Taylor worked there. The two men had last seen each other years earlier, before anyone else cared about how the network began. Seeing Herzfeld now, Taylor was buoyed. He was back among the people who knew the real story. Now they’d straighten things out.

1 最快的百万美元

1 The Fastest Million Dollars

1966 年 2 月

February 1966

鲍勃·泰勒通常开车上班，三十分钟穿过华盛顿东北部连绵起伏的乡村，越过波托马克河到达五角大楼。早上，他会把车停在一个巨大的停车场之一，试图把他最珍贵的财产——一辆宝马 503，停在他能记得的地方。1966 年，五角大楼入口处几乎没有安全检查站。泰勒穿着他平常的服装轻松走进来：运动外套、领带、纽扣式短袖衬衫和休闲裤。每天，还有三万名穿着制服和便装的人蜂拥而至穿过大厅，穿过商店，走进这座巨大建筑的拥挤空间。

Bob Taylor usually drove to work, thirty minutes through the rolling countryside northeast of Washington, over the Potomac River to the Pentagon. There, in the morning, he’d pull into one of the vast parking lots and try to put his most-prized possession, a BMW 503, someplace he could remember. There were few if any security checkpoints at the entrances to the Pentagon in 1966. Taylor breezed in wearing his usual attire: sport coat, tie, button-down short-sleeve shirt, and slacks. Thirty thousand other people swarmed through the concourse level daily, in uniform and mufti alike, past the shops and up into the warrens of the enormous building.

泰勒的办公室在三楼，这是五角大楼最负盛名的楼层，靠近国防部长和高级研究计划局 (ARPA) 局长的办公室。五角大楼最高级别官员的办公室在外层，即 E 环。他们的套房可以看到河流和国家纪念碑的景色。泰勒的老板、ARPA 负责人查尔斯·赫茨菲尔德 (Charles Herzfeld) 的房间位于 3E160 房间，可以看到美景。ARPA 局长拥有国防部 (DOD) 授予的最高权力象征，甚至连他办公桌旁边的官方旗帜都挂在上面。泰勒是信息处理技术办公室 (IPTO) 的主任，就在一条走廊之外，这是 ARPA 的一个不同寻常的独立部门，负责支持国家最先进的计算机研究和开发项目。

Taylor’s office was on the third floor, the most prestigious level in the Pentagon, near the offices of the secretary of defense and the director of the Advanced Research Projects Agency (ARPA). The offices of the highest-ranking officials in the Pentagon were in the outer, or E-ring. Their suites had views of the river and national monuments. Taylor’s boss, Charles Herzfeld, the head of ARPA, was among those with a view, in room 3E160. The ARPA director rated the highest symbols of power meted out by the Department of Defense (DOD), right down to the official flags beside his desk. Taylor was director of the Information Processing Techniques Office (IPTO), just a corridor away, an unusually independent section of ARPA charged with supporting the nation’s most advanced computer research-and-development projects.

IPTO 主任套房位于 D 形环内，泰勒从 1965 年到 1969 年一直将外套挂在这里。他的办公室视野不佳，但舒适宽敞，弥补了这一缺陷。这是一间铺着豪华地毯、装饰华丽的房间，有一张大办公桌、一张厚重的橡木会议桌、玻璃书柜、舒适的皮椅，以及五角大楼精心衡量的所有其他军衔标志，甚至包括烟灰缸的质量。（泰勒因军事事务出差，拥有一星上将军衔。）办公室的一面墙上挂着一张巨大的世界地图；另一面墙上挂着一幅来自泰国的寺庙拓片。

The IPTO director’s suite, where Taylor hung his coat from 1965 to 1969, was located in the D-ring. What his office lacked in a view was compensated for by its comfort and size. It was a plushly carpeted and richly furnished room with a big desk, a heavy oak conference table, glass-fronted bookcases, comfortable leather chairs, and all the other trappings of rank, which the Pentagon carefully measured out even down to the quality of the ashtrays. (Traveling on military business, Taylor carried the rank of one-star general.) On one wall of his office was a large map of the world; a framed temple rubbing from Thailand hung prominently on another.

套房内，泰勒办公室旁边还有一扇门，通往一个称为终端室的小空间。那里并排摆放着三台计算机终端，每台终端的品牌不同，都连接到在三个不同地点运行的独立主机。一台经过改装的 IBM Selectric 打字机终端连接到剑桥麻省理工学院的一台计算机。一台 33 型电传打字机终端，类似于一张金属桌子，里面嵌有一台嘈杂的大型打字机，连接到加州大学伯克利分校的一台计算机。另一台 35 型电传打字机终端专用于加州圣莫尼卡的一台计算机，这台计算机的名字很神秘，叫做 AN/FSQ 32XD1A，绰号 Q-32，是 IBM 为战略空军司令部制造的一台笨重的机器。泰勒套房中的每个终端都是不同计算环境的扩展——不同的编程语言、操作系统等——在每个远程主机中。每个终端都有不同的登录程序；泰勒都知道它们。但他发现，必须记住在哪台计算机上使用哪种登录程序是一件令人厌烦的事情。而且，登录后，还必须记住哪些命令属于哪个计算环境，这更令人厌烦。当他很着急时，这种例行公事尤其令人沮丧，而大多数时候他都是这样。

Inside the suite, beside Taylor’s office, was another door leading to a small space referred to as the terminal room. There, side by side, sat three computer terminals, each a different make, each connected to a separate mainframe computer running at three separate sites. There was a modified IBM Selectric typewriter terminal connected to a computer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge. A Model 33 Teletype terminal, resembling a metal desk with a large noisy typewriter embedded in it, was linked to a computer at the University of California in Berkeley. And another Teletype terminal, a Model 35, was dedicated to a computer in Santa Monica, California, called, cryptically enough, the AN/FSQ 32XD1A, nicknamed the Q-32, a hulking machine built by IBM for the Strategic Air Command. Each of the terminals in Taylor’s suite was an extension of a different computing environment—different programming languages, operating systems, and the like—within each of the distant mainframes. Each had a different log-in procedure; Taylor knew them all. But he found it irksome to have to remember which log-in procedure to use for which computer. And it was still more irksome, after he logged in, to be forced to remember which commands belonged to which computing environment. This was a particularly frustrating routine when he was in a hurry, which was most of the time.

泰勒五角大楼办公室里有三台不同的计算机终端，这反映了 IPTO 与计算机研究界前沿的紧密联系，这些前沿位于美国几所顶尖大学和技术中心。总共有大约 20 名首席研究员，支持数十名研究生，从事众多项目，所有这些项目都由泰勒的小办公室资助，办公室只有泰勒和一名秘书。IPTO 1900 万美元的预算中的大部分被派往波士顿和剑桥的校园实验室，或派往加利福尼亚，以支持有望在计算领域取得革命性进展的工作。在 ARPA 的保护下，20 世纪 60 年代中期，计算机研究领域出现了一种日益增强的社区意识。尽管项目和计算机系统种类繁多，但计算机社区成员之间开始形成紧密的联系。研究人员在技术会议上见面并通过电话交谈；早在 1964 年，有些人甚至开始使用电子邮件的形式在主机计算机非常有限的距离内交换评论。

The presence of three different computer terminals in Taylor’s Pentagon office reflected IPTO’s strong connection to the leading edge of the computer research community, resident in a few of the nation’s top universities and technical centers. In all, there were some twenty principal investigators, supporting dozens of graduate students, working on numerous projects, all of them funded by Taylor’s small office, which consisted of just Taylor and a secretary. Most of IPTO’s $19 million budget was being sent to campus laboratories in Boston and Cambridge, or out to California, to support work that held the promise of making revolutionary advances in computing. Under ARPA’s umbrella, a growing sense of community was emerging in computer research in the mid-1960s. Despite the wide variety of projects and computer systems, tight bonds were beginning to form among members of the computer community. Researchers saw each other at technical conferences and talked by phone; as early as 1964 some had even begun using a form of electronic mail to trade comments, within the very limited proximity of their mainframe computers.

从泰勒办公室旁边的终端机室与该社区进行通信是一个繁琐的过程。设备是最先进的，但房间里堆满了各种计算机终端，就像书房里堆满了几台电视机，每台电视机都专用于不同的频道。“很明显，”泰勒多年后说，“我们应该找到一种方法来连接所有这些不同的机器。”

Communicating with that community from the terminal room next to Taylor’s office was a tedious process. The equipment was state of the art, but having a room cluttered with assorted computer terminals was like having a den cluttered with several television sets, each dedicated to a different channel. “It became obvious,” Taylor said many years later, “that we ought to find a way to connect all these different machines.”

研究天堂

A Research Haven

五角大楼内部居然还存在一个机构，能够支持某些人认为是深奥的学术研究，这要归功于 ARPA 最早创始人的智慧。该机构是由总统德怀特·艾森豪威尔在 1957 年 10 月苏联发射第一颗人造卫星后的国家危机时期成立的。该研究机构是一个与总统和国防部长紧密联系的快速反应机制，以确保美国人再也不会在技术前沿措手不及。艾森豪威尔总统认为 ARPA 非常适合他的战略，即遏制各军种在研发项目方面的激烈竞争。ARPA 的想法始于一个既不是科学家也不是士兵，而是肥皂推销员的人。

That there even existed an agency within the Pentagon capable of supporting what some might consider esoteric academic research was a tribute to the wisdom of ARPA’s earliest founders. The agency had been formed by President Dwight Eisenhower in the period of national crisis following the Soviet launch of the firstSputniksatellite in October 1957. The research agency was to be a fast-response mechanism closely tied to the president and secretary of defense, to ensure that Americans would never again be taken by surprise on the technological frontier. President Eisenhower saw ARPA fitting nicely into his strategy to stem the intense rivalries among branches of the military over research-and-development programs. The ARPA idea began with a man who was neither scientist nor soldier, but soap salesman.

52 岁的尼尔·麦克埃罗伊是国防机构的新人。他从未在政府工作过，从未在华盛顿生活过，除了在国民警卫队服役外，没有任何军事经验。32 年来，他一直在辛辛那提的肥皂制造商宝洁公司不断晋升。

At fifty-two, Neil McElroy was a newcomer to the defense establishment. He had never worked in government, had never lived in Washington, and had no military experience except in the national guard. For thirty-two years, he had climbed the corporate ladder at Procter & Gamble, the giant soap manufacturer in Cincinnati.

毕业于哈佛大学的麦克埃罗伊在宝洁公司的第一份工作是广告部邮递员，每周工资 25 美元。这本应是一份暑期工作；他原本打算在秋季进入商学院学习。但他留了下来，开始挨家挨户推销肥皂。不久，他就成了促销经理。从那以后，他通过在广播和电视上销售肥皂，一步步晋升。电视肥皂剧是麦克埃罗伊的心血结晶，他曾毫不掩饰地表示：“提高文学品味是学校的问题。肥皂剧可以卖出很多肥皂。”到 1957 年，宝洁公司每年销售的象牙、Oxydol、Joy 和 Tide 肥皂价值约 10 亿美元。他已经完善了促进品牌竞争的策略——好像同一家公司生产的类似产品之间真的存在差异一样。过去九年来，高大英俊的他一直担任该公司总裁，大多数人都称他为“麦克”（有些人也称他为“来自辛辛那提的索比麦克”）。直到艾森豪威尔招募他加入内阁。

A Harvard graduate, McElroy took his first job at P&G slitting envelopes as a mail clerk in the advertising department for twenty-five dollars a week. It was supposed to be a summer job; he had intended to enter business school in the fall. But he stayed on and began peddling soap door-to-door. Soon he became promotion manager. From there, he worked his way up by pioneering the selling of soap on radio and television. The TV soap opera was McElroy’s brainchild, about which he once said without apology, “The problem of improving literary taste is one for the schools. Soap operas sell lots of soap.” By 1957, P&G was selling about a billion dollars’worth of Ivory, Oxydol, Joy, and Tide every year. He had perfected the strategy of promoting brand-name competition—as if there were real differences—between similar products made by the same company. And for the past nine years, tall, handsome “Mac” as he was known to most (or “Soapy Mac from Cinci-O” to some), had been the company’s president—until Eisenhower recruited him for his cabinet.

1957 年 10 月 4 日星期五晚上，艾森豪威尔总统新提名的国防部长麦克埃罗伊来到阿拉巴马州的亨茨维尔。他已经得到参议院的批准，正在宣誓就职前参观军事设施。一大群五角大楼工作人员随行，陪同麦克参观红石兵工厂，那里是陆军火箭计划的所在地。晚上六点左右，麦克埃罗伊正在军官俱乐部与现代火箭之父、德国流亡者沃纳·冯·布劳恩交谈，这时一名助手冲上来宣布，苏联人已成功将一颗卫星送入地球轨道。突然之间，在就职之前，麦克埃罗伊就发现自己陷入了一场巨大的危机。一夜之间，苏联的成就让美国战后蓬勃发展的信心和乐观情绪降温，陷入了日益扩大的恐惧和绝望之中。突然间，“全面毁灭的幽灵”——用总统的话来说——袭击了美国人的心灵。

On the evening of Friday, October 4, 1957, President Eisenhower’s new nominee for secretary of defense, McElroy, was in Huntsville, Alabama. He had already been confirmed by the Senate and was touring military installations in advance of his swearing-in. A large entourage of Pentagon staff was in tow for Mac’s tour of Redstone Arsenal, home of the Army’s rocket program. At about six o’clock in the evening in the officers’ club, McElroy was talking to German émigré Wernher von Braun, the father of modern rocketry, when an aide rushed up and announced that the Russians had succeeded in launching a satellite into earth orbit. Now suddenly, even before taking office, McElroy found himself engulfed in a crisis of huge proportions. In one night, the Soviet achievement had reduced America’s booming postwar confidence and optimism to widening fear and despair. Suddenly “the spectre of wholesale destruction,” in the president’s words, bore down on the American psyche.

五天后，麦克埃罗伊宣誓就职，华盛顿正陷入一场争论之中，争论的焦点是谁让苏联人抢占了美国科学技术的先机。一些人曾预测苏联人将发射一颗卫星来纪念国际地球物理年。一位观察家说：“他们之前在荒野中的布道被苏联的科学奇观所弥补。现在它披上了揭示真相的外衣。”“我早就告诉过你了”成为了一种地位的象征。真正的恐惧、不祥的评论和严厉的批评围绕着苏联对国家安全的新威胁这一核心问题。歇斯底里的预言苏联的统治和民主的毁灭随处可见。悲观主义者说，人造卫星是俄罗斯有能力发射洲际弹道导弹的证明，苏联威胁美国只是时间问题。最不恐慌的美国人对俄罗斯在太空探索竞赛中的领先地位感到失望。

Five days later McElroy was sworn in, with Washington fully consumed in controversy over the question of who had let the Soviets steal the march on American science and technology. Some people had predicted the Soviets would launch a satellite in observance of the International Geophysical Year. “Their earlier preaching in the wilderness was redeemed by the Soviet scientific spectaculars,” one observer said. “It now took on the aura of revealed truth.” “I told you so” became a status symbol. Genuine fear, ominous punditry, and harsh criticism flowed around the central issue of the new Soviet threat to national security. Hysterical prophecies of Soviet domination and the destruction of democracy were common.Sputnikwas proof of Russia’s ability to launch intercontinental ballistic missiles, the pessimists said, and it was just a matter of time before the Soviets would threaten the United States. The least-panicked Americans were resigned to disappointment over Russia’s lead in the race to explore space.

艾森豪威尔并不想让一位经验丰富的军事专家领导五角大楼；他自己就是其中之一。总统不信任军事工业联合体和武装部队的封地。他对他们的态度有时近乎蔑视。

Eisenhower hadn’t wanted a seasoned military expert heading the Pentagon; he was one himself. The president distrusted the military-industrial complex and the fiefdoms of the armed services. His attitude toward them sometimes bordered on contempt.

相反，他热爱科学界。他发现科学家鼓舞人心——他们的思想、文化、价值观以及对国家的价值——他身边都是美国最优秀的科学人才。艾森豪威尔是第一位专门在白宫举办晚宴，邀请科学界和工程界作为贵宾的总统，就像肯尼迪家族后来会招待艺术家和音乐家一样。

By contrast, he loved the scientific community. He found scientists inspiring—their ideas, their culture, their values, and their value to the country—and he surrounded himself with the nation’s best scientific minds. Eisenhower was the first president to host a White House dinner specifically to single out the scientific and engineering communities as guests of honor, just as the Kennedys would later play host to artists and musicians.

数百名美国著名科学家在各种委员会中直接为艾森豪威尔政府服务。他自豪地称他们为“我的科学家”。美国国家科学院院长德特列夫·W·布朗克 (Detlev W. Bronk) 表示，艾森豪威尔“喜欢把自己视为我们中的一员”。

Hundreds of prominent American scientists directly served the Eisenhower administration on various panels. He referred to them proudly as “my scientists.” Ike “liked to think of himself as one of us,” observed Detlev W. Bronk, president of the National Academy of Sciences.

两位杰出的科学家曾经与总统共进早餐，离开时艾森豪威尔说，共和党全国委员会抱怨说，与他关系密切的科学家们没有为共和党“大声欢呼”。

Two prominent scientists once had breakfast with the president, and as they were leaving Eisenhower remarked that the Republican National Committee was complaining that scientists close to the him were not out “whooping it up” sufficiently for the Republican Party.

“总统先生，您不知道吗？”其中一名男子笑着回答道。“所有科学家都是民主党人。”

 

 

“我不相信，”艾森豪威尔反驳道。“但无论如何，我喜欢科学家是因为他们的科学，而不是他们的政治。”

当斯普尼克号危机爆发时，艾森豪威尔将他的科学家拉进了自己的圈子。首先，他与政府外的著名科学家举行了多次私人会议。苏联卫星新闻传出 11 天后，即 1957 年 10 月 15 日，艾森豪威尔与他的科学顾问委员会进行了长时间的讨论，该委员会由全国最优秀的人才组成。他和他们中的任何一个人都不关心斯普尼克号的实际意义，就像那些利用这个问题来对付艾森豪威尔的人一样。首先，艾森豪威尔对苏联导弹计划的现状了解得比他公开说的要多得多；他看过 U-2 侦察机拍摄的精美细致的间谍照片。他知道没有导弹差距。他还知道美国军方及其承包商对苏联威胁有既得利益。尽管如此，他还是向他的科学顾问询问了他们对苏联能力的评估。当他们冷静地评估斯普尼克号发射的意义时，艾森豪威尔仔细地听着。他们告诉他，苏联确实取得了令人印象深刻的进展。他们说，除非美国动员起来，否则它将失去其科技领先地位。

When the Sputnikcrisis hit, Eisenhower pulled his scientists still more tightly into his circle. First, he held a number of private meetings with prominent scientists from outside the government. Eleven days after the news of the Soviet satellite, on October 15, 1957, Eisenhower sat down for a lengthy discussion with his Science Advisory Committee, a full contingent of the nation’s best minds. Neither he nor any of them was as concerned about the actual significance ofSputnikas were those who were using the issue against Ike. For one thing, Eisenhower knew a great deal more than he could say publicly about the status of the Russian missile programs; he had seen the exquisitely detailed spy photographs made from a U-2 spy plane. He knew there was no missile gap. He also knew that the American military and its contractors had a vested interest in the Soviet threat. Still, he asked his science advisors for their estimation of Soviet capability. Eisenhower listened closely as they soberly assessed the meaning of theSputniklaunch. They told him the Russians had indeed gained impressive momentum. They said the United States would lose its scientific and technological lead unless it mobilized.

自 20 世纪 50 年代初以来，艾森豪威尔身边的许多科学家一直担心政府要么滥用要么误解了现代科学技术。他们敦促艾森豪威尔任命一位高级总统科学顾问，“一个他可以轻松相处的人”，帮助他做出涉及技术的决策。在第一颗人造卫星发射仅一个月后，斯普尼克二号就发射升空，这进一步增加了压力。第一颗人造卫星是一个篮球大小、重达 184 磅的物体，这已经够糟糕了。它的同伴重达半吨，大小几乎与一辆大众甲壳虫汽车相当。

Many of the scientists around Eisenhower had been worrying since the early 1950s that the government either misused or misunderstood modern science and technology. They urged Eisenhower to appoint a single high-level presidential science advisor, “a person he could live with easily,” to help him make decisions involving technology. The launch ofSputnik IIjust a month after the firstSputnikincreased the pressure. The first satellite, a 184-pound object the size of a basketball, was bad enough. Its fellow traveler weighed in at half a ton and was nearly the size of a Volkswagen Bug.

斯普尼克二号消息传出几天后，艾森豪威尔告诉全国人民，他找到了一位科学顾问，那就是麻省理工学院院长詹姆斯·R·基里安。基里安不是科学家，但他能有效地代表科学发言。1957 年 11 月 7 日，在安抚美国人民、减少恐慌的几次讲话中，总统宣布任命基里安为科学顾问。这一消息在讲话的后期才公布，但第二天就登上了头条新闻。总统将科学与国防联系起来，并表示基里安将“继续推进国防的科学改进”。媒体称基里安为美国的“导弹沙皇”。

A few days after the news of Sputnik II,Eisenhower told the nation that he found his man for science in James R. Killian Jr., president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Killian was a nonscientist who spoke effectively on behalf of science. On November 7, 1957, in the first of several addresses to reassure the American people and reduce panic, the president announced Killian’s appointment as science advisor. It came late in the address but made front-page news the following day. The president had drawn links between science and defense, and said Killian would “follow through on the scientific improvement of our defense.” The press dubbed Killian America’s “Missile Czar.”

在 10 月 15 日与科学顾问的会议中，总统谈到了他对政府研究管理的担忧。“总统怀着极大的热情和决心希望科学家们告诉他科学研究在联邦政府结构中的位置，”总统的行政助理谢尔曼·亚当斯说。此外，艾森豪威尔告诉他们，国防部长麦克埃罗伊是个好人，并敦促科学家们与新任部长会面，他们当天就见面了。

During the October 15 meeting with his science advisors, the president had spoken of his concern over the management of research in government. “With great enthusiasm and determination the president wanted the scientists to tell him where scientific research belonged in the structure of the federal government,” said Sherman Adams, the president’s executive assistant. In addition, Eisenhower told them he had a fine man in Secretary of Defense McElroy and urged the scientists to meet with the new secretary, which they did that very day.

他们发现，麦克埃罗伊部长也同样欣赏他们。他在宝洁公司工作期间最引以为豪的一点就是公司投入到研究上的大量资金。他相信不受约束的科学的价值，相信它能够产生非凡的、即使并非总是可预测的结果。麦克埃罗伊和宝洁公司创建了一个大型的“蓝天”研究实验室，为其提供了充足的资金，而且很少甚至从未向其科学家施压，要求他们证明自己的工作是合理的。这是同类公司中最早开展研究的机构之一，在这个机构中，科学家可以自由地进行几乎任何研究，并得到高层的大力支持。

They found that Secretary McElroy had a similar appreciation for them. One aspect of his career at P&G that he was most proud of was the amount of money the company had devoted to research. He believed in the value of unfettered science, in its ability to produce remarkable, if not always predictable, results. McElroy and P&G had created a large “blue-sky” research laboratory, had funded it well, and rarely if ever pressured its scientists to justify their work. It was one of the first corporate research operations of its kind, one in which scientists were left to pursue almost anything and were well supported from the top.

第二次世界大战期间，大学和政府之间的类似安排也带来了重大的技术进步：雷达、核武器和大型计算机都源自基里安所说的“杰出的学术科学家和工程师的自由发挥方式，他们始终不受任何管制和组织的束缚”。

Significant technological advances had come from a similar arrangement between universities and government during World War II: radar, nuclear weapons, and large calculating machines resulted from what Killian called “the freewheeling methods of outstanding academic scientists and engineers who had always been free of any inhibiting regimentation and organization.”

在与基利安协商后，麦克埃罗伊开始讨论成立一个独立研究机构的想法，基利安的支持至关重要。麦克埃罗伊也许知道，美国商会在人造卫星发射前几个月的国会听证会上提出了为联邦政府成立一个单一研发机构的想法。这样的讨论当时已经很普遍了。这个想法现在在与一个非正式咨询委员会的讨论中浮现出来，该委员会由精明的工业家组成，他们定期与国防部长会面。

In consultation with Killian, whose support was crucial, McElroy began discussing the idea of establishing an independent agency for research. Perhaps McElroy was aware that the U.S. Chamber of Commerce had floated the notion of creating a single research-anddevelopment agency for the federal government during congressional hearings months beforeSputnik.Such talk was in the air. The idea now emerged in discussions with an informal advisory committee of astute industrialists who met regularly with the secretary of defense.

在苏联发射导弹后的几天里，有两个人来见麦克埃罗伊：著名核物理学家欧内斯特·劳伦斯和前孟山都化学公司首席执行官、偶尔担任总统顾问的查尔斯·托马斯。在长达数小时的会谈中，他们讨论了成立一个强大的先进研发机构并向部长汇报的想法，两位来访者都敦促麦克埃罗伊实施这一计划。利弗莫尔实验室主任、艾森豪威尔和基里安的密友、物理学家赫伯特·约克也加入了谈话。与此同时，麦克埃罗伊本人也经常与基里安和总统商议。在基里安看来，军队的传统使命已经被现代科学技术所淘汰。这是将五角大楼带入新时代的一种方式。在麦克埃罗伊看来，研究机构概念的主要吸引力之一是，它将使他能够管理国防部内部在研发项目和预算方面的激烈竞争。竞争达到了荒唐的新高度。陆军、海军和空军指挥官把Sputnik视为新竞赛的发令枪，相互竞争，争夺研发支出的最大份额。

In the days immediately following the Soviet launch, two men had been to see McElroy: eminent nuclear physicist Ernest O. Lawrence, and Charles Thomas, a former CEO of the Monsanto Chemical Company and an occasional advisor to the president. In a meeting lasting several hours, they discussed the idea of a strong advanced R&D agency that would report to the secretary, and both visitors urged McElroy to run with it. Physicist Herbert York, director of the Livermore Laboratory and close confidant to both Eisenhower and Killian, joined the conversations. At the same time, McElroy himself was consulting frequently with Killian and the president. In Killian’s view, the traditional missions of the armed services had been outmoded by modern science and technology. Here was a way to move the Pentagon into the new age. One of the principal attractions of the research agency concept, in McElroy’s mind, was the ability it would give him to manage the fierce competition within DOD over R&D programs and budgets. The competition was reaching absurd new heights. Army, Navy and Air Force commanders treatedSputniklike the starting gun in a new race, each vying against the other for the biggest share of R&D spending.

麦克埃罗伊认为，一个集中管理先进研究项目的机构将减少各军种之间的竞争，因为联邦研发预算基本都由他亲自监督。此外，这几乎肯定会得到总统的青睐，因为军方经常自私的主张和特殊利益的炒作通常会遭到白宫的鄙视。

McElroy believed that a centralized agency for advanced research projects would reduce interservice rivalry by placing federal R&D budgets substantially under his own close supervision. Moreover, it would almost certainly appeal to the president, since the military’s often selfish claims and special-interest hype usually met with disdain in the White House.

艾森豪威尔喜欢国务卿的提议。尽管政府有更大的计划——成立美国国家航空航天局 (NASA)、通过国防重组法案、设立国防研究与工程主任办公室——但这些事情需要时间。高级研究计划局的概念是总统可以立即提出的回应。它将为他提供一个灵活的研发机构，他和他的科学家们将来可以随时调用。

Eisenhower liked the secretary’s proposal. While the administration had larger plans in store—the creation of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), passage of a Defense Reorganization Act, establishment of the office of a Director of Defense Research and Engineering—those things would take time. The Advanced Research Projects Agency concept was a response the president could point to immediately. And it would give him an agile R&D agency he and his scientists could call on in the future.

1957 年 11 月 20 日，麦克埃罗伊首次以国防部长的身份前往国会山。在就美国弹道导弹计划作证时，他提到自己已决定为所有国防研究设立一个新的“单一管理机构”。他告诉国会，短期内，新机构将负责卫星和太空研发计划。第二天，他向参谋长联席会议分发了新机构的章程和指令草案，请他们审查并提出意见。

On November 20, 1957, McElroy went to Capitol Hill for the first time as secretary. In the course of testifying about U.S. ballistic missile programs he mentioned that he had decided to set up a new “single manager” for all defense research. In the near term, he told Congress, the new agency would handle satellite and space R&D programs. The next day he circulated to the Joint Chiefs of Staff a draft charter and directive for the new agency, asking for their review and comments.

军方对这种含蓄的批评勃然大怒。拥有民间科技顾问是一回事，但麦克埃罗伊现在明显侵犯了他们的地盘，计划管理和运营一个控制国防研发计划和未来武器项目的中央办公室。他们准备反击。空军部长詹姆斯·道格拉斯写道：“空军感谢这些提议只是建议。”也就是说，信息是收到的，而不是接受的。陆军、海军和参谋长联席会议退回了宪章草案，并对其进行了大量修改。他们狡猾地修改了有关新机构的合同权的措辞，他们的修改充斥着颠覆性的措辞变化、巧妙的添加和狡猾的删除，所有这些都是为了削弱和限制该机构。

The military bristled at the implied criticism. It was one thing to have civilian science and technologyadvisors,but McElroy was now clearly invading their turf, planning to manage and operate a central office that would control defense R&D programs and future weapons projects. They were prepared to fight back. Secretary of the Air Force James Douglas wrote, “The Air Force appreciates that the proposals are suggestions.” That is, message received, not accepted. The Army, Navy, and Joint Chiefs of Staff returned the draft charter with numerous revisions. They fiddled deviously with language concerning the new agency’s contracting authority, their revisions peppered with subversive word changes, crafty additions, and sly deletions all designed to weaken and confine the agency.

麦克埃罗伊承认了一些小问题，但明确了两点：该机构的主任拥有签订合同的权力，并且该机构的研究范围不受限制。

McElroy conceded a few minor points but made two things clear: The agency’s director would have contracting authority, and the scope of the agency’s research was to be unlimited.

1958 年 1 月 7 日，艾森豪威尔向国会发出信息，要求为高级研究计划局的成立提供启动资金。两天后，他在国情咨文中强调了这一点。“我今天并不想对有害的服务竞争指控作出判断。但有一件事是肯定的。无论它们是什么，美国都希望它们停止。”

On January 7, 1958, Eisenhower sent a message to Congress requesting startup funds for the establishment of the Advanced Research Projects Agency. Two days later he drove the point home in his State of the Union Message. “I am not attempting today to pass judgment on the charges of harmful service rivalries. But one thing is sure. Whatever they are, America wants them stopped.”

艾森豪威尔还肯定了“我们最先进的一些开发项目需要单一控制”，然后向将军们发出致命一击：“军事组织的另一个要求是，军队必须明确服从合法组建的民事当局。这种控制必须是真实的，而不是仅仅停留在表面上。”

Eisenhower also affirmed “the need for single control in some of our most advanced development projects,” then delivered his coup de grâce to the generals: “Another requirement of military organization is a clear subordination of the military services to the duly constituted civilian authority. This control must be real; not merely on the surface.”

1958 年初，通用电气副总裁 Roy Johnson 被任命为 ARPA 的第一任主任；任命五天后，国会批准了资金（作为空军拨款法案的一项），ARPA 开始营业。

In early 1958, Roy Johnson, a vice president of General Electric, was appointed ARPA’s first director; five days after the appointment, funding was approved by Congress (as a line item in an Air Force appropriations bill), and ARPA went into business.

在斯普尼克号之后的恐慌中，太空竞赛对美国人的生活产生了巨大影响，导致学校重新重视科学，恶化了俄罗斯和美国之间的关系，并为研发支出打开了闸门。华盛顿的“外部挑战”研发支出在 1959 年至 1964 年间从每年 50 亿美元增加到每年 130 多亿美元。斯普尼克号开启了军事科学技术的黄金时代。（到 20 世纪 60 年代中期，全国的研发总支出占国民生产总值的 3%，这一基准既是进步的象征，也是其他国家的目标。）

In the postSputnikpanic, the race for outer space cut a wide swath through American life, causing a new emphasis on science in the schools, worsening relations between Russia and the United States, and opening a floodgate for R&D spending. Washington’s “external challenge” R&D spending rose from $5 billion per year to over $13 billion annually between 1959 and 1964.Sputniklaunched a golden era for military science and technology. (By the mid-1960s, the nation’s total R&D expenditures would account for 3 percent of the gross national product, a benchmark that was both a symbol of progress and a goal for other countries.)

当 ARPA 以 5.2 亿美元的拨款和 20 亿美元的预算计划成立时，所有人都注视着它。它负责指导美国所有太空计划和所有先进战略导弹研究。到 1959 年，总部已雇用了约 70 名员工，这个数字多年来一直保持相当稳定。他们主要是科学项目经理，负责分析和评估研发提案，监督数百名承包商的工作。

All eyes were on ARPA when it opened its doors with a $520 million appropriation and a $2 billion budget plan. It was given direction over all U.S. space programs and all advanced strategic missile research. By 1959, a headquarters staff of about seventy people had been hired, a number that would remain fairly constant for years. These were mainly scientific project managers who analyzed and evaluated R&D proposals, supervising the work of hundreds of contractors.

ARPA 的第一任主任罗伊·约翰逊和他的老板一样，是个商人。52 岁时，他被麦克埃罗伊亲自招募，麦克埃罗伊说服他放弃通用电气 16 万美元的薪水，接受华盛顿 1.8 万美元的薪水。

Roy Johnson, ARPA’s first director, was, like his boss, a businessman. At age fifty-two, he had been personally recruited by McElroy, who convinced him to leave a $160,000 job with General Electric and take an $18,000 job in Washington.

毫不奇怪，约翰逊将美国的研发计划视为一个管理问题。管理技能是他的强项。在他看来，他的工作是劝告人们采取一切必要措施来战胜苏联。他经常与满屋子的将军和海军上将激烈争论，并积极反对空军。很快人们就发现，约翰逊是外层空间强大军事存在的严肃而强烈的倡导者。

Not surprisingly, Johnson approached America’s R&D agenda as a management problem. Management skills were his strong suit. His job, as he saw it, was to exhort people to do anything necessary to get the edge on the Soviets. He argued often and vigorously with rooms full of generals and admirals, and aggressively took on the Air Force. It soon became apparent that Johnson was a serious and vociferous advocate of a strong military presence in outer space.

但基里安和艾森豪威尔身边的其他科学家当然希望由一位精通科学和技术问题的人来管理 ARPA。约翰逊被指示聘请一名军官作为他的副手，并选择一名首席科学家来完善他的领导团队。科学职位差点落入沃纳·冯·布劳恩手中，但他坚持要将他的十几名同事的整个团队带到五角大楼。因此，基里安一直热衷的赫伯特·约克得到了这份工作，并从劳伦斯利弗莫尔实验室调到了 ARPA。当他到达五角大楼三楼时，约克立即在办公室墙上挂了一张巨大的月球照片。旁边还挂了一个空相框。他告诉来访者，很快就会把第一张月球背面的照片放进去。

But of course Killian and other scientists around Eisenhower had wanted someone well versed in scientific and technological issues running ARPA. Johnson had been instructed to hire a military flag officer as his deputy, and to select a chief scientist to round out his leadership team. The scientific post had almost gone to Wernher von Braun, until he insisted on bringing his whole team of a dozen associates with him to the Pentagon. So Herbert York, whom Killian had been keen on, was given the job and moved to ARPA from the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory. When he arrived on the third floor at the Pentagon, York promptly hung a large picture of the moon on his office wall. And right beside it he hung an empty frame. He told visitors it would soon be filled with the first picture of the back side of the moon.

ARPA 的其他员工均来自洛克希德、联合碳化物、康维尔和五角大楼其他承包商等行业的顶级技术人才。员工们每天都在从大量未经请求的研发提案中筛选出金子。

The rest of ARPA’s staff was recruited from industry’s top-flight technical talent at places like Lockheed, Union Carbide, Convair, and other Pentagon contractors. The staff’s days were spent sifting for gold in a torrential flow of unsolicited R&D proposals.

ARPA 的成功取决于约翰逊对美国在外层空间角色的极端直言不讳的态度以及他对美苏紧张局势的简单看法。他错误地几乎完全从军事角度定义了 ARPA 的使命，概述了他设想的太空项目类型：全球监视卫星、太空防御拦截飞行器、战略轨道武器系统、固定通信卫星、载人空间站和月球基地。

ARPA’s success hinged on Johnson’s extremely vocal posturing about America’s role in outer space and his simplistic view of Soviet-American tensions. He mistakenly defined ARPA’s mission almost entirely in military terms, outlining the kind of space projects he envisioned: global surveillance satellites, space defense interceptor vehicles, strategic orbital weapon systems, stationary communications satellites, manned space stations, and a moon base.

艾森豪威尔和他的民间科学家继续推进他们的其他议程，到 1958 年夏末，美国国家航空航天局 (National Aeronautics and Space Administration) 已颁布成法。几乎在一夜之间，当约翰逊鼓吹军事力量进军太空时，太空项目和导弹计划被从 ARPA 剥离，并转移到 NASA 或重新交给各军种，导致 ARPA 的预算缩减到区区 1.5 亿美元。ARPA 的投资组合被掏空，其员工几乎没有发挥任何作用。《航空周刊》称这个年轻的机构是“挂在水果柜里的死猫”。

Eisenhower and his civilian scientists had moved ahead with the rest of their agenda, and by the late summer of 1958 the National Aeronautics and Space Administration had been enacted into law. Almost overnight, while Johnson drummed for a military presence in space, the space projects and missile programs were stripped away from ARPA and transferred over to NASA or back to the services, leaving ARPA’s budget whittled to a measly $150 million. ARPA’s portfolio was gutted, its staff left practically without any role.Aviation Weekcalled the young agency “a dead cat hanging in the fruit closet.”

约翰逊辞职。但在离职前，他委托员工起草了一份文件，权衡了四种选择：废除 ARPA、扩大其规模、不做任何改变或重新定义其使命。他的分析师们全身心投入到为第四种选择辩护中，正是他们的坚持才使该机构免于被彻底消灭。他们制定了一系列目标，将 ARPA 的重点转移到国家长期的“基础研究”工作上，从而使其与五角大楼保持距离。这些服务从未对抽象的研究项目感兴趣；他们的世界由短期目标和与工业承包商的亲密关系所驱动。ARPA 的员工看到了一个机会，可以将该机构重新定义为一个能够承担真正先进的“遥远”研究的团体。

Johnson resigned. Before leaving, however, he commissioned his staff to draft a paper weighing four alternatives: abolishing ARPA, expanding it, making no changes, or redefining its mission. His analysts threw themselves into building a case for the fourth alternative, and their tenacity alone saved the agency from sure oblivion. They fleshed out a set of goals to distance ARPA from the Pentagon by shifting the agency’s focus to the nation’s long-term “basic research” efforts. The services had never been interested in abstract research projects; their world was driven by near-term goals and cozy relationships with industrial contractors. The staff of ARPA saw an opportunity to redefine the agency as a group that would take on the really advanced “far-out” research.

最重要的是，ARPA 的工作人员认识到了该机构迄今为止最大的错误：它没有利用那些开展了许多最佳科学工作的大学。不出所料，科学界一致呼吁将 ARPA 重塑为“高风险、高收益”的研究赞助商——这是他们一直梦想的那种研发机构。他们的梦想实现了；ARPA 被赋予了新的使命。

Most important of all, ARPA staffers recognized the agency’s biggest mistake yet: It had not been tapping the universities where much of the best scientific work was being done. The scientific community, predictably, rallied to the call for a reinvention of ARPA as a “high-risk, high-gain” research sponsor—the kind of R&D shop they had dreamed of all along. Their dream was realized; ARPA was given its new mission.

随着 ARPA 的特色逐渐成型，该机构的一个显而易见的特点是其规模相对较小，这使得其主管的个性渗透到整个组织中。随着时间的推移，“ARPA 风格”——随心所欲、敢于承担高风险、灵活——将受到吹捧。其他华盛顿官僚开始羡慕 ARPA 的运作方式。最终，该机构吸引了来自最优秀大学和研究实验室的一支由干劲十足的研发倡导者组成的精英队伍，他们着手建立一个由美国研究领域最优秀的技术和科学人才组成的社区。

As ARPA’s features took shape, one readily apparent characteristic of the agency was that its relatively small size allowed the personality of its director to permeate the organization. In time, the “ARPA style”—freewheeling, open to high risk, agile—would be vaunted. Other Washington bureaucrats came to envy ARPA’smodus operandi. Eventually the agency attracted an elite corps of hard-charging R&D advocates from the finest universities and research laboratories, who set about building a community of the best technical and scientific minds in American research.

该机构新的基础研究和特别项目导向与约翰·肯尼迪当选后华盛顿的气氛变化完美契合。华盛顿的官僚机构对肯尼迪的魅力做出了有力的回应。在五角大楼，新任国防部长罗伯特·麦克纳马拉领导了美国战略态势从“大规模报复”哲学转向“灵活应对”战略，以应对国际上对美国霸权的威胁。科学是新的前沿。

The agency’s new basic research and special-project orientation was ideally suited to the atmospheric change in Washington caused by the election of John F. Kennedy. With vigor, Washington’s bureaucracies responded to the Kennedy charisma. At the Pentagon, Robert S. McNamara, the new secretary of defense, led the shift away from the philosophy of “massive retaliation” in America’s strategic posture, and toward a strategy of “flexible response” to international threats to American supremacy. Science was the New Frontier.

1961 年初，ARPA 的第二任主任奥斯汀·W·贝茨准将辞职，由首位领导 ARPA 的科学家杰克·P·鲁伊纳接任。鲁伊纳拥有出色的学术资历和军事背景。他受过电气工程师的培训，曾担任大学教授，还担任过空军副助理部长。他与白宫科学顾问团成员关系良好。

In early 1961 ARPA’s second director, Brigadier General Austin W. Betts, resigned and was replaced by Jack P. Ruina, the first scientist to direct ARPA. Ruina came with strong academic credentials as well as some military background. Trained as an electrical engineer, he had been a university professor and had also served as a deputy assistant secretary of the Air Force. He was on good terms with members of the science advisory panels to the White House.

ARPA 的黄金时代才刚刚开始。鲁伊纳为该机构带来了一种轻松的管理风格和分散的结构。细节并不吸引他，但寻找优秀人才才是他真正感兴趣的。他相信挑选最优秀的人才，并让他们选择最好的技术。他强烈要求给予项目主管自由发挥的空间。在他看来，他的工作是为他们选择的任何项目争取尽可能多的支持和资金。鲁伊纳有一个理论，即真正有才华的人通常不会选择在政府官僚机构中呆很长时间，但如果提供足够的灵活性和足够大的预算，他们可能会被说服花一两年时间。人员流动并不困扰他。他相信，该机构将从频繁接触新观点中受益。为了保持这一切，他也认为自己是个短期人员。

A golden era for ARPA was just beginning. Ruina brought a relaxed management style and decentralized structure to the agency. Details didn’t interest him; finding great talent did. He believed in picking the best people and letting them pick the best technology. He felt strongly about giving his program directors free rein. His job, as he saw it, was to build as much support and funding as he could for whatever projects they selected. Ruina had a theory that truly talented people wouldn’t normally choose to hang around long in a government bureaucracy but could be convinced to spend a year or two if offered enough flexibility and large enough budgets. Turnover didn’t bother him. The agency, he believed, would benefit from frequent exposure to fresh views. In keeping with all that, he saw himself as a short-timer, too.

随着时间的推移，鲁伊纳将 ARPA 的年度预算提高到 2.5 亿美元。弹道导弹防御和核试验检测等项目（以基础研究的形式）是首要任务。（还有一些项目，如行为研究和指挥与控制，虽然很有趣，但并未引起鲁伊纳的密切关注。）

In time, Ruina raised ARPA’s annual budget to $250 million. Projects in ballistic missile defense and nuclear test detection, couched in terms of basic research, were the top priorities. (There were also programs like behavioral research and command and control which, though interesting, fell below the level of Ruina’s close attention.)

1961 年 5 月，一台计算机（而且是一台非常大的计算机）引起了他的注意。ARPA 使用国防部的紧急资金启动了一项军事指挥和控制问题项目。为了这项工作，空军购买了巨大而昂贵的 Q-32，这是一台庞然大物，将作为国家防空预警系统的后备。这台机器被安装在加利福尼亚州圣莫尼卡的空军主要承包商之一系统开发公司 (SDC) 的一家工厂，用于操作员培训和软件开发工具。

Then in May 1961 a computer, and a very large one at that, demanded his attention. A program in military command and control issues had been started at ARPA using emergency DOD funds. For the work, the Air Force had purchased the huge, expensive Q-32, a behemoth of a machine that was to act as the backup for the nation’s air defense early-warning system. The machine had been installed at a facility in Santa Monica, California, at one of the Air Force’s major contractors, System Development Corporation (SDC), where it was supposed to be used for operator training, and as a software development tool.

随后，美国空军被迫削减开支，圣莫尼卡的这家公司不得不乞求某种方式让员工继续使用计算机。美国空军已经在 SDC 合同上投入了数百万美元，现在突然又多了一个令人尴尬的累赘，那就是一台笨重而笨拙的计算机。

Then the Air Force had been forced to cut back, which left the Santa Monica firm begging for some way to keep its employees working with the computer. The Air Force, which had already sunk millions into the SDC contract, suddenly had an embarrassing white elephant on its hands in the form of one massive, ungainly computing machine.

利克莱德

Licklider

军方与计算机机构之间的关系始于现代计算机行业本身。在第二次世界大战期间，由于人们认为需要比人工操作的机械计算器组更快的计算能力，军方资助了数十次计算实验。海军支持哈佛数学教授霍华德·艾肯，他梦想制造一台大型计算器，最终制造出了 Mark I，这是一台 51 英尺长、8 英尺高的总机，可以在没有操作员干预的情况下执行算术运算。陆军还支持宾夕法尼亚大学著名的电子数字积分器和计算器 (ENIAC) 项目。后来在麻省理工学院，海军和空军先后支持了一台名为 Whirlwind 的计算机。

The relationship between the military and computer establishments began with the modern computer industry itself. During World War II, in the midst of a perceived need for faster calculating ability than could be provided by the banks of mechanical calculators run by human operators, the military funded dozens of computing experiments. The Navy supported Howard Aiken, the Harvard mathematics professor who dreamed of building a large-scale calculator and ended up with the Mark I, a fiftyone-foot-long, eight-foot-tall switchboard that could perform arithmetical operations without the intervention of an operator. The Army also supported the famous Electronic Numerical Integrator And Calculator (ENIAC) project at the University of Pennsylvania. Later at MIT, first the Navy and then the Air Force supported a computer called Whirlwind.

20 世纪 50 年代初期，计算意味着快速进行算术运算。各大公司，尤其是银行，都使用机器进行大规模计算。1953 年，国际商业机器公司 (IBM) 进军大型电子计算机制造业务，当时该公司已经是美国最大的计时钟和机电制表设备制造商。这些是未来的商业机器。IBM 机器并不一定比 Univac（ENIAC 的继任者）更好，但 IBM 的销售人员成为了传奇人物，不久之后，IBM 机器的销量就超过了 Univac。

In the early 1950s computing meant doing arithmetic fast. Companies, especially banks, put their machines to work doing large-scale calculations. In 1953, International Business Machines Corporation (IBM), already the country’s largest manufacturer of time clocks as well as electromechnical tabulating equipment, jumped into the business of making large electronic computers. These were business machines of the future. The IBM machines weren’t necessarily better than the Univac (the successor to the ENIAC), but IBM’s sales staff became legendary, and before too long sales of IBM’s machines had surpassed those of the Univac.

随后，在 20 世纪 50 年代末，正当 IBM 的销售额突破 10 亿美元大关时，个性鲜明、直言不讳的工程师肯·奥尔森 (Ken Olsen) 带着 7 万美元的风险投资离开了麻省理工学院的林肯实验室，将围绕新机器开发的技术投入商业开发：林肯实验室的 TX-2。他成立了数字设备公司 (Digital Equipment Corporation)，制造和销售计算机组件，然后他制造了一种与以前截然不同的东西：一种小型计算机，称为微型计算机，可以直接与用户交互。奥尔森的交互式计算机理念来自麻省理工学院的一群先驱计算机研究人员。那里的另一个稍年轻的团队提出了另一个引人注目的计算概念，该概念开始流行起来，尤其是在学术机构中。他们称之为“分时”，它显然具有吸引力，可以替代缓慢而笨拙的传统“批处理”方法。

Then, in the late 1950s, just as IBM was passing the billion-dollar-sales mark, Ken Olsen, an individualistic and outspoken engineer, left MIT’s Lincoln Laboratory with $70,000 in venture capital to exploit commercially the technology developed around a new machine: the TX-2 at Lincoln Lab. He formed the Digital Equipment Corporation to manufacture and sell computer components, and then he built something radically different from what had existed before: a smaller computer called a minicomputer that interacted directly with the user. Olsen’s idea for an interactive computer had come from a pioneering group of computer researchers at MIT. A different, slightly younger group there came up with another dramatic concept in computing that was beginning to catch on, particularly in academic institutions. They called it “time-sharing,” and it had obvious appeal as an alternative to the slow and awkward traditional method of “batch” processing.

批处理是一种繁琐的计算方式。即使是最小的编程任务，也需要将相关代码打到程序卡上，然后将其与“控制卡”组合起来，以处理计算机的管理功能。计算机操作员将卡片送入计算机或磁带进行处理，一次一批。根据队列的长度以及程序和问题的复杂性，等待时间可能会很长。等待一天或更长时间才能得到结果并不罕见。

Batch processing was a cumbersome way of computing. For even the smallest programming task, it was necessary to have the relevant code punched onto program cards, which were then combined with “control cards” to take care of the computer’s administrative functions. A computer operator fed the cards into the computer or onto magnetic tape for processing, one batch at a time. Depending on the length of the queue and the complexity of the programs and problems, the wait could be long. It was not unusual to wait a day or longer for results.

顾名思义，分时是一种让许多用户从各个终端以交互方式访问计算机的新方法。终端允许他们直接与大型计算机交互。分时技术的革命性之处在于它消除了批处理计算中许多繁琐的等待。分时技术为用户提供了终端，使他们能够直接与计算机交互并立即获得结果。麻省理工学院计算机科学家 Fernando Corbató 回忆道：“我们真的相信这是一种更好的操作方式。我想如果有人说‘我会给你一台免费的机器’，我们可能会说‘我们不需要分时技术’。”但当时的计算机体积很大。它们占据了很大的空间，而且由于组件太多，需要不断维护。Corbató 继续说道：“它们不是随便的东西。当时你通常不会想到拥有一台个人机器——也许是专用的，但不是个人的。所以我们真的看到了尝试改变这种状况的必要性。我们很沮丧。”分时技术的受欢迎程度与直接访问计算机的次数成正比。通常这意味着你编程越多，你就越能理解直接访问的价值。

Time-sharing was, as the term suggests, a new method of giving many users interactive access to computers from individual terminals. The terminals allowed them to interact directly with the mainframe computer. The revolutionary aspect of time-sharing was that it eliminated much of the tedious waiting that characterized batch-process computing. Time-sharing gave users terminals that allowed them to interact directly with the computer and obtain their results immediately. “We really believed that it was a better way to operate,” recalled Fernando Corbató, an MIT computer scientist. “I suppose if somebody had said, ‘I will give you a free machine,’ we might have said, ‘We do not need time-sharing.’” But computers in those days were huge things. They took up large rooms and required continual maintenance because there were so many components. “They were just not a casual thing,” Corbató went on. “You did not normally think of having a personal machine in those days—exclusive use maybe, but not a personal one. So we really saw a need to try to change that. We were frustrated.” The appreciation of time-sharing was directly proportional to the amount of direct access one had to the computer. And usually that meant that the more you programmed, the better you understood the value of direct access.

分时不能消除协调不同用户对机器的竞争需求的必要性。就其本质而言，分时鼓励用户在工作时仿佛可以控制整台机器，而实际上他们只拥有总计算能力的一小部分。将成本分摊给多个用户意味着用户越多越好。当然，太多的用户会使机器陷入困境，因为机器的大部分资源都用于协调多个用户的命令。随着用户数量的增加，更多的计算机资源专用于协调功能，这减少了实际可用的处理时间。如果程序员必须执行非常小的工作（例如收紧代码或对程序进行小幅调试），他们不需要一台功能强大的机器。但是当需要运行完整程序时，其中许多程序会占用大量机器资源，很明显用户仍在相互竞争计算时间。一旦需要大量计算的大型程序加入在线工作，每个人的工作速度都会变慢。

What time-sharing could not do was eliminate the necessity of coordinating competing demands on the machine by different users. By its nature, time-sharing encouraged users to work as if they had the entire machine at their command, when in fact they had only a fraction of the total computing power. Distribution of costs among a number of users meant that the more users the better. Of course, too many users bogged down the machine, since a high percentage of the machine’s resources were allocated to coordinating the commands of multiple users. As the number of users increased, more of the computer’s resources were dedicated to the coordination function, which reduced actual usable processing time. If programmers had to do very small jobs (such as tightening code or minor debugging of a program), they didn’t need a powerful machine. But when it came time to run the programs in full, many of which used a lot of machine resources, it became apparent that users were still in competition with one another for computing time. As soon as a large program requiring a lot of calculations entered the mix of jobs being done on-line, everyone’s work slowed down.

• • •

1961 年，空军将 Q-32 转交给 ARPA 时，鲁伊纳没有人负责管理合同。鲁伊纳考虑的工作具有远超当时紧迫的单一合同的扩展潜力：与指挥和控制相关的计算机，有朝一日可能会提供高速、可靠的信息，作为关键军事决策的依据。这种潜力在很大程度上尚未实现，但似乎前景无限。

巧合的是，鲁伊纳也在寻找可以指导国防部希望 ARPA 运行的行为科学新项目的人。到 1962 年秋天，鲁伊纳找到了可以同时担任这两个职位的候选人，即著名心理学家 JCR Licklider。

When the Air Force passed the Q-32 on to ARPA in 1961, Ruina didn’t have anyone to administer the contract. Ruina had in mind a job with the potential for expansion far beyond the single contract that happened to be pressing at the moment: Computers, as they related to command and control, might one day provide high-speed, reliable information upon which to base critical military decisions. That potential, largely unfulfilled, seemed endlessly promising.

Coincidentally, Ruina also was looking for someone who could direct a new program in behavioral sciences that DOD wanted ARPA to run. By the fall of 1962, Ruina had found the candidate who could fill both posts, an eminent psychologist named J. C. R. Licklider.

利克莱德是领导行为科学办公室的不二人选，但心理学家却不是管理专注于开发尖端计算机技术的政府办公室的不二人选。然而，利克莱德广泛的跨学科兴趣使他非常适合这份工作。利克莱德曾认真涉猎过计算机。“他曾经告诉我，他喜欢花很多时间坐在电脑控制台前，”鲁伊纳回忆道。“他说他会沉迷其中，甚至有点上瘾。”然而，利克莱德不仅仅是一名计算机爱好者。几年来，他一直在宣扬一种激进而富有远见的观点：计算机不仅仅是加法机器。计算机有可能成为整个人类的延伸，成为可以扩大人类智力范围和扩展我们分析能力的工具。

Licklider was an obvious choice to head a behavioral sciences office, but a psychologist wasn’t an obvious choice to oversee a government office focused on developing leadingedge computer technology. Yet Licklider’s broad, interdisciplinary interests suited him well for the job. Licklider had done some serious dabbling in computers. “He used to tell me how he liked to spend a lot of time at a computer console,” Ruina recalled. “He said he would get hung up on it and become sort of addicted.” Licklider was far more than just a computer enthusiast, however. For several years, he had been touting a radical and visionary notion: that computers weren’t just adding machines. Computers had the potential to act as extensions of the whole human being, as tools that could amplify the range of human intelligence and expand the reach of our analytical powers.

约瑟夫·卡尔·罗伯内特·利克莱德 1915 年出生于圣路易斯。他是家中独子，深受宠爱，早年对模型飞机十分着迷。他知道自己想成为一名科学家，但在华盛顿大学的大部分时间里，他都没有专心学习。他转换了好几次专业，从化学到物理，再到美术，最后到心理学。1937 年毕业时，他拥有心理学、数学和物理学学士学位。在撰写心理学硕士论文时，他决定在老鼠群上测试流行的口号“多睡觉，对你有好处”。在接近攻读博士学位时，利克莱德的兴趣转向了心理声学，即听觉系统的心理生理学。

Joseph Carl Robnett Licklider was born in St. Louis in 1915. An only and much-beloved child, he spent his early years nurturing a fascination with model airplanes. He knew he wanted to be a scientist, but he was unfocused through most of his college days at Washington University. He switched concentrations several times, from chemistry to physics to the fine arts and, finally, to psychology. When he graduated in 1937 he held undergraduate degrees in psychology, mathematics, and physics. For a master’s thesis in psychology, he decided to test the popular slogan “Get more sleep, it’s good for you” on a population of rats. As he approached his Ph.D., Licklider’s interests narrowed toward psychoacoustics, the psychophysiology of the auditory system.

利克莱德的博士论文研究了猫的听觉皮层，当他搬到斯沃斯莫尔学院时，他开始研究声音定位之谜，试图分析大脑确定声音距离和方向的能力。如果你闭上眼睛，让某人打个响指，你的大脑就会告诉你响指大概来自哪里以及距离有多远。声音定位之谜也体现在“鸡尾酒会”现象中：在一个拥挤的房间里，人们的听力范围内正在进行几场对话，通过调高某些声音并屏蔽其他声音，人们可以隔离自己选择的对话。

For his doctoral dissertation, Licklider studied the auditory cortex of cats, and when he moved to Swarthmore College, he worked on the puzzle of sound localization, attempting to analyze the brain’s ability to determine a sound’s distance and direction. If you close your eyes and ask someone to snap his fingers, your brain will tell you approximately where the snap is coming from and how far away it is. The puzzle of sound localization is also illustrated by the “cocktail party” phenomenon: In a crowded room where several conversations are taking place within one’s hearing range, it is possible to isolate whatever conversation one chooses by tuning in certain voices and tuning out the rest.

1942 年，利克莱德前往马萨诸塞州剑桥，在哈佛大学心理声学实验室担任研究员。战争年代，他研究了高海拔对语音通信的影响以及静电和其他噪音对无线电接收器接收的影响。利克莱德在 35,000 英尺的高空对 B-17 和 B-24 轰炸机进行了实验。飞机没有增压，机上温度通常远低于冰点。在一次实地测试中，利克莱德的同事兼好友卡尔·克里特看到利克莱德脸色发白。克里特惊慌失措。他打开氧气，对他的朋友大喊：“利克！跟我说话！”就在克里特正要让飞行员下降时，利克莱德的脸色又恢复了原样。他说，他一直非常痛苦，但这种痛苦已经过去了。之后，他在执行高空任务之前不再吃他最喜欢的早餐——可口可乐。

此时，利克莱德已加入哈佛大学任教，并被公认为世界听觉神经系统本质理论的顶尖理论家之一，他曾将听觉神经系统描述为“一位高超的建筑师和一位粗心的工人共同的产物”。

In 1942 Licklider went to Cambridge, Massachusetts, to work as a research associate in Harvard University’s Psycho-Acoustic Laboratory. During the war years, he studied the effects of high altitude on speech communication and the effects of static and other noise on reception by radio receivers. Licklider conducted experiments in B-17 and B-24 bombers at 35,000 feet. The aircraft weren’t pressurized, and the temperatures on board were often well below freezing. During one field test, Licklider’s colleague and best friend, Karl Kryter, saw Licklider turn white. Kryter panicked. He turned up the oxygen and yelled to his friend, “Lick! Speak to me!” Just as Kryter was about to ask the pilot to descend, the color returned to Licklider’s face. He had been in tremendous pain, he said, but it had passed. After that, he stopped partaking of his favorite breakfast—Coca-Cola— before going on high-altitude missions.

By this time, Licklider had joined the Harvard faculty and was gaining recognition as one of the world’s leading theorists on the nature of the auditory nervous system, which he once described as “the product of a superb architect and a sloppy workman.”

当时哈佛大学的心理学深受行为主义者 BF Skinner 等人的影响，他们认为所有的行为都是后天习得的，动物生来就是一张白纸，由偶然、经验和条件反射决定。当 Skinner 甚至将自己的孩子放进所谓的 Skinner 盒子来测试行为主义理论时，其他教员也开始做类似的实验（尽管没有那么激进），Louise Licklider 坚决反对。她的孩子不会放进盒子里，她的丈夫也同意。

Psychology at Harvard in those years was strongly influenced by the behaviorist B. F. Skinner and others who held that all behavior is learned, that animals are born as blank slates to be enscribed by chance, experience, and conditioning. When Skinner went so far as to put his own child in a so-called Skinner box to test behaviorist theories and other faculty members began doing similar experiments (albeit less radical ones), Louise Licklider put her foot down. No child of hers was going into a box, and her husband agreed.

露易丝通常是第一个听到丈夫想法的人。几乎每天晚餐后，他都会回去工作几个小时，但当他晚上 11 点左右回到家时，他通常会花一个小时左右的时间告诉露易丝他的最新想法。“我从小就在他的想法中成长，”她说，“从他种下种子，直到不知何故他看到它们结出果实。”

Louise was usually the first person to hear her husband’s ideas. Nearly every evening after dinner, he returned to work for a few hours, but when he got home at around 11:00P.M.he usually spent an hour or so telling Louise his latest thoughts. “I grew up on his ideas,” she said, “from when the seeds were first planted, until somehow or other he saw them bear fruit.”

每个人都崇拜利克莱德，在他的坚持下，几乎每个人都叫他“利克”。多年来，他永不停歇、多才多艺的天才吸引了一大批崇拜者。

Everybody adored Licklider and, at his insistence, just about everybody called him “Lick.” His restless, versatile genius gave rise through the years to an eclectic cult of admirers.

利克身高六英尺多一点，有着浅棕色的头发和一双大大的蓝眼睛。他最显著的特征是他柔和的、朴实的密苏里口音，但这掩盖了他敏锐的头脑。当他发表演讲或主持座谈会时，他从不准备演讲稿。相反，他会站起来，即兴地就他正在研究的某个问题发表长篇大论。利克的父亲曾是一名浸信会牧师，路易斯偶尔会因为注意到他身上的传教士气质而责备他。“在简报会或座谈会上，利克用那种柔和的乡巴佬口音谈论问题，简直是一场杰作， ”前同事比尔·麦吉尔回忆道。“他会带着密苏里欧扎克的鼻音说话，如果你从街上走进来，你会想，这个乡巴佬到底是谁？但如果你正在研究同样的问题，听他的演讲，你会觉得就像看到了黎明​​的曙光。”

Lick stood just over six feet tall. He had sandy brown hair and large blue eyes. His most pronounced characteristic was his soft, down-home Missouri accent, which belied his acute mind. When he gave talks or led colloquia, he never prepared a speech. Instead, he would get up and make extensive remarks off the cuff about a certain problem he happened to be working on. Lick’s father had been a Baptist minister, and Louise occasionally chided him by noticing the preacher in him. “Lick at play with a problem at a briefing or a colloquium, speaking in that soft hillbilly accent, was atour de force,” recalled Bill McGill, a former colleague. ”He’d speak in this Missouri Ozark twang, and if you walked in off the street, you’d wonder, Who the hell is this hayseed? But if you were working on the same problem, and listened to his formulation, listening to him would be like seeing the glow of dawn.”

利克的许多同事都对他解决问题的能力感到敬畏。他曾被描述为拥有世界上最敏锐的直觉。麦吉尔说：“他可以在我们其他人计算之前找到技术问题的解决方案。这让他显得非常特别。”利克在任何方面都不是形式主义者，也很少为晦涩难懂的定理而苦恼。“他就像一个睁大眼睛的孩子，从一个问题走到另一个问题，充满了好奇心。几乎每天，他都会对我们正在思考的问题产生新的启发。”

Many of Lick’s colleagues were in awe of his problem-solving ability. He was once described as having the world’s most refined intuition. “He could see the resolution of a technical problem before the rest of us could calculate it,” said McGill. “This made him rather extraordinary.” Lick was not a formalist in any respect and seldom struggled with arcane theorems. “He was like a wide-eyed child going from problem to problem, consumed with curiosity. Almost every day he had some new fillip on a problem we were thinking about.”

但与利克一起生活也有其挫折之处。许多人认为，他过于谦虚。他经常坐在会议上抛出各种想法，让任何人都可以认领。“如果有人从他那里偷了一个想法，”路易斯回忆道，“我会拍着桌子说这不公平，他会说，‘功劳归谁并不重要，重要的是把事情做成。’”在他教书的许多年里，他激励所有的学生，甚至是他的本科生，让他们觉得自己是初级同事。他的房子对他们敞开，学生们经常带着一章论文或一个问题出现在前门。“我会竖起大拇指，然后他们就会来到他三楼的办公室，”路易斯说。

But living with Lick had its frustrations, too. He was humble, many believed, to a fault. He often sat in meetings tossing ideas out for anyone to claim. “If someone stole an idea from him,” Louise recalled, “I’d pound the table and say it’s not fair, and he’d say, ‘It doesn’t matter who gets the credit; it matters that it gets done.’” Throughout the many years he taught, he inspired all his students, even his undergraduates, to feel like junior colleagues. His house was open to them, and students often showed up at the front door with a chapter of a thesis or just a question for him. ”I’d put my thumb up and they’d pound up to his third-floor office,” said Louise.

战后，心理学仍是一门年轻的学科，受到那些从事更深入科学研究的人的嘲笑，他们对一个涉及心灵或“人为因素”等神秘事物的新领域没有耐心。但利克莱德是一位最严谨的心理学家。正如一位同事所说，他属于那些“对自己科学活动合法性的自觉关注使他们比许多在更成熟的领域的同事更为坚定的人”。

In the postwar years, psychology was still a young discipline, inviting derision from those in the harder sciences with little patience for a new field that dealt with such enigmatic entities as the mind, or “the human factor.” But Licklider was a psychologist in the most rigorous sense. As one colleague put it, he belonged with those “whose self-conscious preoccupation with the legitimacy of their scientific activity has made them more toughminded than a good many of their colleagues in the better established fields.”

1950 年，利克搬到麻省理工学院，在学院的声学实验室工作。次年，麻省理工学院成立了林肯实验室，作为专门从事防空研究的实验室，利克签约成立了实验室的人体工程学小组。冷战几乎主宰了该机构的整个知识生活。林肯实验室是麻省理工学院与华盛顿的冷战联盟最明显的表现之一。

By 1950, Lick had moved to MIT to work in the Institute’s Acoustics Laboratory. The following year, when MIT created Lincoln Laboratory as a research lab devoted to air defense, Lick signed on to start the laboratory’s human-engineering group. The cold war had come to dominate virtually the entire intellectual life of the institution. Lincoln Lab was one of the most visible manifestations of MIT’s cold war alliance with Washington.

20 世纪 50 年代初，许多军事理论家担心苏联轰炸机携带核武器从北极上空发动突然袭击。正如科学家们在 20 世纪 40 年代联合起来应对德国核武器的可能性一样，1951 年，麻省理工学院也聚集了一个类似的团队，以应对苏联的威胁。他们的研究被称为查尔斯计划。其成果是向空军提出一个研究机构，专门用于开发防御空袭的技术。因此，林肯实验室迅速成立，配备了人员，并在其第一任主任、物理学家阿尔伯特·希尔的领导下开始工作。1952 年，实验室迁出校园，搬到了剑桥以西约 10 英里的列克星敦。其主要项目围绕远程预警的概念——DEW 线：理想情况下，雷达阵列从夏威夷延伸到阿拉斯加，穿过加拿大群岛到格陵兰岛，最后到达冰岛和不列颠群岛。如此庞大而复杂的结构所面临的通信、控制和分析问题只有计算机才能解决。为了满足这一要求，林肯首先接手了麻省理工学院的计算机项目 Whirlwind，然后开发了名为半自动地面环境（SAGE）的后续项目。

In the early 1950s many military theoreticians feared a surprise attack by Soviet bombers carrying nuclear weapons over the North Pole. And just as scientists had coalesced during the 1940s to deal with the possibility of German nuclear armament, a similar team gathered in 1951 at MIT to deal with the perceived Soviet threat. Their study was called Project Charles. Its outcome was a proposal to the Air Force for a research facility devoted to the task of creating technology for defense against aerial attack. Thus Lincoln Laboratory was quickly formed, staffed, and set to work under its first director, the physicist Albert Hill. In 1952, the lab moved off-campus to Lexington, about ten miles west of Cambridge. Its main projects centered around the concept of Distant Early Warning—the DEW line: arrays of radars stretching, ideally, from Hawaii to Alaska, across the Canadian archipelago to Greenland, and finally to Iceland and the British Isles. Problems of communication, control, and analysis for such an extended, complex structure could be handled only by a computer. To satisfy that requirement, Lincoln first took on Whirlwind, a computer project at MIT, and then developed a successor project called the Semi-Automatic Ground Environment, or SAGE.

SAGE 是基于一台大型 IBM 计算机的，非常庞大，以至于操作员和技术人员实际上只能走进机器内部。该系统主要有三大功能：接收来自各种探测和跟踪雷达的数据、解释与不明飞机有关的数据以及将防御武器指向来袭的敌机。SAGE 只是“半自动”的，因为人类操作员仍然是系统的重要组成部分。事实上，SAGE 是第一个完全可操作的实时交互式计算机系统之一。操作员通过显示器、键盘、开关和光枪与计算机通信。用户可以向计算机请求信息并在几秒钟内收到答复。新信息通过电话线不断直接流入计算机内存，供用户使用，操作员可以立即使用。

Based on a large IBM computer, SAGE was so mammoth that its operators and technicians literally walked inside the machine. The system served three major functions: receiving data from various detection and tracking radars, interpreting data relating to unidentified aircraft, and pointing defensive weapons at incoming hostile aircraft. SAGE was only “semiautomatic,” since the human operator remained an important part of the system. In fact, SAGE was one of the first fully operational, real-time interactive computer systems. Operators communicated with the computer through displays, keyboards, switches, and light guns. Users could request information from the computer and receive an answer within a few seconds. New information continuously flowed directly into the computer’s memory through telephone lines to the users, making it immediately available to the operators.

SAGE 系统启发了包括利克莱德在内的一些思想家，让他们以全新的眼光看待计算。SAGE 是利克莱德后来称之为人机“共生”的早期例子，其中机器充当解决问题的伙伴。这种共生关系意味着人类和计算机作为一个单一系统协同工作的相互依赖性。例如，在战斗场景中，没有计算机的人类操作员无法足够快地计算和分析威胁以应对攻击。相反，单独工作的计算机将无法做出关键决策。

The SAGE system inspired a few thinkers, including Licklider, to see computing in an entirely new light. SAGE was an early example of what Licklider would later call the “symbiosis” between humans and machines, where the machine functions as a problemsolving partner. Implied in this symbiotic relationship was the interdependency of humans and computers working in unison as a single system. For instance, in a battle scenario, human operators without computers would be unable to calculate and analyze threats quickly enough to counter an attack. Conversely, computers working alone would be unable to make crucial decisions.

1953 年，麻省理工学院决定在经济系心理学部门成立一个人为因素小组，利克负责该小组的工作。他招募了一批最聪明的学生和同事。利克招聘人员的依据不是他们的博士工作或班级排名，而是他应用的一项简单测试：米勒类比测试。（该测试涵盖了从地质学到历史和艺术等各个领域。它既需要良好的常识，也需要将这些知识应用于人际关系的能力。）“我有一条规则，”他说。“任何在米勒类比测试中能取得 85 分或更高分数的人，都可以聘用他，因为他一定在某些方面非常出色。”

In 1953 MIT decided to start a human factors group in the psychology section of the economics department, and Lick was put in charge. He recruited a handful of his brightest students and colleagues. Lick hired people based not on their doctoral work or class standing but on a simple test he applied: the Miller Analogies Test. (The test covers every field from geology to history and the arts. It requires both good general knowledge and an ability to apply that knowledge to relationships.) “I had a kind of a rule,” he said. “Anybody who could do 85 or better on the Miller Analogies Test, hire him, because he’s going to be very good at something.”

1954 年，利克的团队与斯隆管理学院的社会心理学家和劳工管理专家一起进驻。但该团队的想法与管理问题相去甚远。正如利克莱德早期招募的麦吉尔所描述的那样，他和他的同事对计算机和计算机存储设备更感兴趣，因为它们是人类认知多功能性的模型。利克指导下，该系的第一篇论文来自博士候选人汤姆·马里尔，他研究了理想听觉检测的主题。（和其他进入利克莱德领域的人一样，马里尔将在未来几年在计算机网络的发展中留下自己的印记。）“以前从未见过这样的事情，至少在心理学系没有，”麦吉尔说。该系是历史上第一个认知科学系。“这项工作是基于实验的认知心理学，就像今天的定义一样，但当时我们没有合适的语言或术语。”

In 1954 Lick’s group moved in with the social psychologists and labor-management experts in the Sloan School of Management. But the group’s ideas were far removed from management problems. As McGill, an early Licklider recruit, described it, he and his peers were far more interested in computers and computer memory devices as models for the versatility of human cognition. The first dissertation produced by the department under Lick’s guidance came from Ph.D. candidate Tom Marill, who had examined the subject of ideal auditory detection. (Like others who came into Licklider’s sphere, Marill would make his mark on the development of computer networking in years to come.) “Nothing like this had ever been seen before, at least not in a psychology department,” said McGill. The department was the first cognitive science department in history. “The work was experimentally based cognitive psychology, as it would be defined today, but at the time we had no proper language or nomenclature.”

但最终，麻省理工学院的管理者想要一些更传统的东西，而利克试图通过长期任命来扩大他的新部门的努力失败了。结果，他所有年轻且有市场潜力的门徒都离开了。“我们没有足够的智慧来推广我们所做的事情，我们不知道它有什么独特之处。所以麻省理工学院让这一切溜走了，”麦吉尔说。毕竟，利克是个特立独行的人，有点离经叛道，也许对麻省理工学院来说太过分了。

But eventually MIT administrators wanted something more traditional, and Lick failed in his efforts to expand his new department with permanent appointments. As a result, all his protégés, young and marketable, drifted off. “We did not have the sophistication to promote what we did, and we were unaware that there was anything unique about it. So MIT let it all slip away,” McGill said. Lick was a maverick, after all, and a little far-out, perhaps too much so for MIT.

然而，利克并不为该团体的解散而感到惋惜，因为他自称注意力不集中。多年来，他的兴趣经常发生巨大变化。他曾建议一位年轻朋友永远不要签约一个持续五到七年以上的项目，这样他就可以随时转向其他事情。利克对任何感兴趣的事情都会深入研究。

Yet Lick did not lament the demise of the group, for he had a self-professed short attention span. His interests changed often and dramatically over the years. He once advised a young friend never to sign on for a project that lasted more than five to seven years, so he could always move on to other things. And anything Lick got interested in, he plunged into in great depth.

也许最能激起利克对计算机及其作为交互仪器的潜力的兴趣的事件是他在 20 世纪 50 年代与林肯实验室一位聪明、固执己见的年轻工程师韦斯利·克拉克的相遇。克拉克当时是一名年轻的研究员，正在研究 TX-2 机器，这是数字计算领域的最先进机器，也是 TX-0 计算机的后继者。在肯·奥尔森离开去创办数字设备公司之前，克拉克和奥尔森一起制造了 TX-0。

克拉克的办公室在林肯的地下室。一天，在从走廊另一端的储藏室回来的路上，克拉克决定进入一个似乎一直被禁止进入的房间。大多数实验室的门都开着，但这扇门不是。它总是关着的。克拉克试了试门，惊讶地发现门没有锁，于是他走进了房间。“我穿过一个由挡板和障碍物组成的小迷宫，走了进去，”克拉克回忆道。 “实验室的一侧非常昏暗，我走了进去，在黑暗中摸索了一会儿后，发现一个人坐在一些显示器前。他正在做一些心理测量，显然是个有趣的人。我对他正在做的事情和他的仪器很感兴趣，我记得我曾向他建议，他可以用电脑获得同样的结果。”这个人就是利克莱德。克拉克邀请利克莱德到大厅来看看 TX-2 并学习一些基础知识。

Perhaps the incident that most piqued Lick’s interest in computers and their potential as interactive instruments was an encounter he had in the 1950s with a smart, opinionated young engineer at Lincoln Labs named Wesley Clark. Clark was a young researcher working on the TX-2 machine, the state of the art in digital computation and the successor to a computer called the TX-0. Clark had built the TX-0 with Ken Olsen before Olsen left to start Digital Equipment Corporation.

Clark’s office was in the Lincoln basement. One day, on his way back from the stockroom at the other end of the corridor, Clark decided to venture into a room that had always seemed vaguely off-limits. Most lab doors stood open, but not this one. It was always closed. Clark tried the door, which he was surprised to find unlocked, and entered the room. “I wandered in and back through a little labyrinth of baffles and barriers,” Clark recalled. “Off to one side was this very dark laboratory and I went in, and after probing around in the dark for a while I found this man sitting in front of some displays. He was doing some kind of psychometrics, and he was clearly an interesting fellow. I got interested in what he was doing and in his apparatus, and as I recall I suggested to him that he could achieve the same results by using a computer.” The man was Licklider. Clark invited Lick to come down the hall to see the TX-2 and learn some fundamentals.

教利克如何真正编程机器太难了。编程像 TX-2 这样的计算机就像是一门黑魔法。TX-2 包含 64,000 字节内存（相当于今天的简单手持计算器），占用了几个房间。许多年后，计算机中央处理器的微型微芯片在当时是巨大的机架，上面有许多独立的插件，每个插件由数十个晶体管和相关电子零件组成。更大的空间被大型控制台所占据，上面覆盖着开关和指示灯，以帮助操作员或故障排除人员了解系统正在做什么。所有这些设备都需要一架又一架的设备，其中只有一小部分——视频显示屏和键盘——今天可能被识别为普通的计算机部件。“和利克一起坐在 TX-2 旁边，就像被埋在一堆看似无关紧要的东西中，”克拉克说。即使对于像利克莱德这样反应敏捷的人来说，成为 TX-2 的“用户”也是一项艰巨的任务。一方面，当时没有教学工具，没有教学辅助工具或帮助菜单。另一方面，标准化机器编程的操作系统也尚未编写。

Teaching Lick actually to program the machine would have been too difficult. Programming a computer like the TX-2 was something of a black art. The TX-2, which contained 64,000 bytes of memory (as much as a simple handheld calculator today), took up a couple of rooms. What many years later became tiny microchips for the computer’s central processing unit were, in those days, huge racks of many separate plug-in units, each consisting of dozens of transistors and associated electronic parts. Still more space was taken up with large consoles covered with switches and indicator lights to help the operator or troubleshooter understand what the system was doing. All of this equipment required rack upon rack of gear, only a tiny fraction of which—the video display screen and keyboard—might be recognizable today as ordinary computer parts. “To sit at the TX-2 with Lick was to be embedded in a welter of seemingly irrelevant stuff,” Clark said. To become a TX-2 “user” would have been a daunting exercise even for someone as quick as Licklider. For one thing, there were no teaching tools per se, no instructional aids or help menus. For another, the operating system, which would standardize programming for the machine, had yet to be written.

TX-2 的一个出色功能就是在视频屏幕上显示信息。这使它成为最早用于交互式图形工作的机器之一。正是这个功能帮助克拉克向利克展示了交互式使用的主要思想。

One thing the TX-2 did do very well was display information on video screens. That made it one of the earliest machines for interactive graphics work. It was this feature that helped Clark demonstrate for Lick the main ideas of interactive use.

与克拉克的会面给利克留下了不可磨灭的印象。他从心理学转向了计算机科学。随着兴趣的转变，利克对计算机改变社会的潜力的信念变成了一种痴迷。在计算的诱惑下，他开始一次花几个小时坐在交互式显示控制台前。路易斯相信，如果他没有得到报酬，他会自己花钱做这件事的。

The sessions with Clark made an indelible impression on Lick. He drifted further from psychology and toward computer science. As his interests changed, Lick’s belief in the potential for computers to transform society became something of an obsession. Succumbing to the lure of computing, he began spending hours at a time at the interactive display console. Louise believed that if he weren’t being paid for this work, he’d have paid to do it.

利克的世界观的核心思想是技术进步将拯救人类。政治进程是他最喜欢的例子。利克以麦克卢汉式的观点看待电子媒体的力量，他看到了这样一个未来：在很大程度上得益于计算机的普及，大多数公民将“了解、关注并参与政府进程”。他想象着所谓的“家用电脑控制台”和电视机通过一个巨大的网络连接在一起。他写道：“政治进程本质上将是一场大型电话会议，而竞选将是候选人、宣传员、评论员、政治行动团体和选民之间长达数月的一系列沟通。关键在于通过良好的控制台和良好的网络与一台好的计算机进行真正有效的信息交互时，随之而来的自我激励的兴奋。”

The idea on which Lick’s worldview pivoted was that technological progress would save humanity. The political process was a favorite example of his. In a McLuhanesque view of the power of electronic media, Lick saw a future in which, thanks in large part to the reach of computers, most citizens would be “informed about, and interested in, and involved in, the process of government.” He imagined what he called “home computer consoles” and television sets linked together in a massive network. “The political process,” he wrote, “would essentially be a giant teleconference, and a campaign would be a months-long series of communications among candidates, propagandists, commentators, political action groups, and voters. The key is the self-motivating exhilaration that accompanies truly effective interaction with information through a good console and a good network to a good computer.”

1960 年，利克发表了开创性的论文《人机共生》，他对计算机在人类生活中可能扮演的角色的思考达到了高潮。在这篇论文中，他将自己的许多想法提炼为一个核心论点：人类与“伙伴关系的电子成员”之间的紧密结合最终将导致合作决策。此外，决策将由人类使用计算机做出，而不再像利克所说的那样“僵化地依赖预定的程序”。他认为，计算机将继续自然地用于它们最擅长的事情：所有死记硬背的工作。这将使人类能够将精力投入到做出更好的决策和发展更清晰的洞察力上，而这些是他们在没有计算机的情况下无法做到的。利克认为，人与机器的合作将比任何一方单独行动时表现得更出色。此外，与计算机合作解决问题可以节省后现代最宝贵的资源：时间。“希望，”利克莱德写道，“在不久的将来，人类的大脑和计算机将结合在一起……紧密结合，由此产生的合作伙伴关系将以人类大脑从未有过的方式思考，并以我们今天所知的信息处理机器无法接近的方式处理数据。”

Lick’s thoughts about the role computers could play in people’s lives hit a crescendo in 1960 with the publication of his seminal paper “Man-Computer Symbiosis.” In it he distilled many of his ideas into a central thesis: A close coupling between humans and “the electronic members of the partnership” would eventually result in cooperative decision making. Moreover, decisions would be made by humans, using computers, without what Lick called “inflexible dependence on predetermined programs.” He held to the view that computers would naturally continue to be used for what they do best: all of the rote work. And this would free humans to devote energy to making better decisions and developing clearer insights than they would be capable of without computers. Together, Lick suggested, man and machine would perform far more competently than either could alone. Moreover, attacking problems in partnership with computers could save the most valuable of postmodern resources: time. “The hope,” Licklider wrote, “is that in not too many years, human brains and computing machines will be coupled . . . tightly, and that the resulting partnership will think as no human brain has ever thought and process data in a way not approached by the information-handling machines we know today.”

利克莱德的想法源于几年前在林肯实验室地下室的一次偶然相遇，代表了当时最大胆、最富想象力的想法。麻省理工学院的一位前学生罗伯特·罗辛 (Robert Rosin) 于 1956 年选修了利克莱德的实验心理学课程，后来进入计算机科学领域，他读了《人机共生》后，对这位老人的才智之广感到敬畏。罗辛说：“我一生都无法想象，一位在 1956 年对计算机一无所知的心理学家，怎么会在 1960 年写出如此深刻和有见地的关于‘我的领域’的论文。”“利克莱德的论文给我留下了深刻的印象，让我更加意识到，一个全新的计算时代已经到来。”

Licklider’s ideas, which had their beginnings just a few years earlier in a chance encounter in the basement of Lincoln Lab, represented some of the most daring and imaginative thinking of the day. One former MIT student, Robert Rosin, who had taken an experimental psychology course from Lick in 1956 and later went into computer science, read “Man-Computer Symbiosis” and was awestruck by the elder’s intellectual versatility. “For the life of me, I could not imagine how a psychologist who, in 1956, had no apparent knowledge of computers, could have written such a profound and insightful paper about ‘my field’ in 1960,” Rosin said. “Lick’s paper made a deep impression on me and refined my own realization that a new age of computing was upon us.”

在利克莱德发表论文的那一刻，他作为计算机科学家的声誉就永远定格了。他摆脱了心理学的束缚，开始从事计算机研究。他已经无法回头了。在论文发表的几年前，利克莱德离开了麻省理工学院，到剑桥一家名为 Bolt Beranek and Newman 的小型咨询和研究公司工作。该公司同意为他购买两台计算机用于他的研究，他正享受着人生中最美好的时光。

In the moment that Licklider published the paper, his reputation as a computer scientist was fixed forever. He shed the mantle of psychology and took on computing. There was no turning him back. A couple of years before the paper was published, Licklider had left MIT to work at a small consulting and research firm in Cambridge called Bolt Beranek and Newman. The company had agreed to buy him two computers for his research, and he was having the time of his life.

1962 年的一天，ARPA 主任杰克·鲁伊纳 (Jack Ruina) 打电话给利克莱德，告诉他有一份新工作。利克莱德不仅要接手 ARPA 的指挥和控制部门，还要接手一个新的行为科学部门，他会怎么想？而且，这份工作中还会涉及一台巨大的计算机 Q-32。

One day in 1962, ARPA director Jack Ruina called Licklider with a new job possibility. What would Lick say to taking on not just ARPA’s command and control division, but a new behavioral sciences division as well? And there’d be a huge computer, the Q-32, thrown into the deal.

鲁伊纳还拜访了弗雷德·弗里克，他是利克在林肯实验室的朋友和同事。弗里克和利克莱德一起会见了鲁伊纳。利克莱德进来时只准备倾听，但很快就滔滔不绝地谈论这个话题。他告诉鲁伊纳，指挥和控制的问题本质上是人机交互的问题。“我认为基于批处理的指挥和控制系统简直太荒谬了，”多年后他回忆道。“如果一个人必须在战斗中编写程序，谁能指挥战斗呢？”利克莱德和弗里克都认为这份工作看起来很有趣，但他们都不想离开自己正在做的事情。

Ruina also called on Fred Frick, a friend and colleague of Lick’s at Lincoln Lab. Frick and Licklider met with Ruina together. Licklider went in prepared just to listen but was soon waxing eloquent on the topic. The problems of command and control, he told Ruina, were essentially problems of human-computer interaction. “I thought it was just ridiculous to be having command and control systems based on batch processing,” he recalled years later. “Who can direct a battle when he’s got to write the program in the middle of the battle?” Licklider and Frick agreed that the job seemed interesting, but neither wanted to leave what he was doing.

然而，鲁伊纳的推销非常激烈，他让这项任务显得如此重要，以至于弗里克和利克莱德决定由他们其中一人来做这件事。他们掷硬币决定，利克莱德接受了这个职位，条件是他可以自由地领导这个项目，朝他认为合适的任何方向发展。一方面是因为鲁伊纳非常忙，另一方面是因为他自己不懂电脑，所以他毫不犹豫地同意了这个条件。

Ruina’s sales pitch was so intense, however, and he made the mission seem so critical, that Frick and Licklider decided one of them should do it. They tossed a coin, and Lick accepted the position on the condition that he be given the freedom to lead the program in any direction he saw fit. Partly because Ruina was very busy, and partly because he didn’t understand computers himself, he agreed to the proviso without hesitation.

利克是一小群计算机科学家中的一员，他们相信，如果人们手边有一台具有良好显示和良好数据库的计算机系统，他们的工作效率就会大大提高。1962 年秋天，在搬到华盛顿之前，利克在五角大楼举办了一系列计算机研讨会，国防部和军方官员出席了研讨会。他的理念在剑桥已经是一种口头禅，但对军方听众来说仍然很陌生，那就是计算机应该是任何人都可以直接与之交互的东西，消除了计算机操作员作为解决问题的中间人的作用。

Lick belonged to a small group of computer scientists who believed that people could be much more effective if they had at their fingertips a computer system with good displays and good databases. Before moving to Washington in the fall of 1962, Lick gave a series of computer seminars at the Pentagon, well attended by Defense Department and military officials. His message, already something of a mantra up in Cambridge but still largely unfamiliar to a military audience, was that a computer should be something anyone could interact with directly, eliminating computer operators as the middlemen in solving their problems.

为此，利克看到了分时的巨大潜力，并成为分时最热心的推广者之一。分时并没有真正把电脑放在每个人的办公桌上，但它创造了一种这样的假象。它把电脑的强大功能带到了每个人的指尖。它让人们对机器有了强烈的感觉。

To this end, Lick saw great promise in time-sharing and was one of its most ardent evangelists. Time-sharing didn’t exactly put a computer on everyone’s desk, but it created the illusion of just that. It brought the power of the computer right to everyone’s fingertips. It gave people a strong feel for the machine.

推广分时技术绝非利克来到 ARPA 时的唯一使命。他同样热衷于探索多年来围绕人机交互酝酿的理念。

The promotion of time-sharing was by no means Lick’s sole mission when he arrived at ARPA. He was just as keen on exploring the ideas that had been percolating around human-machine interaction for several years.

1962 年 10 月 1 日，利克第一天上班时，他的秘书说：“好吧，利克莱德博士，您今天只有一个约会。预算局的几位先生将前来审查您的计划。”预算官员到达后，他们惊讶地发现这是利克莱德的第一天上班。目前还没有太多实质性内容要讨论。指挥和控制计划包括一份价值 900 万美元的合同——与系统开发公司签订——预算中剩余的 500 万美元左右仍未分配。会议没有进行预算审查，而是变成了一场私人座谈会，利克在会上阐述了分时、交互式计算和人工智能等主题。和他们之前的许多人一样，会计师们也被利克莱德的热情所感染。“我告诉他们我感到兴奋的事情，结果这对我非常有利，因为他们对此很感兴趣，”他后来说。“当我们确实就此举行会议时，他们没有拿走我的任何钱。”

When Lick arrived for his first day at work, on October 1, 1962, his secretary said, “Well, Dr. Licklider, you have just one appointment today. There are some gentlemen coming from the Bureau of the Budget to review your program.” When the budget officers arrived, they were amused to discover it was Licklider’s first day. There wasn’t much of substance to discuss yet.
