As Marill argued in a letter to Roberts in 1965, computing had reached an unfortunate state of affairs; time-sharing projects were proliferating, but there was no “common ground for exchange of programs, personnel, experience, or ideas.” His impression of the computer science community was “of a number of essentially similar projects, each going off in its own direction with complete disregard for the others.” Why waste resources?

TX-2 实验的规模非常宏大。两台计算机之间的连接采用一种特殊的 Western Union 四线全双工服务（全双工提供两点之间同时双向传输）。Marill 在该服务上连接了一种简陋的调制解调器，以每秒 2,000 比特的速度运行，他称之为自动拨号器。通过直接连接两台计算机，Marill 解决了它们之间不兼容的问题。其想法是将两台计算机连接起来，就像一对连体双胞胎，在原地运行程序。虽然没有来回传输文件，但实验确实允许两台计算机相互发送消息。Marill 设置了一个程序，将字符分组为消息，通过链接发送它们，并检查消息是否到达。如果没有确认，则重新传输消息。Marill 将这套来回发送信息的程序称为消息“协议”，这促使一位同事询问道：“你为什么使用这个词？我以为它是指外交。”

As far as it went, the TX-2 experiment was ambitious. The link between the two computers was made using a special Western Union four-wire full-duplex service (full duplex provides simultaneous transmission in both directions between two points). To this Marill attached a crude form of modem, operating at 2,000 bits per second, which he called an automatic dialer. By directly linking the machines, Marill got around the problem of incompatibilities between them. The idea was to connect the computers like a pair of Siamese twins, running programsin situ.Though not transferring files back and forth, the experiment did allow the machines to send messages to each other. Marill set up a procedure for grouping characters into messages, sending them across the link, and checking to see if the messages arrived. If no acknowledgment followed, the message was retransmitted. Marill referred to the set of procedures for sending information back and forth as a message “protocol,” prompting a colleague to inquire, “Why do you use that term? I thought it referred to diplomacy.”

在 1966 年的一份总结实验初步结果的报告中，马里尔写道，他“预见到只要付出合理的努力，就没有任何障碍无法克服”。尽管付出了努力，但当马里尔和罗伯茨真正连接这两台机器时，结果好坏参半。连接本身按计划运行。但连接的可靠性和响应时间，正如罗伯茨几年后所描述的那样，简直糟透了。

In a 1966 report summarizing the initial results of the experiment, Marill wrote that he could “foresee no obstacle that a reasonable amount of diligence cannot be expected to overcome.” Diligence notwithstanding, when Marill and Roberts actually connected the two machines, the results were mixed. The connection itself worked as planned. But the reliability of the connection and the response time were, as Roberts would describe them several years later, just plain lousy.

把两台不同的计算机连接在一起是一回事，但罗伯茨离开林肯大学前往 ARPA 工作的项目则是另一回事，而且挑战更大。将一组具有不同特征的机器连接起来将非常复杂。要做到这一点，罗伯茨可能需要请来他认识的计算和通信领域的每一位专家。

Bringing together two different computers was one thing, but the project for which Roberts had been pulled away from Lincoln to work at ARPA was another, much greater challenge. Interconnecting a matrix of machines, each with distinct characteristics, would be exceedingly complicated. To pull it off was probably going to require calling on every expert Roberts knew in every area of computing and communications.

幸运的是，罗伯茨的同事圈子很广。他最好的朋友之一是林肯实验室的莱昂纳德·克莱因罗克，他曾与克莱因罗克一起开发过 TX-2。克莱因罗克是一位聪明而雄心勃勃的工程师，曾获得全额奖学金进入麻省理工学院学习。如果说有谁对罗伯茨最早的计算机网络思想产生了影响，那一定就是克莱因罗克了。

Fortunately, Roberts’s circle of colleagues was wide. One of his best friends from Lincoln Laboratory, with whom he had worked on the TX-2, was Leonard Kleinrock, a smart and ambitious engineer who had attended MIT on a full scholarship. If anyone influenced Roberts in his earliest thinking about computer networks, it was Kleinrock.

克莱因罗克的论文早在 1959 年就已提出，是一项重要的理论工作，描述了一系列通信网络的分析模型。1961 年，在与罗伯茨合作期间，克莱因罗克在麻省理工学院发表了一份报告，分析了网络中的数据流问题。克莱因罗克还研究过随机路由程序，并对将消息分成块以有效利用通信信道有一些初步想法。当时克莱因罗克在加州大学洛杉矶分校，罗伯茨给了他一份 ARPA 合同，让他在那里建立官方网络测量中心，这是一个专门用于网络性能测试的实验室。

Kleinrock’s dissertation, proposed as early as 1959, was an important theoretical work that described a series of analytical models of communication networks. And in 1961, while working with Roberts, Kleinrock had published a report at MIT that analyzed the problem of data flow in networks. Kleinrock had also worked on random routing procedures, and had some early thoughts on dividing messages into blocks for efficient use of communication channels. Now Kleinrock was at UCLA, and Roberts gave him an ARPA contract to set up the official Network Measurement Center there, a lab devoted to network performance testing.

罗伯茨和克莱因罗克之间的友谊远远超出了他们共同的职业兴趣。脑筋急转弯是他们共同的兴趣之一。赚钱计划是他们共同的兴趣。他们彼此都鼓励对方对财务冒险持开放态度。那些认为罗伯茨只工作不玩耍的人从未见过他和朋友们一起行动。

The friendship between Roberts and Kleinrock went well beyond the professional interests they shared. Brain teasers were one common interest. Money-making schemes were another. Each reinforced the other’s openness to fiscal adventure. Those who thought Roberts was all work and no play had never seen him in action with his friends.

罗伯茨和克莱因罗克是赌场的赌徒。罗伯茨为二十一点发明了一种“高低”算牌方案，并把它教给了克莱因罗克。他们从未被列入官方黑名单算牌者名单，但赌场侦探不止一次发现他们并要求他们离开。

Roberts and Kleinrock were inveterate casino gamblers. Roberts developed a “high-low” counting scheme for blackjack and taught it to Kleinrock. They never made it into the official rogues’gallery of blacklisted card counters, but more than once, they were spotted by casino detectives and asked to leave.

在另一个大胆的事件中，罗伯茨和克莱因罗克想出了一个利用轮盘物理学赚钱的计划。他们的想法是利用基本的运动定律来预测球何时会偏离轨道。要做到这一点，他们需要知道球在一个方向上移动的速度，以及轮盘在另一个方向上移动的速度。他们决定制造一台可以进行预测的小型机器，但他们需要一些数据。于是罗伯茨拿来一台录音机，手里拿着一个麦克风，做了一个模型，让他看起来像是手腕骨折了。两人坐在桌边，罗伯茨把手放在轮盘旁边，录下球经过的声音，然后他们可以从中推断出球的速度。克莱因罗克的工作是通过玩几轮轮盘来分散赌场老板的注意力。“一切都很顺利，除了一件事，”克莱因罗克说。“我开始赢钱了。这引起了人们的注意。赌场老板看了看，发现这个家伙手臂骨折，手放在轮盘附近，他抓住拉里的胳膊说：“让我看看你的胳膊！”拉里和我迅速离开了那里。”

• • •

And in another daring episode, Roberts and Kleinrock cooked up a plan to cash in on the physics of roulette. The idea was to predict, employing rudimentary laws of motion, just when the ball would fall off its trajectory. To do this, they needed to know the speed of the ball, which traveled in one direction, and the speed of the wheel, which traveled in the other. They decided to build a small machine that would make the predictions, but they needed a little data. So Roberts got a tape recorder, put a microphone in his hand, and made a cast that made it appear he had a broken wrist. The two sat down at the table and Roberts placed his hand next to the wheel to record the sound of the passing ball, from which they could later extrapolate its speed. Kleinrock’s job was to distract the pit boss by playing several rounds of roulette. “Everything was working fine except for one thing,” Kleinrock said. “I started winning. It drew attention to me. The pit boss looks over and sees this guy with a broken arm with his hand near the roulette wheel, and he grabs Larry’s arm and says, ‘Let me see your arm!’Larry and I made fast tracks out of there.”

• • •

罗伯茨同意泰勒的观点，认为网络的快速响应时间至关重要，因为较低的消息延迟时间对于交互性至关重要。任何使用过通过标准通信线路传输数据的分时系统的人都知道这种系统有多慢。数据以每秒几百比特的极慢速度往返于主计算机。检索或发送哪怕是少量信息的过程都会留下足够的时间给自己倒一杯咖啡，甚至泡一壶咖啡，而调制解调器则在不停地运转。没有人想要一个反应迟钝的网络。

Roberts agreed with Taylor that fast response time for the network was critical, because a low message delay time was crucial to interactivity. Anyone who had used time-sharing systems that passed data over standard communications lines knew how sluggish they could be. Data traveled to and from the main computer at excruciatingly slow rates of a few hundred bits per second. Retrieving or sending even a small amount of information was a process that left plenty of time to pour yourself a cup of coffee, or even brew an entire pot, while the modem churned away. No one wanted a sluggish network.

在罗伯茨召集的松散顾问小组的一次早期会议上，有人一拳打在桌子上说：“如果这个网络不能给我一秒钟的响应时间，那就没用了。”乐观地说，半秒的响应时间被写入了要求中。当然，第二个优先事项是可靠性。如果网络要有效，用户需要完全相信它能够毫无障碍地来回发送数据。

During an early meeting of the loose group of advisors Roberts had assembled, someone banged his fist on the table and said, “If this network can’t give me a one-second response, it’s no good.” Optimistically, a half-second response time was written into the requirements. The second priority, of course, was reliability. If a network was to be effective, users needed complete confidence in its ability to send data back and forth without snafus.

另一个令人担忧的问题是如何规划网络。一些人建议在一台集中式计算机上共享资源，这台计算机位于奥马哈，那里是长途电话交换机的热门地点，因为它位于美国的地理中心。如果集中化对电话网络有意义，那么对计算机网络为什么不行呢？也许网络应该使用专用电话线（这个问题仍未解决），这将有助于保持成本统一。巴兰一直避免使用集中式系统，因为这会增加其脆弱性。罗伯茨也反对集中式方法，但他决定推迟最终决定，直到他能向一大群人提出这个话题。他的机会很快就来了，在 1967 年初密歇根州安娜堡举行的 ARPA 首席研究员会议上。

Another source of consternation was the question of how the network would be mapped out. Several people had proposed that the resource sharing be done on a single centralized computer, sitting in, say Omaha, a popular place for long-distance telephone switches because it lay at the nation’s geographic center. If centralization made sense for a telephone network, why not for a computer network? Perhaps the network should use dedicated phone lines—a question that was still unresolved—which would help keep costs uniform. Baran had avoided a centralized system because that increased its vulnerability. Roberts, too, was opposed to a centralized approach, but decided to delay his final decision until he could bring up the topic with a large group. His chance came soon, at a meeting for ARPA’s principal investigators in Ann Arbor, Michigan, in early 1967.

泰勒召集了这次会议，会议的主要议题是网络实验。罗伯茨介绍了他的初步计划。他描述说，这个想法是通过拨号电话线将所有分时计算机直接连接起来。网络功能将由每个站点的“主机”计算机处理。换句话说，主机将承担双重职责，既是研究计算机，又是通信路由器。这个想法并没有得到太多的欢迎。来自拟议主机站点的人们预见到麻烦无穷。没有人愿意放弃一部分宝贵的计算资源来管理一个他们几乎不感兴趣的网络。此外，还有几十种特殊的变化需要处理，其中最不重要的是每台机器使用的语言都与其他机器大不相同。围绕一套协议进行标准化似乎几乎是不可能的。

Taylor had called the meeting, and the principal item on the agenda was the networking experiment. Roberts laid out his initial plan. The idea, as he described it, was to connect all of the time-sharing computers to one another directly, over dial-up telephone lines. The networking functions would be handled by the “host” computers at each site. So, in other words, the hosts would do double duty, as both research computers and as communications routers. The idea was greeted with little enthusiasm. People from the proposed host sites foresaw no end of trouble. No one wanted to relinquish an unknown portion of valuable computing resources to administer a network about which they were hardly excited. Then there were dozens of idiosyncratic variations to cope with, not the least of which was the fact that each machine spoke a language substantially different from the others. It seemed nearly impossible to standardize around one set of protocols.

安阿伯会议表明，人们对泰勒和罗伯茨的提议缺乏热情，甚至可以说是完全的敌意。很少有 ARPA 首席研究员愿意参与这项实验。这种态度在东海岸大学的研究人员中尤为明显，他们认为没有理由与西部的校园建立联系。他们就像灯塔山上的上流社会妇女，当被告知可以使用长途电话服务拨打德克萨斯时，她会重复梭罗的名言：“但我能对德克萨斯的人说什么呢？”

The Ann Arbor meeting revealed the lack of enthusiasm, if not downright hostility, to Taylor and Roberts’s proposal. Few ARPA principal investigators wanted to participate in the experiment. This attitude was especially pronounced among researchers from the East Coast universities, who saw no reason to link up with campuses in the West. They were like the upper-crust woman on Beacon Hill who, when told that long-distance telephone service to Texas was available, echoed Thoreau’s famous line: “But what would I possibly have to say to anyone in Texas?”

1967 年，斯坦福研究所 (SRI) 的计算机科学家道格拉斯·恩格尔巴特 (Douglas Engelbart) 清楚地记得那次会议。“第一个反应是，‘天哪，我有一台分时计算机，而我的资源本来就很稀缺。’另一个反应是，‘我为什么要让我的研究生沉迷于这种事情？’”尽管如此，罗伯茨的认真态度很快就显而易见。首先，他试图消除人们对资源共享的怀疑，指出每个人的计算机上都有一些其他人可能想要的东西。“我记得一个人转向另一个人说，‘你的电脑里有什么我可以用的？’”恩格尔巴特回忆道，“另一个人回答说，‘嗯，你不看我的报告吗？’”没有人接受这个想法。“人们在想，‘既然我这里什么都有，为什么还需要别人的电脑？’”当时还是加州大学洛杉矶分校研究生的乔恩·波斯特尔回忆道。 “他们有什么东西是我想要的？我又有什么东西是我想让别人看到的？”

Douglas Engelbart, a computer scientist at Stanford Research Institute (SRI) in 1967, remembered the meeting clearly. “One of the first reactions was, ‘Oh hell, here I’ve got this time-sharing computer, and my resources are scarce as it is.’ Another reaction was, ‘Why would I let my graduate students get sucked off into something like this?’” Nonetheless, it quickly became clear just how serious Roberts was. First he tried to allay the skepticism about resource-sharing by pointing out that everyone had something of interest on his computer that others might want. “I remember one guy turning to the other and saying, ‘What have you got on your computer that I could use?’” Engelbart recalled, “And the other guy replied, ‘Well, don’t you read my reports?’” No one was taken with the idea. “People were thinking, ‘Why would I need anyone else’s computer when I’ve got everything right here?” recalled Jon Postel, then a graduate student at UCLA. “What would they have that I want, and what would I have that I want anyone else to look at?”

更困难的问题在于克服不同计算机之间的通信障碍。例如，如何让 TX-2 与 UCLA 的 Sigma-7 或 SRI 的计算机进行通信？这些机器、它们的操作系统、它们的编程语言都不同，只有天知道它们之间还存在哪些不协调之处。

An even more difficult problem lay in overcoming the communications barriers between disparate computers. How could anyone program the TX-2, for instance, to talk to the Sigma-7 at UCLA or the computer at SRI? The machines, their operating systems, their programming languages were all different, and heaven only knew what other incongruities divided them.

会议结束前，韦斯·克拉克递给罗伯茨一张纸条，上面写着：“你已经把网络搞透了。”罗伯茨很感兴趣，他想听更多；然而，会议快结束了，人们都离开了。会议结束后，罗伯茨、泰勒和其他几个人围在克拉克身边，一小群人决定在回机场的路上继续讨论。在车里，克拉克勾勒出他的想法：尽可能不要使用主机，而是在每台主机和传输线网络之间插入一台小型计算机。（巧合的是，这正是戴维斯在英国单独得出的结论。）

Just before the meeting ended, Wes Clark passed a note up to Roberts. It read, “You’ve got the network inside out.” Roberts was intrigued, and he wanted to hear more; however, the meeting was breaking up, and people were already leaving. Roberts, Taylor and a few others huddled around Clark afterward, and a small group decided to continue the discussion during the ride back to the airport. In the car, Clark sketched out his idea: Leave the host computers out of it as much as possible and instead insert a small computer between each host computer and the network of transmission lines. (This was, by coincidence, precisely what Davies had concluded separately in England.)

按照克拉克的解释，解决方案显而易见：一个由小型、相同的节点组成的子网络，所有节点都相互连接。这个想法解决了几个问题。它对所有主机的要求要少得多，相应地对负责这些主机的人的要求也少得多。当然，组成这个内部网络的小型计算机都会使用同一种语言，它们（而不是主机）将负责所有路由。此外，主机只需调整一次语言即可与子网对话。克拉克的想法不仅在技术上很有意义，而且也是一个管理解决方案。ARPA 可以直接控制整个网络，而不必过多担心每个主机的特性。此外，为每个站点提供自己的相同计算机将使实验更加统一。

The way Clark explained it, the solution was obvious: a subnetwork with small, identical nodes, all interconnected. The idea solved several problems. It placed far fewer demands on all the host computers and correspondingly fewer demands on the people in charge of them. The smaller computers composing this inner network would all speak the same language, of course, and they, not the host computers, would be in charge of all the routing. Furthermore, the host computers would have to adjust their language just once— to speak to the subnet. Not only did Clark’s idea make good sense technically, it was an administrative solution as well. ARPA could have the entire network under its direct control and not worry much about the characteristics of each host. Moreover, providing each site with its own identical computer would lend uniformity to the experiment.

最令人好奇的是，这个想法是克拉克想出来的。他一直没有太关注安阿伯的会议进程。事实上，他对这一切感到有点厌烦。他已经明确地告诉罗伯茨，他不想把他在圣路易斯华盛顿大学的计算机放到网络上。克拉克对分时甚至资源共享都不太友好。他一直在研究个人使用的计算机，没有理由与网络上的人共享他的设备。但当他听到关于如何部署 ARPA 实验的争论时，他忍不住提出了一个建议。也许正是克拉克对分时技术的反感让他想到了这一点。通过将路由任务分配给主机，罗伯茨和其他人实际上是在添加另一个分时功能。克拉克的想法是减轻主机的额外负担，并建立一个由相同的、非共享的计算机组成的网络，专门用于路由。

The most curious thing about the idea was that Clark thought it up. He hadn’t been paying much attention to the proceedings in Ann Arbor. In fact, he was a bit bored by it all. He had already told Roberts in no uncertain terms that he had no desire to put his computer at Washington University in St. Louis on the network. Clark was not friendly toward time-sharing, or even resource-sharing. He had been working on computers designed for individual use and saw no particular reason to share his facility with people on a network. But when he heard the discord over how the ARPA experiment should be deployed, he couldn’t help but hazard a suggestion. Perhaps it was Clark’s antipathy toward time-sharing that enabled him to think of this. By assigning the task of routing to the host computers, Roberts and others were essentially adding another time-sharing function. Clark’s idea was to spare the hosts that extra burden and build a network of identical, nonshared computers dedicated to routing.

在去机场的路上，大家的讨论变得热烈起来。由多台计算机组成的整个子网络会不会太昂贵，违背了省钱的初衷？罗伯茨想知道韦斯·克拉克认为谁能制造出这样的东西？“全国只有一个人能做到这一点，”克拉克回答道。“弗兰克·哈特。”

During the ride to the airport, the discussion turned lively. Wouldn’t an entire subnetwork composed of individual computers be prohibitively expensive and defeat the original goal of saving money? And who, Roberts wanted to know, did Wes Clark think could build such a thing? “There’s only one person in the country who can do that,” Clark responded. “Frank Heart.”

拉里·罗伯茨认识弗兰克·哈特。两人曾在林肯实验室共事，罗伯茨还曾与哈特的妻子简共用一间办公室，简是林肯实验室的一名程序员。罗伯茨和哈特从未直接共事过，但罗伯茨知道哈特是一位严谨的系统工程师。他是实时系统方面的专家，该系统专为满足现实世界在几分之一秒内（或至少在下一组数据到达之前）做出响应的需求而构建。任何以时间紧迫的方式处理传入信息的东西，例如发送到 SAGE 系统的雷达跟踪数据和地震期间生成的地震信息，都被认为是实时系统，而在 20 世纪 60 年代，很少有人像哈特一样了解实时系统。

Larry Roberts knew Frank Heart. The two had worked together at Lincoln Lab, and Roberts had shared an office with Heart’s wife, Jane, a programmer at Lincoln. Roberts and Heart had never worked together directly, but Roberts knew Heart to be an exacting systems engineer. He was an expert in real-time systems built for when the physical world demands a response within fractions of seconds—or at least before the next set of data arrives. Anything dealing with incoming information in a time-critical fashion, such as radar tracking data sent to the SAGE system, and seismic information generated during an earthquake, was considered a real-time system, and in the 1960s few people understood real-time systems as well as Heart did.

罗伯茨还知道哈特和克拉克在林肯大学时就是好朋友，十多年前哈特曾在那里向克拉克传授编程技巧。现在，据罗伯茨所知，哈特在剑桥的博尔特贝拉内克和纽曼公司工作，他于 1966 年搬到那里，研究计算机在医学中的应用。

Roberts also knew that Heart and Clark were good friends from Lincoln, where Heart had shown Clark the ropes of programming more than a decade earlier. Now, as far as Roberts knew, Heart was at Bolt Beranek and Newman in Cambridge, where he had moved in 1966 to work on the use of computers in medicine.

ARPA 网络并非旨在打造一个实时系统，与真正的实时系统所理解的“实时”一词的含义并不相同。（任何需要超过 10 到 20 毫秒（延迟达到人眼可察觉的程度）的事物都不算实时。）严格来说，ARPA 网络是一个存储转发系统。但数据在节点之间来回传输的速度非常快，从人的角度来看，响应时间也非常快，因此它属于实时问题。该系统必须应对数十个涉及紧密序列事件和极其紧密时间安排的问题。网络状态会不断变化，无论是谁编写了组成 Clark 所提议子网的计算机，都需要知道如何让系统以非常快的速度可靠地处理传入和传出数据。

The ARPA network wasn’t intended as a real-time system, not in the same sense of the word that true real-timers understand it. (Anything that takes more than 10 to 20 milliseconds, the point at which delays become humanly perceptible, is not considered real-time.) Strictly speaking, the ARPA network was to be a store-and-forward system. But data would zip in and out of the nodes so quickly, and the response time from a human perspective would be so rapid, that it qualified as a real-time problem. The system would have to cope with dozens of problems involving closely sequenced events and extremely tight timing. The status of the network would change constantly, and whoever programmed the computers that composed Clark’s proposed subnet would need to know how to make the system handle incoming and outgoing data reliably at very fast rates.

尽管克拉克的建议合乎逻辑，但罗伯茨不能简单地把这项工作交给哈特。ARPA 必须遵守政府的合同规则。多年来，大多数申请资助的提案都是主动提交给 ARPA 的。该机构很少真正征求提案。但这一次不同。该机构内部提出了网络构想，在这方面它很不寻常。此外，由于该网络将是由 ARPA 集中控制的政府财产，不会驻留在一个校园或一家研究公司，罗伯茨和其他人决定必须将这个项目提交给竞标者。

Despite the logic of Clark’s recommendation, however, Roberts couldn’t simply turn the job over to Heart. ARPA had to play by the government’s contracting rules. Over the years, most proposals requesting funding arrived at ARPA unsolicited. Seldom had the agency actually requested proposals. But this one was different. The agency had come up with the network idea internally, and in that respect it was unusual. Also, because the network would be government property controlled centrally by ARPA and wouldn’t reside on one campus, say, or at one research firm, Roberts and others decided they had to send this project out for competitive bids.

回到华盛顿后，罗伯茨写了一份备忘录，描述了克拉克的想法，并将其分发给了克莱因罗克和其他人。他将控制网络的中间计算机称为“接口消息处理器”，简称 IMP，他将其读作“imps”。它们将执行连接网络、发送和接收数据、检查错误、在发生错误时重新传输、路由数据以及验证消息是否到达其预定目的地的功能。将建立一个协议来定义 IMP 应如何与主机通信。克拉克的想法传开后，最初对网络的敌意有所减弱。首先，一台单独的计算机来执行交换功能可以消除将这些功能添加到主机中可能产生的繁琐的临时解决方案（临时解决方案是解决技术问题的不优雅解决方案）。人们还将其视为一种让另一台计算机发挥作用的方式。

When he returned to Washington, Roberts wrote a memorandum describing Clark’s idea and distributed it to Kleinrock and others. He called the intermediate computers that would control the network “interface message processors,” or IMPs, which he pronounced “imps.” They were to perform the functions of interconnecting the network, sending and receiving data, checking for errors, retransmitting in the event of errors, routing data, and verifying that messages arrived at their intended destinations. A protocol would be established for defining just how the IMPs should communicate with host computers. After word of Clark’s idea spread, the initial hostility toward the network diminished a bit. For one thing, a separate computer to carry out the switching functions removed the burdensome kludge (a kludge is an inelegant solution to a technical problem) that could result from adding those functions to the host computer. People also saw it as a way of getting another computer to play with.

1967 年底，在田纳西州加特林堡举行的另一场计算机会议推动了网络计划的推进。这次研讨会由计算机协会主办，该协会是不断发展的计算机行业历史最悠久、最负盛名的专业组织。虽然人数不多，但与会者代表了计算机科学界的最高水平。

At the end of 1967 another computer conference, this one in Gatlinburg, Tennessee, helped advance the network plan. This symposium was sponsored by the Association for Computing Machinery, the oldest and most prestigious of professional organizations for the growing computer industry. Though small in number, the attendees represented the highest levels of the computer science establishment.

加特林堡是罗伯茨发表第一篇论文的理想场所，论文的主题是他所谓的“ARP​​A 网络”。在演讲中，罗伯茨重点介绍了网络的原因，并描述了 IMP 子网，但对网络的实际工作方式只字未提。还有一个大难题需要解决，那就是数据究竟是如何传输的——通过什么样的通道。考虑到成本，罗伯茨在演讲结束时简短讨论了他所谓的“通信需求”。他考虑使用他和玛丽尔在小型 TX-2 实验中使用的同一种电话线：全双工、四线线路。讨论结束时，大家有些沮丧。普通的拨号电话线（与专用租用线路相反）速度很慢，而且保持线路畅通是一种浪费。罗伯茨仍然没有找到一种高效的数据传输方式。

Gatlinburg was a perfect venue for Roberts to present his first paper on what he called the “ARPA net.” In his presentation, Roberts focused on the reasons for the network and described the subnet of IMPs, but said little else about how the network would actually work. One big puzzle still to solve was the question of how the data would actually be transmitted—over what kind of channel. Ever mindful of cost, Roberts closed his presentation with a brief discussion of what he called “communication needs.” He was thinking of using the same type of telephone lines that he and Marill had used for their small TX-2 experiment: full-duplex, four-wire lines. Talk of the matter ended on a note of frustration. Ordinary dial-up phone lines (as opposed to dedicated, leased lines) were slow, and holding a line open was wasteful. Roberts still hadn’t found a highly efficient means of carrying the data.

几个月前在安阿伯举行的会议相当于一场酒吧斗殴，而加特林堡会议则像是下午茶。人们礼貌地接受了建立网络的想法。罗伯茨的演讲受到了普遍的好评，有些人甚至热情地欢迎他。

Whereas the Ann Arbor meeting months earlier had been the intellectual equivalent of a barroom brawl, Gatlinburg was high tea. People were politely coming around to the idea of a network. Roberts’s presentation was generally well received, even greeted enthusiastically by some.

另一篇论文由罗杰·斯坎特伯里 (Roger Scantlebury) 发表。该论文来自国家物理实验室的唐纳德·戴维斯 (Donald Davies) 团队，讨论了英国正在进行的工作。他的论文介绍了分组交换网络的详细设计研究。这是罗伯茨第一次听说这个。之后，罗伯茨和其他几个人找到了斯坎特伯里，他们开始讨论 NPL 的工作。讨论在酒店的酒吧里持续进行，一直持续到深夜。斯坎特伯里向罗伯茨提出了线路速度的问题。他说，他和戴维斯计划使用比罗伯茨提议的 2,000 比特/秒速度快得多的线路。他建议罗伯茨用更少的线路构建 ARPA 网络，以超过二十倍的速度传输数据，从而缩短响应时间。

Another paper was presented by Roger Scantlebury. It came from Donald Davies’ team at the National Physical Laboratory and discussed the work going on in England. His paper presented a detailed design study for a packet-switched network. It was the first Roberts had heard of it. Afterward, Roberts and a few others approached Scantlebury, and they began to discuss the NPL work. The discussion continued at the hotel bar and went late into the night. Scantlebury raised the issue of line speed with Roberts. He said that he and Davies were planning to use lines that operated much faster than the 2,000 bits per second speed Roberts was proposing. He suggested Roberts build the ARPA network with fewer lines carrying data at speeds more than twenty times higher to improve the response time.

罗伯茨还首次从斯坎特伯里那里了解到保罗·巴兰几年前在兰德公司所做的工作。罗伯茨回到华盛顿后，找到了兰德公司的报告，这些报告实际上已经在信息处理技术办公室里积尘数月，罗伯茨仔细研究了这些报告。罗伯茨在设计这个实验网络时，主要考虑的不是可存活通信，甚至不是次要考虑。核战争场景以及指挥和控制问题并不是罗伯茨的首要任务。但巴兰对数据通信的见解仍然引起了他的兴趣，1968 年初，他与巴兰会面。此后，巴兰成为罗伯茨组建的网络设计小组的非正式顾问。斯坎特伯里代表英国提交的加特林堡论文显然也对他产生了影响。戴维斯在设计 ARPA 网络期间拜访罗伯茨时说：“我发现我们的论文被反复使用，以至于纸张都散了。”

Roberts also learned from Scantlebury, for the first time, of the work that had been done by Paul Baran at RAND a few years earlier. When Roberts returned to Washington, he found the RAND reports, which had actually been collecting dust in the Information Processing Techniques Office for months, and studied them. Roberts was designing this experimental network not with survivable communications as his main—or even secondary—concern. Nuclear war scenarios, and command and control issues, weren’t high on Roberts’s agenda. But Baran’s insights into data communications intrigued him nonetheless, and in early 1968 he met with Baran. After that, Baran became something of an informal consultant to the group Roberts assembled to design the network. The Gatlinburg paper presented by Scantlebury on behalf of the British effort was clearly an influence, too. When he visited Roberts during the design of the ARPA network, Davies said, “I saw that our paper had been used so much that its pages were falling apart.”

罗伯茨认为网络应该从四个站点开始——加州大学洛杉矶分校、斯坦福研究院、犹他大学和加州大学圣巴巴拉分校——最终发展到十九个左右。加州大学洛杉矶分校被选为第一个站点，因为 Len Kleinrock 的网络测量中心就在那里。在其他每个站点，ARPA 资助的研究都已在进行中，这些研究将为网络提供宝贵的资源。加州大学圣巴巴拉分校的研究人员正在研究交互式图形。犹他州的研究人员也在做大量的图形工作，并为军方研究夜视技术。戴夫·埃文斯 (Dave Evans) 后来与伊万·萨瑟兰 (Ivan Sutherland) 创办了先锋图形公司 Evans and Sutherland，当时他在犹他州组装一个可以拍摄图像并用计算机处理它们的系统。埃文斯和他的团队还对网络是否可以用于文本交换以外的其他用途感兴趣。

Roberts thought the network should start out with four sites—UCLA, SRI, the University of Utah, and the University of California at Santa Barbara—and eventually grow to around nineteen. UCLA was chosen as the first site because Len Kleinrock’s Network Measurement Center was there. At each of the other sites, ARPA-sponsored research that would provide valuable resources to the network was already under way. Researchers at UCSB were working on interactive graphics. Utah researchers were also doing a lot of graphics work as well as investigating night vision for the military. Dave Evans, who, with Ivan Sutherland, later started Evans and Sutherland, a pioneering graphics company, was at Utah putting together a system that would take images and manipulate them with a computer. Evans and his group were also interested in whether the network could be used for more than just textual exchanges.

斯坦福研究所（后来与斯坦福断绝关系，改名为 SRI）之所以被选为首批地点之一，是因为有远见卓识的科学家道格·恩格尔巴特（Doug Engelbart）在那里工作。几年前，鲍勃·泰勒（Bob Taylor）在美国宇航局工作时，曾资助恩格尔巴特发明第一台计算机鼠标（恩格尔巴特获得了该设备的专利，该设备是“显示系统的 XY 位置指示器”），多年后，泰勒自豪地表示他支持恩格尔巴特的鼠标。

Stanford Research Institute (later it severed its ties to Stanford and became just SRI) had been chosen as one of the first sites because Doug Engelbart, a scientist of extraordinary vision, worked there. Several years earlier, when Bob Taylor was at NASA he had funded Engelbart’s invention of the first computer mouse (Engelbart received a patent for the device as an “X-Y position indicator for a display system”), and for years afterward Taylor pointed with pride to his support of Engelbart’s mouse.

1967 年，泰勒和拉里·罗伯茨宣布，他们中的十几个人将通过一个实验网络将他们的计算机连接在一起，并且每个站点都将在网络上提供其计算机资源，当时恩格尔巴特参加了 ARPA 首席研究员在安阿伯举行的会议。虽然其他人对该计划持怀疑态度，但恩格尔巴特对此感到非常高兴。当时，他正在领导一个 SRI 计算机研究实验室。与利克莱德一样，恩格尔巴特对使用计算机来增强人类智力很感兴趣。根据 ARPA 的合同，他正在开发一个依赖于计算机知识社区的系统（称为 NLS，即离线系统）。他认为 ARPA 实验网络是将 NLS 扩展到广泛分布式协作领域的绝佳工具。“我意识到有一个现成的计算机社区，”恩格尔巴特回忆道。“这正是我在寻找的东西。”

NLS 的优势之一在于它在创建数字图书馆以及存储和检索电子文档方面非常有用。Engelbart 还认为 NLS 是支持 ARPA 网络信息交换中心的自然方式。毕竟，如果人们要共享资源，那么让每个人都知道有哪些资源可用是很重要的。在密歇根会议上，Engelbart 自愿组建网络信息中心，该中心后来被称为 NIC（发音为“nick”）。Engelbart 还知道，他在门洛帕克的研究小组也会对网络同样充满热情。他的同事都是才华横溢的程序员，他们一看到一个有趣的项目就会认出来。

Engelbart had been in attendance at the 1967 Ann Arbor meeting of ARPA’s principal investigators when Taylor and Larry Roberts announced that a dozen or so of them would be expected to tie their computers together over an experimental network and that each site would be expected to make its computer resources available on the network. While others had responded skeptically to the plan, Engelbart had been delighted with it. At the time, he was directing an SRI computer research lab. Not unlike Licklider, Engelbart was interested in using computers to augment human intellect. Under a contract from ARPA, he was developing a system (called NLS, for oNLine System) that depended on computer-literate communities. He saw the ARPA experimental network as an excellent vehicle for extending NLS to a wide area of distributed collaboration. “I realized there was a ready-made computer community,” Engelbart recalled. “It was just the thing I was looking for.”

Part of the strength of NLS was its usefulness in creating digital libraries and in storing and retrieving electronic documents. Engelbart also saw NLS as a natural way to support an information clearinghouse for the ARPA network. After all, if people were going to share resources, it was important to let everyone know what was available. At the Michigan meeting, Engelbart volunteered to put together the Network Information Center, which came to be known as the NIC (pronounced “nick”). Engelbart also knew that his research group back home in Menlo Park would be equally enthusiastic about the network. His colleagues were talented programmers who would recognize an interesting project when they saw it.

与斯坎特伯里的对话让罗伯茨理清了几个问题。这位英国人对分组交换的评论尤其帮助罗伯茨更接近详细的设计。在指定网络要求时，罗伯茨遵循了一些基本原则。首先，IMP 子网应充当通信系统，其基本任务是将比特从源位置可靠地传输到指定目的地。其次，通过子网的平均传输时间应小于半秒。第三，子网必须能够自主运行。那个时代的计算机通常每周需要几个小时的维护停机时间。IMP 不能依赖本地主机或主机站点人员；无论主机是否运行，它们都应该能够继续运行和路由网络流量。当个别 IMP 因服务中断时，子网也必须继续运行。维护可靠性应该由子网而不是主机负责，这一想法是一个关键原则。罗伯茨和其他人认为，IMP 还应该负责路线选择和收据确认等任务。

The conversation with Scantlebury had clarified several points for Roberts. The Briton’s comments about packet-switching in particular helped steer Roberts closer to a detailed design. In specifying the network requirements, Roberts was guided by a few basic principles. First, the IMP subnet was to function as a communications system whose essential task was to transfer bits reliably from a source location to a specified destination. Next, the average transit time through the subnet should be less than half a second. Third, the subnet must be able to operate autonomously. Computers of that era typically required several hours per week of maintenance downtime. IMPs could not afford to be dependent on a local host computer or host-site personnel; they should be able to continue operating and routing network traffic whether or not a host was running. The subnetwork also had to continue functioning when individual IMPs were down for service. This idea that maintaining reliability should be incumbent on the subnetwork, not the hosts, was a key principle. Roberts and others believed the IMPs should also attend to such tasks as route selection and acknowledgment of receipt.

到 1968 年 7 月底，罗伯茨已经完成了征求建议书的起草工作。他将其发送给了 140 家对开发接口信息处理器感兴趣的公司。这份文件详细阐述了网络应该是什么样子，以及接口信息处理器应该做什么。这是一篇内容丰富的技术文章，充满了各种想法。克莱因罗克影响了罗伯茨对理论可能性的最初想法。巴兰为该技术概念所基于的知识基础做出了贡献，罗伯茨的动态路由方案也为巴兰的工作锦上添花；罗伯茨采用了戴维斯的术语“数据包”，并融入了他和斯坎特伯里的更高线路速度；克拉克的子网想法是技术天才之举。“技术发展的过程就像建造一座大教堂，”巴兰多年后评论道。 “几百年来，新人不断出现，每个人都在旧地基上放上一块石头，每个人都说，‘我建造了一座大教堂。’下个月，另一块石头又被放在了之前的那块上面。然后一位历史学家问道，‘那么，是谁建造了这座大教堂？’彼得在这里加了一些石头，保罗又加了一些。如果你不小心，你可能会自欺欺人地认为你做了最重要的部分。但事实是，每一项贡献都必须遵循前人的工作。一切都与其他一切息息相关。”

By the end of July, 1968, Roberts had finished drafting the request for proposals. He sent it out to 140 companies interested in building the Interface Message Processor. The document was thick with details of what the network should look like and what the IMPs would be expected to do. It was a rich piece of technical prose, filled with an eclectic mix of ideas. Kleinrock had influenced Roberts’s earliest thoughts about the theoretical possibilities. Baran had contributed to the intellectual foundation on which the technical concept was based, and Roberts’s dynamic routing scheme gave an extra nod to Baran’s work; Roberts had adopted Davies’ term “packet” and incorporated his and Scantlebury’s higher line speeds; Clark’s subnet idea was a stroke of technical genius. “The process of technological development is like building a cathedral,” remarked Baran years later. “Over the course of several hundred years new people come along and each lays down a block on top of the old foundations, each saying, ‘I built a cathedral.’Next month another block is placed atop the previous one. Then comes along an historian who asks, ‘Well, who built the cathedral?’ Peter added some stones here, and Paul added a few more. If you are not careful, you can con yourself into believing that you did the most important part. But the reality is that each contribution has to follow onto previous work. Everything is tied to everything else.”

但 1968 年，网络的主要架构师是 Larry Roberts：他做出了最初的决定，并制定了参数和操作规范。尽管他会听取其他人的意见，但 Roberts 才是决定谁来构建网络的人。IBM 和控制数据公司 (CDC) 率先响应了提案请求。IBM 当时是世界上最大的计算机制造商，并主导着大型计算机系统市场。CDC 虽然比不上 IBM，但也是在开发大型系统方面投入巨资的另一家公司。两家公司都拒绝投标，理由相同：他们直截了当地说，这个网络永远无法建成，因为没有足够小的计算机来实现成本效益。对于 IMP，IBM 曾考虑过提出使用 360 Model 50 计算机，这是一种大型主机。但 Model 50 的价格是小型计算机的很多倍，太贵了，不值得考虑大量购买。

But in 1968 the network’s principal architect was Larry Roberts: He made the initial decisions, and he established the parameters and operational specifications. Although he would get input from others, Roberts would be the one to decide who built it. The first responses to the request for proposals were from IBM and Control Data Corporation (CDC). IBM was then the world’s largest computer manufacturer and dominated the market for large computer systems. CDC, though dwarfed by IBM, was another company that had invested heavily in developing large systems. Both declined to bid, and their reasons were identical: The network could never be built, they said flatly, because there existed no computers small enough to make it cost-effective. For the IMP, IBM had thought about proposing a 360 Model 50 computer, a large mainframe. But at a price many times that of a minicomputer, the Model 50 was too expensive to consider buying in large quantities.

而罗伯茨则想得比较小。他想到的第一台计算机是 PDP-8，这是由数字设备公司生产的一款小型计算机。数字设备公司于 1965 年发布了 PDP-8。这不仅是该公司的第一款畅销产品，而且 PDP-9 还确立了小型计算机作为计算机行业新先锋的地位。罗伯茨在林肯认识了肯·奥尔森，他认为数字设备公司甚至可能会对这款机器提供批量折扣。

Roberts, on the other hand, was thinking small. The first computer he had thought of was the PDP-8, a minicomputer made by Digital Equipment Corp. Digital had released the PDP-8 in 1965. Not only was it the company’s first big hit but the PDP-9 also established minicomputers as the new vanguard of the computer industry. Roberts knew Ken Olsen from Lincoln, and he thought Digital might even offer a quantity discount on the machine.

当投标开始进行时，大多数人选择了霍尼韦尔的计算机。这是一台名为 DDP-516 的小型计算机；霍尼韦尔刚刚推出它。这台新机器的声望部分在于它可以按照重型规格制造。其“加固”版本的价格约为 80,000 美元。这台机器推出后不久，在拉斯维加斯举行的计算机会议上，加固的军用版本被起重机从展厅地板上吊起。当它从连接在起重机上的绳索上摆动时，一名霍尼韦尔员工用大锤敲打它。这次演习的目的是证明这台机器足够坚固，可以在战场上使用。对于投标人来说，516 更可能吸引人的地方是其令人印象深刻的性价比和输入/输出系统的设计。

When bids started coming in, the majority had chosen a Honeywell computer instead. It was a minicomputer called the DDP-516; Honeywell had just introduced it. Part of the new machine’s cachet was that it could be built to heavy-duty specifications. In its “ruggedized” version, it cost about $80,000. Shortly after the machine’s introduction, at a computer conference in Las Vegas, the hardened military version was hoisted off the showroom floor by a crane. As it swung from ropes attached to the crane, a Honeywell employee took a sledgehammer to it. The point of the exercise was to demonstrate that the machine was tough enough to operate on a battlefield. For bidders, the more likely appeal of the 516 was its impressive cost-performance ratio and the design of its input/output system.

有十多个投标书，最终堆积成六英尺高的纸堆。马里尔的公司 CCA 与 Digital 联合投标。雷神公司和 Bunker-Ramo 也参与了投标。令罗伯茨惊喜的是，有几位投标人相信他们可以构建一个比规格中列出的目标速度更快的网络。

More than a dozen bids were submitted, resulting in a six-foot stack of paper. Marill’s company, CCA, bid jointly with Digital. Raytheon bid, and so did Bunker-Ramo. Roberts was pleasantly surprised that several of the respondents believed they could construct a network that performed faster than the goal listed in the specifications.

雷神公司是领跑者。雷神公司是波士顿地区一家主要的国防承包商，专门从事电子系统组件业务，该公司已经提议建设一个高速短距离计算机网络。12 月中旬，罗伯茨与雷神公司就 IMP 合同进行了最后谈判。雷神公司的官员回答了 ARPA 剩余的技术问题并接受了价格。

Raytheon was a frontrunner. A major defense contractor in the Boston area specializing in electronic systems components, Raytheon had already proposed to build a high-speed, short-distance computer network. In the middle of December, Roberts entered into final negotiations with Raytheon for the IMP contract. Raytheon officials answered ARPA’s remaining technical questions and accepted the price.

因此，就在圣诞节前几天，ARPA 宣布将建造作为其实验网络核心的接口消息处理器的合同授予马萨诸塞州剑桥的一家小型咨询公司 Bolt Beranek and Newman，这让所有人都感到惊讶。

So it surprised everyone when, just a few days before Christmas, ARPA announced that the contract to build the Interface Message Processors that would reside at the core of its experimental network was being awarded to Bolt Beranek and Newman, a small consulting firm in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

3 第三大学

3 The Third University

1948 年，理查德·博尔特 (Richard Bolt) 和利奥·贝拉内克 (Leo Beranek) 创办了他们的咨询公司，当时他们还没有考虑过高级计算。贝拉内克是一名电气工程师，博尔特是一名建筑师和物理学家。两人都是声学家，在 20 世纪 40 年代都是麻省理工学院的教员。二战期间，博尔特曾在海军工作，研究利用声音探测潜艇的方法。战后，作为麻省理工学院声学实验室的负责人，博尔特和贝拉内克都从事咨询工作。麻省理工学院开始收到全国各地新建筑声学规划援助请求，并将它们转交给博尔特和贝拉内克。两人各自独立地在所谓的空气声学（音乐厅和电影院中传播的声音）以及建筑物噪音控制和降噪方面做了大量工作。

When Richard Bolt and Leo Beranek started their consulting company in 1948, advanced computing was not on their minds. Beranek was an electrical engineer, Bolt an architect and physicist. Both were acousticians and members of the MIT faculty during the 1940s. Bolt had worked for the Navy in World War II on methods for using sound to detect submarines. Following the war, as head of MIT’s acoustics laboratory, Bolt did consulting work, as did Beranek. MIT began receiving requests for aid in acoustical planning for new buildings around the country and passed them on to Bolt and Beranek. Independently of each other, the two had already done quite a bit of work in what is known as airborne acoustics—the sound carried in concert halls and movie theaters—as well as in noise control and noise reduction in buildings.

当联合国要求博尔特为其位于曼哈顿东河旧屠宰场区的新建筑群设计声学效果时，博尔特把贝拉内克叫到办公室，向他展示了一叠写明联合国工作的文件。这项工作一个人承担不起。当时，贝拉内克正忙于改善布鲁克林一家连锁电影院的声学效果。但博尔特说服贝拉内克和他一起创办一家咨询公司，承接联合国的项目。一年后，他们聘请了罗伯特·纽曼，一位拥有物理学背景的建筑师，曾是博尔特的学生，于是博尔特·贝拉内克和纽曼公司就诞生了。

When the United Nations asked Bolt to design the acoustics for its new complex of buildings in an old slaughterhouse district on Manhattan’s East River, Bolt called Beranek into his office and showed him the pile of papers spelling out the UN job. It was too much for one person to take on. At the time, Beranek was busy on a project to improve the acoustics in a chain of Brooklyn movie theaters. But Bolt convinced Beranek to join him in starting a consulting firm to take on the UN project. A year later they took in Robert Newman, an architect with a physics background who had been a student of Bolt’s, and Bolt Beranek and Newman was born.

在早期，BBN 是一家真正的咨询公司。也就是说，Bolt 和 Beranek 雇佣员工，为他们提供办公空间，并期望他们找到工作。他们确实找到了工作。联合国项目取得了如此显著的成功，以至于该公司在成立后的前十年都不需要做广告。随着 BBN 为办公楼、公寓大楼和表演艺术中心的声学系统设计提供咨询，业务不断发展。当在克利夫兰附近建造一个用于测试喷气发动机的大型风洞时，噪音打扰了十英里范围内的人们，当地居民威胁要关闭该设施。BBN 工程师想出了一种消除噪音的方法。该公司正在发展分析录音带的专业技能：1963 年约翰·肯尼迪总统遇刺后，该公司被召集参与分析，1970 年肯特州立大学枪击案发生后，该公司再次被召集参与分析。该公司最著名的录音带分析发生在 1974 年水门事件期间，当时 BBN 参与分析了尼克松录音带中臭名昭著的 18.5 分钟空白。由迪克·博尔特领导的一个委员会得出结论，删除录音带是故意的。

In its earliest days, BBN was truly a consulting company. That is, Bolt and Beranek hired people, provided them with office space—and expected them to find the work. And find work they did. The UN project was such a conspicuous success that the company didn’t need to advertise for the first ten years of its existence. The business grew as BBN consulted on the design of acoustical systems for office buildings, apartment complexes, and performing arts centers. When a large wind tunnel was built for testing jet engines near Cleveland, the noise disturbed people within a ten-mile radius, and local residents threatened to have the facility shut down. BBN engineers figured out a way to muffle the sound. The company was developing expertise in analyzing audio tapes: It was called in after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in 1963 and would be called on again after the shootings at Kent State University in 1970. Its most famous tape analysis would come during the Watergate scandal in 1974, when BBN would be involved in the analysis of the infamous 18.5-minute gap in the Nixon tapes. A committee headed by Dick Bolt would conclude that the erasure was deliberate.

1957 年，贝拉内克招募利克莱德加入 BBN。战争期间，利克莱德曾在哈佛大学与利克共事，而当利克去麻省理工学院时，他又说服利克也去那里。当贝拉内克聘请利克加入 BBN 时，他之所以感兴趣，并不是因为他有心理声学背景，而是因为他对人机交互感兴趣。贝拉内克感觉到，帮助公司制造能够更有效地放大人力的机器，从而实现人机之间的某种兼容性，咨询工作将会蓬勃发展。“我不知道这个行业有多大，”贝拉内克后来回忆道。“但我认为这是对我们正在做的事情的一个很好的补充。”

当然，利克对此考虑得更周全。他相信科学研究的未来将与高速计算机紧密相连，他认为计算是 BBN 进入的一个好领域。他在 BBN 工作不到一年，就告诉贝拉内克他想买一台电脑。为了说服利克，他强调说，他心目中的计算机是一种非常现代化的机器——它的程序和数据都记录在纸带上，而不是传统的 IBM 卡片堆上。

In 1957 Beranek had recruited Licklider to BBN. He had worked with Lick at Harvard during the war, and when he went to MIT, he convinced Lick to go there too. When Beranek hired Lick at BBN, it wasn’t so much Lick’s background in psychoacoustics but his interest in human-machine interaction that Beranek thought was interesting. Beranek sensed that consulting jobs would pick up in the business of helping companies build machines that were more efficient amplifiers of human labor, which meant bringing about some kind of compatibility between humans and machines. “I didn’t know how big a business it was,” Beranek later recalled. “But I thought it was a good supplement to what we were doing.”

Lick, of course, had thought it through more fully. He believed the future of scientific research was going to be linked to high-speed computers, and he thought computing was a good field for BBN to enter. He had been at BBN for less than a year when he told Beranek he’d like to buy a computer. By way of persuasion, Lick stressed that the computer he had in mind was a very modern machine—its programs and data were punched on paper tape rather than the conventional stacks of IBM cards.

“要花多少钱？”贝拉内克问他。“大约 25,000 美元。”“这可是一大笔钱，”贝拉内克回答道。“你打算怎么用这笔钱？”“我不知道。”

“What will it cost?” Beranek asked him. “Around $25,000.” “That’s a lot of money,” Beranek replied. “What are you going to do with it?” “I don’t know.”

利克莱德确信该公司能够获得政府的合同，使用计算机进行基础研究。他向贝拉内克保证，这 25,000 美元不会被浪费。

Licklider was convinced the company would be able to get contracts from the government to do basic research using computers. The $25,000, he assured Beranek, wouldn’t be wasted.

公司的三位负责人都不太懂计算机。贝拉内克知道，利克则相反，他几乎是狂热的信徒，坚信计算机不仅会改变人们思考问题的方式，还会改变解决问题的方式。最终，贝拉内克对利克莱德的信任赢得了胜利。“我认为，花 25,000 美元购买一台用途不明的机器是值得的，”贝拉内克说。他为利克购买的计算机是 LGP-30，由皇家打字机公司的子公司 Royal-McBee 于 1958 年制造。它采用鼓式存储器，即使以当时的标准来看，速度也很慢。然而，利克还是立即开始摆弄它，用它进行冗长的统计计算和心理声学实验。

None of the company’s three principals knew much about computers. Beranek knew that Lick, by contrast, was almost evangelistic in his belief that computers would change not only the way people thought about problems but the way problems were solved. Beranek’s faith in Licklider won the day. “I decided it was worth the risk to spend $25,000 on an unknown machine for an unknown purpose,” Beranek said. The computer he purchased for Lick was an LGP-30, manufactured in 1958 by Royal-McBee, a subsidiary of the Royal Typewriter Company. It had a drum memory and was slow even by the standards of its day. Yet Lick went straight to work tinkering with it, using it for lengthy statistical calculations and psychoacoustics experiments.

计算机到达后不久，肯·奥尔森 (Ken Olsen) 就顺道参观了 Royal-McBee 机器，并向 BBN 介绍了他正在新公司 Digital Equipment 制造的计算机。奥尔森想借给贝拉尼克一台机器的原型机，他称之为 PDP-1，以便 BBN 工程师可以看看。贝拉尼克同意了。但这台计算机长 4 英尺，宽 8 英尺，BBN 的门口很少，没法挤进去。所以它被放在了大厅里。大约一个月后，每个人都玩了一会儿，BBN 把它送回给奥尔森，并附上微调建议。当 PDP-1 以略低于 15 万美元的价格上市时，BBN 买下了第一台。

Not long after the computer arrived, Ken Olsen stopped by to see the Royal-McBee machine and to tell BBN about the computer he was building at his new company, Digital Equipment. Olsen wanted to lend Beranek a prototype of the machine, which he called the PDP-1, so BBN engineers could take a look at it. Beranek agreed. But the computer measured four feet by eight feet, and there were few doorways at BBN through which to squeeze it. So it was set up in the lobby. A month or so later, after everyone had a chance to play with it, BBN sent it back to Olsen with recommendations for fine-tuning. When the PDP-1 went on the market for slightly less than $150,000, BBN bought the first one.

PDP-1 的存在以及利克莱德用它所做的工作吸引了许多顶尖的计算机科学家来到 BBN。该公司还以招聘麻省理工学院辍学生的招聘理念而闻名。他们的想法是，如果他们能进入麻省理工学院，他们就是聪明人，如果他们辍学，你可以以更低的价格找到他们。贝拉尼克给了利克很大的自由，让他雇佣任何他喜欢的人，利克莱德也这样做了，偶尔会忘记告诉贝拉尼克。“有一天，我在大楼里闲逛，想看看计算机那边发生了什么，我看到两个奇怪的家伙坐在那里的一个大房间里，”贝拉尼克说。（利克很乐意穿着西装去野餐，但他雇佣的人显然不那么正式。）贝拉尼克不知道这两个人是谁。“我走到第一个人面前，问他，‘你是谁？’然后他说，‘你是谁？’”原来，这两个年轻人是利克莱德在麻省理工学院的朋友——马文·明斯基和约翰·麦卡锡，两人都是新兴人工智能领域最杰出的人物。

The presence of the PDP-1 and the work Licklider was doing with it attracted a number of leading computer scientists to BBN. The firm had also become well known as a place whose hiring philosophy was to recruit MIT dropouts. The idea was that if they could get into MIT they were smart, and if they dropped out, you could get them cheaper. Beranek gave Lick a great deal of freedom to hire whomever he pleased, and Licklider did just that, occasionally forgetting to tell Beranek. “I was wandering around the building one day to see what was going on in the computer side, and I saw two strange guys sitting in one of the large rooms there,” Beranek said. (Lick would have been happy to wear a suit to a picnic, but his hirees were decidedly less formal.) Beranek had no idea who the two men were. “I walked up to the first fellow and said, ‘Who are you?’ and he said, ‘Who are you?’” The two young men, it turned out, were friends of Licklider’s from MIT— Marvin Minsky and John McCarthy, two of the most prominent figures in the emerging field of artificial intelligence.

PDP-1 的计算能力大致相当于今天的袖珍型记事本，但内存略小。BBN 的员工让这台计算机日夜不停地进行交互式编程。他们甚至围绕它构建了一个分时系统，将屏幕划分为四个同时使用的用户。分时演示大获成功，BBN 决定在波士顿地区开展分时服务，在全市范围内放置终端。然而，通用电气很快也做出了类似的努力，并迅速抢走了 BBN 的大部分分时业务。

The PDP-1 had computing power roughly equivalent to today’s pocket organizers and a little less memory. People at BBN kept the computer going day and night doing interactive programming. They even built a time-sharing system around it, dividing the screen for four simultaneous users. The time-sharing demonstration was a success, and BBN decided to start a time-sharing service in the Boston area by placing terminals throughout the city. Soon, however, General Electric mounted a similar effort and quickly stole the bulk of BBN’s time-sharing business.

计算机的出现激发了公司的变革。每个人都开始思考可以用计算机做些什么。BBN 的一位科学家乔丹·巴鲁克 (Jordan Baruch) 认为医院可以使用计算机来保存更准确的患者信息，因此他着手将麻省总医院的记录处理计算机化。利克和其他人开始探索计算机可以改变图书馆的方式。但 20 世纪 60 年代初期的计算机仍然功能不足，无法做很多事情。

The presence of an accessible computer inspired a change in the company. Everyone began thinking up things that could be done with it. One BBN scientist, Jordan Baruch, decided hospitals could use computers to keep more accurate information on patients, so he set out to computerize the record handling at Massachusetts General Hospital. Lick and others began exploring ways in which computers could transform libraries. But computers in the early 1960s were still too underpowered to do much.

此时，BBN 已开始认真关注计算机技术。BBN 浓厚的学术氛围为这家咨询公司赢得了剑桥“第三所大学”的美誉。“我的政策是，我们雇用的每个人都必须比之前的人更优秀，”贝拉内克说。除了麻省理工学院和哈佛大学，BBN 成为波士顿地区最具吸引力的工作场所之一。有些人甚至认为它比大学更好，因为没有教学义务，也不用担心获得终身教职。这是一个稀有的环境——研究业务的干邑白兰地。

By this time, BBN had begun to concentrate seriously on computer technology. The richly academic atmosphere at BBN earned the consulting firm a reputation as “the third university” in Cambridge. “I had the policy that every person we hired had to be better than the previous people,” said Beranek. Next to MIT and Harvard, BBN became one of the most attractive places to work in the Boston area. Some people even considered it better than the universities because there was no teaching obligation and no worry over earning tenure. It was a rarefied environment—the cognac of the research business.

20 世纪 60 年代初，该公司的建筑声学部门经历了一场危机，当时 Beranek 受聘为纽约林肯中心的新爱乐音乐厅（后来更名为 Avery Fisher 音乐厅）进行声学设计。Beranek 和首席建筑师都因忽视音乐厅设计中某些重要的声学原则而受到批评。经过多次尝试进行细微调整后，情况显然已经无可救药。必须用蛮力解决这个问题：拆除墙壁和阳台，连同天花板——总共一万吨建筑材料——并运往垃圾场。在一位新顾问的监督下，修复工作耗时数年，耗资数百万美元。在对这些问题的详尽报道中，《纽约时报》将注意力集中在 Leo Beranek 身上。

The firm’s architectural-acoustics division went through a crisis in the early 1960s, when Beranek was hired to design the acoustics for the new Philharmonic Hall (later renamed Avery Fisher Hall) at New York’s Lincoln Center. Both Beranek and the chief architect were criticized for overlooking certain acoustical principles important in designing concert halls. After many attempts at minor adjustment, it became clear that the situation was hopeless. The problem had to be solved by brute force: The walls and balconies were torn out, along with the ceiling—ten thousand tons of building material in all—and carted to dumps. The repair took several years and millions of dollars to carry out, under the supervision of a new consultant. In its exhaustive coverage of the problems, theNewYork Timesfocused its attention on Leo Beranek.

如果 BBN 当时没有涉足计算机研究，林肯中心的失败可能意味着它的终结。然而，到了 20 世纪 60 年代中期，该公司的办公室已经扩大到一排低矮、相当不起眼的建筑，大部分是旧仓库，位于剑桥西部边缘 Fresh Pond 附近一条安静的小街上。这些办公室的建筑风格随意统一，最好被描述为廉价的现代主义——没有色彩的蒙德里安风格。这些是简约、朴素的箱形建筑，其平屋顶、少数窗户和薄墙散发出简洁和经济的设计。在 BBN 购买并改造成办公室、商店和实验室之前，其中四座建筑曾用于其他用途，主要是作为仓库空间。2 号楼由博尔特亲自设计，具有几个不寻常的特点：它的地基“漂浮”在剑桥的泥浆中，有效地将整个结构与外部振动隔离开来；它是为 BBN 雇佣的那种人设计的——学者——博尔特希望他们的办公室里摆满书籍。因此，他设计的新建筑能够承受不同寻常的重量。BBN 的所有建筑之间都有走廊和封闭的人行天桥，因此冬天人们可以沿着蜿蜒的小路穿过整排建筑，而不必外出。有一段时间，BBN 依靠从相邻洗衣房借来的蒸汽来为部分房间供暖。

If BBN hadn’t already diversified into computer research, the Lincoln Center debacle could have spelled its end. By the mid-1960s, however, the company’s offices had expanded into a row of low, fairly nondescript buildings, mostly old warehouses that stood along a quiet side street near Fresh Pond on Cambridge’s western edge. The offices had a casual architectural uniformity best described as low-rent modernism—Mondrian without the colors. These were stripped-down, spare, boxlike buildings whose flat roofs, few windows, and thin walls exuded simplicity and economy in design. Four of the buildings had been built for other purposes, mainly as warehouse space, before BBN bought and converted them into offices, shops, and laboratories. Building Number 2 was designed by Bolt himself and had a couple of unusual features: Its foundation “floated” in the Cambridge mud, effectively isolating the entire structure from external vibrations; and it was designed for the kind of people BBN was hiring—academicians—whom Bolt expected to fill their offices with books. Therefore he designed the new building to withstand an unusual amount of weight. There were corridors and enclosed footbridges between all of the BBN buildings, making it possible to follow a kind of meandering path through the complete row without going outside during the winter. For a while, BBN depended on borrowed steam piped in from an adjacent laundry to heat some of the quarters.

计算机研究人员中有 Wally Feurzeig 和 Seymour Papert，他们当时正在研究教育应用。Papert 在 20 世纪 60 年代末担任 BBN 顾问约四年。在此期间，他构思并设计了一种可供学龄儿童使用的编程语言。这个想法被 Feurzeig 领导的 BBN 教育小组采纳为研究主题，该语言后来被称为 LOGO。

Among the computer researchers were Wally Feurzeig and Seymour Papert, who were working on educational applications. Papert was a consultant to BBN for about four years in the late 1960s. While there, he conceived of and made the first rough design of a programming language that would be accessible to school-age children. The idea was adopted as a research theme by BBN’s education group, which Feurzeig ran, and the language came to be called LOGO.

虽然声学专家通常穿着夹克和领带上班，但计算机方面的氛围明显更加轻松。“当我们进入计算机行业时，我们雇佣了最奇怪的人，”贝拉内克说。他欣赏利克雇佣的人的才华，但与他们相处时很少感到自在。他回忆起 1965 年左右被邀请参加一位计算机工程师家举办的除夕晚会。“这就像去亚当斯一家的房子，”贝拉内克说。“他们都光着脚。女人们穿着紧身衣。我戴着领带出现，不得不把它脱掉。”

While the acousticians usually came to work in jackets and ties, the atmosphere on the computer side was decidedly more relaxed. “When we got into the computer business we had the strangest people working for us,” said Beranek. He appreciated the brilliance of the people Lick hired but seldom felt comfortable around them. He recalled being invited to a New Year’s Eve party at the home of a computer engineer around 1965. “It was like going to the Addams Family house,” Beranek said. “They were all in bare feet. The women were wearing tight-fitting clothing. I showed up with a tie on and had to take it off.”

弗兰克·哈特是个例外。哈特当时是麻省理工学院林肯实验室的计算机系统工程师，衣着保守，行事谨慎。1966 年，BBN 开始招募他参与医院计算机项目。哈特是一位以能干出成绩而闻名的工程师。告诉他你想要建造某样东西，上帝保佑，你就能得到它。但哈特也很固执，很难从林肯那里得到好处。

Frank Heart was a notable exception. Conservative in his attire and prone to caution in general, Heart was at that time a computer systems engineer at MIT’s Lincoln Lab. In 1966 BBN embarked on a campaign to hire him for its hospital computer project. Heart was an engineer with a reputation for making things happen. Tell him you wanted something built and, by god, you would have it. But Heart was also hardheaded and not easy to pry away from Lincoln.

哈特自称是“来自扬克斯的受到过度保护的犹太孩子”，他喜欢读书，高中时有点书呆子气。弗兰克非常想上麻省理工学院，但这对他家境贫寒的父母来说是个难题。（在大萧条时期，哈特的父亲设法保住了奥的斯电梯工程师的工作。）对于弗兰克的母亲来说，把自己唯一的儿子送到这么远的学校尤其困难，因为她对弗兰克过度保护。麻省理工学院于 1947 年录取了他，但奖学金很少，这让他的父母不得不继续陷入经济困境。

A self-described “overprotected Jewish kid from Yonkers,” Heart was bookish and, in high school, a bit of a nerd. Frank wanted desperately to attend MIT, which posed a problem for his parents, who were of modest means. (Through the Depression, Heart’s father managed to keep his job as an engineer for Otis Elevator.) The thought of sending her only son to a school so far away was particularly difficult for Frank’s mother, who did most of the overprotecting. MIT admitted him in 1947, but with a scholarship so small as to guarantee continued financial struggles for his parents.

弗兰克的父亲是电梯控制系统的制造者，弗兰克在进入麻省理工学院之前就决定成为一名电气工程师。为了减轻家庭的经济压力，他报读了五年制硕士学位课程，工作和学习交替进行。他在通用电气工厂工作了一个夏天，测试大型电力变压器。“那是你只想做一次的事情，”哈特回忆道。第二年，他选择专攻电力工程——大型电力系统的设计，如发电厂、建筑变压器、发电机和电动机。

Following the example set by his father, who built elevator control systems, Frank had decided to become an electrical engineer before entering MIT. To ease the financial strain on his family, he enrolled in a five-year master’s degree program, in which work and school were combined in alternate semesters. He worked one summer at a General Electric factory testing large power transformers. “That was something you want to do just once,” Heart recalled. In his second year, he chose to specialize in power engineering—the design of large-scale electrical systems, such as power plants, building transformers, generators, and motors.

后来，他发现了计算机。1951 年，也就是哈特读大四那年，麻省理工学院开设了第一门计算机编程课程，由客座教授戈登·韦尔奇曼 (Gordon Welchman) 讲授。哈特报名了。“对我来说，计算机这种东西竟然存在，真是难以置信，”哈特说。他退出了勤工俭学计划，这个决定让很多人感到震惊，因为这个计划很难进入。“我收到了麻省理工学院和通用电气公司的各种恶意信件。”但他迷上了计算机，从此再也没有回头。

Then he discovered computers. In 1951, Heart’s senior year, MIT offered its first course ever in computer programming, taught by a visiting professor named Gordon Welchman. Heart signed up. “It was an unbelievable revelation to me that a thing like a computer could exist,” Heart said. He dropped out of the work-study program, a decision that shocked many people because it was such a difficult program to get into. “I got all sorts of nasty letters from MIT and G.E.” But he had caught the computer bug and never looked back.

在韦尔奇曼的介绍下，哈特对计算机产生了浓厚的兴趣，提前一个学期获得了学士学位，并在担任旋风项目研究助理的同时完成了硕士学位。旋风项目负责控制一个用于跟踪飞机的雷达防御系统。雷达（雷达探测和测距）系统测量从物体反射的电磁脉冲，以提供有关其方向和距离的信息。干扰设备可以破坏单个雷达的数据，但如果雷达阵列与计算机协同工作，则可以弥补这一缺陷。旋风项目让哈特首次体验了实时环境中的编程。当旋风项目调到林肯实验室时，哈特也随之调动。“这是能想象到的最轻松的工作变动，”哈特说。

Thanks to Welchman’s introduction, Heart became so interested in computers that he earned his bachelor’s degree one term early and finished his master’s degree while working as a research assistant on the Whirlwind Project. Whirlwind controlled a radar defense system for tracking aircraft. A radar (RAdioD etectionA ndR anging) system measures electromagnetic pulses reflected from an object to provide information concerning its direction and distance. Jamming devices can destroy data from a single radar, but an array of radars can compensate if they are working in concert with a computer. Whirlwind gave Heart his first taste of programming in a real-time environment. When Whirlwind was transferred to Lincoln Lab, Heart was transferred with it. “It was the most painless kind of job change one could imagine,” Heart said.

20 世纪 50 年代的许多程序都是用“机器语言”编写的，即计算机的“自然语言”中的实际指令。命令必须详尽无遗地指定；程序的每一行与机器的每条指令之间都有一一对应关系。使用机器语言工作可能很乏味，错误很难发现和纠正。但它让程序员对机器产生了强烈的认同感。计算机编程当时还很新，很少有人理解它的复杂性。许多从事更传统科学的人忽视（或拒绝）那些将计算机作为一门科学进行探索的人。

Many programs in the 1950s were written in “machine language,” the actual instructions in the “natural language” of the computer. Commands had to be specified in exhaustive detail; there was a one-to-one correspondence between each line of the program and each instruction to the machine. Working in machine language could be tedious, and mistakes were difficult to find and correct. But it gave programmers a strong sense of identification with the machine. Computer programming was still so new that few people understood its intricacies. Many who worked in the more traditional sciences ignored (or dismissed) those who were exploring computers as a science.

事实证明，林肯实验室是 ARPA 推动计算进入互动和互联时代所需的天才的完美孵化器。它已经成为一些最重要的早期计算和网络工作的温床。它的许多校友（其中包括利克莱德、罗伯茨、哈特和其他即将加入的人）将在 ARPA 网络的设计和开发中发挥关键作用。在早期，林肯的计算机程序员并不被看好。只有成熟的物理学家和数学家才被允许加入研究人员队伍，因此许多程序员离开了林肯。但哈特打破了偏见。他从一名研究生程序员做起，成为一名工作人员，不久之后就管理着一个团队。

Lincoln Laboratory was proving to be a perfect incubator for the kind of genius that ARPA would need to push computing into the interactive, and interconnected, age. It had already turned into a breeding ground for some of the most important early work in computing and networking. Many of its alumni—among them, Licklider, Roberts, Heart, and others still to come—would play crucial roles in the design and development of the ARPA network. In the early days, computer programmers at Lincoln were poorly regarded. Only full-fledged physicists and mathematicians were allowed on the research staff, and many programmers left Lincoln as a result. But Heart broke through the prejudice. He started out as a graduate student programmer, became a staff member, and before long he was running a group.

哈特也无视这些规定。他无法容忍职业划分，也不太在意头衔。当一位名叫戴夫·沃尔登的年轻程序员来到林肯公司工作时，他被聘为技术助理。他的安全徽章上清楚地表明，这不是一个员工级别的职位。头衔在林肯公司很重要，除其他外，徽章还让他无法参加员工研讨会。哈特无视这一切，藐视将非员工分配到最不理想的工作空间的协议，将沃尔登安排在一间办公室，与沃尔登的一位导师、麻省理工学院的年轻毕业生威尔·克劳瑟共事。克劳瑟是一位物理学家，后来成为计算机科学家。

Heart also disregarded the rules. He had little tolerance for professional delineations and didn’t take titles too seriously. When a young programmer named Dave Walden came to work at Lincoln, he was hired on with the title of technical assistant. The fact that this was not a staff-level post was clearly indicated on his security badge. Titles were important at Lincoln, and among other things, the badge kept him out of staff-member seminars. Ignoring all that, and flouting the protocol that assigned nonstaff to the leastdesirable work space, Heart set Walden up in an office with one of Walden’s mentors, a young MIT graduate named Will Crowther. Crowther was a physicist turned computer scientist.

20 世纪 50 年代末到 60 年代初，哈特、克劳瑟和他们身边的人接连开展了一个又一个开创性的项目。随着时间的推移，哈特和他在林肯大学的团队成为了通过电话线将各种测量设备连接到计算机以收集信息的专家。这反过来又使他们成为构建实时计算系统的专家。

In the late 1950s and early 1960s, Heart, Crowther, and others close to them worked on one groundbreaking project after another. In time, Heart and his team at Lincoln became experts at connecting a variety of measuring devices to computers via phone lines for information gathering. This in turn made them experts in building real-time computing systems.

1958 年，哈特的一群同事离开公司，创办了 MITRE 公司，但哈特依然坚定地留在了林肯，部分原因是他一直不喜欢改变，部分原因是他热爱自己所做的事情。他无法想象自己还能找到比这更有趣的工作或与比这更才华横溢的团队共事。

When a group of Heart’s colleagues left to start MITRE Corporation in 1958, Heart remained firmly moored to Lincoln, partly because he had always disliked change and partly because he loved what he was doing. He couldn’t imagine ever having a more interesting job or a more talented group with which to work.

1965 年夏天，哈特遇到了丹尼·鲍勃罗，后者当时在 BBN 从事人工智能研究。鲍勃罗建议哈特离开林肯医院，到 BBN 工作，负责一个将计算机技术引入医院的项目。当哈特拒绝时，迪克·博尔特介入了。

In the summer of 1965, Heart met Danny Bobrow, who had been working on artificial intelligence at BBN. Bobrow suggested to Heart that he leave Lincoln for a job at BBN, overseeing a project to introduce computer technology into hospitals. When Heart declined, Dick Bolt stepped in.

BBN 的负责人急于争取 Heart 的其中一个原因是，Heart 在组建高效现场系统方面拥有丰富的经验。公司需要这样的人才。尽管 BBN 进行了诸多创新，但未能成功将其创意转化为功能齐全、可用的系统。“当时 BBN 的文化是先做有趣的事情，然后再做下一件有趣的事情，”一位前员工说。他们更愿意提出有趣的想法并加以探索，而不是在开发完成后试图利用它们。

One of the reasons the principals at BBN were anxious to woo Heart was that he had fruitful experience in putting together systems that worked efficiently in the field. The company needed someone like that. For all its innovation, BBN hadn’t been very successful at turning its ideas into functioning, usable systems. “The culture at BBN at the time was to do interesting things and move on to the next interesting thing,” said one former employee. There was more incentive to come up with interesting ideas and explore them than to try to capitalize on them once they had been developed.

博尔特邀请哈特到他家做客。他们在 BBN 举行了更多会议。他们在当地的霍华德约翰逊酒店见面。哈特仍然不情愿，但 BBN 的工作有些方面吸引着他。和利克莱德一样，哈特一直持有他所描述的“行善者”的观点：哈特相信计算机和技术可以帮助社会。林肯实验室与军队紧密相连，从未远离空军的需求。事实上，实验室的狭隘重点促使肯·奥尔森和韦斯·克拉克等人离开，他们离开去制造计算机。哈特也对计算机在生命科学中的应用感兴趣，博尔特让他知道，他将有机会在 BBN 追求这一兴趣。此外，哈特在扬克斯的朋友杰里·埃尔金德也在 BBN，哈特非常尊重埃尔金德。“我还想到，”哈特承认，“我有机会在一家私营公司赚点钱。”

Bolt invited Heart to his house. They had more meetings at BBN. They met at the local Howard Johnson’s. Heart remained reluctant, but there were aspects of the BBN job that appealed to him. Like Licklider, Heart had always held what he described as a “dogooder’s” view: Heart believed computers and technology could help society. Wedded as it was to the military, Lincoln Lab had never gone very far afield of the Air Force’s needs. In fact, the lab’s narrow focus had precipitated the departure of people like Ken Olsen and Wes Clark, who left to build computers. Heart was also interested in the application of computers to the life sciences, and Bolt let him know he would have the opportunity to pursue that interest at BBN. Moreover, a friend of Heart’s from Yonkers, Jerry Elkind, was at BBN, and Heart respected Elkind quite a bit. “It also occurred to me,” Heart admitted, “that there was a chance I could make some money at a private corporation.”

最后，博尔特说服他接受了这份工作，但当哈特来到 BBN 时，公司的计算机研究已由两个独立的部门进行：信息科学和计算机系统。一般来说，拥有博士学位的人在信息科学或研究部门工作，而没有博士学位的人则在计算机系统部门工作。信息科学部门的一名成员将计算机系统部门描述为一群拿着烙铁的人。换句话说，他们只是把东西建起来，而研究部门的人则认为自己更关心发明未来。这两个群体之间没有太多的交叉影响。他们在不同的建筑物里工作，被一条狭窄的玻璃封闭人行天桥隔开。确切地说，他们之间的分歧不是敌意，也不是竞争。每个人都知道对方的局限性，因此对对方阵营发生的事情明显缺乏兴趣。弗兰克·哈特是一个彻头彻尾的系统专家。

In the end, Bolt convinced him to take the job, but by the time Heart got to BBN, the company’s computer research was being carried out by two separate divisions: information sciences and computer systems. As a general rule, those with Ph.D.’s worked in the information sciences, or research, division, while those without Ph.D.’s worked in the computer systems division. One member of the information sciences division described the computer systems division as consisting of a bunch of guys with soldering irons. In other words, they just got things built, while those in the research division considered themselves more concerned with inventing the future. There was not much cross-pollination between the two groups. They worked in separate buildings, divided by a narrow, glass-enclosed footbridge. It wasn’t animosity, exactly, that separated them, nor was it rivalry. Each was aware of the other’s limitations, resulting in a conspicuous lack of interest in what happened in the other camp. Frank Heart was a systems guy through and through.

投标

Bidding

1968 年 8 月，当 ARPA 向 BBN 发出 IMP 建造提案请求时，该公司有 30 天的时间做出回应。杰瑞·艾尔金德 (Jerry Elkind) 现在是哈特的老板，负责两个计算机部门。他认为 BBN 应该投标，他认为哈特是公司最适合管理该项目的人。自从他上任后不久医院计算机项目就夭折以来，哈特一直在寻找一个可以全身心投入的长期项目。此外，哈特可能在构建 ARPA 寻求的那种计算机系统方面拥有最丰富的经验。尽管如此，当艾尔金德建议他接受这个任务时，哈特还是像往常一样谨慎行事。

When ARPA’s request for proposals to build the IMP arrived at BBN in August 1968, the company had thirty days to respond. Jerry Elkind, who now was Heart’s boss, was in charge of both computer divisions. He thought BBN should bid, and he thought Heart was the best person at the company to manage it. Since the demise of the hospital computer project shortly after he had arrived, Heart had been searching for a long-term project in which to immerse himself. Moreover, Heart probably had the most experience in building the kind of computer system that ARPA was seeking. Nonetheless, when Elkind suggested he take it on, Heart was typically cautious.

一开始，哈特的言行举止可能很难理解。亚历克斯·麦肯齐断断续续为哈特工作了 27 年，他回忆起第一次遇到新老板时的情景——当时哈特在走廊的另一端，用高亢的声音大声和别人说话，似乎有些焦躁不安。“他真的在大喊大叫，我以为他一定有什么麻烦，”麦肯齐回忆道。“后来我发现他只是热情而已。”几年后，麦肯齐和哈特一起坐飞机时，终于告诉了他他对哈特的第一印象。哈特扬起了眉毛。“大喊大叫？！”哈特喊道，他的声音达到了标志性的假声，大到足以引起周围所有人的注意。“我不大喊大叫！”也就是说，生气的时候不会大喊大叫。“他生气的时候会变得非常安静，”麦肯齐说。

Heart could be difficult to interpret at first. Alex McKenzie, who worked for Heart on and off for twenty-seven years, recalled the first time he encountered his new boss—from the other end of a hallway. Heart was speaking in a loud, high-pitched voice to someone else and seemed agitated. “He was really yelling, and I thought it must be trouble,” McKenzie recalled. “Then later I found out it was simply enthusiasm.” A few years later, while on an airplane with Heart, McKenzie finally told him about his initial impression. Heart raised his eyebrows. “YELLING?!” Heart yelled, his voice reaching for its trademark falsetto, loud enough to attract the attention of everyone around them. “I don’t yell!” Not, that is, when angry. “When he’s angry he gets very quiet,” McKenzie said.

和 Heart 开会时，偶尔会有很多喊叫声。“但第二天，你会发现，他听到了你喊叫的声音，”另一位长期员工回忆道。“如果你愿意忍受他的喊叫声，他就能把事情说清楚，不像大多数喜欢喊叫的人。”Heart 精力充沛，很难一次静坐几分钟。他在家里最放松的时候，在地下室的木工店工作，在那里，他可以完美地吹奏长而复杂的乐曲，却很少意识到自己在这样做。当事情紧张或不确定时，他会咬指甲或用手指敲击桌面。

Meetings with Heart occasionally involved a lot of shouting. “And then the next day it turns out he’s heard what you said through all the yelling and shouting,” recalled another longtime employee. “If you were willing to put up with the yelling and shouting, he made things come out right, unlike most people who yell and shout.” Heart had prodigious energy, which made it difficult for him to sit still for more than a few minutes at a time. He was most relaxed when he was at home, working in his basement woodworking shop, where he whistled long complex pieces of music flawlessly, seldom aware that he was doing so. When things were tense or uncertain, he bit his fingernails or drummed his fingers on tabletops.

Heart 对为他工作的人非常忠诚，而他们也对他非常忠诚。他不仅对自己的三个孩子非常关爱（他很乐意承担许多照顾孩子的琐事，而这些在当时丈夫是不需要承担的），而且对他的员工也很关爱。与此同时，他对很多事情都很在意，尤其是当有人离开他的团队去其他地方工作时，即使只是去另一个部门。Heart

最大的优势之一是确保他所签约的工作真正完成，而在接受 ARPA 的工作时，他担心公司可能会承担一些可能无法完成的任务。该项目充满了不确定性和未开发的技术。Heart 发现很难准确评估涉及的内容。他没有时间做他想在系统软件项目上做的那种详细规划，例如估计需要的代码行数。

Heart was intensely loyal to the people who worked for him and they in turn were loyal to him. He was also nurturing, not just toward his three children (he happily took on many child-care chores not expected of husbands in those days) but also toward his employees. At the same time, he took a lot of things personally, particularly when people left his group to go work somewhere else, even if it was only across the hall to another division.

One of Heart’s greatest strengths was making certain that jobs he signed up for really got done, and in taking on the ARPA job he was concerned about the risk of committing the company to something it might not be able to accomplish. The project was packed with uncertainties and unexplored technology. Heart found it difficult to gauge exactly what was involved. There wasn’t time to do the kind of detailed planning he’d like to do on a systems software project, such as estimating the number of lines of code that would be needed.

风险评估对任何工程企业来说都是必不可少的。因为没有一个重大的技术项目是完全没有风险的，所以特定设计的成功和失败的概率是需要考虑和权衡的。潜在的麻烦分为三类：可预见的、不可预见但可预见的以及不可预见的。在最后一种情况下，工程师们不得不双手合十地做出决定。Heart 面临的情况在很大程度上属于最后一种情况，因为该系统的大部分都没有先例可以作为风险评估的依据。

Risk assessment is essential in any engineering enterprise. Because no significant technological project can be entirely risk-free, the probabilities for success and failure of particular designs are factored and weighed. The potential for trouble falls into three categories: the foreseen, the unforeseen but foreseeable, and the unforeseeable. In the last case engineers are forced to make decisions with their fingers crossed. The situation facing Heart fell largely into this last category, since so much of the system had no precedent on which to base risk estimates.

软件的不确定性已经够严重了，但还有许多其他未知因素。例如，这样的网络在不出现拥堵的情况下能够处理多少流量？一个节点的故障传播到整个网络的可能性有多大？例如，1965 年 11 月，一个过载的中继器引发了连锁反应，导致整个美国东北部的电网瘫痪。最重要的是，网络能够正常工作的可能性有多大？签署 ARPA 网络这样的项目需要一定程度的坚定信心，这让 Heart 感到不安。

The software uncertainties were serious enough, but a plethora of other unknowns existed. For example, how much traffic could such a network handle without encountering logjams? What was the chance that the failure of one node would propagate through the network? In November 1965, for example, one overloaded relay caused a ripple effect that brought down the electric power grid serving the entire northeastern United States. Above all, what was the probability that the network would even work? Signing on for a project like the ARPA network required a certain amount of sheer faith, and that disturbed Heart.

埃尔金德的动机是，他认为 ARPA 正在推动计算技术进入一个新时代，从商业角度来看，向这个未来推出 BBN 非常有意义。埃尔金德承认 Heart 的担忧是合理的。“但我觉得这是一份我们必须完成的合同，而且我们可以做得和任何人一样好，”埃尔金德说。“我们知道如何与 ARPA 合作，我们的计算机技能和周围的人一样好。”

Elkind was motivated by his sense that ARPA was pushing the state of the art of computing into a new era, and from a business point of view, it made a lot of sense to launch BBN toward that future. Elkind recognized that Heart’s concerns were rational. “But it struck me that this was a contract we had to do and could do as well as anybody,” Elkind said. “We knew how to work with ARPA and had computer skills as good as anyone around.”

艾尔金德向哈特建议，让 BBN 的一小群人聚在一起，决定如何处理 ARPA 的提案请求。他们同意举行非正式会议，并选择丹尼·鲍勃罗在贝尔蒙特的房子作为地点。第一次会议一直开到深夜。会议结束时，哈特已经转变了态度，BBN 的参与几乎得到了保证。

Elkind suggested to Heart that a small group from BBN get together to decide what to do with ARPA’s request for proposals. They agreed to meet informally and chose Danny Bobrow’s house in Belmont as the location. The first meeting went well into the night. By the time it was over, Heart was converted and BBN’s participation had been as much as guaranteed.

这还不算什么。接下来，他们只有一个月的时间来撰写详细的提案。参与该提案的首批人员之一是鲍勃·卡恩 (Bob Kahn)，他是麻省理工学院休假的电气工程教授，在 BBN 的信息科学部工作。在麻省理工学院，卡恩曾是一名应用数学家，研究通信和信息理论。他的大多数同事都具备理论和应用工程技能的结合。有一天，卡恩和麻省理工学院的一位资深同事谈论他感兴趣的不同技术问题，他问道：“你怎么知道一个问题比另一个问题更有趣？”“这只是经验问题，”卡恩的同事回答道。“如何获得经验？”卡恩问道。“找一个经验丰富的人，然后和他一起工作。”卡恩获得经验的一个明显地方就是 BBN。于是他就去了。

That was the easy part. They then had just one month to write a detailed proposal. One of the first people to get involved with the proposal was Bob Kahn, a professor of electrical engineering on leave from MIT and working in BBN’s information sciences division. At MIT, Kahn had been an applied mathematician working on communications and information theory. Most of his colleagues possessed a combination of theoretical and applied engineering skills. One day Kahn had been talking with a senior colleague at MIT about the different technical problems in which he was interested, and he asked, “How can you tell when one problem is more interesting than another?” “It’s just experience,” Kahn’s colleague responded. “How does one get that?” Kahn inquired. “Find someone who has a lot of experience and go work with him.” One obvious place for Kahn to acquire that experience was BBN. So he went.

巧合的是，1967 年，当拉里·罗伯茨 (Larry Roberts) 在华盛顿制定网络项目及其要求时，卡恩在 BBN 有自己关于网络的想法。更巧合的是，在杰里·埃尔金德 (Jerry Elkind) 的敦促下，他一直在向鲍勃·泰勒 (Bob Taylor) 和罗伯茨发送未经请求的技术备忘录。当罗伯茨告诉卡恩 ARPA 计划资助一个全国性的网络时，这对卡恩来说是一个令人愉快的启示。然后埃尔金德告诉他，BBN 计算机系统部门的一个小组有兴趣为 ARPA 网络制定一份提案，并建议卡恩参与这个过程。

By coincidence, in 1967, at the time that Larry Roberts was in Washington formulating the network project and its requirements, Kahn was at BBN having his own thoughts about networking. Still more coincidentally, at Jerry Elkind’s urging he had been sending unsolicited technical memos to Bob Taylor and Roberts. When Roberts told Kahn that ARPA was planning to fund a nationwide network, it was a pleasant revelation to Kahn. Then Elkind told him that a group in the BBN computer systems division was interested in putting together a proposal for the ARPA network and suggested that Kahn get involved in the process.

不久之后，弗兰克·哈特 (Frank Heart) 来到卡恩的办公室。“我从杰里那里得知，你一直在考虑网络领域。我们可以聊聊吗？”“好的，当然可以，”卡恩回答道。“你是谁？”

1968 年，BBN 拥有 600 多名员工。弗兰克·哈特的团队占据了 3 号楼内铺有油毡的走廊沿线的一排办公室。走廊一端是一间会议室，里面有很多黑板和座位，可供大型聚会使用。办公室本身很小，很朴素，办公桌由 BBN 的建筑车间安装的门腿改造而成。硬背木椅和帆布靠背导演椅是首选款式。荧光灯、一些个人物品、许多架子，除此之外，几乎没有其他东西。

In 1968 BBN had more than six hundred employees. Frank Heart’s group occupied a row of offices along a stretch of linoleum tiled corridor in Building Number 3. At one end of the hall was a conference room with plenty of chalkboards and seating for large gatherings. The offices themselves were small and unassuming, with desks fashioned from doors to which legs had been attached by BBN’s construction shop. Stiff-backed wooden chairs and canvas-backed director’s chairs were the preferred styles. Fluorescent lighting, a few personal effects, lots of shelves and little else completed the picture.

哈特喜欢与由非常聪明的人组成的小团队一起工作。他认为，个人的生产力和才能不是相差两三倍，而是相差十倍甚至一百倍。哈特擅长发现能够实现目标的工程师，因此他在林肯管理的团队往往异常高效。

Heart liked working with small, tightly knit groups composed of very bright people. He believed that individual productivity and talent varied not by factors of two or three, but by factors of ten or a hundred. Because Heart had a knack for spotting engineers who could make things happen, the groups he had supervised at Lincoln tended to be unusually productive.

Heart 邀请的第一批 IMP 提案的参与者之一是 Dave Walden，他跟随 Heart 从林肯来到了 BBN。Walden 虽然很年轻，只有四五年的编程经验，但他在实时系统方面拥有丰富的专业知识——非常适合 ARPA 网络工作。接下来，Heart 选择了 Bernie Cosell，一位曾在 BBN 计算机系统部门工作的年轻程序员。Cosell 是一位出色的调试者，他可以研究一个他从未见过的计算机程序，并在两天内解决数周未解决的问题。Heart 还招募了 Hawley Rising，一位说话温和的电子工程师，他是 Heart 在麻省理工学院读书时的老朋友。

One of the first people Heart called upon to help with the IMP proposal was Dave Walden, who had followed Heart from Lincoln to BBN. Though young, with only four or five years of programming experience, Walden had a highly cultivated expertise in realtime systems—ideal for the ARPA network job. Next Heart drafted Bernie Cosell, a young programmer who had been working in BBN’s computer systems division. Cosell was a debugger par excellence, someone who could go poking around in a computer program he had never seen before and in two days fix a problem that had gone unsolved for weeks. Heart also enlisted Hawley Rising, a soft-spoken electrical engineer who was an old friend from Heart’s student days at MIT.

Heart 的硬件高手是 Severo Ornstein，38 岁的林肯大学校友，多年来断断续续地为 Heart 工作。Ornstein 是一个兴趣广泛、热情洋溢的人。作为钢琴演奏家和著名作曲家的儿子，Ornstein 曾就读于哈佛大学，曾短暂地考虑过音乐专业，但被父母劝退。他最终选择了地质学。离开哈佛后，Ornstein 对计算机产生了兴趣，并进入林肯大学工作。当他的同事 Wes Clark 前往圣路易斯华盛顿大学制造自己设计的计算机时，Ornstein 也跟着去了。在圣路易斯待了三年后，Ornstein 渴望回到剑桥，于是他打电话给 Heart，Heart 为他提供了一个 BBN 的职位。

Heart’s hardware ace was Severo Ornstein, a thirty-eight-year-old Lincoln alumnus who had worked for Heart on and off for years. Ornstein was an intense man of many and diverse interests. The son of a virtuoso pianist and prominent composer, Ornstein had attended Harvard and had flirted briefly with a major in music before his parents argued him out of it. He finally settled on geology. After leaving Harvard, Ornstein had become interested in computers and had gone to work at Lincoln. When his colleague Wes Clark left for Washington University in St. Louis to build a computer of his own design, Ornstein went with him. After three years in St. Louis, Ornstein itched to return to Cambridge, so he called Heart, who offered him a position at BBN.

当 ARPA 的提案请求书寄来后，Heart 递给 Ornstein 一份副本，并说：“你为什么不把它带回家看看，看看你觉得怎么样？”第二天，Ornstein 回到 Heart 的办公室，说：“好吧，当然，我想如果你愿意的话我们可以建造它。但我不明白人们想要这样的东西有什么用。”尽管如此，Ornstein 认为 IMP 建设项目看起来很有趣，这一直是他的主要考虑因素。

When the request for proposals arrived from ARPA, Heart handed a copy to Ornstein and said, “Why don’t you take this home and have a look at it, see what you think?” Ornstein returned to Heart’s office the next day and said, “Well, sure, I suppose we could build that if you wanted to. But I can’t see what one would want such a thing for.” Nonetheless, Ornstein thought the IMP-building project looked like fun, which was always a primary consideration for him.

哈特对人的评判方式并非基于外表、举止或政治观点，而几乎完全基于他认为他们有多聪明。或者，用他喜欢的说法，基于他们大脑每立方厘米包含多少个神经元。如果他认为这个数字异常高，那么哈特很可能会容忍一个人的怪癖，而不是另一个他认为灰质密度较低的人的怪癖。在非技术性场合，哈特经常使用计算机术语。如果他们决定周日下午有空，他可能会对妻子简说：“这是无操作”。（无操作或无操作是指一行代码什么也不做。）或者，他会对他们的一个小孩说：“这是二进制的”，意思是这是一个非黑即白的情况。

Heart had a predilection for judging people not by their looks or manners or political views, but almost purely by how smart he believed them to be. Or, as he liked to put it, by how many neurons per cubic centimeter their brains contained. If he decided the number was unusually high, Heart was likely to tolerate a lot more idiosyncrasy in one than in another whose gray matter he thought was less densely packed. When talking, Heart often used computer jargon in nontechnical circumstances. “It’s a no-op,” he might say to his wife Jane if they decided to leave a Sunday afternoon free. (No-op, or no operation, refers to a line of code that accomplishes nothing.) Or he might say, “It’s binary,” to one of their small children, meaning it is a black-and-white situation.

哈特擅长组建高效的工程团队，这使他成为备受推崇和重视的项目经理。他寻找的是致力于共同使命而非个人议程的人。他喜欢保持团队规模小，这样每个人都可以随时与其他人交流。哈特选择了那种对自己所做的事情承担个人责任的人。虽然哈特容忍个人特质，但他避开以自我为中心的“精神病患者”，无论他们有多聪明。

Heart’s knack for putting together effective engineering teams had made him a highly regarded and valuable project manager. He looked for people who would be committed to a common mission rather than a personal agenda. He preferred to keep teams small so that everyone was always talking to everyone else. Heart chose the kind of people who took personal responsibility for what they did. And while Heart tolerated idiosyncrasy, he shied away from egocentric “head cases,” no matter how smart they were.

在为 ARPA 提案组建 BBN 团队时，哈特确保他招募的工程师具备完成这一雄心勃勃的任务所需的所有技能。例如，卡恩就是一位完美的理论家。他比 BBN 的任何人都更了解通过电话线发送信息所带来的问题，并且他对最佳错误控制机制有着清晰的想法。奥恩斯坦是一位完美主义者，这一点在他制造的硬件中得到了体现，而沃尔登则带来了他对实时系统的了解以及愿意长时间工作的坚定意愿。科塞尔有能力钻研复杂的软件程序，比 BBN 的任何人都能更快地发现错误。正因为如此，科塞尔是公司的一项人性化保险政策：项目将由团队进行，但每位 BBN 经理都知道，如果他的项目遇到麻烦，他可以让科塞尔接手这项工作，然后超人的事情就会迅速发生。尽管还有大量详细的设计工作要做，但团队成员都了解最重要的技术问题。

In assembling BBN’s team for the ARPA proposal, Heart made certain he pulled in engineers with all the requisite skills for such an ambitious undertaking. Kahn, for instance, was the consummate theoretician. He, more than anyone at BBN, understood the problems associated with sending information over telephone lines, and he had clear ideas about the best error-control mechanisms.
