Honeywell hadn’t attempted to develop any diagnostics to test the design; it had simply tried to produce a faithful implementation of the block diagrams that Ornstein had drawn and that BBN had included in its proposal to ARPA. The trouble was that in furnishing Honeywell with a set of fairly generic block diagrams, BBN assumed that Honeywell’s familiarity and expertise with its own machines would enable the computer manufacturer to anticipate any peculiar problems with BBN’s requested modifications to the model 516. Honeywell had its own logic modules, its own design system. But instead of working out the essential details in the blueprints, Honeywell had built BBN’s machine without verifying that the BBNdesigned interfaces, as drawn, would work with the 516 base model.

当然，无论是绘制框图的 BBN 还是实施设计的 Honeywell，实际上都没有在第一次测试中创建完美运行的原型 IMP 所需的所有工具。Barker 说，在制造新计算机时，操作假设是，你设计出你认为可以运行的东西，准备好原型，开始测试，然后逐渐修复设计错误，直到机器通过测试。如果机器立即完美运行，那将是一次工程上的侥幸。但即使是第一次测试，这台原型机的状况也是不可接受的。

Of course, neither BBN in drawing the block diagrams nor Honeywell in implementing the design actually had all of the necessary tools to create a perfectly working prototype IMP on the first pass. In building new computers, said Barker, the operative assumption is that you design something you think will work, get the prototype ready, start testing, then gradually fix the design errors until the machine passes the test. It would have been an engineering fluke if the machine ran perfectly straight away. But even as a first pass, the condition of this prototype machine was unacceptable.

如果说奥恩斯坦担心霍尼韦尔的表现，那么巴克则完全是紧张的。作为首席调试员，他负责让机器真正运转起来。他说，在 IMP 项目的这个阶段，516 上的接口“即使霍尼韦尔正确实施了它们，也几乎无法正常工作。”

If Ornstein was concerned about Honeywell’s performance, Barker was downright nervous. As the chief debugger, he was the one responsible for getting the machine to actually work. At this stage in the IMP project, the interfaces on the 516, he said, “wouldn’t have come close to working even if Honeywell had implemented them properly.”

巴克正盯着未来几周的集中工作。他感到日程安排的压力突然加大。如果 BBN 硬件团队打算在近期将修改后的霍尼韦尔 516 的工作版本交给 BBN 编程团队，以便克劳瑟、沃尔登和科塞尔有时间对他们的操作代码进行最后的调试，那么硬件专家就必须抓紧时间了。在奥恩斯坦的帮助下，巴克必须“利用霍尼韦尔制造的东西，”他说，“并弄清楚如何让它真正发挥预期的作用。”

Barker was staring at weeks of concentrated work ahead. He felt the weight of the schedule suddenly grow heavier. If the BBN hardware team intended to hand off to the BBN programming team a working version of the modified Honeywell 516 any time soon, so that Crowther, Walden, and Cosell would have time for final debugging of their operating code, then the hardware specialists would have to hustle. With Ornstein’s help, Barker would have to “take the stuff Honeywell had built,” he said, “and figure out how to make it actually do what it was intended to do.”

IMP 原型机的问世标志着一次真正的挫折；纠正路线需要时间，而很快，时间就所剩无几了。

巴克带着一台示波器、一把绕线枪和一把拆线工具，每天独自在机器上工作十六个小时。计算机的电路依赖于针脚块或绕线板，它们充当着数以百计的电线的中央连接点。有无数个 34 针的针脚块，逻辑板插在针脚块中，并载有形成正确电路的组件。在弄清楚电线应该去哪里之后，巴克必须将每根紧密缠绕的错误连接的电线从其针脚上拆下来。每个针脚块中的针脚长约一英寸，间距很近（相距 1/20 英寸），呈方阵；每个针脚块看起来就像一个微型钉床，电线像美杜莎一样从中进出。一旦确定了正确的电线应该重新连接的位置，巴克就会用绕线枪将每根电线小心地缠绕在正确的针脚上。这是一个漫长、费力且细致的过程。

Armed with an oscilloscope, a wire-wrap gun, and an unwrap tool, Barker worked alone on the machine sixteen hours a day. The circuitry of the computer relied on pin blocks, or wire-wrapped boards, that served as the central connection points to which wires, hundreds upon hundreds of wires, were routed. There were numerous blocks of thirtyfour pins into which logic boards were plugged and which carried components to form the correct circuits. After figuring out where the wires should actually go, Barker had to unwrap each tightly wound misconnected wire from its pin. The pins in each block were about an inch long, and were closely spaced (1/20th of an inch apart) in a square matrix; each block looked like a miniature bed of nails with wires streaming Medusa-like into and out of it. Once he determined where the correct wires should be reconnected, Barker used the wire-wrap gun to wrap each wire carefully on its correct pin. It was a long, laborious, and delicate process.

更复杂的是，巴克的手有些麻痹。使用绕线枪需要手稳定，注意力高度集中。针脚间距很近，绕线枪很重，枪上的喷嘴尺寸很大，需要在一小片针脚林中滑过一根针脚，所有这些都对他不利。危险在于将电线穿入错误的针脚，或者弯曲或折断针脚。如果不小心，可能会毁掉很多精细的作品。因此，当巴克用绕线枪对准 IMP 内的针脚座时，他手上的抖动引起了其他 IMP 成员的极大轰动。

To complicate matters, Barker had a slight palsy in his hands. Working with a wire-wrap gun called for a steady hand and good concentration. The close spacing of the pins, the weight of the wire-wrap gun, and the size of the nozzle on the gun that had to be slipped down over a single pin amid a small forest of pins all conspired against him. The risk was in getting the wire on the wrong pin or bending or breaking a pin. You could destroy a lot of fine work if you weren’t careful. So the shake in Barker’s hands caused quite a stir among the other IMP Guys when Barker took his wire-wrap gun to the pin blocks inside the IMP.

大部分重新接线都是在断电的情况下进行的。当某些事情必须在通电的情况下进行时，则使用滑入插针的小夹子引线来完成。然而，这里存在短路和烧断电路的真正危险。

Most of the rewiring was done with the power off. When something had to be done with the power on, it was done with little clip-leads that slipped onto the pins. Here, though, there was a very real danger of shorting things out and blowing circuits.

巴克花了几个月的时间调试这台机器。奥恩斯坦负责监督原型机的设计修正，并确保将其反馈给霍尼韦尔的工程师。霍尼韦尔计划交付的下一台机器将是第一台加固型 516，所有设计缺陷都已解决：IMP Number One，将运往加州大学洛杉矶分校。“我们费了好大劲才拿到可行的设计，以便及时发货，”巴克说。夏天到了。

Barker spent months debugging the machine. Ornstein was overseeing the design corrections in the prototype and making sure they got relayed back to Honeywell’s engineers. The next machine Honeywell was scheduled to deliver would be the first ruggedized 516 with all the design bugs worked out: IMP Number One destined for UCLA. “The sweat was to get working designs in time to ship,” said Barker. The summer was upon them.

哈特对大批好奇的研究生的警惕促使 BBN 构思出对 IMP 的更强有力的保护措施。随着时间的推移，哈特团队所做的最具创造性的事情之一是发明了从网络 IMP 获取关键运行数据的方法——从远处不引人注意地读取机器的生命体征。哈特希望能够坐在剑桥的终端前，查看洛杉矶、盐湖城或任何其他地方的 IMP 在做什么。BBN 全面实施的远程诊断工具和调试功能后来成为一笔巨大的财富。当网络成熟时，远程控制将使 BBN 能够从一个运营中心监控和维护整个系统，收集数据并在情况发生变化时诊断问题。每个 IMP 都会定期向剑桥发送“其状态快照”，即一组有关其运行状况的数据。可以检测到网络中的细微变化和重大变化。哈特团队设想，有一天人们能够通过网络了解是否有机器发生故障、是否有线路发生故障，或者是否有人在干扰机器。

Heart’s wariness about the hordes of curious graduate students drove BBN to conceptualize even greater measures of protection for the IMPs. In time, among the most creative things Heart’s team did was invent ways of obtaining critical operating data from the network IMPs—reading the machines’vital signs—unobtrusively from a distance. Heart wanted to be able to sit at a terminal in Cambridge and see what an IMP in Los Angeles, Salt Lake City or any place else was doing. BBN’s full implementation of remote diagnostic tools and debugging capabilities would later become a huge asset. When the network matured, remote control would enable BBN to monitor and maintain the whole system from one operations center, collecting data and diagnosing problems as things changed. Periodically, each IMP would send back to Cambridge a “snapshot of its status,” a set of data about its operating conditions. Changes in the network, minor and major, could be detected. Heart’s group envisioned someday being able to look across the network to know whether any machine was malfunctioning or any line was failing, or perhaps if anyone was meddling with the machines.

尽管如此，BBN 甚至还没有让原型 IMP 达到可以运行操作代码的状态。而编程团队——Crowther、Walden 和 Cosell——现在正进入一个困难的领域：设计一个灵活的或“动态”的路由系统，允许替代路由，以便数据包可以自动绕过有问题的节点和链路。固定路由方案本来很简单：您将发送一个带有明确指令的数据包，使其通过地图上的 x、y 和 z 点。但如果点 y 被击倒，所有流量都会被阻止。这将破坏具有多个链路和节点的网络的优势之一。ARPA

的原始请求指定了动态路由，但没有提供如何使其工作的线索。Crowther 找到了一种方法。他正在构建一个动态路由表系统，该系统每隔一秒钟左右就会更新一次。这些表将告诉 IMP 将每个尚未到达目的地的数据包转发到哪个方向。路由表将反映诸如线路故障和拥塞等网络状况，并以最短的路径路由数据包。让这种设计真正发挥作用似乎是一个令人费解的问题——直到克劳瑟想出了一套简单而完美的代码。正如奥恩斯坦对克劳瑟不可思议的直觉天赋的描述，克劳瑟“总是埋头苦干”。

Nonetheless, BBN still hadn’t even gotten the prototype IMP to a state in which it could run operational code. And the programming team—Crowther, Walden, and Cosell—was now moving into difficult territory: the design of a flexible, or “dynamic” routing system, allowing alternative routing, so that packets would automatically flow around troubled nodes and links. A fixed-routing scheme would have been straightforward: You would send a packet with clear instructions to travel via x, y, and z points on the map. But if point y was knocked out, all traffic would be held up. And that would thwart one of the advantages of a network with multiple links and nodes.

The original request from ARPA had specified dynamic routing, without offering a clue as to how to make it work. Crowther had found a way to do it. He was building a system of dynamic-routing tables that would be updated every split second or so. These tables would tell the IMPs in which direction to forward each packet that hadn’t yet reached its destination. The routing tables would reflect such network conditions as line failures and congestion, and they would route packets the shortest way possible. Making this design actually work seemed a mind-bending problem—until Crowther came up with a simple, perfect set of code. Crowther “always had his head right down in the bits,” as Ornstein described Crowther’s uncanny, intuitive talent.

Crowther 的动态路由算法是一首编程诗歌。“它极其简约，而且效果惊人，”Walden 说道。同事们认为 Crowther 是世界上 1% 的顶级程序员。有时 Crowther 代码的优雅简约不足以处理现实世界系统的复杂性。其他程序员必须对 Crowther 所创建的代码进行微调。但他的核心思想往往非常出色。“我们大多数人靠处理 Will 动脑筋的结果来谋生，”Walden 说道。

Crowther’s dynamic-routing algorithm was a piece of programming poetry. “It was incredibly minimalistic and worked astoundingly well,” Walden observed. Crowther was regarded by his colleagues as being within the top fraction of 1 percent of programmers in the world. On occasion the graceful minimalism of Crowther’s code wasn’t enough to handle the complexity of real-world systems. Other programmers would have to fine-tune what Crowther had created. But his core ideas were more often than not brilliant. “Most of the rest of us made our livings handling the details resulting from Will’s use of his brain,” Walden observed.

流控制是另一项编程挑战。但是当 Kahn 查看 Crowther 的代码并看到他如何实现从网络的一端到另一端的数据包流控制时，他感到担心。主机之间的消息将通过子网通过逻辑“链接”传输。子网将在给定链接上一次接受一条消息。等待进入子网的消息存储在队列中的内存缓冲区（机器内部的等待区域）中。直到发送 IMP 收到确认（类似于回执）表示前一条消息已无错误到达目标主机后，才会发送下一条消息。当一条链接清除并且可以发送新消息时，子网将通过特殊控制信号通知发送 IMP，BBN 工程师称之为“准备接收下一条消息”或 RFNM（发音为 RUFF-num）。发送主机缓冲区中等待链接清除的消息就像餐厅里等待餐桌的顾客一样； RFNM 相当于领班宣布“您的餐桌准备好了”。

Flow control was another programming challenge. But when Kahn looked at Crowther’s code and saw how he had implemented control of the flow of packets from one side of the network to the other, he was worried. Messages between hosts were to be transmitted by the subnet over logical “links.” The subnet would accept one message at a time on a given link. Messages waiting to enter the subnet were stored in a memory buffer (a waiting area inside the machine), in a queue. The next message wasn’t sent until the sending IMP received an acknowledgment (similar to a return receipt) saying that the previous message had arrived error-free at the destination host. When one link was cleared and a new message could be sent, the subnet would notify the sending IMP by means of a special control signal that the BBN engineers called Ready for Next Message, or RFNM (pronounced RUFF-num). Messages in the sending host’s buffers, waiting for links to clear, were like patrons in a restaurant waiting for tables; RFNMs were the equivalent of the maître d’s announcing “Your table is ready.”

这意味着不可能通过系统中的任何单个链路将连续的消息流从一个主机发送到另一个主机。RFNM 是一种拥塞控制策略，旨在保护 IMP 免于过载，但代价是减少对主机的服务。早在 ARPA 网络项目开始之前，Kahn 就研究过拥塞控制问题。他对 Crowther 的解决方案的反应是，链路和 RFNM 仍然会导致网络主干道出现致命拥塞。他说，IMP 的缓冲区将被填满。接收 IMP 中会有不完整的消息，等待最终数据包到达，以便重新组装整个消息，而没有空间让数据包到达。

This meant it was impossible to send a continuous stream of messages over any single link through the system from one host to another. RFNM was a congestion-control strategy designed to protect the IMPs from overload, but at the expense of reducing service to the host. Kahn had studied the problem of congestion control even before the ARPA network project began. His reaction to Crowther’s solution was that the links and RFNMs would still allow fatal congestion of the network’s arteries. The IMP’s buffers would fill up, he said. You’d have incomplete messages sitting in the receiving IMPs waiting for their final packets to arrive so the entire message could be reassembled, and there would be no room for the packets to arrive.

卡恩的重组僵局场景在航运业中也有类似的例子。假设萨克拉门托的一家丰田经销商从横滨的仓库订购了一组替换的发动机缸体和活塞。这两件物品对于经销商手头的工作来说是必不可少的。在横滨港，货船正在装载大型集装箱，所有集装箱的大小都相同，里面装满了各种各样的产品。发动机缸体和活塞最终被装到不同的船上。当装有发动机缸体的集装箱抵达旧金山时，它被卸载到一个集装箱仓库，仓库里的东西也是部分装运的，等待其他部件到达后再发送：电视机部件、钢琴针座等。当载有活塞的货船到达时，它发现仓库已经满了。之后的每一艘船都有同样的问题：没有人可以卸货；仓库里什么都不能离开。僵局。解决方案？横滨托运人同意下次提前打电话预订所有一起装运的集装箱的空间。如果没有空间，他会等到有空间后再发货。

Kahn’s reassembly lockup scenario has an analog in the shipping business. Say that a Toyota dealership in Sacramento orders sets of replacement engine blocks and pistons from a warehouse in Yokohama. Both items together are essential for the jobs the dealer has at hand. In the Yokohama harbor, freighters are loading large containers, all the same size, filled with products of many kinds. The engine blocks and pistons wind up in separate ships. When the container of engine blocks arrives in San Francisco, it is unloaded to a warehouse of containers whose contents are also partial shipments awaiting the arrival of other parts before being sent onward: components for television sets, pin blocks for pianos, and so on. When the freighter with the pistons arrives, it finds the warehouse full. Every later ship has the same problem: Nobody can unload; nothing can leave the warehouse. Deadlock. Solution? The Yokohama shipper agrees to call ahead next time to reserve space for all containers that go together. If space is unavailable, he waits until it becomes available before shipping.

卡恩还预测了另一种可能导致数据包丢失的死锁。他说，当子网中的流量很大时，一个 IMP 的缓冲区中塞满了要路由到另一个 IMP 的数据包，反之亦然。这将导致一种僵局，任何一方都无法接受另一方的数据包。根据路由软件的编写方式，IMP 会丢弃数据包。

Kahn also predicted another type of deadlock that might lead to loss of packets. He said that it would occur in heavy traffic within the subnet when the buffers of one IMP were filled with packets routed to another, and vice versa. A kind of standoff would result, in which neither one would be able to accept the other’s packets. The way the routing software had been written the IMPs would discard the packets.

卡恩和克劳瑟就僵局问题进行了长时间的辩论。在这些问题上，卡恩的概念性观点与其他 IMP 成员的务实倾向发生了公开冲突，并引发了他们之间的广泛分歧。团队的其他成员只想让网络按计划启动和运行。随着网络的发展，他们将有时间提高其性能，解决问题并完善算法。

Kahn and Crowther debated the gridlock question at length. Over points such as these Kahn’s conceptual views came into open conflict with the pragmatic bent of the rest of the IMP Guys and cracked open a wide disagreement between them. The rest of the team just wanted to get the network up and running on schedule. As the network grew they’d have time to improve its performance, work out problems, and perfect the algorithms.

但卡恩坚持己见。“我能看到一些对我来说是明显缺陷的东西，”他说。“最明显的缺陷是网络可能会死锁。”卡恩确信网络会死锁，他立即告诉了哈特和其他人。他们与他争论起来。“鲍勃对事物的理论和数学感兴趣，但他对实现并不真正感兴趣，”克劳瑟说。克劳瑟和卡恩开始讨论这个问题，两人发生了克劳瑟所说的“大争吵”。流量控制方案不是为大型网络设计的，克劳瑟认为他们可以用少量节点来解决这个问题。

But Kahn persisted. “I could see things that to me were obvious flaws,” he said. “The most obvious one was that the network could deadlock.” Kahn was certain the network would lock up, and he told Heart and the others so immediately. They argued with him. “Bob was interested in the theory of things and the math, but he wasn’t really interested in the implementation,” said Crowther. Crowther and Kahn began to talk it through, and the two had what Crowther described as “grand little fights.” The flow-control scheme wasn’t designed for a huge network, and with a small number of nodes Crowther thought they could get by with it.

Heart 认为 Kahn 过于担心假设的、不太可能发生的网络状况。他采取的方法是等待观望。其他一些人认为 Kahn 并不了解他们正在努力解决的许多问题。“他提出的一些建议非常荒唐，完全是错误的，”Ornstein 说。Kahn 想要在屏幕上观看网络流量的模拟。他想要一个程序来显示数据包在网络中的移动。事实上，数据包的移动速度永远不会达到人类可观察到的速度；它们会以微秒和毫秒的速度“飞驰”而过。“我们说，‘鲍勃，你从这个角度看永远不会理解问题。’”其他 IMP 成员尊重 Kahn，但有些人认为他走错了方向。渐渐地，他们不再关注他了。“我们小组中的大多数人都在试图让 Kahn 不再困扰我们，”Ornstein 说。

Heart thought that Kahn was worrying too much about hypothetical, unlikely network conditions. His approach was to wait and see. Some of the others thought Kahn didn’t understand many of the problems with which they were grappling. “Some of the things he was suggesting were off-the-wall, just wrong,” said Ornstein. Kahn wanted to watch simulations of network traffic on a screen. He wanted to have a program that would show packets moving through the network. In fact, the packets would never move at a humanly observable speed; they’d be going “zip-zip” in microseconds and milliseconds. “We said, ‘Bob, you’ll never understand the problems looking at it that way.’” The other IMP Guys respected Kahn, but some believed he was going in the wrong direction. Gradually, they paid less attention to him. “Most of us in the group were trying to get Kahn out of our hair,” Ornstein said.

哈特否决了卡恩使用模拟的建议。哈特不愿看到他的编程团队花时间进行模拟或编写除操作代码之外的任何东西。他们已经被他不喜欢的另一件事分散了注意力——构建软件工具。哈特担心拖延。多年来，他见过太多程序员沉迷于工具构建，而他的职业生涯中一直在阻止年轻工程师做可能浪费金钱或时间的事情。哈特部门的人知道，如果他们向他请求允许他们花几个小时编写编辑器、汇编器和调试器，他们会遭到强烈抵制，甚至会大喊大叫。所以没有人问过；他们只是这样做，当他们认为这是正确的事情时，他们就会构建工具，不管哈特怎么想。这是他们在测试系统时最终需要的软件。所有这些都是专门为 ARPA 项目设计的定制程序。

Heart scotched Kahn’s suggestion that they use a simulation. Heart hated to see his programming team spend time on simulations or on writing anything but operational code. They were already becoming distracted by something else he disliked—building software tools. Heart feared delay. Over the years he had seen too many programmers captivated by tool building, and he had spent a career holding young engineers back from doing things that might waste money or time. The people in Heart’s division knew that if they asked him for the okay to clock hours writing editors, assemblers, and debuggers, they would meet with stiff resistance, perhaps even a shouting match. So no one ever asked; they just did it, building tools when they thought it was the right thing to do, regardless of what Heart thought. This was software they would eventually need when the time came to test the system. All were customized pieces of programming, specifically designed for the ARPA project.

随着夏季的到来，一个令人困扰的问题浮现出来：BBN 仍在等待霍尼韦尔交付第一台生产型 IMP，所有调试接口均按照 BBN 的规格制造。编程团队放弃了等待，继续工作，在低级开发机器上加载了团队设计的模拟程序，以模仿生产型 IMP 及其 I/O 接口的操作。不过，在真实机器上测试软件是首选方法。每当机器进来时，Barker 都需要时间对其进行调试。剩下的时间越来越少了。到了夏末，机器仍未通过 BBN 的装卸码头。距离 IMP 到加利福尼亚的预定交付时间只有几周了，BBN 自己的声誉也岌岌可危。

As summer peaked, a troubling problem loomed: BBN was still awaiting Honeywell’s delivery of the first production IMP, with all the debugged interfaces built to BBN’s specifications. The programming team had given up waiting and gone ahead with its work by loading a lower-grade development machine with a simulation program the team had designed to mimic the operations of the production model IMP and its I/O interfaces. Still, testing the software on the real machine was the preferred approach. And whenever the machine came in, Barker would first need time to debug it. The time left was dwindling. By late summer, the machine still hadn’t crossed BBN’s loading dock. Scheduled delivery of the IMP to California was now only a few weeks away, and BBN’s own reputation was on the line.

错误

The Bug

最后，在劳动节前两周左右，霍尼韦尔匆忙将第一台加固型 516 IMP 从车间运到剑桥。机器一落地，巴克就准备好开始操作。他在后屋启动了 IMP 一号。

Finally, about two weeks before Labor Day, Honeywell rushed the first ruggedized 516 IMP out its shop door and over to Cambridge. As soon as the machine touched the floor at BBN, Barker was ready to work on it. He powered up IMP Number One in the backroom.

巴克加载了 IMP 诊断代码。当他尝试运行它时，什么也没发生。机器没有反应。仔细检查后，很明显 BBN 收到的机器不是它订购的。这台 516 几乎没有经过巴克和奥恩斯坦在调试原型时精心设计的修改；事实上，它的接线方式与原始故障原型的接线方式一样。随着最后期限的临近，巴克只有一个办法：在 BBN 修理它。这一次至少他已经知道每根电线应该去哪里了。机器放在大房间的中间，巴克开始实施所有必要的设计修改，使其成为一台正常运行的 IMP。

Barker loaded the IMP diagnostic code. When he tried running it, nothing happened. The machine didn’t respond. On closer inspection, it was apparent that the machine BBN received was not what it had ordered. This 516 had few of the modifications that Barker and Ornstein had worked out painstakingly in debugging the prototype; in fact, it was wired just like the original dysfunctional prototype had been wired. With the deadline closing in, Barker had only one recourse: fix it at BBN. This time at least he already knew where every wire should go. With the machine sitting in the middle of the large room, Barker went to work implementing all of the design modifications necessary to make it a functioning IMP.

几天之内，巴克就让机器重新运转起来。他设法激活了 IMP 的接口，但计算机却开始不时地崩溃。崩溃的随机性异常严重。这种间歇性问题简直是魔鬼。IMP 会连续运行 12 到 40 个小时，然后死机，并停在“偏僻地区”的某个地方。该怎么办？奥恩斯坦回忆道：“我们不知道到底发生了什么。”

Within a few days, Barker had coaxed the machine to life. He managed to activate the IMP’s interfaces—whereupon the computer began crashing at random intervals. The randomness of the crashes was unusually bad. Intermittent problems of this sort were the devil. The IMP would run for anywhere from twelve hours to forty hours at a stretch, then die and be somewhere “off in the boonies.” What to do? Recalled Ornstein, “We couldn’t figure out what the hell was going on.”

随着劳动节的临近，他们给 IMP 施加了压力，让它接受尽可能多的严格测试。它可能会运行 24 小时，然后莫名其妙地死机。巴克会寻找线索，找出问题所在，修复它，但机器还是会再次崩溃。距离交货期限仅剩几天，看起来他们无法完成任务了。

As Labor Day approached, they pressured the IMP, putting it through as many hard tests as possible. It might run fine for twenty-four hours, then inexplicably die. Barker would look for a clue, chase what appeared to be a problem, fix it, and still the machine would crash again. With only a few days left before the delivery deadline, it looked like they were not going to make it.

一直在检查电脑的巴克怀疑问题出在机器的正时链上。这只是一种直觉。

IMP 有一个时钟，由操作系统用来计时，而不是

The IMP had a clock used by the operating system to keep time in the machine, not as

IMP 有一个时钟，操作系统使用它来记录机器的时间，而不是以微秒（每秒一百万个滴答）为单位——在当时这很快，但比今天的个人电脑慢一百倍。这个时钟为 IMP 提供了一个运行框架，它同步调节计算机的许多功能。在通信系统中，消息会不经通知就到达；信号会异步中断机器。就像晚餐中间的电话一样，一个传入的数据包会按照自己的时间表出现在 IMP 门口，并说：“现在就带我走。”

The IMP had a clock used by the operating system to keep time in the machine, not as microsecond (one million ticks per second) increments—fast for its day but a hundred times slower than today’s personal computers. This clock provided a framework in which the IMP operated, and it regulated the computer’s many functions synchronously. In a communications system, messages arrive unannounced; signals interrupt the machine asynchronously. Like a telephone call in the middle of dinner, an incoming packet shows up on its own schedule at the IMP’s door and says, “Take me now.”

计算机拥有一套复杂的系统，可以有条不紊地处理传入的中断，以免扰乱其所有功能的同步操作。如果设计不当，这种同步器可能会因在错误时刻出现的传入信号而失效。同步器故障很少见。但是，当它们发生并且同步器无法正确响应中断时，其后果将严重扰乱机器的整体运行。人们可以称之为神经崩溃；计算机科学家对此有另一个术语：同步器进入“亚稳态”。“在这种情况下，”奥恩斯坦说，“机器总是会陷入一种无可救药的混乱状态——每次都不一样。”

The computer had a sophisticated system for handling the incoming interruptions in a methodical manner, so as not to upset the synchronous operation of all its functions. If not properly designed, such synchronizers can be thrown off by an incoming signal occurring at just the wrong moment. Synchronizer bugs are rare. But when they occur and the synchronizer fails to respond properly to an interrupt, the consequences are profoundly disturbing to the machine’s total operation. One might call it a nervous breakdown; computer scientists have another term for it: The synchronizer goes into a “metastable” condition. “Under such circumstances,” Ornstein said, “the machine invariably dies in a hopelessly confused state—different each time.”

奥恩斯坦对同步器故障了如指掌。几年前，他和韦斯·克拉克在圣路易斯组装的电脑中就曾处理过这个问题。奥恩斯坦是最早发表的几篇关于该主题的论文的作者，也是世界上少数真正有过这种特殊故障经验的人之一。

Ornstein knew all too well about synchronizer bugs. He had dealt with the problem in the computer he and Wes Clark had built a few years earlier in St. Louis. Ornstein was the author of some of the first published papers on the subject, and was one of the few people in the world who actually had any experience with this particular gremlin.

由于同步器错误不可预测，因此它成为最令人沮丧的错误之一，因为其导致的崩溃没有任何可识别的模式。与大多数可能导致计算机崩溃的其他问题不同，同步器错误几乎没有留下任何有用的法医证据，无法让诊断人员找到问题所在。事实上，没有线索是最有用的线索之一。此外，这种错误导致的故障非常罕见（即使在全面测试中也只有每天一次左右），以至于不可能在示波器上检测到任何证据。只有最精明的调试者才知道他们正在处理什么。

Their unpredictability made synchronizer bugs among the most frustrating of bugs because of the absence of any recognizable pattern to the resulting crashes. Unlike most other problems that could cause computers to crash, a synchronizer bug left behind virtually no useful forensic evidence that might point a diagnostician to the problem. In fact, the absence of clues was one of the most useful clues. Furthermore, the failures caused by this bug were so infrequent (only once every day or so even in full-bore tests), that it was impossible to detect any evidence on an oscilloscope. Only the most astute debuggers had any idea what they were dealing with.

这似乎就是 Ornstein 和 Barker 面临的问题。但谁知道呢，因为你无法真正追踪它。现在该怎么办？Honeywell 516 从未用于像分组交换网络这样要求严格的应用。它是一台快速的机器；IMP Guys 选择它正是因为它的 I/O 功能。其他人可能永远不会在 516 计算机的典型应用中看到这个问题。“如果他们的机器每年死机一次，”Ornstein 说，“他们永远不会注意到。他们只会重新启动。”但 IMP Guys 正在努力驾驶这台机器。进出 IMP 的数据包流比 Honeywell 设计师预期的要快。516 机器似乎无法处理这样的流量。也许 BBN 过于乐观了。Ornstein 和 Barker 去了 Honeywell，坚持要求制造商“从幕后挖掘出”516 计算机的设计者。奥恩斯坦不得不承认，他是个非常聪明的人，但起初这位霍尼韦尔人拒绝承认机器中可能存在亚稳态。他从未读过奥恩斯坦的论文，也从未发现过这个问题。“尽管充满怀疑，”奥恩斯坦说，但他“至少明白我们在说什么。”

This seemed to be the problem Ornstein and Barker had on their hands. But who knew, because you couldn’t actually trace it. What to do now? The Honeywell 516 had never been used in an application as demanding as the packet-switching network. It was a fast machine; the IMP Guys had chosen it precisely for its I/O capabilities. No one else was likely ever to see the problem in a typical application of the 516 computer. “If their machine died once a year,” Ornstein said, “they’d never notice. They would just restart.” But the IMP Guys were driving the machine hard. The flow of packets into and out of the IMP happened faster than the Honeywell designers had anticipated. The 516 machine didn’t seem capable of handling such traffic. Maybe BBN had been overly optimistic. Ornstein and Barker went to Honeywell and insisted that the manufacturer “dig out of the woodwork, way in the backroom” the designer of the 516 computer. He was a very smart guy, Ornstein had to admit, but at first the Honeywell man refused to admit that a metastable state was possible in the machine. He had never read Ornstein’s papers, and had never seen the problem.“Though filled with disbelief,” said Ornstein, he “at least understood what we were saying.”

在正常情况下，516 可以运行数年而不会遇到同步器问题。然而，在 ARPA 的分组交换网络条件下，机器几乎每天都会出现一次故障。试着告诉 Frank Heart，可靠性先生，他只能忍受这种情况。

Under normal conditions, the 516 would run for years without experiencing the synchronizer problem. However, under ARPA’s packet-switching network conditions, the machine was failing once every day or so. Try telling Frank Heart, Mr. Reliability, that he’d just have to live with that.

奥恩斯坦和巴克挤在一起。IMP 的同步器出现问题，这只是一个猜测。为了验证这一假设，奥恩斯坦设计并连接了一个“加重器”，它故意以巴克所说的“剧烈的速率”发出数据请求。它增加了在暴露问题的那一纳秒内发生中断的概率。加重器有一个像调谐器一样工作的旋钮。使用这个旋钮，奥恩斯坦和巴克可以“调整”请求的时间，以产生与时钟完全不一致的信号，这是最坏的情况。然后，他们使用示波器观察了机器的“心跳”和其他内部功能。

Ornstein and Barker huddled. It was only a guess that the IMP had a synchronizer problem. To test the hypothesis, Ornstein designed and wired an “aggravator” that deliberately produced data requests at what Barker called a “fierce rate.” It increased the probability of getting interruptions at the exact nanosecond that would reveal the problem. The aggravator had a knob that worked like a tuner. Using the knob, Ornstein and Barker could “tune” the timing of requests to bring in a signal perfectly out of kilter with the clock, the worst case. Then, using an oscilloscope, they observed the machine’s “heartbeat” and other internal functions.

调试人员开始工作。他们在示波器上寻找的图案非常微弱，只有在黑暗的房间里才能看到。因此，他们关掉了 IMP 室的所有灯，打开了所有诊断设备和霍尼韦尔，一边观察，一边摆弄加重器。他们在示波器上看到的痕迹很明亮，位置规则，节奏稳定——这是健康机器的生命体征。

The debugging crew went to work. The patterns they were looking for on the oscilloscope would be so faint as to be visible only in a darkened room. So with all the lights out in the IMP room and with all their diagnostic equipment and the Honeywell turned on, they watched, while fooling with the aggravator. The traces they saw on the scope were bright, regularly positioned, and steadily paced—the vital signs of a healthy machine.

即使有了加重器，调试团队也花了很长时间才找到他们要找的东西。然而，每隔几分钟，示波器上就会出现一条非常微弱的幽灵痕迹。是它吗？这条转瞬即逝的痕迹可能是唯一能表明撞车事故是由计时问题引起的迹象：同步器在亚稳态下停滞的时间太长了几纳秒。这相当于赛车手一瞬间的困惑或犹豫，最终导致致命撞车。证据似乎是无可辩驳的，霍尼韦尔最终承认了这一点。

Even with the aggravator, it took the debugging team quite a while to find what it was looking for. Still, every few minutes a very faint ghost trace flitted across the oscilloscope. Was that it? The fleeting trace was perhaps the only telltale sign that the crashes were caused by a timing problem: a synchronizer stalled in a metastable condition for a few nanoseconds too long. It was the computer equivalent of the one split second of confusion or indecision by a race car driver that ends suddenly in a fatal crash. The evidence seemed fairly incontrovertible, and Honeywell finally acknowledged it.

与此同时，巴克设计了一个可行的修复方案，并重新连接了 IMP 的中央正时链。当巴克将机器重新启动、加载诊断代码并查看示波器时，幽灵痕迹消失了。

In the meantime, Barker designed a possible fix, and rewired the IMP’s central timing chain. When Barker brought the machine back up, loaded in his diagnostic code, and looked in the scope, the ghost traces were gone.

虽然 Barker 和 Ornstein 确信问题已经解决，但他们无法确定，除非机器连续几天运行不崩溃。而他们没有几天时间。Heart 已经批准第二天将第一台接口消息处理器运往加利福尼亚。IMP 一号即将出货。

While Barker and Ornstein were reasonably certain that the problem was fixed, they had no way of knowing for sure unless the machine ran for a few consecutive days without crashing. And they didn’t have a few days. Heart had already approved shipping the first Interface Message Processor to California the next day. IMP Number One was almost out the door.

5 做吧，特鲁特

5 Do It to It Truett

史蒂夫·克罗克和文特·瑟夫从就读洛杉矶圣费尔南多谷的范奈斯高中起就成为了好朋友。他们都热爱科学，两人经常在周六晚上一起制作三维国际象棋游戏，或者尝试重现埃德温·兰德的色彩感知实验。

Steve Crocker and Vint Cerf had been best friends since attending Van Nuys High School in L.A.’s San Fernando Valley. They shared a love for science, and the two spent more than a few Saturday nights building three-dimensional chess games or trying to re-create Edwin Land’s experiments with color perception.

文特是个瘦削、热情、热情的孩子。他加入了高中的后备军官训练团，以逃避体育课。在那些他没有穿着后备军官训练团制服去学校的日子里，文特会穿上夹克打上领带。他总是带着一个棕色的大公文包。按照当地的标准，即使在 20 世纪 50 年代末，这也是一种不寻常的着装方式。“我用外套和领带来区别于人群——也许是书呆子们的与众不同方式，”他回忆道。尽管如此，令他的朋友大为惊愕的是，文特从不费力地吸引异性的注意。大家都认为他是独一无二的。

Vint was a wiry, intense, effusive kid. He joined his high school ROTC unit to avoid gym class. On the days he didn’t show up at school in his ROTC uniform, Vint wore a jacket and tie. And he always toted a large brown briefcase. By local standards, it was an unusual mode of dress, even in the late 1950s. “I used the coat and tie to distinguish myself from the crowd—maybe a nerd’s way of being different,” he recalled. Nonetheless, much to the consternation of his friends,Vint never had trouble attracting the attention of the opposite sex. He was, everyone agreed, one of a kind.

文特从小就渴望能像他父亲一样，在北美航空公司（现为罗克韦尔国际公司）一路晋升，成为高级管理人员。文特的两个弟弟都踢足球，轮流担任学生会主席。文特是个书虫。他的文学品味偏向奇幻。成年后，他经常抽出几天时间重读《指环王》三部曲。文特的化学成绩特别好，但他的热情在于数学。当史蒂夫·克罗克在范奈斯高中创办数学俱乐部时，文特是第一批加入的人之一。

From an early age,Vint aspired to match the accomplished track record of his father, who had risen through the ranks to become a senior executive at North American Aviation (now Rockwell International). Both of Vint’s younger brothers played football and took turns as president of the student body.Vint was the bookworm. His literary tastes tilted toward fantasy. Well into his adult life, he regularly set aside several days to rereadThe Lord of the Ringstrilogy.Vint did particularly well in chemistry, but his passion was math. When Steve Crocker started the math club atVan Nuys High,Vint was one of the first to join.

由于早产，文特患有听力障碍。尽管后来双耳佩戴助听器纠正了大部分缺陷，但他在成长过程中想出了在听力世界中进行交流的聪明策略。多年后，在他们成为朋友后，鲍勃·卡恩向朋友们透露了瑟夫的一些听觉技巧，瑟夫最终写了一篇名为《听障工程师的自白》的论文，在其中分享了他的一些秘密。

As a result of premature birth, Vint was hearing-impaired. Although hearing aids in both ears later corrected much of the deficit, he grew up devising clever strategies for communicating in the hearing world. Years later, after they became friends, Bob Kahn brought some of Cerf’s aural tricks to his friends’attention and Cerf eventually wrote a paper called “Confessions of a Hearing-Impaired Engineer,” in which he shared some of his secrets.

在特别嘈杂的环境中（自助餐厅、餐馆以及有狗和小孩的家庭），聋人对对话背景的依赖通常会受到严重影响。一种典型的策略是主导对话，不是全程讲话，而是提出很多问题。这样，聋哑听众至少会知道说话者在回答什么问题，即使他听不到所有的回答。在小组对话中，如果你问的问题是别人刚刚问过的问题，这可能会适得其反，令人尴尬。一种变体（同样令人尴尬）是热情地建议刚刚建议的事情，例如：

In particularly noisy environments (cafeterias, restaurants, and homes with dogs and small children), the deaf person’s reliance on conversational context often suffers badly. A typical strategy here is to dominate the conversation, not by doing all the talking, but by asking a lot of questions. In this way, the deaf listener will at least know what question the speaker is addressing, even if he cannot hear all of the response. In a group conversation, this can backfire embarrassingly if the question you ask is one which was just asked by someone else. A variation (equally embarrassing) is to enthusiastically suggest something just suggested, for example:

朋友 A：我想知道这个词的起源是什么？朋友 B：我们为什么不去牛津英语词典里查一下呢？朋友 A：是的，可惜我们没有牛津英语词典。瑟夫：我知道。我们为什么不去牛津英语词典里查一下呢？

Friend A: I wonder what the origin of this term is? Friend B: Why don’t we look it up inThe Oxford English Dictionary? Friend A: Yeah, but too bad we don’t have anO.E.D. Cerf: I know. Why don’t we look it up inThe Oxford English Dictionary?

史蒂夫·克罗克在文特的生活中来来去去。史蒂夫的父母离婚了，高中时期他一直在芝加哥郊区和圣费尔南多谷之间奔波。史蒂夫总是早熟，从小就知道自己可能是房间里最聪明的孩子。十三岁时，有一天感冒了，他自学了微积分的基础知识。十年级结束时，他学会了计算机编程的基础知识。“我记得当我终于理解了循环的概念时，我非常激动，”克罗克回忆道，“它使计算机能够仅使用相对较少的指令来执行非常长的操作序列。我当时有点幼稚，但我记得我认为这种启示一定让阿基米德赤身裸体地跑到街上大喊‘尤里卡！’”

Steve Crocker drifted in and out of Vint’s life. Steve’s parents were divorced, and he spent his high school years shuttling between suburban Chicago and the San Fernando Valley. Always precocious, Steve grew up knowing he was probably the smartest kid in any given room. At age thirteen, while home one day with a cold, he taught himself the elements of calculus. And at the end of tenth grade, he learned the rudiments of computer programming. “I remember being thrilled when I finally understood the concept of a loop,” Crocker recalled, “which enabled the computer to proceed with a very lengthy sequence of operations with only a relatively few instructions. I was a bit callow, but I remember thinking this was the kind of revelation that must have led Archimedes to run down the street naked yelling, ‘Eureka!’”

1960 年左右，史蒂夫回到洛杉矶，文特跟着他进入加州大学洛杉矶分校的计算机实验室。尽管史蒂夫还在读高中，但他已经获准使用加州大学洛杉矶分校的计算机，但他和文特唯一的空闲时间就是周末。一个星期六，他们到达计算机实验室时发现大楼被锁上了。“我别无选择，只能放弃，回家，”克罗克说。但他们抬头看到二楼有一扇敞开的窗户。他们互相看了一眼。“接下来，文特就趴在我肩上，”克罗克回忆道。瑟夫从窗户进去，打开门，用胶带封住门闩，这样他们就可以进出大楼。“十二年后，当水门事件窃贼做同样的事情并被抓获时，我浑身发抖，”克罗克说。

Around 1960, when Steve had returned to L.A., Vint followed him into the computer lab at UCLA. Although still in high school, Steve had gotten permission to use the UCLA computer, but the only free time he andVint had was on the weekends. One Saturday they arrived to find the computer lab building locked. “I couldn’t see any choice but to give up and go home,” said Crocker. But they looked up and saw an open second-story window. They looked at each other. “Next thing I know, Vint is on my shoulders,” Crocker recalled. Cerf went through the window and, once inside, opened the door and taped the latch so they could get in and out of the building. “When the Watergate burglars did the same thing a dozen years later and got caught, I shuddered,” said Crocker.

高中毕业后，瑟夫凭借父亲公司提供的四年奖学金进入斯坦福大学学习。他主修数学，但很快就迷上了严肃的计算。“编程有一种惊人的吸引力，”他说。“你创造了自己的宇宙，你是它的主人。计算机会做任何你编程让它做的事情。这是一个令人难以置信的沙箱，里面的每一粒沙子都在你的控制之下。”

After high school, Cerf attended Stanford on a four-year scholarship from his father’s company. He majored in math but soon got hooked on serious computing. “There was something amazingly enticing about programming,” he said. “You created your own universe and you were the master of it. The computer would do anything you programmed it to do. It was this unbelievable sandbox in which every grain of sand was under your control.”

1965 年毕业后，瑟夫决定先工作一段时间再去读研究生。IBM 当时正在斯坦福大学招聘，瑟夫在洛杉矶的 IBM 找到了一份工作。他开始担任 IBM 分时系统的系统工程师。意识到自己需要更好的计算机科学基础，他很快加入了朋友克罗克的行列，克罗克现在是加州大学洛杉矶分校计算机科学系的研究生。当时计算机科学还是一门年轻的学科，加州大学洛杉矶分校的博士学位项目是全国最早的博士学位项目之一，也是当时仅有的十几个博士学位项目之一。瑟夫来到时，克罗克正要前往麻省理工学院。克罗克在加州大学洛杉矶分校的论文导师是杰里·埃斯特林，几年前保罗·巴兰曾与他共事。埃斯特林与美国高级研究计划局 (ARPA) 签订了“Snuper Computer”的合同，该项目使用一台计算机观察第二台机器上程序的执行情况。埃斯特林聘请瑟夫担任该项目的研究生；它成为了瑟夫博士论文的基础。1968 年夏天，克罗克回到加州大学洛杉矶分校，加入了瑟夫的埃斯特林小组。

对于瑟夫和克罗克来说，1968 年标志着他们对计算机网络终生着迷的开始。对于瑟夫来说，计算机网络将成为他职业生涯的核心。虽然克罗克会长时间转向其他领域，但他最终也会回到网络领域。

After graduating in 1965, Cerf decided he wanted to work for a while before going on to graduate school. IBM was recruiting on the Stanford campus, and Cerf took a job at IBM in Los Angeles. He went to work as the systems engineer for an IBM time-sharing system. Realizing he needed better grounding in computer science, he soon joined his friend Crocker, now a graduate student in UCLA’s computer science department. Computer science was still a young discipline, and UCLA’s Ph.D. program—one of the first in the country—was one of only a dozen in existence at the time. Cerf arrived just as Crocker was leaving for MIT. Crocker’s thesis advisor at UCLA was Jerry Estrin, the same professor Paul Baran had worked with a few years earlier. Estrin had an ARPA contract for the “Snuper Computer,” which used one computer to observe the execution of programs running on a second machine. Estrin took on Cerf as a research student for the project; it became the basis for Cerf’s doctoral thesis. In the summer of 1968 Crocker returned to UCLA and joined Cerf in Estrin’s group.

For both Cerf and Crocker, 1968 marked the beginning of a lifelong fascination with the networking of computers. For Cerf, computer networking would become the centerpiece of his professional career. Although Crocker would move on to other things for long stretches at a time, he too would eventually return to the field of networking.

1968 年秋，ARPA 将合同从 Estrin 转给了加州大学洛杉矶分校的 Len Kleinrock。Kleinrock 当时正在建立自己的网络测量中心，ARPA 每年与他签订了 20 万美元的合同。巧合的是，Kleinrock 拿到合同时，隔壁办公室的人正好搬走了，于是 Kleinrock 扩大了自己的业务范围；他拆掉了两个办公室之间的墙，安装了一张大会议桌，用于与学生和教职员工开会。Kleinrock 忙着建立自己的小帝国，会议变得频繁起来。

In the fall of 1968, ARPA transferred its contract from Estrin to Len Kleinrock at UCLA. Kleinrock was setting up his Network Measurement Center, with a $200,000 annual contract from ARPA. By coincidence, when Kleinrock got the contract, the person in the office next door conveniently moved out, so Kleinrock expanded his domain; he tore down the wall between the two offices and installed a large conference table for meetings with students and staff. The meetings were frequent as Kleinrock busily built a small empire.

在规划 ARPA 网络时，Larry Roberts 设想将网络测量中心作为负责大部分性能测试和分析的组织。测量中心的设计大致类似于一条测试跑道，驾驶员在这里测试高性能汽车的极限。Kleinrock 和他的团队负责收集数据（网络总响应时间、流量密度、延迟和容量），这些是评估网络性能所需的指标。与 Bob Kahn 一样，Kleinrock 也有理论家的倾向；他的工作是模拟、建模和分析。通过模拟，他尽可能接近地监控网络的运行方式，而无需实际运行网络。他很高兴有机会在真实网络上测试他的理论。

In planning the ARPA network, Larry Roberts had conceived of the Network Measurement Center as the organization that would be responsible for most of the performance testing and analysis. The measurement center was intended to be roughly analogous to a test track where drivers push the outer limits of high-performance cars. Kleinrock and his group were in charge of gathering data—total network response time, traffic density, delays, and capacity—the measures needed to evaluate how the network is performing. Like Bob Kahn, Kleinrock had a theoretician’s bent; his business was simulation, modeling, and analysis. Through simulations, he had come as close as he could to monitoring the ways in which networks perform without actually having a network to run. He welcomed the chance to test his theories on the real thing.

BBN 的工程师们并没有过多关注克莱因罗克。他们认为他过于注重理论，而对工程设计则相当轻描淡写。克莱因罗克认为 BBN 团队对性能基本不感兴趣，因此他们也对此持怀疑态度。BBN 的程序员非常出色，但克莱因罗克说：“总的来说，程序员只是想得到一个可以运行的软件。这已经够难了。它是否高效运行通常不是问题所在。”他可能不知道沃尔登和克劳瑟对软件效率的痴迷，但无论如何，克莱因罗克认为，

完善网络性能是他的工作。

The engineers at BBN didn’t pay too much attention to Kleinrock. They thought he was a trifle heavy on theory and fairly light on engineering. The skepticism was mutual, for Kleinrock believed that the BBN team was largely uninterested in performance. BBN’s programmers were outstanding, but, said Kleinrock, “By and large, a programmer simply wants to get a piece of software that works. That’s hard enough. Whether it works efficiently or well is not usually the issue.” He was unaware, perhaps, of Walden and Crowther’s obsession with software efficiency, but in any case,

perfectingnetworkperformance, Kleinrock decided, was his job.

不久之后，克莱因罗克就管理着 40 名帮助管理该中心的学生。克罗克和瑟夫是克莱因罗克团队的资深成员。另一位重要成员是乔恩·波斯特尔。他留着浓密的长胡子，一年到头都穿着凉鞋，一生中从未打过领带。瑟夫总是衣冠楚楚，总体上比较保守，与波斯特尔一贯的休闲装扮形成了鲜明的对比。非正式领导者克罗克则处于中间位置。他在麻省理工学院留了胡子（“警察看我的眼神有点严肃，但女孩们要友好得多，这是我可以接受的代价，”克罗克说），但愿意时不时穿上一双正装鞋。

Before long Kleinrock was managing forty students who helped run the center. Crocker and Cerf were among the senior members of Kleinrock’s group. Another important member was Jon Postel. He had a long bushy beard, wore sandals year-round and had never put on a tie in his life. Always dapper and generally more conservative, Cerf presented a striking contrast to Postel’s steadfastly casual appearance. Crocker, the unofficial leader, was somewhere in the middle. He had grown a beard at MIT (“Cops looked at me a little harder, but girls were a lot friendlier, and that was a trade-off I could live with,” Crocker said), but was willing to put on a pair of dress shoes every now and then.

虽然瑟夫和克罗克都是学术明星，但 25 岁的波斯特尔的学术生涯却比较坎坷。他在附近的格伦代尔和谢尔曼奥克斯长大，也曾就读于范奈斯高中，成绩平平。波斯特尔对计算机的兴趣是在当地一所社区大学培养起来的。当他到加州大学洛杉矶分校攻读工程学本科学位（当时最接近计算机科学的学科）时，计算就是他的生命。加州大学洛杉矶分校最终决定将计算机科学设立为一个正式的系，当时波斯特尔正进入该大学的研究生院。波斯特尔性格沉默寡言，但他有很强的意见。计算机科学系的负责人偶尔会将波斯特尔的坚定意见解读为一种不良态度。

While Cerf and Crocker were academic stars, Postel, who was twenty-five, had had a more checkered academic career. He had grown up in nearby Glendale and Sherman Oaks, and he too had attended Van Nuys High School, where his grades were mediocre. Postel’s interest in computers developed at a local community college. By the time he got to UCLA to finish an undergraduate degree in engineering (the closest thing to computer science at the time) computing was his life. UCLA eventually decided to establish computer science as a formal department, at just about the time Postel was entering the university’s graduate school. Postel was quiet, but he had strong opinions. The people running the computer science department occasionally interpreted the firmness of Postel’s opinions as a bad attitude.

1966 年，瑟夫与一位名叫西格丽德的年轻插画家结婚。她听力严重受损。他们的第一次见面是由他们的助听器经销商安排的，这位经销商在一个周六的早上为他们安排了相邻的约会，希望他们能相遇并一拍即合。他们一起吃了午饭，西格丽德对她同伴的广泛好奇心感到敬畏。当文特描述他在电脑方面的工作时，他似乎兴奋得在椅子上手舞足蹈。他们继续了私密的交流，参观了洛杉矶郡艺术博物馆，欣赏了西格丽德最喜欢的一些画作。瑟夫没有受过艺术教育，但渴望学习，他久久地盯着一幅巨大的康定斯基作品。“这东西让我想起了绿色汉堡包，”他最后说道。一年后，他们结婚了，史蒂夫·克罗克担任文特的伴郎（几年后，两人的角色互换了）。克罗克的电子专业知识派上了用场，就在婚礼开始前几分钟，他发现婚礼音乐的录音机出了故障。伴郎和焦急的新郎躲进圣坛附近的一个小房间，及时修好了录音机。

In 1966 Cerf had married a young illustrator named Sigrid. She was profoundly deaf. Their first meeting had been contrived by their hearing-aid dealer, who scheduled adjacent appointments for them one Saturday morning in hopes that they would cross paths and hit it off. They went to lunch and Sigrid was awestruck by her companion’s eclectic curiosity. Vint seemed to dance in his chair with excitement as he described his work with computers. They extended theirtête-à-têtewith a visit to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art to see some of Sigrid’s favorite paintings. Unschooled in art but eager to learn, Cerf stared for a long time at a huge Kandinsky. “This thing reminds me of a green hamburger,” he finally remarked. A year later they were married, with Steve Crocker as Vint’s best man (roles that would be reversed a few years later). Crocker’s electronics expertise came in handy when, minutes before the ceremony was to begin, he discovered the tape recorder for the wedding music was malfunctioning. Best man and frantic groom retreated to a tiny room near the altar and fixed it just in time.

克莱因罗克虽然只比他的团队其他成员大 10 岁，但在排队理论（研究人们和物品排队等待的时间、排队时间长短以及如何设计系统以减少等待时间）方面享有盛誉。他已经出版了一本书，并负责一个不断发展的实验室；他的精力似乎无穷无尽。此外，他是罗伯茨开始 ARPA 项目之前为数不多的几位已经制作出存储转发网络分析模型的科学家之一。

Kleinrock, although only ten years older than the rest of his group, had a great reputation in queueing theory (the study of how long people and things spend waiting in lines, how long the lines get, and how to design systems to reduce waiting). He had already published a book and he was in charge of a growing lab; his energy seemed boundless. Moreover, he was one of just a handful of scientists who had produced analytic models of store-and-forward networks before Roberts got started on the ARPA project.

当时，加州大学洛杉矶分校计算机科学系拥有一台由科学数据系统公司制造的计算机，名为 Sigma-7，这是该公司计算机系列中的最新产品。加州大学洛杉矶分校还有三个大型计算机中心，配备了 IBM 7094 大型机。但 Sigma-7 是分配给研究生使用的机器。没有人喜欢 Sigma-7。它不可靠，编程困难。正如加州大学洛杉矶分校团队的一名成员所说，Sigma-7 是一条狗。（“但它是我们的狗，”瑟夫多年后说道。）它也是他们唯一可以玩的计算机——直到 ARPA 网络出现。加州大学洛杉矶分校的计算机科学家不仅将收到第一台 IMP，而且据推测该网络将为其他站点的各种不同主机打开大门。

At the time, the UCLA computer science department owned a computer made by Scientific Data Systems called the Sigma-7, the latest in that firm’s line of computers. UCLA also had three major computer centers equipped with IBM 7094 mainframes. But the Sigma-7 was the machine assigned to the graduate students. No one liked the Sigma-7 much. It was unreliable and difficult to program. As a member of the UCLA team put it, the Sigma-7 was a dog. (“But it was our dog,” Cerf said years later.) It was also the only computer they had to play with—until, that is, the ARPA network came along. Not only would the computer scientists at UCLA be receiving the first IMP, but presumably the network would open doors to all kinds of different host machines at the other sites.

1969 年夏天最紧迫的任务是构建 Sigma-7 和 IMP 之间的接口（硬件和软件的组合）。正如 UCLA 人员所理解的那样，BBN 正在制定一些如何构建这种连接的规范。每次围绕不同的计算机模型建立新站点时，都必须从头开始构建主机到 IMP 的接口。后来，使用相同模型的站点可以购买自定义接口的副本。

The most pressing task in the summer of 1969 was to build the interface—a combination of hardware and software—between the Sigma-7 and the IMP. As the UCLA guys understood it, BBN was working out some specifications for how to construct such a connection. The host-to-IMP interface had to be built from scratch each time a new site was established around a different computer model. Later, sites using the same model could purchase copies of the custom interface.

几乎同样紧迫的是编写允许整个网络中的主机相互通信的软件的更大挑战。这就是主机到主机协议，这是一套非常广泛的操作术语，适用于所有机器。它必须像旅行支票一样：在任何地方都有效，并且能够支持从远程登录到文件传输到文本处理等一系列应用程序。发明它并不容易。

Nearly as urgent was the more far-reaching challenge of writing the software that allowed host computers throughout the network to communicate with one another. This was to be the host-to-host protocol, a very broad based set of operating terms that would be common to all machines. It had to be like a traveler’s check: good anywhere and able to support a gamut of applications, from remote log-ins to file transfers to text processing. Inventing it wouldn’t be easy.

寻找协议

The Search for Protocols

1968 年夏天，来自首批四个主办地点（加州大学洛杉矶分校、斯坦福研究院、加州大学圣巴巴拉分校和犹他大学）的一小群研究生在圣巴巴拉会面。他们知道网络正在规划中，但除此之外，他们知之甚少。但网络总体而言，尤其是 ARPA 实验，都是热门话题。

In the summer of 1968, a small group of graduate students from the first four host sites— UCLA, SRI, UC Santa Barbara, and the University of Utah—had met in Santa Barbara. They knew that the network was being planned, but they’d been given few details beyond that. But networking in general, and the ARPA experiment in particular, were hot topics.

这次会议意义重大，因为它激发了人们的热情。“我们有很多问题 — IMP 和主机如何连接，主机之间会说什么，以及将支持哪些应用程序，”Crocker 说。“没有人能给出答案，但前景似乎令人兴奋。我们发现自己在想象各种可能性 — 交互式图形、协作流程、自动数据库查询、电子邮件 — 但没有人知道从哪里开始。”

The meeting was seminal, if only because of the enthusiasm it generated. “We had lots of questions—how IMPs and hosts would be connected, what hosts would say to each other, and what applications would be supported,” Crocker said. “No one had any answers, but the prospects seemed exciting. We found ourselves imagining all kinds of possibilities— interactive graphics, cooperating processes, automatic database query, electronic mail— but no one knew where to begin.”

从那次会议开始，一批年轻的研究人员开始致力于研究、思考和规划网络主机到主机的通信。为了加快进程，他们决定定期会面。理论上，计算机网络可以减少 ARPA 资助的部分旅行，但不久之后，克罗克的旅行次数就太多了，克莱因罗克不得不为他单独准备旅行预算。

From that meeting emerged a corps of young researchers devoted to working on, thinking through, and scheming about the network’s host-to-host communications. To speed up the process, they decided to meet regularly. Theoretically, a computer network would cut down on some of the ARPA-funded travel, but before long Crocker was traveling enough that Kleinrock had to procure a separate travel budget for him.

新小组开始开会后大约一个月，克罗克和其他人意识到，他们最好开始收集讨论记录。如果会议本身没有定论，也许写下来有助于理清思路。克罗克自愿写下最初的会议记录。他是一个非常体贴的年轻人，对别人很敏感。“我记得当时非常害怕我们会冒犯官方礼仪设计者。”当然，没有官方礼仪设计者，但克罗克不知道。当时他和朋友住在一起，整晚都在写第一份记录，在浴室里写，以免吵醒家里的任何人。他并不担心自己想说什么，而是想找到合适的语气。“基本规则是任何人都可以说任何话，没有什么是官方的。”

A month or so after the new group began meeting, it became clear to Crocker and others that they had better start accumulating notes on the discussions. If the meetings themselves were less than conclusive, perhaps the act of writing something down would help order their thoughts. Crocker volunteered to write the first minutes. He was an extremely considerate young man, sensitive to others. “I remember having great fear that we would offend whoever the official protocol designers were.” Of course, there were no official protocol designers, but Crocker didn’t know that. He was living with friends at the time and worked all night on the first note, writing in the bathroom so as not to wake anyone in the house. He wasn’t worried about what he wanted to say so much as he wanted to strike just the right tone. “The basic ground rules were that anyone could say anything and that nothing was official.”

为了避免听起来过于直白，他将便条标记为“征求意见”，并于 1969 年 4 月 7 日发出。便条的标题为“主机软件”，它像所有第一批征求意见 (RFC) 一样分发给其他站点：放在信封里，盖上邮票。RFC 1 号用技术术语描述了两台计算机之间的基本“握手”——如何处理最基本的连接。事实证明，“征求意见”是一个完美的标题选择。它听起来既关切又严肃。而且它很贴切。

To avoid sounding too declarative, he labeled the note “Request for Comments” and sent it out on April 7, 1969. Titled “Host Software,” the note was distributed to the other sites the way all the first Requests for Comments (RFCs) were distributed: in an envelope with the lick of a stamp. RFC Number 1 described in technical terms the basic “handshake” between two computers—how the most elemental connections would be handled. “Request for Comments,” it turned out, was a perfect choice of titles. It sounded at once solicitous and serious. And it stuck.

“当你读到 RFC 1 时，你会有一种感觉，‘哦，这是一个俱乐部，

“我也可以加入，”后来成为卡内基梅隆大学研究生的 Brian Reid 回忆道。“它有规则，但欢迎其他成员，只要他们知道这些规则。” RFC 的语言温暖而热情。其理念是促进合作，而不是自负。克罗克在第一个 RFC 中保持了自负，这一事实树立了风格，并激励其他人在随后的数百个友好合作的 RFC 中效仿。“不可能低估这一点的重要性，”Reid 断言。“我并没有感到被一小群协议之王排除在外。我感到被一群友好的人接纳，他们认识到网络的目的就是让每个人参与进来。”多年来（直到今天），RFC 一直是计算机网络社区公开表达的主要手段，是推荐、审查和采用新技术标准的公认方式。

I can play in too,’” recalled Brian Reid, later a graduate student at Carnegie-Mellon. “It has rules, but it welcomes other members as long as the members are aware of those rules.” The language of the RFC was warm and welcoming. The idea was to promote cooperation, not ego. The fact that Crocker kept his ego out of the first RFC set the style and inspired others to follow suit in the hundreds of friendly and cooperative RFCs that followed. “It is impossible to underestimate the importance of that,” Reid asserted. “I did not feel excluded by a little core of protocol kings. I felt included by a friendly group of people who recognized that the purpose of networking was to bring everybody in.” For years afterward (and to this day) RFCs have been the principal means of open expression in the computer networking community, the accepted way of recommending, reviewing, and adopting new technical standards.

不久之后，这个团体开始自称为网络工作组（NWG）。它是该国年轻且才华横溢的通信程序员的高级委员会。它的主要挑战是原则上就协议达成一致——如何共享资源、如何传输数据、如何完成工作。实际上，这意味着编写程序，或者至少采用某些程序编写规则，这些规则必须得到大多数人的同意。达成一致是必要条件。这是一个平等的社区。他们都可以编写代码——或者重写别人写的代码。NWG 是一个由极富创造力、睡眠不足、个性鲜明、善意的计算机天才组成的临时组织。他们总是半期待着，随时会有人礼貌地感谢他们的工作，并迅速被他们想象中的该领域真正的专业人士取代。没有人告诉他们，他们是最正式的。 RFC 是一种向任何人开放的文档分发简单机制，它对思想传播的速度以及网络文化的传播具有克罗克所描述的“一级效应”。

Before long, the assemblage began calling itself the Network Working Group, or NWG. It was a high commission for the country’s young and exceptionally talented communication programmers. Its main challenge was to agree in principle about protocols—how to share resources, how to transfer data, how to get things done. In real terms, that meant writing programs, or at least adopting certain rules for the way programs got written, rules to which a majority could consent. Agreement was thesine qua non.This was a community of equals. They could all write code—or rewrite the code someone else had written. The NWG was an adhocracy of intensely creative, sleepdeprived, idiosyncratic, well-meaning computer geniuses. And they always half-expected, any day, to be politely thanked for their work and promptly replaced by others whom they imagined to be the field’s true professionals. There was no one to tell them that they were as official as it got. The RFC, a simple mechanism for distributing documentation open to anybody, had what Crocker described as a “first-order effect” on the speed at which ideas were disseminated, and on spreading the networking culture.

为迎接网络建设，网络工作组继续定期开会，新术语和新发明经常通过协商一致的方式出现。基于网络用户之间需要集体协商，“协议”一词进入了计算机网络语言。长期以来，该词一直用于外交礼仪和某些外交协议。但在古希腊语中，protokollon 的意思是卷轴的第一页，即附在纸莎草卷轴顶部的扉页，其中包含手稿的概要、其真实性和日期。事实上，指卷轴顶部的单词与数据包的报头非常吻合，数据包中包含地址信息的部分。但一个不太正式的含义似乎更合适。“协议的另一个定义是，它是各方之间的手写协议，通常在午餐袋的背面制定，”瑟夫评论道，“这非常准确地描述了大多数协议设计是如何完成的。”

Anticipating the construction of the network, the Network Working Group continued meeting regularly, and new terms and inventions often emerged by consensus. The very word “protocol” found its way into the language of computer networking based on the need for collective agreement among network users. For a long time the word has been used for the etiquette of diplomacy and for certain diplomatic agreements. But in ancient Greek,protokollonmeant the first leaf of a volume, a flyleaf attached to the top of a papyrus scroll that contained a synopsis of the manuscript, its authentication, and the date. Indeed, the word referring to the top of a scroll corresponded well to a packet’s header, the part of the packet containing address information. But a less formal meaning seemed even more fitting. “The other definition of protocol is that it’s a handwritten agreement between parties, typically worked out on the back of a lunch bag,” Cerf remarked, “which describes pretty accurately how most of the protocol designs were done.”

但是网络工作组的最初几次会议成果并不多。在 1969 年春夏期间，该小组继续努力解决主机协议设计问题。每个人都对计算机间通信的潜力抱有憧憬，但没有人坐下来构建可以实际使用的协议。BBN 的工作不是担心这个问题。BBN 成员对计划中的 IMP 子网络做出的唯一承诺是它将来回移动数据包，并确保它们到达目的地。主机完全需要弄清楚如何与另一台主机通信，或者在收到消息后如何处理它们。这被称为“主机到主机”协议。

But the first few meetings of the Network Working Group were less than productive. Over the course of the spring and summer of 1969, the group continued struggling with the problems of host-protocol design. Everyone had a vision of the potential for intercomputer communication, but no one had ever sat down to construct protocols that could actually be used. It wasn’t BBN’s job to worry about that problem. The only promise anyone from BBN had made about the planned-for subnetwork of IMPs was that it would move packets back and forth, and make sure they got to their destination. It was entirely up to the host computer to figure out how to communicate with another host computer or what to do with the messages once it received them. This was called the “host-to-host” protocol.

计算机本身是极其自我中心的设备。当时典型的大型机表现得好像它是宇宙中唯一的计算机。没有明显或简单的方法可以让两台不同的机器进行哪怕是来回移动比特所需的最低限度的通信。你可以连接机器，但一旦连接起来，它们会互相说什么？在那些日子里，计算机与连接到它的设备交互，就像君主与臣民交流一样。连接到主计算机的所有设备都执行特定的任务，并且每个外围设备都被认为随时准备执行“拿我的拖鞋”类型的命令。（在计算机术语中，这种关系称为主从通信。）计算机是专门为这种交互而设计的；它们向下属的读卡器、终端和磁带单元发送指令，并发起所有对话。但是，如果另一台设备实际上拍了拍计算机的肩膀，发出信号说：“嗨，我也是一台计算机”，接收机器就会不知所措。设计主机到主机协议的目标是让大型计算机能够作为对等体进行通信，这样双方都可以发起简单的对话，而另一方则可以至少确认另一台机器的存在并做出响应。

The computers themselves were extremely egocentric devices. The typical mainframe of the period behaved as if it were the only computer in the universe. There was no obvious or easy way to engage two diverse machines in even the minimal communication needed to move bits back and forth. You could connect machines, but once connected, what would they say to each other? In those days a computer interacted with the devices that were attached to it, like a monarch communicating with his subjects. Everything connected to the main computer performed a specific task, and each peripheral device was presumed to be ready at all times for a fetch-my-slippers type of command. (In computer parlance, this relationship is known as master-slave communication.) Computers were strictly designed for this kind of interaction; they send instructions to subordinate card readers, terminals, and tape units, and they initiate all dialogues. But if another device in effect tapped the computer on the shoulder with a signal that said, “Hi, I’m a computer, too,” the receiving machine would be stumped. The goal in devising the host-to-host protocol was to get the mainframe machines talking as peers, so that either side could initiate a simple dialogue and the other would be ready to respond with at least an acknowledgment of the other machine’s existence.

史蒂夫·克罗克 (Steve Crocker) 曾将主机到主机协议的概念比作发明 2x4 木板。“你想象着城市、建筑和房屋等，但你看到的只有树木和森林。在某个时候，你发现 2x4 木板是中间的构建块，于是你说，好吧，我可以从所有这些树中得到 2x4 木板，”克罗克回忆道。“我们当时没有 2x4 木板的等效概念，没有让所有计算机说话的基本协议，也不知道它对构建所有应用程序有用。”网络工作组试图发明的就是 2x4 木板的计算机等效物。

Steve Crocker once likened the concept of a host-to-host protocol to the invention of twoby-fours. “You imagine cities and buildings and houses, and so forth, but all you see are trees and forest. And somewhere along the way, you discover two-by-fours as an intermediate building block, and you say, well, I can get two-by-fours out of all these trees,” Crocker recalled. “We didn’t have the concept of an equivalent of a two-by-four, the basic protocols for getting all the computers to speak, and which would be useful for building all the applications.” The computer equivalent of a two-by-four was what the Network Working Group was trying to invent.

在构思协议时，NWG 成员必须问自己几个基本问​​题。共同基础应采用什么形式？是否应该有一个单一的基础协议来构建所有应用协议？还是应该更复杂、细分、分层、分支？无论他们选择哪种结构，他们都知道他们希望它尽可能开放、适应性强并易于创新。一般观点是，任何协议都是潜在的构建块，因此最好的方法是定义简单的协议，每个协议的范围都有限，并期望其中任何一个协议将来都可能以各种意想不到的方式连接或修改。NWG 采用的协议设计理念开创了后来被广泛接受的“分层”协议方法。

In conceiving the protocol, the NWG members had to ask themselves a few basic questions. What form should the common base take? Should there be a single, foundational protocol on which to build all application protocols? Or should it be more complex, subdivided, layered, branched? Whatever structure they chose, they knew they wanted it to be as open, adaptable, and accessible to inventiveness as possible. The general view was that any protocol was a potential building block, and so the best approach was to define simple protocols, each limited in scope, with the expectation that any of them might someday be joined or modified in various unanticipated ways. The protocol design philosophy adopted by the NWG broke ground for what came to be widely accepted as the “layered” approach to protocols.

在主机之间构建底层协议的最重要的目标之一是能够将数据包流从一台计算机移动到另一台计算机，而不必担心数据包中的内容。底层的工作只是移动通用的未识别位，而不管这些位可能定义什么：文件、两个终端之间的交互会话、图形图像或任何其他可以想象的数字数据形式。类似地，水龙头里的一些水用于煮咖啡，一些用于洗碗，一些用于洗澡，但管道和水龙头并不关心；它们无论如何都会输送水。主机到主机协议在网络基础设施中执行基本相同的功能。

One of the most important goals of building the lower-layer protocol between hosts was to be able to move a stream of packets from one computer to another without having to worry about what was inside the packets. The job of the lower layer was simply to move generic unidentified bits, regardless of what the bits might define: a file, an interactive session between people at two terminals, a graphical image, or any other conceivable form of digital data. Analogously, some water out of the tap is used for making coffee, some for washing dishes, and some for bathing, but the pipe and faucet don’t care; they convey the water regardless. The host-to-host protocol was to perform essentially the same function in the infrastructure of the network.

设计主机到主机协议并不是该小组面临的唯一任务。NWG 还必须编写用于特定任务（例如传输文件）的网络应用程序。随着讨论的重点逐渐明确，他们决定前两个应用程序应用于远程登录和文件传输。

Designing the host-to-host protocol wasn’t the only job before the group. The NWG also had to write the network applications for specific tasks such as transferring files. As the talks grew more focused, it was decided that the first two applications should be for remote log-ins and file transfers.

1969 年春天，就在克莱因罗克和 UCLA 主机团队预计收到第一台 IMP 的几个月前，他们收到了一封来自剑桥的厚厚的信封。UCLA 的家伙们早就盼着它了。信封里是 BBN 报告 1822，这是一套新编写的规范，用于将主机连接到即将交付的 IMP。ARPA 网络似乎终于要建成了。

In the spring of 1969, a few months before Kleinrock and the UCLA host team were expecting to receive the first IMP, a thick envelope arrived from Cambridge. The guys at UCLA had been anticipating it. Inside the package was BBN Report 1822, the newly written set of specifications for connecting host computers to the soon-to-be-delivered IMPs. The ARPA network finally seemed to be coming into place.

经过数月的猜测，加州大学洛杉矶分校的团队现在知道了他们应该如何准备站点并构建硬件接口。BBN 报告 1822 还指示站点创建一个称为设备驱动程序的软件（用于控制外围设备的代码和表的集合）来操作主机到 IMP 接口。最后，BBN 发布的规范明确了 IMP 和主机之间的界限。很明显，BBN 计划不在 IMP 中包含任何用于执行主机到主机通信的特殊软件。这个问题将一劳永逸地留给主机，从而留给 NWG。

After months of guessing, the UCLA team now learned what it was expected to do to get its site ready and build its hardware interface. BBN Report 1822 also instructed the sites in creating a piece of software called a device driver—a collection of code and tables for controlling a peripheral device—to operate the host-to-IMP interface. And, finally, BBN’s issuance of the specifications clarified the boundary between the IMP and the host. It was clear that BBN planned to include no special software in the IMP for performing host-to-host communication. That problem would be left, once and for all, to the host computer and, thus, to the NWG.

这意味着洛杉矶的学生们要在暑假里做很多工作。他们认为自己可能能够及时完成主机到 IMP 接口的构建。但编写主机到主机协议已经让克罗克、瑟夫和整个网络工作组停滞了几个月。他们决定告诉每个站点暂时拼凑自己的临时协议，而不是急于赶工。

This meant a lot of summertime work for the students in Los Angeles. They thought they might be able to finish building the host-to-IMP interface in time. But writing the host-tohost protocol had already stalled Crocker, Cerf, and the entire Network Working Group for months. Rather than try to rush something out in time, they decided to tell every site to patch together its own makeshift protocols for the time being.

加州大学洛杉矶分校要求 Sigma-7 制造商 Scientific Data Systems 的技术人员为其主机到 IMP 连接构建接口硬件。该公司的回应令人沮丧：这将花费数月时间，并且可能无法在 IMP 到货前完成。此外，该公司要求为这项工作支付数万美元。因此，当一个名叫 Mike Wing-field 的研究生要求这份工作时，他得到了这份工作。为什么不呢？Wingfield 是硬件方面的专家，刚刚为另一台计算机构建了一个复杂的图形界面。

UCLA asked technicians at Scientific Data Systems, makers of the Sigma-7, to build the interface hardware for their host-to-IMP connection. The company’s response was discouraging: It would take months and probably wouldn’t be finished in time for the IMP’s arrival. Moreover, the company wanted tens of thousands of dollars for the job. So when a graduate student named Mike Wing-field asked for the job, he got it. And why not? Wingfield was a whiz at hardware and had just finished building a complex graphics interface for another computer.

BBN 为主机与 IMP 之间的相互作用和连接制定的规范是一份出色的蓝图。这份文档由鲍勃·卡恩以晶莹的散文形式撰写，可以说是一本食谱，并附有详细的图表。卡恩的规范为温菲尔德提供了将 Sigma-7 与 IMP 配对的基本要求。温菲尔德几乎还没反应过来，夏天就过去了，接口已经顺利建成。

BBN’s specification for the host-to-IMP interactions and connections was a splendid blueprint. A cookbook of sorts, written by Bob Kahn in crystalline prose, the document was accompanied by detailed diagrams. Kahn’s specification gave Wingfield the basic requirements for mating the Sigma-7 to an IMP. Almost before Wingfield knew it, the summer had flown by and the interface had been built without a hitch.

在 IMP 预计于 9 月 1 日抵达的一周前，Wingfield 完成了硬件的调试，并准备好连接到 IMP。Crocker 对此印象深刻，他将其描述为一件“华丽”的作品。但是，为了完成通信软件，Crocker 落后了。他本来就有拖延的倾向，而 IMP 的缺席只会助长这种倾向。

现在，像任何试图超越最后期限的人一样，Crocker 看了看日历并做了一些计算。他指望至少能多一天，因为 9 月 1 日是劳动节。此外，他听说 BBN 在 IMP 的正时链方面遇到了一些问题。同步器错误非常严重。他们的错误是他的好运，他想，如果运气好的话，它甚至可以为他赢得一两个星期的时间。因此，当 Len Kleinrock 告诉他 BBN 即将把 IMP 装上飞机，并于 8 月 30 日星期六（提前两天）抵达洛杉矶时，他感到非常惊讶。

One week before the IMP was scheduled to arrive on September 1, Wingfield had the hardware finished, debugged, and ready to connect to the IMP. Crocker was so impressed he described it as a “gorgeous” piece of work. But, trying to get the communications software done, Crocker was running behind. He had a tendency to procrastinate anyway, and the absence of the actual IMP had only encouraged this tendency.

Now, like anyone trying to outsmart a deadline, Crocker looked at the calendar and did a few calculations. He counted on having at least one extra day, since September 1 was Labor Day. Moreover, he had heard BBN was having some troubles with the IMP’s timing chain. Synchronizer bugs were horribly nasty. Their bug was his good fortune, and with a little luck it might even buy him an extra week or two, he thought. So he was more than mildly surprised when Len Kleinrock told him that BBN was about to put the IMP on an airplane due to arrive in Los Angeles on Saturday, August 30, two days early.

在剑桥，弗兰克·哈特全神贯注于如何将 IMP 运往 UCLA。经过几天的争论，哈特决定通过空运，本·巴克也应该随行。商业航班是不可能的。经过改装的霍尼韦尔 516（现在正式称为 BBN 接口信息处理器一号）对于客机的货舱来说太大了。它必须通过空运。如果哈特能做到，他会直接把巴克铐在 IMP 上，把他塞进货机的货舱里。别忘了他之所以选择这台机器，正是因为它身经百战；战斗的严酷性与航空货运人员所能施加的惩罚相比微不足道。“他希望有人在那里，对货运人员大喊大叫，确保他们没有疏忽大意，”巴克回忆道。但巴克必须单独乘坐商业客机。 BBN 洛杉矶办事处的技术员 Truett Thach 将被要求迎接飞机。

In Cambridge, Frank Heart was preoccupied with the question of how best to ship the IMP to UCLA. After debating for a couple of days, Heart decreed that it should go by air, and that Ben Barker should go with it. A commercial flight was out of the question. The modified Honeywell 516—now officially BBN Interface Message Processor Number One—was just too big for the cargo bay of a passenger plane. It had to go out by air freight. Had Heart been able to, he would have put Barker straight into the cargo plane’s hold with his wrist handcuffed to the IMP. Never mind that he had chosen the machine precisely because it was battle-hardened; the rigors of combat were nothing compared to the punishment airline freight handlers could dish out. “He wanted somebody to be there, yelling at the cargo people to make sure they weren’t careless with it,” Barker recalled. But Barker would have to travel separately on a commercial passenger flight. Truett Thach, a technician in BBN’s Los Angeles office, would be told to meet the plane.

IMP 装箱后，巴克用红色记号笔在箱子侧面用大号字母写上“DO IT TO IT TRUET”。它被装上一架从波士顿洛根机场起飞的早班飞机，当天下午，萨奇在洛杉矶国际机场接机。当他在一名货运搬运工的陪同下到达时，他松了一口气地看着箱子从飞机上下来，但当他注意到巴克给他的信是倒着的时，他感到震惊。“在途中，IMP 被倒置了奇数次，”他观察到。萨奇让托运人把箱子摆正，然后把它装上卡车。然后他跟着他们去了加州大学洛杉矶分校。

Once the IMP was crated, Barker took a red Magic Marker and in large letters wroteDO IT TO IT TRUETTon the side of the crate. It was loaded onto an early-morning flight out of Boston’s Logan Airport, and Thach was there to meet it at LAX that afternoon. When he arrived, accompanied by a freight mover, he was relieved to watch the crate come off the plane but appalled when he noticed that Barker’s message to him was upside down. “Somewhere along the way, the IMP had been inverted an odd number of times,” he observed. Thach had the shippers right the box before loading it on their truck. Then he followed them to UCLA.

那是劳动节前的星期六，萨奇注意到从韦斯特伍德一直到校园的街道都异常安静。巴克已经和其他十几个人一起在博尔特大厅的装卸码头上等着了——克莱因罗克、克罗克、波斯特尔、温菲尔德、文特和西格丽德·瑟夫，还有几个好奇的游客。瑟夫夫妇带来了一些香槟。看到板条箱后，有人立即提出一个问题，板条箱是否能装进电梯；IMP 被拆开，以便塞进去。

It was the Saturday before Labor Day and Thach noticed the streets were unusually quiet all the way through Westwood and onto the campus. Barker was already waiting on the loading dock at Boelter Hall with about a dozen other people—Kleinrock, Crocker, Postel, Wingfield, Vint and Sigrid Cerf, and a handful of curiosity seekers. The Cerfs had brought along some champagne. Immediately upon seeing the crate, someone raised a question as to whether the crate would fit into the elevator; the IMP was unpacked so it could be wedged in.

当机器从板条箱中取出时，欢迎者对它的大小感到惊讶。虽然它比 Sigma-7 小，但不是一个小设备。它大约有冰箱那么大，重 900 多磅，坚固地包裹在战舰灰色的钢中，完全符合军用规格。IMP 顶部有四个钢制吊环螺栓，可以通过起重机或直升机将其吊到船上。在加州大学洛杉矶分校，IMP 就像一个身穿战斗服的士兵闯入教职员工聚会。

当电梯到达三楼时，搬运工将机器推到走廊尽头，绕过拐角，进入 3400 房间的新家。Sigma-7 在附近嗡嗡作响，对即将侵犯其隐私的巨大干扰毫不在意。“这有点像看到你的父母邀请一个你从未见过的人共进晚餐，”克罗克说。“你不会太在意，直到你发现他们真的打算把你嫁给这个陌生人。”

When the machine was removed from the crate, the welcoming party was surprised by its size. Though smaller than the Sigma-7, it was not a small device. It was roughly the size of a refrigerator, weighing more than nine hundred pounds, and was formidably encased in battleship-gray steel, exactly to military specifications. There were four steel eyebolts on top of the IMP for lifting it onto a ship by crane or helicopter. At UCLA the IMP was like a soldier in combat fatigues crashing a faculty party.

When the elevator reached the third floor, the freight movers wheeled the machine down the hall and around the corner to its new home in room 3400. The Sigma-7 hummed nearby, oblivious to the massive disturbance that was about to invade its privacy. “It was a little like seeing your parents invite to dinner someone you’ve never met,” Crocker said. “You don’t pay much attention until you discover they actually intend to marry you off to this stranger.”

塔奇和巴克花了几分钟为 IMP 接线并通电。机器的核心内存立刻知道该做什么：它从剑桥中断的地方继续运行，运行 IMP 专家为其编写的诊断程序。接下来，迈克·温菲尔德连接了他的接口。由于这是节点一号，因此没有网络可以测试它。但巴克可以在 Sigma-7 和 IMP 之间进行分流实验，就像他们在莫尔顿街的机器之间做过很多次以模拟网络链接一样。一小时内，Sigma-7 和 IMP 就可以来回传递数据，就像它们已经这样做了很多年一样。

Thach and Barker spent a few minutes cabling the IMP and powering it. Instantly the machine’s core memory knew just what to do: It picked up just where it had left off in Cambridge, running the diagnostics that the IMP Guys had written for it. Next, Mike Wingfield attached his interface. Since this was node number one, there wasn’t a networkper seon which to test it. But Barker could do shunting experiments between the Sigma-7 and the IMP as they had done many times at Moulton Street between machines to simulate network links. Within an hour the Sigma-7 and the IMP were passing data back and forth as if they had been doing so for years.

巴克仍然不能完全确定同步器问题是否已经解决。但他有足够的信心考虑回家。那天晚上，巴克打电话给 Heart。“我们搞定了，一切都正常了，”他说。“现在正在和迈克（温菲尔德）的团队沟通。我打算明天早上坐飞机回家。”

Barker was still not absolutely certain that the synchronizer problem had been solved. But he was confident enough to consider going home. That night, Barker called Heart. “We’re done, it’s all working,” he said. “It’s talking to Mike’s [Wingfield] stuff. I’m thinking of getting a flight home in the morning.”

哈特停顿了一下，巴克感觉到了接下来会发生什么。“你为什么不在那里待几天？”哈特回答道。“只是看看会不会出什么问题。”巴克花了三天时间与撒奇一起放松，游览洛杉矶，等待 IMP 坠毁。但 IMP 并没有坠毁。

Heart paused, and Barker sensed what might be coming. “Why don’t you just hang out there a few days?” Heart responded. “Just to see if something goes wrong.” Barker spent three days relaxing with Thach, touring Los Angeles, and waiting for the IMP to crash. It didn’t.

真实的网络

A Real Network

在 UCLA 安装第一台 IMP 一个月后，IMP 2 号于 1969 年 10 月 1 日准时抵达 SRI。同月，鲍勃·泰勒离开了 ARPA。他早已不再参与网络项目的细节工作。正如他所解释的那样，在 20 世纪 60 年代，“ARPA”是一个神奇的词。泰勒的办公室经常被要求解决其他人无法解决的问题。1967 年和 1968 年，泰勒多次被派往越南，帮助解决由军事信息中心处理的陆军“尸体数量”报告的争议等问题。这段经历让泰勒精疲力竭。他去了犹他大学任职。

A month after the first IMP was installed at UCLA, IMP Number Two arrived at SRI, right on schedule on October 1, 1969. That same month, Bob Taylor left ARPA. He had long since removed himself from the details of the network project. As he explained it, in the 1960s, “ARPA” was a magic word. Taylor’s office was often called upon to sort out problems that others couldn’t. In 1967 and 1968, Taylor had been sent repeatedly to Vietnam to help straighten out, among other things, the controversy over the Army’s “body count” reports handled by the military information centers. The experience had left Taylor burned out. He took a post at the University of Utah.

到目前为止，网络实验已经取得了许多里程碑：泰勒获得了资金支持，并成功说服了罗伯茨；罗伯茨提出了网络概念；BBN 建造并交付了第一台 IMP。但 IMP 2 号的安装标志着迄今为止最重要的成就。研究人员终于可以将两台不同的计算机连接起来，让它们像一对老战友一样互相交谈。

Many milestones in the network experiment had been passed so far: Taylor’s funding victory and successful wooing of Roberts; Roberts’s network concept; BBN’s construction and delivery of the first IMP. But the installation of IMP Number Two marked the most important achievement to date. At last the researchers could connect two disparate computers and get them talking to each other like a couple of old comrades.

和之前的 UCLA 团队一样，SRI 团队也为 IMP 的到来而疯狂准备。两个站点之间的一个关键区别是，UCLA 团队不喜欢他们的 Sigma-7，而 SRI 团队则喜欢他们的主机 SDS 940。和 Sigma-7 一样，940 也是由 Scientific Data Systems 制造的。但 Sigma-7 是作为商用处理器设计的，而 940 基本上是一种学术设备，是一种革命性的分时系统，最初由一组伯克利研究人员组装而成，后来以 SDS 的名义出售。因此，它的编程比 Sigma-7 有趣得多。

Like the UCLA team earlier, SRI’s group had a similar mad scramble getting ready for the arrival of the IMP. One crucial difference between the two sites was that whereas the UCLA guys disliked their Sigma-7, the SRI guys loved their host computer, an SDS 940. Like the Sigma-7, the 940 was built by Scientific Data Systems. But the Sigma-7 had been designed as a commercial processor, whereas the 940 was basically an academic device, a revolutionary time-sharing system first put together by a team of Berkeley researchers, later to be sold under the SDS nameplate. As a result, it was far more fun to program than the Sigma-7.

SRI 研究员 Bill Duvall 花了大约一个月的时间，为 940 编写了一个巧妙的程序，该程序基本上欺骗了它，使它以为它不是在与另一台计算机通信，而是在与一个“哑”终端通信。哑终端既不能计算也不能存储信息；它只能显示与其链接的计算机发送给它的最新信息集。Duvall 的程序是针对主机到主机通信问题的一个非常具体的临时解决方案。数周以来，加州大学洛杉矶分校的研究人员一直在为他们的第一个登录会话做准备，他们实际上使用调制解调器和电传打字机远程拨号接入 SRI 系统，以熟悉 SRI 的分时系统。现在两个 IMP 都已到位，两个主机都在运行，测试实际的双节点 ARPA 网络的时刻终于到来了。

Bill Duvall, an SRI researcher, spent about a month writing a clever program for the 940 that essentially fooled it into thinking it was communicating not with another computer but with a “dumb” terminal. A dumb terminal can neither compute nor store information; it serves only to display the most recent set of information sent to it by the computer to which it’s linked. Duvall’s program was a very specific interim solution to the host-tohost communication problem. For weeks, the UCLA researchers had been preparing for their first log-in session by actually dialing into the SRI system long-distance using a modem and a teletype, to familiarize themselves with SRI’s time-sharing system. With both IMPs now in place, and both hosts running, the moment to test the actual two–node ARPA network had finally arrived.

当然，要做的第一件事就是连接。与当今大多数要求用户输入登录名和密码的系统不同，SRI 系统会等待命令后才确认连接。“LOGIN”就是其中一条命令。

The first thing to do, of course, was to connect. Unlike most systems today, which prompt the user for a log-in name and password, the SRI system waited for a command before acknowledging a connection. “L-O-G-I-N” was one of those commands.

第一个 IMP 上像藤壶一样固定着一个类似电话的小盒子，里面有电线和耳机。它与 IMP 共享线路，并使用用于语音对话的子信道。语音线路与数据线路一样，是一条专用链路。IMP 在 SRI 安装几天后，当时在加州大学洛杉矶分校读本科的查理·克莱恩 (Charley Kline) 拿起洛杉矶的电话耳机，按下按钮，门洛帕克的 IMP 上响起了铃声。SRI 恩格尔巴特小组的一名研究员接了电话。对克莱恩来说，这比拨打普通电话更令人兴奋。

Fastened to the first IMPs like a barnacle was a small phonelike box, with a cord and headset. It shared the line with the IMPs and used a subchannel intended for voice conversations. The voice line was, like the data line, a dedicated link. A few days after the IMP was in place at SRI, Charley Kline, then an undergraduate at UCLA, picked up the telephone headset in L.A. and pressed a button that rang a bell on the IMP in Menlo Park. A researcher in Engelbart’s group at SRI answered it. It was somehow more thrilling to Kline than dialing a regular telephone.

网络连接质量不太好，而且两人都坐在嘈杂的机房里，这更不利于通话。于是克莱恩对着话筒大声喊道：“我要打一个L！”克莱恩打出了一个L。

The quality of the connection was not very good, and both men were sitting in noisy computer rooms, which didn’t help. So Kline fairly yelled into the mouthpiece: “I’m going to type anL!” Kline typed anL.

“你读出L 了吗？ ”他问道。“我读出 114，”SRI 研究员回答道；他正在读取八进制编码信息，八进制编码使用以 8 为基数的数字表示。当克莱恩进行转换时，他发现传输的确实是L。他输入了一个O。

“Did you get the L?” he asked. “I got one-one-four,” the SRI researcher replied; he was reading off the encoded information in octal, a code using numbers expressed in base 8. When Kline did the conversion, he saw it was indeed anLthat had been transmitted. He typed anO.

“你拿到 O了吗？ ”他问道。

“我得到了 117，”回复来了。这是一个O。克莱恩输入了一个G。

“I got one-one-seven,” came the reply. It was an O. Kline typed aG.

“计算机崩溃了，”SRI 的那位人士说。这次故障是由于 Duvall 的巧妙编程造成的。一旦 SRI 机器识别出字母 LOG，它就会完成这个单词。“我认为错误就出在这里，”Kline 回忆道。“当 SRI 940 系统收到 G 时，它试图发回“GIN”，而终端程序还没有准备好一次处理多个字符。”

当天晚些时候，他们又试了一次。这一次它运行得非常完美。Crocker、Cerf 和 Postel 去了 Kleinrock 的办公室告诉他这件事，以便他可以亲自来看看。回到 UCLA 实验室后，Kline 登录到 SRI 机器，并能够在 940 的分时系统上执行命令。门洛帕克的 SRI 计算机的反应就像洛杉矶的 Sigma-7 是一个真正的哑终端。

“The computer just crashed,” said the person at SRI. The failure came thanks to a clever bit of programming on Duvall’s part. Once the SRI machine recognized the letters L-O-G, it completed the word. “I think that is where the bug was,” Kline recalled. “When the SRI 940 system received theG,it tried to send back “G-I-N,” and the terminal program wasn’t ready to handle more than one character at a time.”

Later that day they tried again. This time it worked flawlessly. Crocker, Cerf, and Postel went to Kleinrock’s office to tell him about it so he could come see for himself. Back in the UCLA lab Kline logged on to the SRI machine and was able to execute commands on the 940’s time-sharing system. The SRI computer in Menlo Park responded as if the Sigma-7 in L.A. was a bona fide dumb terminal.

具有讽刺意味的是，第一个在网络上使用的程序是让远程计算机伪装成终端的程序。为了让两台计算机相互通信，他们付出了巨大的努力，但最终却陷入了网络本应消除的主从局面。不过，技术进步往往始于尝试做一些熟悉的事情。研究人员通过证明我们可以用新技术来做我们理解的事情来建立对新技术的信任。一旦他们做到了这一点，随着人们开始思考得更远，下一步就开始展开。随着人们接受变化，下一代的思想已经开始发展。

There is no small irony in the fact that the first program used over the network was one that made the distant computer masquerade as a terminal. All that work to get two computers talking to each other and they ended up in the very same master-slave situation the network was supposed to eliminate. Then again, technological advances often begin with attempts to do something familiar. Researchers build trust in new technology by demonstrating that we can use it to do things we understand. Once they’ve done that, the next steps begin to unfold, as people start to think even further ahead. As people assimilate change, the next generation of ideas is already evolving.

现在网络已经存在。第一个 ARPA 网络图如下所示：

 

 

11 月 1 日，第三台 IMP 在加州大学圣巴巴拉分校安装完毕。为了安装圣巴巴拉分校的 IMP，巴克再次飞往加州。此时，哈特已经放松了许多。第一次飞行时那种紧张的气氛已经荡然无存。事实上，安装 IMP 已开始成为常规工作。

IMP Number Three was installed at UC Santa Barbara on November 1. For the Santa Barbara installation, Barker flew out to California again. By this time, Heart was more relaxed. There were few traces of the suspense that had attended the first trip. In fact, installing IMPs was beginning to seem routine.

当月晚些时候，拉里·罗伯茨决定飞往加利福尼亚，首次亲自检查网络。罗伯茨不喜欢旅行。即使旅行，他也不会在最后一刻出发赶飞机。这让他的秘书抓狂不已，但人们都记得他只错过一班飞机。那是一天下午，他在前往杜勒斯机场的路上因超速被拦下。罗伯茨确信自己车速不是太快，于是决定对罚单提出异议。他在完全停车后驶入乔治华盛顿公园大道附近被警车拦下，他辩称，在这么短的距离内，他不可能将大众甲壳虫加速到警官指控的速度。罗伯茨回到现场，仔细测量了距离。他收集了大众甲壳虫的发动机输出功率和重量数据，考虑了牛顿惯性定律并做了一些其他计算，准备向法官陈述自己的案情。直到朋友们说服他不可能找到一位拥有物理学学位的法官后，他才承认了这一点，并支付了罚款，而不是上法庭。

Later that month, Larry Roberts decided to fly to California to inspect the network firsthand for the first time. Roberts didn’t like to travel. When he did travel, he never left to catch his plane until the last minute. It drove his secretary crazy, but he missed only one plane that anyone could remember. That happened one afternoon when he was stopped for speeding on his way to Dulles Airport. Convinced that he hadn’t been going too fast, Roberts decided to contest the ticket.
