He had been pulled over by the squad car near the point at which he had come onto the George Washington Parkway after a full stop, and his contention was that in that short distance he could not possibly have accelerated his Volkswagen Beetle to the speed alleged by the officer. Roberts went back to the scene and carefully measured off the distances. He gathered data on the engine output and weight of his VW bug, factored in Newton’s law of inertia and made a few other calculations, and was prepared to go before a judge to make his case. It wasn’t until friends convinced him he was unlikely to get a judge with a physics degree that he conceded the point and paid the fine instead of taking it to court.

幸运的是，这次旅行没有超速罚单。罗伯茨和他的项目经理巴里·韦斯勒平安无事地飞往加利福尼亚，在克莱因罗克位于博尔特大厅的实验室里，他们观察了网络的运行情况。这一次，克莱因罗克负责打字，不到一分钟，他就登录了 SRI 的主机。罗伯茨仔细观察，对实验的成功感到满意。

Fortunately, there were no speeding tickets on this trip. Roberts and his program manager, Barry Wessler, flew to California without incident, and in Kleinrock’s lab at Boelter Hall they watched the network in operation. This time, Kleinrock did the typing and in less than a minute he had logged on to the host computer at SRI. Roberts watched closely and left satisfied that the experiment was succeeding.

第四站是犹他州。此时正值十二月，滑雪旺季。现场还恰好安排了网络工作组会议。BBN 团队的全体成员，甚至 Frank Heart 都热衷于滑雪，前往盐湖城为 IMP 打广告。（讽刺的是，Barker 是唯一一个没有参加犹他州之行的人——这一事实他多年来一直让其他人难以忘怀。）

Fourth was Utah. By now it was December—prime ski season. There also happened to be a Network Working Group meeting scheduled at the site. Keen skiers all, the whole BBN team, even Frank Heart, went to Salt Lake City to plug in the IMP. (Ironically, Barker was the only one excluded from the Utah trip—a fact he would not let the others forget for many years.)

日益增多的通信链路的布局正成为一个有趣的问题。首先，并不是每对站点之间都有点对点链路。出于经济原因，罗伯茨决定加州大学洛杉矶分校和犹他州之间，或圣巴巴拉和犹他州之间不需要直接连接，这样所有发往犹他州的流量都必须通过 SRI 的 IMP。只要它正常运行，那就没问题。如果它崩溃了，网络就会分裂，犹他州就会被切断，直到 SRI 重新上线。事实证明，罗伯茨设计的四节点网络并不是一个强大的冗余连接网络。

The layout of the growing number of communications links was becoming an interesting problem. For one thing, there was not a point-to-point link between every pair of sites. For reasons of economy, Roberts decided that no direct link was needed between UCLA and Utah, or between Santa Barbara and Utah, so that all traffic destined for Utah had to go through the IMP at SRI. That was fine as long as it was up and running. If it crashed, the network would divide and Utah would be cut off until SRI was brought back on-line. As it would turn out, the four-node network that Roberts designed was not a robust web of redundant connections.

系统中断也以不太明显的方式表现出来。这一点很早就显现出来了，当时圣巴巴拉的学生们开始做 Heart 所担心的事情：摆弄他们的新玩具。他们的态度是，为什么不呢？他们从来没有担心过外部连接，也没有想到他们在计算机实验室里做的事情可能会对其他地方产生影响。“我们兴高采烈地认为 IMP 是我们的玩具，”圣巴巴拉研究员罗兰·布莱恩回忆道。“我们测试它，打开和关闭它，重置它，重新加载它，然后重试。”结果，那些正在进行网络测量并依靠通过圣巴巴拉的网络路径的人的实验被打乱了。“虽然我们没有破坏其他站点之间的链接，但我们扰乱了 BBN 和加州大学洛杉矶分校正在进行的数据流量分析，”布莱恩说。“我们没有想到，每次我们这样做，外面的某个人都会受到影响。”

Disruptions in the system also manifested themselves in less obvious ways. This was made clear very early, when the students at Santa Barbara began doing exactly what Heart had feared they might: fiddling with their new toy. And their attitude was, Why not? They had never had to worry about outside connections, and it didn’t occur to them that something they did in their computer lab might have an effect elsewhere. “We merrily thought the IMP was ours to play with,” recalled Roland Bryan, a Santa Barbara researcher. “We were testing it out, turning it on and off, resetting it, reloading it, and trying again.” As a result, people who were taking network measurements, and who counted on the network path through Santa Barbara, would have their experiment thrown off. “Although we did not hurt the links between other sites, we were disrupting the data traffic analysis being carried on by BBN and UCLA,” Bryan said. “We didn’t think about the fact that every time we did that, someone out there would suffer.”

到 1969 年底，网络工作组仍未提出主机到主机协议。迫于压力，该工作组在 12 月与罗伯茨的会议上向 ARPA 展示了一些东西，于是他们提出了一个拼凑起来的协议 — Telnet — 允许远程登录。罗伯茨对这项工作的有限范围感到不满。虽然 Telnet 显然很有用，而且很基础，因为它可以让一个终端访问多台远程计算机，但远程登录程序本身并不能解决让两台计算机协同工作的问题。此外，Telnet 是一种使用网络的方式，而不是一个较低级别的构建块。罗伯茨让他们回去继续尝试。经过一年的会议和几十份 RFC 之后，该小组在 1970 年夏天重新提出了一个用于基本、朴素的主机到主机通信协议的初步版本。一年后，“故障清理委员会”完成工作后，NWG 终于制定了一个完整的协议。它被称为网络控制协议，或 NCP。

By the end of 1969, the Network Working Group still hadn’t come up with a host-to-host protocol. Under duress to show something to ARPA at a meeting with Roberts in December, the group presented a patched-together protocol—Telnet—that allowed for remote log-ins. Roberts was not pleased with the limited scope of the effort. Though Telnet was clearly useful and fundamental in that it let one terminal reach multiple remote computers, a remote login program by itself didn’t solve the problem of letting two computers work together. Moreover, Telnet was a way to use the network, not a lower-level building block. Roberts sent them back to keep trying. After another year of meetings and several dozen RFCs, in the summer of 1970 the group reemerged with a preliminary version of a protocol for basic, unadorned host-to-host communications. When the “glitch-cleaning committee” finished its work a year later, the NWG at last produced a complete protocol. It was called the Network Control Protocol, or NCP.

1970 年 1 月，鲍勃·卡恩决定，在前四个节点正常运行的情况下，是时候测试网络可能遭遇拥塞故障的各种场景了。最让他担心的锁定类型，也就是他几个月前向克劳瑟提出的场景，将由目标 IMP 的拥塞引起。他推测存储缓冲区会变得太满，以至于重组消息所需的数据包无法流入目标 IMP，而目标 IMP 本身将充满等待完成的碎片消息部分。

In January 1970, Bob Kahn decided that with the first four nodes working, it was time to test his various scenarios in which the network could suffer congestive failure. The kind of lockup that most worried him, the scenario he had suggested to Crowther months earlier, would be caused by congestion at a destination IMP. He had speculated that storage buffers would become so full that the packets necessary for reassembling messages wouldn’t be able to flow into a destination IMP, which itself would be filled with dismembered message parts awaiting completion.

为了验证这一假设并安抚卡恩，哈特建议卡恩和戴夫·沃尔登飞往洛杉矶，对网络进行测试。卡恩想了几个实验。他想将所有可能的流量排列从 IMP 发送到 IMP，改变数据包的大小和发送频率，试图引发死锁。沃尔登同意了，因为他是一名动手能力强的程序员，知道如何操纵代码，让数据包按照卡恩的意愿运行。沃尔登负责重新配置 IMP，使其以特定模式发送流量。他可以延长或截断数据包，每三秒或每半秒发送一次。IMP 软件、算法和整个设计都将面临重大考验。

To test that hypothesis and appease Kahn, Heart suggested that Kahn and Dave Walden fly out to Los Angeles to put the network through its paces. Kahn had several experiments in mind. He wanted to send all possible permutations of traffic from IMP to IMP, changing the size of the packets and the frequency at which they were sent, in an attempt to induce deadlock. Walden went along because he was the hands-on programmer who knew how to manipulate the code and make the packets do what Kahn wanted them to do. Walden took charge of reconfiguring the IMPs to send traffic in specific patterns. He could elongate or truncate the packets, send them out every three seconds or every half second. The IMP software, the algorithms, the whole design was in for a major wringing out.

卡恩首先进行的测试是为了证明他对重组死机的担忧是有道理的。正如卡恩所预测的那样，通过用数据包围攻 IMP，几分钟内他和沃尔登就能够迫使网络陷入紧张状态。“我认为我们在前十二个数据包中就做到了，”卡恩回忆道。“整个事情都陷入了停滞。”

The first thing Kahn set up was a test to demonstrate that his fear of a reassembly lockup was well founded. Just as Kahn had predicted, by besieging the IMPs with packets, within a few minutes he and Walden were able to force the network into catatonia. “I think we did it in the first twelve packets,” Kahn recalled. “The whole thing came to a grinding halt.”

卡恩的言论被证明是正确的。他和沃尔登又呆了几天，继续实验。沃尔登曾在剑桥呆了好几个月，在与世隔绝的环境中编写代码，看到网络运行起来，他感到很欣慰，即使他现在的目标是破解它。他玩得很开心。“我是为了赚钱而黑客攻击，”沃尔登回忆道。“我被驱使着尽可能快地学习尽可能多的东西。”

Kahn was vindicated. He and Walden stayed on for a number of days, continuing the experiments. For Walden, who had spent so many months cooped up in Cambridge writing code in a quasi vacuum, it was gratifying to see the network in operation, even if his goal now was to break it. He was having a blast. “I was hacking for pay,” Walden recalled. “I was driven to learn as much as I could as fast as I could.”

卡恩和沃尔登养成了一个习惯。每天早上，他们起床后都会去圣莫尼卡酒店旁边的 Sambo 餐厅吃早餐。沃尔登利用这些早晨来满足他家乡加利福尼亚人对鲜榨橙汁的喜好，这在波士顿仍然很少见。然后他们开车前往加州大学洛杉矶分校，花了一整天和大部分晚上来测试 IMP 的极限。有时他们会在晚餐时间休息；有时他们没有注意到晚餐时间已经过去了。他们休息了一个晚上去看刚刚上映的电影《陆军野战医院》 。

Kahn and Walden established a routine. Every morning, they got up and ate breakfast at the Sambo’s restaurant next to their hotel in Santa Monica. Walden used these mornings as an opportunity to indulge his native Californian’s taste for fresh-squeezed orange juice, still a rarity back in Boston. Then they drove to the UCLA campus and spent all day and much of the evening testing the limits of the IMPs. Sometimes they took a dinner break; sometimes they didn’t notice that dinnertime had come and gone. They took one night off to see the movieM*A*S*H,which had just been released.

瑟夫经常会加入他们，偶尔克罗克和波斯特尔也会加入。在测试的某个阶段，瑟夫对 Sigma-7 进行编程，使其向 IMP 生成流量，并使用主机收集结果数据。这是他第一次在一个具有挑战性的项目上与卡恩密切合作，巩固了双方将持续多年的专业联系。

Often they were joined by Cerf, and occasionally by Crocker and Postel as well. At one point in the testing, Cerf programmed the Sigma-7 to generate traffic to the IMP and used the host machine to gather data on the results. This was the first time he had worked closely with Kahn on a challenging project, cementing a professional link that would last for years to come.

到了周末，卡恩的笔记本上已经写满了数据，可以证明他的观点。当他和沃尔登回到剑桥时，他们与克劳瑟和哈特分享了他们的发现。克劳瑟没有多说什么，但卡恩怀疑，一系列的测试让他开始思考这个问题。“不知何故，克劳瑟一定在脑海里意识到，如果我们两个人回来报告这个问题，那可能就是有问题的，”卡恩说。回到实验室后，克劳瑟模拟了卡恩和沃尔登在现场所做的工作，并亲自发现网络确实可能锁定。他把自己的发现报告给了略显沮丧的哈特，哈特指示克劳瑟和卡恩一起解决这个问题。“鲍勃感觉好多了，弗兰克感觉更糟了，”沃尔登谈到整个事件时说。“当然，弗兰克从不认为事情是完美的，但当事情不顺利时，他总是很沮丧。”

By the end of the week, Kahn’s notebook was filled with data proving his case. When he and Walden returned to Cambridge, they shared their findings with Crowther and Heart. Crowther didn’t say much, but Kahn suspected that the battery of tests caused him to start thinking about the problem. “Somehow Crowther must have registered in the back of his mind that if two of us were coming back and reporting this problem, maybe there was an issue,” Kahn said. Back in the lab, Crowther built a simulation of what Kahn and Walden had done in the field and discovered for himself that the network could indeed lock up. He reported his findings to a slightly crestfallen Heart, who instructed Crowther to work with Kahn on fixing the problem. “Bob got to feel a lot better, and Frank got to feel a little worse,” Walden said of the entire episode. “Of course, Frank never thought the thing was perfect, but he always got discouraged when things didn’t go right.”

Heart 有充分的理由忽略这个新生网络中开始出现的几个缺陷。毕竟，拥塞控制问题可以解决。从更大范围来看，该公司进行了一项冒险的实验，涉及从未测试过的想法和技术。而且它成功了。硬件成功了，软件成功了。ARPA 开展业务的独特方式以及与承包商的关系也成功了。

Heart had every reason to look past the few flaws that were beginning to show up in the nascent network. After all, problems with congestion control could be fixed. On a larger scale, the company had taken on a risky experiment, involving ideas and techniques never tested before. And it had worked. The hardware worked and the software worked. And the unique ways in which ARPA went about its business and its relationship with its contractor worked too.

最重要的是，整个企业赖以生存的深奥概念——分组交换——成功了。关于彻底失败的预测是完全错误的。

6 砍砍杀杀、大声叫喊

6 Hacking Away and Hollering

这个网络是真实存在的，但由于只有四个节点聚集在西海岸，因此其拓扑结构简单，实验规模很小。东海岸的计算中心，如麻省理工学院和林肯实验室，虽然那里发生了许多事情，但却没有连接。鲍勃·泰勒梦想建立网络的地方，即五角大楼的 ARPA 终端室，也尚未连接。BBN 本身也没有连接。所有人都在等待新机器，霍尼韦尔承诺，这些机器将在 1969 年圣诞节前投入生产。

The network was real, but with only four nodes clustered on the West Coast, its topology was simple, the experiment small. East Coast computing powerhouses like MIT and Lincoln Laboratory, where so much was happening, weren’t connected. The very spot where Bob Taylor had daydreamed about a network, the ARPA terminal room in the Pentagon, wasn’t yet wired in. Nor was BBN itself. All were awaiting new machines, which Honeywell promised were in production as Christmas came in 1969.

过去的十二个月对 ARPA 来说很艰难。该机构的预算达到了历史最高点，然后开始下降。越南战争消耗了一切。1969 年 12 月，ARPA 被迫搬出五角大楼总部，搬到弗吉尼亚州阿灵顿的一栋租赁办公楼。主任 Stephen Lukasik 称这是“美国被流放到西伯利亚的等价物”。ARPA 曾经在主任办公桌后面挂着五角大楼发行的美国国旗，现在却悄悄地去掉了这些装饰。尽管士气低落，ARPA 官员们还是保留了他们的国旗，并在新总部展示，希望没有重要人物注意到它只有四十八颗星。

计算仍然是该机构预算中唯一没有在 20 世纪 70 年代初下降的项目。Larry Roberts 决心赢得高层的支持，他做到了。他同样决心让全国另外十几位首席研究员接受 ARPA 网络的想法。他一直在努力。他不断向新站点施压，要求他们做好准备，迎接 IMP 和 BBN 团队上门服务的那一天，将他们的主机连接到网络。这不是一个是否会发生的问题，而是一个何时发生的问题，Roberts 总是这样提出问题。

The past twelve months had been rough on ARPA. The agency’s budget had reached a historic peak and gone into decline. The Vietnam War was consuming everything. In December 1969 ARPA had been pushed out of its headquarters in the Pentagon and forced to move into a leased office building in Arlington, Virginia. Director Stephen Lukasik called it “the American equivalent of being banished to Siberia.” The ARPA that once rated a Pentagon-issue American flag behind the director’s desk was quietly stripped of such trappings. Despite low morale, ARPA officials kept their flag and displayed it in the new headquarters, hoping no one important would notice that it had only forty-eight stars.

Computing continued to be the one line in the agency’s budget that didn’t turn downward at the beginning of the 1970s. Larry Roberts was determined to win support from the top, and did. He was equally determined to get an additional dozen principal investigators across the country to buy into the idea of the ARPA network. He kept pushing. He kept steady pressure on new sites to prepare for the day when an IMP would arrive at their doors with a team from BBN to connect their host computers to the network. It wasn’t a question of if but when, and Roberts always posed it that way.

在剑桥，莫尔顿街上的活动开始呈现出一种生产氛围——有人称之为“工厂”。大部分工作都转移到低矮建筑后面的大房间，那里有装卸码头，霍尼韦尔的货物就在这里接收；每台新机器都在那里进行调试和测试，然后运往现场。与此同时，哈特的团队继续快速改进 IMP 的设计，开发、测试和调整软件和硬件。第五、第六和第七台 516 计算机于今年头几个月从霍尼韦尔运抵。

In Cambridge, the activity on Moulton Street began taking on an air of production—“the factory,” some called it. The majority of the effort moved into the large room at the back of the low building with the loading dock where deliveries from Honeywell were received; and there each new machine was set up to be debugged and tested before being shipped into the field. At the same time, Heart’s team continued apace improving the design of the IMP, developing, testing, and tweaking the software and hardware. The fifth, sixth, and seventh 516 computers arrived from Honeywell in the first months of the year.

3 月底，ARPA 实验网络安装了第一条跨国线路。这条新的 50 千比特线路将 UCLA 的计算机中心与 BBN 的 Moulton Street 站点连接起来，后者成为该网络的第五个节点。这不仅仅是从西海岸到东部的一次象征性突破（反向边界扩展）；这条横跨大陆的链路也对网络维护和故障排除大有裨益。

In late March the first cross-country circuit in the ARPA experimental network was installed. The new 50-kilobit line connected UCLA’s computer center to BBN’s Moulton Street site, which became the fifth node in the network. And it wasn’t just a breakthrough symbolically from the West Coast to the East (frontier expansion in reverse); the transcontinental link was also an immediate boon to network maintenance and troubleshooting.

在 BBN 拥有自己的机器并连接到网络之前的几个月里，处理西部四节点集群的网络问题是一项由现场人员处理的工作。通常情况下，这意味着加利福尼亚州或犹他州的某个人会花几个小时打电话与 BBN 的某个人进行跨国通话，而自愿解决问题的不幸者则在电话和 IMP 之间穿梭，执行来自剑桥的口头指示。在早期，Heart 的团队花了很多时间打电话，并或多或少地持续出现在现场，像家长一样指导新生网络的启动。有一次，Walden 飞往犹他州、斯坦福大学、圣巴巴拉分校和加州大学洛杉矶分校，亲自交付新软件版本。

In the months before BBN had its own machine and was connected to the network, dealing with network problems in the four-node cluster out west was a job handled by people who were on site. More often than not, it meant someone in California or Utah would spend hours on the phone talking cross-country with someone at BBN, while the unfortunate soul who had volunteered to fix the problem shuttled between the telephone and the IMP to carry out the verbal instructions coming from Cambridge. During the early going, Heart’s team spent a lot of time on the phone and kept a more or less continuous presence in the field, parentally guiding the startup of the infant network. At one point, Walden flew to Utah, Stanford, Santa Barbara, and UCLA to hand-deliver a new software release.

但是，当 1970 年初春在 BBN 安装 IMP 时，突然就有了一种方法可以将数据和状态报告以电子方式从西海岸 IMP 直接发送回 BBN。Heart 对可靠性的执着不仅仅是将计算机包裹在厚重的钢壳中。他坚持制造坚固的计算机——并保持对他投入现场的计算机的控制——这启发了 BBN 团队发明了一项技术：远程维护和诊断。BBN 团队在 IMP 和网络中设计了远程控制这些机器的能力。他们既使用此功能进行故障排除，有时实际上通过远程控制修复消息处理器，又全天候监视 IMP。

But when an IMP was installed at BBN in the early spring of 1970, suddenly there was a way to ship data and status reports electronically from the West Coast IMPs directly back to BBN. Heart’s obsession with reliability had resulted in more than computers encased in heavy steel. His insistence on building robust computers—and on maintaining control over the computers he put in the field—had inspired the BBN team to invent a technology: remote maintenance and diagnostics. The BBN team had designed into the IMPs and the network the ability to control these machines from afar. This they used both for troubleshooting and sometimes actually fixing the message processors by remote control, as well as keeping a watchful eye on the IMPs twenty-four hours a day.

尽管哈特对研究生会摆弄他的 IMP 感到恐惧，但他一直致力于制造能够基本无人值守运行的机器。他将自己的痴迷投入到发明这套非常有用的工具和系统管理技术上。远程控制网络的功能已融入 IMP 的硬件和软件设计中。

Horrified as he was at the prospect of graduate students messing with his IMPs, Heart had sought to build machines that could run largely unattended. He channeled his obsession into inventing this set of remarkably useful tools and system management techniques. Features for the remote control of the network had been built integrally throughout the IMP’s hardware and software designs.

在硬件方面，BBN 为 BBN 消息处理器添加了具有日志记录功能的电传打字机终端，以及用于指示网络故障的特殊警告灯和声音警报。在设计 IMP 时，BBN 实现了机器的主机和调制解调器接口的环路，以便进行“环回”测试。环回测试可以远程执行，将 IMP 的输出连接到其输入，从而有效地将 IMP 与网络的其余部分隔离开来。这会通过接口生成测试流量，并允许 BBN 检查返回流量与 IMP 生成的传出流量。

At BBN, on the hardware side, a Teletype terminal with logging capabilities was added to the BBN message processor, along with special warning lights and an audible alarm to indicate network failures. In designing the IMPs, BBN made it possible to loop the host and modem interfaces of the machine, so they could conduct “loopback” tests. The loopback test, which could be performed remotely, connected an IMP’s output to its input, effectively isolating the IMP from the rest of the network. This generated test traffic through the interface and allowed BBN to check the returning traffic against the outgoing traffic generated by the IMP.

环路测试极其重要；它们提供了一种隔离故障源的方法。通过排除法，即环路一个或另一个组件，BBN 可以确定问题出在电话线、调制解调器还是 IMP 本身。如果测试流量完整无误地完成环路，那么问题几乎肯定出在电路的某个外部部分 — 最有可能是电话公司的线路或调制解调器。环回测试进行得非常频繁，以至于 IMP 的两位成员 Ben Barker 和 Marty Thrope 都成为了以恰当的频率沿线路吹口哨以模仿电话公司用于测试线路的信号的专家。

Loop tests were extremely important; they provided a way of isolating sources of trouble. By a process of elimination, looping one component or another, BBN could determine whether a problem lay with the phone lines, the modems, or an IMP itself. If test traffic completed the loop intact and error-free, then the problem was almost certainly in some exterior portion of a circuit—most likely in the phone company’s lines or in the modems. And the loopback tests were conducted often enough that two of the IMP Guys, Ben Barker and Marty Thrope, became expert at whistling down the line at just the right frequency to imitate the signals that the telephone company used to test the lines.

在位于 Moulton Street 的 PDP-1 计算机室（BBN 的网络监控设备就安装在该计算机室），IMP Guys 可以知道网络中任何电话线路何时出现故障。通过线路中传输的消息和数据包的质量，他们可以看到信号质量何时下降、线路何时丢失比特、何时引入噪音或信号完全衰减。如果问题出在电话线路或调制解调器上，那么电话公司就会被要求修复它。

From the PDP-1 computer room at Moulton Street where BBN’s network monitoring equipment was installed, the IMP Guys could tell when a phone circuit anywhere in the network acted up. They could see, by the quality of messages and packets crossing a circuit, when the signal quality was being degraded, when the line was dropping bits, when it was introducing noise, or fading altogether. When the problem was in the phone lines or the modems, then the phone company would be called upon to fix it.

BBN 的工程师们喜欢利用他们从远处检测并最终预测线路故障的能力来吓唬电话公司的维修人员。通过检查数据，BBN 有时可以预测线路即将中断。电话公司的维修办公室从未听说过这样的事情，并且对此不太适应。当 BBN 的环回测试确定一条线路出现故障时，比如说，位于门洛帕克（斯坦福）和圣巴巴拉之间的线路，Heart 在剑桥的一位工程师拿起电话打电话给太平洋贝尔。“你的门洛帕克和圣巴巴拉之间的线路有问题，”他会说。

The engineers at BBN relished opportunities to spook the telephone company repair people with their ability to detect, and eventually predict, line trouble from afar. By examining the data, BBN could sometimes predict that a line was about to go down. The phone company’s repair offices had never heard of such a thing and didn’t take to it well. When BBN’s loopback tests determined there was trouble on a line, say, between Menlo Park (Stanford) and Santa Barbara, one of Heart’s engineers in Cambridge picked up the phone and called Pacific Bell. ”You’re having trouble with your line between Menlo Park and Santa Barbara,” he’d say.

太平洋贝尔的技术员会问：“您是从门洛帕克还是圣巴巴拉打来的？”

“我在马萨诸塞州的剑桥。”“是的，没错。”

”I’m in Cambridge, Massachusetts.” “Yeah, right.”

最终，当 BBN 的呼叫被证明完全正确时，电话公司开始派出维修队去解决 BBN 发现的所有问题。

由于远程检测地理分散系统中的组件故障非常困难，网络软件随着时间的推移变得越来越复杂。IMP 人员做出的基本假设之一是，检测故障的最有效方法是通过主动报告机制。他们设计了系统，以便每个 IMP 定期编制一份关于其本地环境状态的报告（IMP 处理的数据包数量、链路中的错误率等），并通过网络将报告转发到 BBN 在剑桥设立的集中式网络运营中心。然后，该中心将整合来自所有 IMP 的报告，并构建网络最有可能的当前状态的全局图景。

Eventually, when BBN’s calls proved absolutely correct, the telephone company began sending repair teams out to fix whatever trouble BBN had spotted.

Due to the difficulty of remotely detecting component failures in the geographically dispersed system, the network software grew more complicated with time. Among the basic assumptions made by the IMP Guys was that the most effective way of detecting failures was through an active reporting mechanism. They designed their system so that each IMP periodically compiled a report on the status of its local environment—number of packets handled by the IMP, error rates in the links, and the like—and forwarded the report through the network to a centralized network operations center that BBN had set up in Cambridge. The center would then integrate the reports from all the IMPs and build a global picture of the most likely current state of the network.

在最初的几个月里，他们称其为网络控制中心。但实际上，它只不过是 BBN 办公室的一个很小的角落。网络监控是非正式的。日志电传打字机通过网络本身连接到现场的所有 IMP，终端发出咔嗒声，每 15 分钟从每个 IMP 那里获取报告。偶尔，出于好奇，BBN 的某个人会进去查看机器正在运行的日志，只是为了看看网络发生了什么。没有人专门负责扫描日志。没有人在工作时间之外检查，因此有时很长一段时间都无法检测到线路故障，尤其是在晚上。但是，如果网络站点有人打电话说“嘿，似乎有问题”，那么 IMP 人员之一会立即查看电传打字机日志并试图找出发生了什么。

In the first few months they called it the Network Control Center. But in fact it was really nothing more than a fairly small corner of an office at BBN. And the network monitoring was informal. The logging Teletype was connected via the network itself to all the IMPs in the field, and the terminal clacked away, taking reports from each IMP every fifteen minutes. Every once in a while, out of curiosity, someone at BBN would go in and look at the log that was running out of the machine, just to see what was going on with the network. No one had specific responsibility for scanning the log. No one checked, outside of business hours, so there were sometimes long periods in which line failures went undetected, especially at night. But if someone at a network site actually called in to say, “Hey there seems to be a problem,” then one of the IMP Guys would immediately go look at the Teletype log and try to figure out what was going on.

Heart 的团队将 IMP 设计为尽可能无人值守运行，赋予 IMP 在断电或崩溃后自行重启的能力。“看门狗定时器”是触发 IMP 自我纠正措施的关键组件。整个网络“一直在自我监控”，Heart 说，“发回一些小消息告诉我们它感觉如何，告诉我们哪里发生了什么事情，这样我们就可以启动工作”，如果有必要的话。

Heart’s team had designed the IMPs to run unattended as much as possible, bestowing on the IMPs the ability to restart by themselves after a power failure or crash. The “watchdog timer” was the crucial component that triggered self-corrective measures in the IMPs. The network as a whole “did a lot of looking in its navel all the time,” said Heart, “sending back little messages telling us how it was feeling, and telling us what kind of things were happening where, so we could in fact initiate work” if necessary.

并非所有问题都可以远程诊断或恢复正常。有时，BBN 的员工会注意到 IMP 刚刚停止运行，因此必须重新加载软件。首先，BBN 必须提醒电话线另​​一端的某人，并要求他重新插入纸带或拨动几个开关并按下重置按钮。因此，他们会从莫尔顿街按“管家”铃，即连接到每个 IMP 的电话交换机，希望联系到某人。由于 IMP 安装在大型、高度活跃的计算机中心，因此无法确定谁会接听。这几乎就像拨打付费电话一样。您可能会接通专家，也可能接通看门人或不知道发生了什么事的大学生。无论谁接了电话，BBN 的技术人员都会尝试与该人讨论必要的修复方法。即使是现场对计算机真正了解一两点的人，也被要求遵循 BBN 的严格指示。

Not everything could be diagnosed or restored to working order remotely. There were times when people at BBN noticed that an IMP had just stopped running, making it necessary to reload the software. First, BBN would have to alert someone at the other end of the line and ask him to reinsert a paper tape or flip a few switches and push the reset button. So from Moulton Street they would ring the “butler” bell, the telephone switchbox attached to every IMP, hoping to reach someone. Since the IMPs were installed in large, highly active computer centers, there was no telling who might answer. It was almost like calling a pay phone. You might get an expert or you might get a janitor or some undergraduate who didn’t have a clue as to what was going on. Regardless of who picked up the phone, the technicians at BBN would try to talk that person through whatever fixes were necessary. Even people at the sites who actually knew a thing or two about the computers were asked, just the same, to follow BBN’s strict instructions.

“我记得偶尔会花半个小时到一个小时的时间把电话贴在耳边，”瑟夫回忆道，他的听力障碍使他从一开始就不喜欢电话，“按照 BBN 某人的指示，‘按下这个按钮。翻转这个东西。输入这些东西，’试图找出问题所在并让机器重新运行。”BBN 在一个笔记本中记录了详细的站点列表、每台机器的确切位置以及各个位置的联系人，其中至少有一次包括大楼警卫作为最后的资源人员。

“I can remember spending an occasional half hour to an hour with the telephone glued to my ear,” recalled Cerf, whose hearing impairment made him no friend of the telephone in the first place, “following instructions from someone at BBN saying, ‘Push this button. Flip this thing. Key these things in,’to try to figure out what had gone wrong and get the thing running again.” In a notebook, BBN kept a detailed list of sites, exact locations for each machine, and contacts at the various locations, which in at least one case included the building guard as a resource person of last resort.

在 BBN 安装 IMP Number Five 后，团队立即加强了测试计划，以测量网络性能及其局限性。每个人都想知道网络在各种情况下的表现如何，以及它是否能承受极重的负载。但当 Len Kleinrock 和 UCLA 网络测量中心的其他人故意试图让网络崩溃时，BBN 工程师们自己也并不介意。测试找出了错误并启发了纠正。不过，有一件事是显而易见的：在中等流量下，网络的速度与 BBN 预测的一样快。BBN 向罗伯茨报告说，新网络可以描述为“紧密的通信系统”。也就是说，进入网络的消息没有丢失的趋势。“我们观察到，即使在高流量负载下，消息也不会在网络中四处游荡，”BBN 团队在其定期技术报告中写道。

As soon as IMP Number Five had been installed at BBN, the team stepped up its testing program to measure network performance and its limitations. Everyone was interested in knowing how well the network would perform under various scenarios, and whether it would stand up to extremely heavy loading. But the BBN engineers were not above becoming testy themselves when Len Kleinrock and others at UCLA’s Network Measurement Center would deliberately try to crash the network. The tests ferreted out bugs and inspired corrections. Still, one thing was obvious: Under moderate traffic, the network was every bit as fast as BBN had predicted it would be. BBN reported to Roberts that the new network could be described as a “taut communications system.” That is, messages entering the network showed no tendency to get lost. “We observed that messages do not wander about the net, even at high traffic loads,” the BBN team wrote in one of its periodic technical reports.

到 1970 年夏天，六号、七号、八号和九号机器已从霍尼韦尔移出，目前在麻省理工学院、兰德公司、系统开发公司和哈佛大学运行。AT&T 用一条新的 50 千比特线路取代了第一条跨国链路，将 BBN 连接到兰德公司。第二条跨国链路连接了麻省理工学院和犹他大学。ARPA 网络以每月一个节点的速度增长。

By summer 1970, machines number six, seven, eight, and nine had been extracted from Honeywell and were now operating at MIT, RAND, System Development Corp., and Harvard. AT&T had replaced the first cross-country link with a new 50-kilobit line linking BBN to RAND. A second cross-country link connected MIT and the University of Utah. The ARPA network was growing at a rate of about one node per month.

1970 年的一天，一辆霍尼韦尔的送货卡车停在莫尔顿街装卸码头，开始倒车卸下另一台新的 516 电脑。塞韦罗·奥恩斯坦得知卡车来了，便急忙出门，快速检查了一下还在卡车上的机器，然后大声挥手示意司机离开。哈特从办公室出来，想看看这场骚动是怎么回事，他站在那里大吃一惊，因为奥恩斯坦告诉司机掉头把机器开回霍尼韦尔；他拒绝收货。

One day in 1970, a delivery truck from Honeywell pulled up to the Moulton Street loading dock and started backing up to unload another new 516 computer. Alerted to the truck’s arrival, Severo Ornstein hurried out the door, made a quick inspection of the machine while it was still in the truck, and loudly waved the driver off. Heart, who had come out of his office to see what the commotion was about, stood watching, taken aback, as Ornstein told the driver to turn around and drive the machine back to Honeywell; he was rejecting the delivery.

Ornstein 已经受够了延迟交货和不完整、有故障的设备。他说，退回卡车在霍尼韦尔引起了轩然大波。但这一次他们的注意力集中了。在解决一些问题之前，BBN 不会再接受另一台霍尼韦尔 516。困难一直在增加。对于 Heart 的团队来说，与霍尼韦尔的关系更像是一场扳手腕比赛，而不是合作伙伴关系。“他们不断向我们运送有同样缺陷的机器，”Ornstein 回忆道。装卸码头事件发生后，他开始定期去霍尼韦尔检查每台新机器，然后再将其发送给 BBN。

Ornstein had had it with late deliveries and incomplete, faulty equipment. Sending the truck back caused an uproar at Honeywell, he said. But for once their attention was focused. BBN wasn’t accepting another Honeywell 516 until some things were straightened out. The difficulties had been growing. To Heart’s team, the relationship with Honeywell felt more like an arm-wrestling match than a partnership. “They kept shipping us machines that had the same old errors in them,” Ornstein recalled. After the loading dock incident, he began going to Honeywell regularly to inspect each new machine before it was sent to BBN.

不久之后，霍尼韦尔就召集了 IMP 制造团队，开始生产出合格的机器。IMP 被交付给林肯实验室和斯坦福大学，到年底，卡内基梅隆大学和凯斯西储大学也接入了网络。到那时，IMP 软件中已经写入了数百个小修订。硬件也进行了调整和改造。电话公司也尽了自己的一份力量，现在已经在网络中安装了 14 条 50 千比特的链路。BBN 的远程诊断和网络管理工具也在不断改进。ARPA 延长了 BBN 的合同，以继续生产 IMP 并运行控制中心，一切都进展顺利。

Before long, Honeywell had pulled its IMP-building team together and was producing acceptable machines. IMPs were delivered to Lincoln Laboratory and Stanford, and by the end of the year Carnegie-Mellon University and Case Western Reserve University were also connected to the network. By that point, hundreds of minor revisions had been written into the IMP software. Hardware had been tuned and retrofitted. The telephone company, doing its part, now had fourteen 50-kilobit links installed in the network. BBN’s remote-diagnostic and network-management tools were also undergoing constant improvement. ARPA had extended BBN’s contract to keep producing IMPs and run the control center, and it was all clicking.

BBN 监控中心的活动水平不断提高。随着网络的稳步扩张，进入 BBN 的诊断报告开始变得臃肿和繁琐。IMP 人员很难掌握数据、扫描电传打字机日志的打印输出并找到故障迹象。他们需要一个管家。因此，他们决定将一台备用机器（BBN 最早的原型 IMP）连接到 ARPA 网络，它将作为常规 BBN IMP 后面的主机。这台新主机将用于帮助处理网络状态报告。BBN 程序员编写了新代码，以每小时汇编更频繁的 IMP 状态消息摘要，这些消息现在以每分钟一条的速度从每个 IMP 堆积起来。代码的操作假设是没有消息就是坏消息：如果网络控制中心三分钟内未收到来自 IMP 的状态消息，则网络状态读数将指示该 IMP 已死。这一改进和其他改进使得检测网络中的重要状态变化变得更加容易。

The level of activity in the monitoring center at BBN increased. With the network’s steady expansion, the diagnostic reports coming into BBN were starting to bloat and grow cumbersome. The IMP Guys were having difficulty staying on top of the data, scanning the printout of the Teletype log and locating trouble signs. They needed a housekeeper. So they decided to connect a spare machine, BBN’s earliest prototype IMP, to the ARPA Network, where it would function as a host machine behind the regular BBN IMP. This new host machine would be used to help process the network status reports. The BBN programmers wrote new code to compile hourly summaries of the more frequent IMP status messages that were now stacking up at the rate of one per minute from each IMP. The code’s operative assumption was that no news was bad news: If the Network Control Center failed to receive a status message from an IMP for three minutes, the network status readout would indicate that that IMP was dead. This and other improvements made it easier to detect important status changes in the network.

1970 年 11 月，亚历克斯·麦肯齐 (Alex McKenzie) 结束了短暂的休假，回到了 BBN。他和妻子在欧洲露营了六个月。在他离开的短短时间内，网络项目取得了显著进展。回到剑桥后，麦肯齐意识到，像管理电力公司一样管理网络对 BBN 非常重要。这意味着必须重新安排某些基本假设。他认为，是时候将网络从实验模式转变为运营模式了。麦肯齐开始向所有同事灌输这种观点。麦肯齐做事有条理、一丝不苟，似乎是负责 BBN 网络控制中心的最佳人选，哈特任命他担任这项任务。

It was November 1970 when Alex McKenzie returned to BBN from a short leave of absence. He and his wife had spent six months camping in Europe. In the short time he was gone, the network project had advanced dramatically. Settled back into Cambridge now, McKenzie realized the importance to BBN of managing the network as if it were an electrical utility. That meant a reordering of certain fundamental assumptions would have to occur. The time had come to shift the network from an experimental to operational mode, he reasoned. And McKenzie began pressing that view on all of his colleagues. Organized and meticulous, McKenzie seemed the perfect candidate to take charge of BBN’s Network Control Center, and Heart appointed him to the task.

BBN 周围还发生了其他文化变革。麦肯齐对网络项目的敏感度与整体上更注重商业的公司保持一致。BBN 本身也在成长。在麦肯齐推动将网络作为公用事业运营后的一两年内，BBN 买下了位于繁忙的莫尔顿街尽头的 Superior Laundry，并将其拆除，为一座新的七层总部大楼腾出空间。最终，网络控制中心和 Heart 的其他部门搬到了新总部的五楼。从建筑上看，这座令人印象深刻的新建筑的风格巧妙地暗示了一座光滑的堡垒。它建于 20 世纪 70 年代初反战运动的高峰期，反映了 BBN 新兴的企业意识，即反建制威胁对与美国国防部签订合同的公司构成威胁。大楼一楼没有窗户，那里有一个大型计算机中心。它还设有一个地下停车场，建筑本身设计得比较靠后，周围环绕着一条巨大的无水护城河，只能通过一座短人行天桥才能进入前门。

Other cultural changes were in the wind around BBN. McKenzie’s sensibility about the network project was in tune with a more business-oriented company overall. BBN itself was growing. Within a year or two after McKenzie made his push for running the network as a utility, BBN had bought the Superior Laundry at the busy end of Moulton Street and torn it down to make space for a new seven-story headquarters building. Eventually, the Network Control Center and the rest of Heart’s division moved to the fifth floor of the new quarters. Architecturally, the style of the impressive new building subtly suggested a sleek fortress. Built at the height of the antiwar movement in the early 1970s, it reflected BBN’s emerging corporate consciousness about antiestablishment threats to companies engaged in U.S. Defense Department contracting. The building had no windows on the ground floor, where a large computer center was located. It also had a basement parking garage designed so that the building itself stood back, surrounded by a substantial, waterless moat, allowing access to the front door only over a short footbridge.

在五楼，网络控制中心占据了一间大房间，房间的大型平板玻璃窗向北望去，可以看到剑桥以外的群山。Heart 的团队约有三十人，分布在整层楼的现代化办公室和设备齐全的实验室中。Heart 的部门是整栋楼唯一一个拥有自己的小厨房的楼层，位于中央走廊，这是 Heart 的特别要求，他们打算将来给厨房配备一台餐厅级的意大利浓缩咖啡机。

控制中心的一面大墙上挂着一张网络逻辑图。这张图由金属背景上的可移动磁性部件构成，是一张显示所有 IMP、主机和链路的接线图——用方形、圆形和三角形标记表示。颜色代码和指针指示每个 IMP、节点和链路的状态。操作员一眼就能看出哪些线路或 IMP 出现故障，以及流量绕过故障点的位置。除了关键信息外，偶尔还会用磁铁贴上一些笑话或漫画，就好像控制图是一扇大冰箱门一样。

On the fifth floor, the Network Control Center occupied one large room with large plateglass windows looking north to the hills beyond Cambridge. Heart’s team, numbering about thirty people, was spread out in modern offices and well-equipped labs throughout the floor. Heart’s division had the only floor in the building with its own tiny kitchenette tucked off a central corridor, a special request by Heart, who intended to equip it with a restaurant-quality Italian espresso machine someday.

Dominating one large wall of the control center was a logical map of the network. Constructed of movable magnetic pieces on a metal background, the map was a wiring diagram showing all of the IMPs, host computers, and links—indicated by square, round, and triangular markers. Color codes and pointers indicated the status of each IMP, node, and link. At a glance, operators could tell which lines or IMPs were down and where traffic was being routed around the trouble spots. Besides critical information, an occasional joke or cartoon might be tacked up with a magnet as if the control map were one big refrigerator door.

NCC 的主要任务之一是发布软件升级并在必要时重新加载 IMP 操作程序。操作员采用了一种巧妙的合作方案，每个 IMP 都从邻居那里下载软件。每周二上午 7:00 至 9:00，BBN 都会将网络保留用于软件分发、网络测试和维护。在这两个小时内，NCC 的操作员可以让网络中的每个 IMP 运行新版本的软件。最终，所有新版本的 IMP 操作代码都以这种方式分发。电子传播过程将从剑桥开始，新软件程序被下载到附近的站点，然后该站点再根据操作员的命令将软件包下载到另一个邻居。

One of the NCC’s primary tasks was to issue software upgrades and reload IMP operating programs when necessary. The operators used a cleverly cooperative scheme by which every IMP downloaded the software from a neighbor. Every Tuesday from 7:00 to 9:00A.M., BBN had the network reserved for software distribution, network testing, and maintenance. Within these two hours, operators in the NCC could have every IMP on the network running a new software release. All new versions of the IMP operating codes were eventually distributed this way. The process of electronic propagation would begin in Cambridge as a new software program was downloaded to a nearby site, which in turn would download the software package to another neighbor, at the command of the operators.

该方法还具有恢复潜力。如果发现 IMP 的操作程序被破坏，IMP 可以向相邻的 IMP 发送程序重新加载请求。响应的 IMP 将发回其自身程序的副本。

The method also had restorative potential. If an IMP’s operating program were found to be destroyed, the IMP could send a request for a program reload to a neighboring IMP. The responding IMP would send back a copy of its own program.

微调

Fine Tuning

网络的第二年还发生了其他重大变化。BBN 和 ARPA 认为加固型 Honeywell 516 过于担心可靠性，是一种过度杀伤的表现。而且价格昂贵。516 的价格比新版计算机 Honeywell 316 贵了大约 20%，而后者没有加固型。Ben Barker 一直密切参与目前在现场的十几台 IMP 的维护和故障排除，他实际上得出的结论是加固型 516 上的机柜是可靠性降低的一个原因，因为它妨碍了本来应该很容易完成的日常维护任务。

Other big changes had also taken place in the network’s second year. BBN and ARPA decided that the ruggedized Honeywell 516, reflecting too much worry about reliability, was an expression of overkill. It was expensive, too. The 516 cost roughly 20 percent more than a newer version of the computer, the Honeywell 316, which was not available in ruggedized form. Ben Barker, who remained intimately involved in maintaining and troubleshooting more than a dozen IMPs now in the field, actually concluded that the cabinetry on the ruggedized 516 was a source ofreducedreliability, because it hampered what should have been easily performed routine maintenance tasks.

霍尼韦尔签订了负责日常维护的合同。但在这方面，他们也迟迟没有接受 BBN 的新观点——麦肯齐的效用模型——即计算机网络应该如何运行。有些时候，IMP 的停机时间平均每月高达 3% 或 4%。如果电力设施或电话系统停机时间如此之长——每月一天——其性能将被视为糟糕透顶。但霍尼韦尔必须说服 BBN 和 ARPA 规划网络的发展方向。

Honeywell was under contract to handle routine maintenance. But here, too, they were slow in coming around to BBN’s emerging view—McKenzie’s utility model—of how a computer network should operate. There were periods in which the downtime of the IMPs averaged as much as 3 or 4 percent on a monthly basis. If an electrical utility or the telephone system were down that much of the time—a day out of every month—its performance would be considered abysmal. But Honeywell had to be coaxed into picturing where BBN and ARPA wanted to go with the network.

“我记得我们与霍尼韦尔的人讨论这些数字时召开了一次很棒的会议，”巴克回忆道。“霍尼韦尔的人说，‘等一下。你是说这些机器每天停机半小时到一小时？这相当于 3% 的停机时间。你的意思是，这些机器在一天 24 小时内有 97% 的时间处于运行状态。你是怎么做到的！？’”

“I remember a great meeting when we went over the numbers with the guys at Honeywell,” Barker recalled. “The Honeywell guys said, ‘Wait a minute. You’re saying these machines are down between half an hour and an hour a day? That’s like, uh, three percent downtime. You mean, these machines are up ninety-seven percent of the time on a twenty-four-hour a day basis. How are you doing that!?’”

令霍尼韦尔惊讶的是，3% 的停机时间，用 BBN 的话来说，是“长期硬件故障综合症”。BBN 报告称，呼叫霍尼韦尔现场工程师并与他们合作的正常程序未能解决其中几个“持续故障”。他们特别关注华盛顿特区地区几个站点的问题。

The 3 percent downtime that amazed Honeywell, was, in BBN’s words, “prolonged hardware failure syndrome.” The normal procedures of calling in and working with Honeywell field engineers had not cleared up several of these “persistent failures,” reported BBN. They were particularly concerned about problems at several sites in the Washington, D.C., area.

罗伯茨对不断出现的维护问题感到沮丧，他曾含糊地威胁要取消 BBN 的合同。巴克最终找到了哈特，提议让他组建一支由 BBN 指挥的维护团队，包括足够的现场工作人员进行定期维护，以及一名巡回专家“消防员”。但麦肯齐坚决反对这个想法，并不是因为他对霍尼韦尔的现状感到满意，而是因为他担心巴克只会让事情变得更糟。麦肯齐是个一丝不苟的人，他对巴克邋遢的个人风格做出了反应；他说巴克的办公室看起来就像一辆垃圾车倒过来倒空了里面的东西，这确实是一个合适的形象。很少有人会质疑，巴克的办公室在好日子里是一团糟。他们也不会质疑他敏锐的技术知识和技能。因此，作为交换，巴克齐心协力保持办公室整洁，哈特把组建和指挥一支精干维护团队的工作交给了他。

Frustrated by recurring maintenance problems, Roberts threatened, ever so vaguely, to cancel BBN’s contract. Barker eventually went to Heart and proposed letting him put together a BBN-directed maintenance team, with an adequate field staff for periodic maintenance and a roving expert “firefighter.” But McKenzie adamantly opposed the idea, not because he was content with how things were going with Honeywell but because he feared that Barker would only make things worse. It was Barker’s slovenly personal style to which McKenzie, a fastidious man, was reacting; he said Barker’s office looked like a garbage truck had been backed up to it and emptied of its contents, and indeed it was a fitting image. Few would dispute that Barker’s office was, on a good day, a total mess. Nor would they dispute the sharpness of his technical knowledge and skills. So in trade, Barker made a concerted effort to keep his office clean, and Heart handed him the job of building and directing a crack maintenance team.

除了维护之外，Heart 本人对网络内在可靠性的信心在第一年就增强了。他亲眼目睹了 IMP 在现场成功运行。他的团队通过了初步测试。一段时间后，他对现场调查人员和研究生的可信度也稍微放心了一些。因此，霍尼韦尔 516 的最后一台加固版于 1970 年底左右驶入莫尔顿街，最终作为 IMP 15 号运往宾夕法尼亚州保利的 Burroughs 公司。大约在同一时间，伊利诺伊大学香槟分校收到了延迟的 12 号机器。

Maintenance aside, Heart’s own confidence about the network’s intrinsic reliability had grown in the first year. He had seen the IMPs functioning successfully in the field. His team had met its initial tests. He was also a little more relaxed after a while about the trustworthiness of the on-site investigators and graduate students. As a consequence, the last ruggedized version of the Honeywell 516 rolled into Moulton Street around the end of 1970 and eventually was shipped as IMP Number Fifteen, headed for the Burroughs Corporation in Paoli, Pennsylvania. At about the same time, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign received machine Number Twelve, which had been delayed.

此时，BBN 已获得 ARPA 的批准，开始进行另一项密集的工程工作：设计基于 316 的 IMP 原型。霍尼韦尔承诺在 1971 年初交付该机器。向更轻的 316 IMP 的过渡只是 ARPA 网络发展结构转变的一部分。

By now, BBN had received ARPA’s go-ahead to shift into another intensive engineering effort: designing a prototype 316-based IMP. Honeywell promised delivery of the machine in early 1971. The transition to the lighter 316 IMP was only part of a developing structural shift in the ARPA network.

几个月来，哈特的团队和罗伯茨一直在讨论不通过主机将许多新用户连接到网络的可能性。看来他们可以通过一个简单的终端设备（电传打字机或带键盘的 CRT）直接连接到 IMP，从而登录网络、访问远程主机并控制远程资源。新方案将消除每个用户和 IMP 子网之间对主机的需求。要使其工作，您只需要一个连接到 IMP 的哑终端。这将打开许多新的接入点。

For months, Heart’s team and Roberts had been discussing the possibility of connecting many new users to the net without going through a host computer. It appeared they could make it possible to log onto the network, reach a distant host, and control remote resources through a simple terminal device—a Teletype or a CRT with a keyboard— directly connected to an IMP. The new scheme would eliminate the need for a host computer between every user and the IMP subnet. All you’d need to make it work would be a dumb terminal connected to an IMP. This would open up a lot of new access points.

如果技术上能够解决这个问题，那么数百甚至数千名用户可能无需物理接近主机即可访问网络。然后，网络将不再只是拥有大型机账户的铁杆计算机科学家的实验，而是向更多普通用户开放——军官、政府官僚、大学管理人员、学生——他们将被纳入网络社区。这将使世界更接近实现利克莱德的愿景，即计算机成为沟通和人类互动的促进者。

If it could be worked out technically, then hundreds or even thousands more users might gain access to the network without physical proximity to a host computer. Then, the network would no longer be just an experiment for the hardcore computer scientists with mainframe accounts, but open to a whole panoply of more casual users—military officers, government bureaucrats, university administrators, students—who would be brought into the networking community. That would bring the world one step closer to realizing Licklider’s vision of the computer as a facilitator of communication and human interaction.

但是，无论是原始 IMP 还是新的 316 IMP 都无法支持超过四个主机接口。这两台机器都无法容纳终端连接。为了使新概念可行，Heart 的团队必须构建一个新接口，以处理接入 IMP 和网络的数十条终端线路。BBN 意识到朝这个新方向发展的价值，于是加快了设计终端控制器的步伐，该控制器可以管理直接连接或通过拨号线路连接的大量终端设备产生的流量。新设备被简称为终端 IMP，或 TIP。

But neither the original IMPs nor the new 316 IMPs could support more than four host interfaces. Neither machine could accommodate a terminal connection. To make the new concept workable, Heart’s team would have to build a new interface that could handle dozens of terminal lines feeding into the IMP and the network. Sensing the value of going in this new direction, BBN launched an accelerated effort to design a terminal controller that could manage the traffic generated by a large number of terminal devices connected directly or through dial-up lines. The new device was called simply a Terminal IMP, or TIP.

在六个月内，BBN 和霍尼韦尔完成了基于 316 的两台新原型机的设计和制造。第一台是基本的 IMP，另一台是 TIP，它包含一个多线控制器，能够同时管理多达 63 个终端的信号流量。连接到 TIP 的所有终端设备都可以寻址，就像属于网络上的单个主机一样。在 BBN 接收货物的后室里，Heart 的团队建立了一个小型测试单元来调试进来的机器；最后一批 516 台机器每四周以相当稳定的速度进门，任何时候都可能有两三台机器，有时更多，连接在一起以测试它们的性能并模拟网络流量。首批四台可交付的 TIP 计划于 1971 年夏末抵达 BBN。

Within six months, BBN and Honeywell completed the design and construction of two new prototype machines based on the 316. The first was a basic IMP, the other a TIP that included a multi-line controller capable of managing the signal traffic of up to sixty-three terminals at once. All terminal devices attached to a TIP would be addressable as if belonging to a single host on the network. In the backroom where BBN took deliveries, Heart’s team had set up a small test cell to debug the incoming machines; the last of the 516 machines had been coming in the door at a fairly steady pace every four weeks, and at any time there might be two or three machines, sometimes more, linked together to test their performance and simulate network traffic. The first four deliverable TIPs were scheduled to arrive at BBN by late summer of 1971.

一切似乎都按照设计运行。BBN 开始探索可能连接到网络的各种终端设备。选项包括图形 CRT 显示器、慢速和快速行式打印机、字母数字显示器和类似电传打字机的终端。该团队还在考虑如何连接到读卡器、磁带录音机和其他外围设备。

Everything seemed to be working according to design. BBN began exploring the gamut of terminal devices that might be connected to the network. The options ranged from graphics CRT displays, to slow and fast line printers, to alphanumerical displays, and Teletype-like terminals. The team was also considering how to link to card readers, magnetic tape recorders, and other peripheral devices.

更多的路由算法测试、吞吐量测试、流量控制方案测试和远程诊断测试继续占据 BBN 团队的每一天、每一周的工作，从而稳步改进他们的分组交换技术。

Still more routing algorithm tests, throughput tests, tests of flow-control schemes, and remote diagnostics tests continued to occupy the BBN team on a daily basis, week in and week out, leading to steady improvements in their packet-switching technology.

网络控制中心随着网络的扩大而不断扩大。维护网络的压力也越来越大。它成为 ARPA 与该公司合同中固定的一部分，很快该中心就每周七天、每天 24 小时都有工作人员值班。有一次，NCC 升级了一些设备，并在系统中增加了一个自动电话拨号器。自动拨号器专门用于监控遍布整个网络的调制解调器的状况。有几十个调制解调器处理发往 TIP 的数据流量。BBN 故障排除人员让自动拨号器运行一个简单的测试：拨号器被编程为每天呼叫每个调制解调器一次并听取应答。如果调制解调器接通并发出呼啸声，则其生命体征被认为是正常的。任何没有应答或不正确发出信号回复的调制解调器都会出现在故障报告中。

The Network Control Center kept expanding with the network. Pressure to maintain the network grew. It became a steady part of ARPA’s contract with the firm, and soon the center was staffed around the clock, seven days a week. At one point, the NCC upgraded some equipment and added an automatic phone dialer to the system. The auto-dialer was intended specifically to monitor the condition of modems spread throughout the network. There were dozens of modems handling data traffic to the TIPs. The BBN troubleshooters had the auto-dialer run a simple test: The dialer was programmed to call each modem once a day and listen for an answer. If a modem picked up and whistled back, its vital signs were considered normal. Any modem not answering or signaling back improperly turned up on a trouble report.

有一次，NCC 的工作人员发现，每当自动拨号器检查时，某个调制解调器似乎就会出现故障。有人建议通过自动拨号器给有问题的调制解调器打电话，让技术人员监听一下；也许技术人员可以诊断回来的信号。于是他拨打了电话，听着调制解调器接通，然后听到电话线另一端传来一个愤怒的声音。在无数次的复述中，据说那个声音在摔下听筒之前说：“嘿，玛莎，又是那个吹口哨的疯子！”

At one point, the NCC staff picked up on a particular modem that appeared to be malfunctioning whenever the auto-dialer ran its check. Someone suggested placing a call through the auto-dialer to the troublesome modem, while a technician listened in; perhaps he could diagnose the signal coming back. So he placed the call, listened for the modem to pick up, and heard an angry voice on the other end of the line. Before slamming down the receiver, the voice is reputed in countless retellings to have said, “Hey, Martha, it’s that nut with the whistle again!”

拥塞控制是 Kahn 实验中发现的一个棘手问题，但这一问题已经得到解决和改进。BBN 重新设计了该方案，在 IMP 内存缓冲区中保留足够的空间用于重组传入的数据包。在允许消息进入网络之前，目标 IMP 将为每条消息保留一定量的重组空间。发送 IMP 将进行检查，如果被告知目标 IMP 的缓冲区中没有足够的可用空间，则 RFNM（请求下一消息）将被延迟。该解决方案与许多航空乘客遇到的情况类似，当飞机因目的地机场的恶劣天气而无法降落时，他们无法起飞。乘客坐在地上等待目的地机场的空位。在模拟中，新方案成功阻止了超过目标 IMP 处理能力的流量进入网络。

Congestion control, one of the troublesome problems demonstrated by Kahn’s experiments, had been attacked and improved. BBN had redesigned the scheme to reserve enough space in the IMP memory buffers for reassembly of incoming packets. A specific amount of reassembly space for each message would be reserved at a destination IMP before the message would be allowed to enter the network. The sending IMP would check, and if told that there was insufficient space available in the destination IMP’s buffers, the RFNM (Request For Next Message) was delayed. The solution was not unlike the treatment many an airline passenger has experienced when a plane cannot take off because bad weather at the destination airport prevents the plane from landing. The passenger sits on the ground and waits for an opening at the destination. In simulations, the new scheme succeeded in preventing the insertion of more traffic into the network than the destination IMP could handle.

如果现在要稳步推进网络开发，BBN 引入终端 IMP 的努力与网络工作组开发协议的努力之间就需要更密切的协调。因此，Heart 的团队决定更深入地参与网络工作组的工作。到 1971 年中期，BBN 已加入 NWG 委员会（McKenzie 是 BBN 代表），致力于主机到主机协议、文件传输协议和 Telnet 协议。

If development of the network was to proceed at a steady pace now, closer coordination would be necessary between BBN’s effort to introduce the Terminal IMP and the Network Working Group’s effort to develop protocols. So Heart’s team decided to involve itself much more deeply in the work of the Network Working Group. By mid1971, BBN had injected itself into the NWG’s committees (McKenzie was the BBN representative) working on the host-to-host protocol, the file-transfer protocol, and the Telnet protocol.

尽管花了一年多的时间才制定出 Telnet 协议，但它是一个相对简单的程序。它是一种允许两台主机之间进行基本通信的最小机制。前四个节点连接了四台不同的机器，而其他主机站点则提供了更多不兼容的计算机，从 DEC PDP-10 到大型 IBM，再到 Honeywell 和 Xerox 机器。Telnet 的设想是为了克服简单的差异，例如建立连接和确定使用哪种字符集。TIP 和 Telnet 共同为网络的快速扩展铺平了道路。

Although it took more than a year to work out, the Telnet protocol was a relatively simple procedure. It was a minimal mechanism that permitted basic communication between two host machines. The first four nodes had connected four different machines, while other host sites offered a further melange of incompatible computers, ranging from the DEC PDP-10 to large IBMs, to Honeywell and Xerox machines. Telnet was conceived in order to overcome simple differences, such as establishing a connection and determining what kind of character set to use. It was TIPs and Telnet together that paved the way for rapid expansion of the network.

文件传输是下一个挑战。几年来，六名研究人员一直在努力找到一种可接受的文件传输协议 (FTP)。文件传输协议指定了通过网络交换的数据文件的格式。传输文件是网络的生命力。文件传输相当于数字呼吸 — 数据吸入，数据呼出，永无止境。FTP 使机器之间共享文件成为可能。移动文件看似简单，但机器之间的差异使它变得非常困难。FTP 是第一个允许两台机器作为对等体进行协作而不是将一台机器视为另一台机器的终端的应用程序。将此功能引入网络取决于 FTP 工作组能否拿出一个可行的最终产品。

该小组主席 Abhay Bhushan 是麻省理工学院的研究生和系统架构师，是 Multics 的专家，Multics 是一个雄心勃勃且复杂的操作系统。Bhushan 研究了单台计算机中的多任务问题。下一步是最终在 ARPA 网络等多计算机系统中传输数据块。

File transfers were the next challenge. For a couple of years, a half-dozen researchers had been trying to arrive at an acceptable file-transfer protocol, or FTP. The file-transfer protocol specified the formatting for data files traded over the network. Transferring files was something of a life force for the network. File transfers were the digital equivalent of breathing—data inhale, data exhale, ad infinitum. FTP made it possible to share files between machines. Moving files might seem simple, but the differences between machines made it anything but. FTP was the first application to permit two machines to cooperate as peers instead of treating one as a terminal to the other. Bringing this functionality to the network depended on the FTP working group coming up with a working final product.

The chairman of the group, Abhay Bhushan, an MIT graduate student and systems architect, was an expert in Multics, an ambitious and complex operating system. Bhushan had studied problems of multitasking in a single computer. The next step was to eventually transfer blocks of data in a multicomputer system like the ARPA network.

在开发文件传输协议的六个月中，团队通常会在网络工作组的定期会议上面对面会面。但也经常使用实时计算机电话会议。团队成员会同时登录，从帕洛阿尔托、剑桥、洛杉矶和盐湖城，一连一两个小时来回交换意见。通过键盘和终端交谈不像说话那样自发，但 Bhushan 认为这迫使他们思路清晰。它还有一个优势，就是可以记录他们的工作。1972 年 7 月初，FTP 完成了最后的润色，Jon Postel（现在是《征求意见稿》的编辑和发行人）将其发布为 RFC 354。

In the six months it spent working on the file-transfer protocol, the team usually met face to face in regular sessions of the Network Working Group. But it also frequently used real-time computer teleconferencing. Members of the team would all log on at once, from Palo Alto and Cambridge and L.A. and Salt Lake, and for an hour or two at a stretch trade comments back and forth. Conversing through keyboards and terminals was less spontaneous than speaking, but Bhushan believed it forced clarity into their thinking. It also had the advantage of creating a record of their work. In early July 1972, the final touches were put on FTP, and Jon Postel, now the editor and distributor of the Requests For Comments, released it as RFC 354.

炫耀

Showing It Off

现在这个网络唯一真正的问题是负载。也就是说，负载并不大。起初，由于协议较晚，流量很小。现在，在正常情况下，信道几乎是空的。1971 年秋季，该网络平均每天仅承载 675,000 个数据包，仅略高于其每天 3000 万个数据包容量的 2%。加州大学洛杉矶分校网络测量中心继续生成测试流量，以探测所有网络算法的弱点。但网络上的自然流量不足以真正突破路由和防拥塞方案的极限。

The only real problem with this network now was load. That is, there wasn’t much of it. At first, traffic was light because the protocols were late. Now, on a normal day the channels were virtually empty. In the fall of 1971, the network carried an average of just 675,000 packets per day, barely more than 2 percent of its capacity of 30 million packets a day. The UCLA Network Measurement Center continued generating test traffic to probe the weaknesses of all the network algorithms. But there wasn’t enough natural traffic on the network to really push the limits of the routing and anticongestion schemes.

早期有一些有趣的用途。SRI 的程序员使用 Utah 的 PDP-10 编译器来准备安装他们自己的 PDP-10，并且他们产生了最多的实际流量。UCLA 的 Jon Postel 正在使用该网络运行 SRI 的在线系统。

There were some interesting early uses. Programmers at SRI were using Utah’s PDP-10 compiler in preparation for installing their own PDP-10, and they generated the most actual traffic. Jon Postel at UCLA was using the network to run SRI’s oNLine System.

在麻省理工学院工作的哈佛研究生鲍勃·梅特卡夫和他在哈佛任教的朋友丹尼·科恩在网络上进行了一项令人兴奋的早期实验。梅特卡夫和科恩使用哈佛的 PDP-10 模拟航空母舰着陆，然后在麻省理工学院的图形终端上显示图像。图形在麻省理工学院进行处理，结果（航空母舰飞行甲板的视图）通过 ARPA 网络传回哈佛的 PDP-1，后者也显示了这些图像。实验表明，程序可以在网络上以接近实时的速度移动。梅特卡夫和其他人撰写了一份 RFC 来宣布这一胜利，并将其命名为“网络的历史性时刻”。

Bob Metcalfe, a Harvard graduate student working at MIT, and a friend, Danny Cohen, who taught at Harvard, did one of the more exciting early experiments over the network. Metcalfe and Cohen used Harvard’s PDP-10 to simulate an aircraft carrier landing and then displayed the image on a graphics terminal at MIT. The graphics were processed at MIT, and the results (the view of the carrier’s flight deck) were shipped back over the ARPA network to the PDP-1 at Harvard, which also displayed them. The experiment demonstrated that a program could be moved around the network at such high speed as to approximate real time. Metcalfe and others wrote up an RFC to announce the triumph and titled it “Historic Moments in Networking.”

其他的则没有那么成功。早期曾有人尝试设计一种称为数据重新配置服务的东西；这是一次失败的尝试，即编写一种可以解释不同计算机上不兼容文件的编程语言。

Others weren’t so successful. There was an early attempt to devise something called a data-reconfiguration service; it was a failed attempt to write a programming language that would interpret incompatible files on different computers.

然而，除了计算机研究界的内幕之外，ARPA 网络几乎无人知晓。只有一小部分研究兴趣是网络的计算机界人士认为 ARPA 网络是一个可用的工具。对他们来说，这是一个很棒的实验，但你必须参与队列理论或通信理论等研究才能欣赏它。另一方面，如果你从事人工智能、机器人技术、计算机图形学或该社区正在研究的几乎任何其他领域，那么这个庞大的跨大陆分组交换系统的实用性尚未实现。没有人提出资源共享的有用演示；使其工作的协议甚至还没有到位。ARPA 网络是一个不断增长的链接和节点网络，仅此而已，就像没有汽车的高速公路系统一样。

The ARPA network, however, was virtually unknown everywhere but in the inner sancta of the computer research community. And for only a small portion of the computer community, whose research interest was networking, was the ARPA network developing into a usable tool. To them it was a fantastic experiment—but you had to be involved in things like queueing theory or communications theory to appreciate it. If, on the other hand, your work was in artificial intelligence or robotics or computer graphics or almost anything else the community was investigating, the utility of this grand transcontinental packet-switching system had yet to be realized. No one had come up with a useful demonstration of resource-sharing; the protocols to make it work weren’t even in place. The ARPA network was a growing web of links and nodes, and that was it—like a highway system without cars.

然而，表面上看，整个社区都有丰富的资源可供共享。卡内基梅隆大学拥有一流的人工智能部门和独特的应用。斯坦福大学拥有一支非凡的机器人团队。从理论上讲，几乎每个站点都可以为网络贡献一些独特的能力。

Yet ostensibly throughout the community there were rich resources to be shared. Carnegie-Mellon had a premier artificial-intelligence department and unique applications attendant to it. Stanford had an extraordinary robotics group. Theoretically, at just about every site some unique capability could be contributed to the network.

如果网络要成为网络测量和网络控制中心生成的人工流量的试验台，那么就必须传播其潜力。拉里·罗伯茨知道是时候进行公开演示了。罗伯茨是第一届国际计算机通信会议的项目委员会成员，该会议将于 1972 年 10 月在华盛顿举行。他确定了日期，并打电话给仍在 BBN 的鲍勃·卡恩，请他组织一次 ARPA 网络演示，作为会议上的唯一展品。会议大约在一年后举行。罗伯茨要求卡恩立即开始计划。事实上，卡恩已经计划离开 BBN，去 ARPA 为罗伯茨工作。但两人都认为，卡恩最好在 BBN 待一段时间来计划演示。

If the network was ever going to become anything more than a testbed for the artificial traffic generated by the Network Measurements and Network Control Centers, word of its potential had to spread. Larry Roberts knew it was time for a public demonstration. Roberts was on the program committee of the first International Conference on Computer Communication, to be held in Washington in October 1972. He circled the date and called Bob Kahn, who was still at BBN, and asked him to organize a demonstration of the ARPA network as the sole exhibit at the meeting. The conference was about a year away. Roberts asked Kahn to start planning immediately. Kahn had in fact already been planning to leave BBN and go work for Roberts at ARPA. But both men decided it would be a good idea for Kahn to stay at BBN for a while to plan the demonstration.

卡恩的第一步是招募麻省理工学院 MAC 项目负责人阿尔·维扎 (Al Vezza) 协助他。维扎总是给人留下良好的印象。他善于交际，口齿伶俐；他有敏锐的科学头脑和一流的管理本能。这两个人之间，可能没有他们不知道的美国研究界的某个关键计算机项目，也没有他们无法说服的关键人物加入他们。

Kahn’s first move was to recruit Al Vezza, of MIT’s Project MAC, to assist him.Vezza always made a good impression. He was sociable and impeccably articulate; he had a keen scientific mind and first-rate administrative instincts. Between the two men there probably wasn’t a key computer project in the U.S. research community they didn’t know about or a key player they couldn’t persuade to join them.

1971 年中，卡恩和维扎召集了来自全国各地的约 8 名首席研究员组成的小组，来到位于剑桥的麻省理工学院科技广场开会。他们提出了一个想法，即通过网络对社区最有趣的资源进行高度可访问、引人入胜的演示。维扎知道，如果要产生影响，演示必须是一个现场互动演示。会议上有人极力主张录制演示，以确保演示过程中计算机不会崩溃。维扎对此表示怀疑，并同样极力主张，除了使用实际设备和软件进行现场演示之外，任何其他方式都意味着整个 ARPA 网络实验存在不确定性和潜在失败。演示必须实时进行，必须是任何人坐在终端前都可以触摸和控制的东西。这是一场赌博。参与者必须使用 Telnet 和文件传输协议，而当时他们还没有太多的操作经验。这增加了演示失败的风险。但如果演示成功，那就证明该网络不仅是真实的，而且是有用的。

In mid-1971, Kahn and Vezza called a small group of about eight principal investigators from around the country to come to a meeting at MIT’s Tech Square in Cambridge. They presented the idea of a highly accessible, engaging demonstration of the community’s most interesting resources—accessible over the network. Vezza knew it would have to be a live, interactive demonstration if it was going to have any impact. Someone at the meeting argued strenuously in favor of a videotaped presentation, to ensure against computer crashes during the show. Vezza was incredulous and argued just as strenuously that anything but a hands-on, live demonstration using actual equipment and software would signal uncertainty and potential failure for the whole ARPA network experiment. It had to be done in real time, it had to be something that could be touched and controlled by anyone just sitting down at a terminal. It was a gamble. There still wasn’t much operational experience with the Telnet and File Transfer protocols, which the participants would have to employ. And this increased the risk that the demonstration would fail. But if the demonstration succeeded, it would prove the network was not only real but useful.

在接下来的九个月里，卡恩和维扎用罗伯茨的预算走遍了全国。“有很多死胡同，”维扎回忆道。他们会见了计算机行业的数十家供应商，要求每家供应商都参加会议，将自己的终端带到华盛顿希尔顿酒店，在那里举行会议，TIP 会将它们连接到 ARPA 网络。罗伯茨安排 AT&T 将两条 50 千比特的线路引入​​酒店。计划是在尽可能多的机器上进行演示，连接到尽可能多的站点。组织者将邀请与会者进来，坐下，登录并使用网络资源。

For the next nine months, Kahn and Vezza traveled the country on Roberts’s budget. “There were lots of blind alleys,” Vezza recalled. They met with dozens of vendors in the computer industry, asking each to participate by bringing its own terminals to the Washington Hilton, where the meeting would be held and where a TIP would connect them to the ARPA network. Roberts was arranging for AT&T to bring two 50-kilobit lines into the hotel. The plan was to run demonstrations on as many machines as possible, connected to as many sites as possible. Organizers would invite conference-goers to come in, sit down, log on, and use the network’s resources.

在各个网络站点举行了数十次会议，设计了有趣的场景。研究生和首席研究员团队签署了协议。他们签署协议后，几乎立刻就开始感到恐慌。为了实现这一目标，他们必须加紧努力，完成未完成的网络工具和协议。罗伯茨非常正确地预见到了 1972 年 10 月安排一次备受瞩目的公开演示的可能性，这将给社区带来压力，迫使他们动员起来，确保网络在那一天之前完美运行。卡恩也承认，这次演示是“为了让网络的效用发生在最终用户身上”。

Dozens of meetings took place at the various network sites to design interesting scenarios. Teams of graduate students and principal investigators signed on. And almost as soon as they did, they began to feel a certain panic. To pull this off, they would have to step up their efforts to finalize the unfinished network tools and protocols. Roberts, ever so correctly, had foreseen the likelihood that scheduling a highly visible public demonstration for October 1972 would build pressure on the community to mobilize and make sure the network would be functioning flawlessly by that date. Kahn too acknowledged that the demonstration was “set up to force the utility of the network to occur to the end users.”

1971 年秋，BBN 在莫尔顿街 50 号运行了一个原型 TIP。另外两个 TIP 在网络的其他地方运行，当时仅包含 19 个节点。基于霍尼韦尔 316 的 TIP 与所有旧款 516 完全兼容。到 1972 年初，又安装了几个额外的 316 IMP 和 TIP，东海岸和西海岸之间的网络中心部分开始填补空白。到 1972 年 8 月，又增加了第三条跨国线路。除了散布在国家中部的 IMP 外，现在在四个地理区域还有 IMP 集群：波士顿、华盛顿特区、旧金山和洛杉矶。随着 ICCC 演示的临近，现在被广泛称为 ARPANET 或更常见的网络的网络中已有 29 个节点。

In the fall of 1971, BBN had a prototype TIP running at 50 Moulton Street. Two other TIPs were operational elsewhere in the network, at this time consisting of just nineteen nodes. The TIPs, based on the Honeywell 316, were completely compatible with all of the older 516s. By early 1972 several additional 316 IMPs and TIPs had been installed and the central part of the network between the East and West Coasts was beginning to fill in. By August 1972, a third cross-country line had been added. In addition to IMPs scattered around the center of the country, there were now clusters of IMPs in four geographic areas: Boston; Washington, D.C.; San Francisco; and Los Angeles. As the ICCC demonstration approached, there were twenty-nine nodes in what was now being widely referred to as theARPANETor, more often, just the Net.

现场的人们忙得不可开交。来自美国各地学术和研究界的数十位主要贡献者都参与其中。他们正在加紧努力调试应用程序，让主机在公开演示之前及时启动和运行。每家终端制造商都被邀请来证明其设备可以与 ARPANET 配合使用：他们排队在演示中展示 40 多种不同的计算机终端。Vezza 与华盛顿特区的一家当地供应商进行了谈判，该供应商同意借出一大块防静电架空计算机房地板，用于安装在希尔顿酒店的会议室中，TIP 和终端将放在那里。AT&T 承诺将提供数据链路。在不到六个月的时间内安装这样的电路并非易事，而对于 AT&T 来说，在 ICCC 临近时将这条线路接入希尔顿酒店绝对不是一件小事。

And people at the sites were madly scrambling. Dozens of major contributors from throughout the U.S. academic and research communities had become involved. Intensive efforts were under way to debug applications and get host computers up and running in time for the public demonstration. Every terminal manufacturer had been invited to prove its equipment could work with theARPANET: They were lining up to show more than forty different computer terminals in the demonstration. Vezza negotiated with a local vendor in the Washington, D.C., area who agreed to lend a large section of antistatic, raised computer-room flooring for installation in the meeting room at the Hilton where the TIP and terminals would be located. AT&T promised it would come through with the data link. Getting such a circuit installed anywhere in less than six months was no small issue, and it certainly wasn’t a small matter for AT&T to have that line into the Hilton as the ICCC approached.

会议召开前几天，网络设备和人员陆续抵达酒店。卡恩和维扎绘制了平面图。TIP 位于大型会议室中心的一块架空地板上。房间周围有几十个终端，几乎没有两个是相同的。所有设备需要几天时间才能移到位、连接、通电和检查完毕。几个小时后，房间里就堆满了电线，人们都在喋喋不休地谈论技术问题。技术人员到处都在拉电缆。Heart 团队的成员手拿工具，全神贯注地帮助各个终端制造商修改大量终端设备上的连接器电缆，以便每个设备都可以连接到 TIP。剥线、重新接线、重新连接、测试和调试花费了数小时。

Several days before the meeting, the networking equipment and people began arriving at the hotel. Kahn and Vezza had drawn up a floor plan. The TIP was located up on a section of raised flooring in the center of the large meeting room. Around the perimeter of the room were to be the dozens of terminals, virtually no two alike. It would take a couple of days for all the gear to be moved into place, connected, powered up, and checked out. In a matter of hours, the room was a teeming tangle of wire and people speaking technical jabber. Technicians were stretching cables everywhere. Members of Heart’s team were all around, tools in hand, deeply engaged in helping the various terminal manufacturers modify the connector cables on each of the multitude of terminal devices, so that each could be connected to the TIP. Hours were spent stripping wires, rewiring the connectors, reconnecting, testing, and debugging.

许多参与者都工作得如火如荼。许多人在项目尚未完成时就收拾好行李，来到华盛顿进行最后的润色。这是整个社区第一次同时出现在一个地方。“如果有人在华盛顿希尔顿酒店投下一颗炸弹，那么当时美国几乎所有的网络社区都会被摧毁，”卡恩说道。更不用说国际社会了，甚至连“分组交换”一词的创始人唐纳德·戴维斯也从英国赶来，看看这一切将如何运作。“这真是一次奇妙的经历，”温特·瑟夫说。“我们一边砍杀一边大喊大叫，说‘不，不……你搞错了。’把所有细节都弄对了。”

Many of the participants were working at a fever pitch. Many had packed up while still finishing their projects and came to Washington to add the final touches. It was the first time the whole community showed up in one place at one time. “If somebody had dropped a bomb on the Washington Hilton, it would have destroyed almost all of the networking community in the U.S. at that point,” observed Kahn. Not to mention the international community, for even Donald Davies, father of the term “packet-switching,” had come over from England to see how this would all work out. “It was just an amazing experience,” said Vint Cerf. “Hacking away and hollering and screaming and saying, ‘No, no . . . you got this one wrong. ’Getting all the details right.”

星期六（会议于星期一开幕）结束时，BBN TIP 就像一位国王坐在王座上，电线遍布房间的各个角落。AT&T 完成了自己的工作，在正确的时间带着正确的线路出现。星期日又是忙碌的准备日，但现在 TIP 开始运作，人们开始运行程序并进行最后的检查。许多人直到星期日下午晚些时候才完成，就在为 VIP 组（华盛顿的国会议员、五角大楼官员和其他人）安排的预览演示之前。大约晚上六点，在大门打开的几分钟前，Vezza 站在 TIP 附近，Metcalfe 毫不急切地说：“我们正在丢失数据包！”

At the end of Saturday (the conference opened on Monday), the BBN TIP was like a king on a throne of wire running to all corners of the room. AT&T had done its job and turned up at the right moment with the right line. Sunday was another frantic day of preparation, but now the TIP was in action, so people were starting to run programs and do their final checkouts. Many didn’t finish until late Sunday afternoon, just before a preview demonstration was scheduled for a group of VIPs—a Washington coterie of congressmen, Pentagon officials, and others. At about six o’clock in the evening, minutes before the doors were to open,Vezza was standing near the TIP when Metcalfe said, with no faint urgency in his voice, ”We’re losing packets!”

维扎看了一眼站在那儿的麦肯齐：“亚历克斯，发生了什么变化？”麦肯齐拿起剑桥的热线电话，对着电话大声喊道：“快说！快说！”

过去几天，网络控制中心一直在监视和监控网络中一条稍微有点故障的线路。他们认为当天下午就解决了问题，并将线路重新添加到网络中。在麦肯齐打电话后的三十秒内，NCC 的操作员就断开了该链路，数据包再次在 TIP 上顺畅传输。

The Network Control Center had been watching and monitoring a slightly glitchy line in the network for the past few days. They thought they’d solved the problem that afternoon and had added the circuit back into the network. Within thirty seconds of McKenzie’s call, the link was removed by the operators at the NCC and packets were flowing smoothly at the TIP again.

BBN 的远程管理技术从未有过如此出色的表现。

那天晚上晚些时候，乔恩·波斯特尔坐在展览室的键盘前，登录到加州大学洛杉矶分校的主机。他的团队设计了一个演示，让华盛顿的人通过洛杉矶的主机调出波士顿的文件。他们的想法是，然后在希尔顿酒店的展览室打印出这个文件。当波斯特尔把文件送到他旁边的打印机时，什么也没发生。他环顾四周。还有许多其他的演示，其中之一是麻省理工学院制造的一只小型机器人乌龟。这只乌龟是为了演示如何编写计算机程序来指挥机器的运动。孩子们可以用 LOGO 语言编写自己的程序，说“向左走、向右走、向前走、后退、侧向移动”，当程序运行时，乌龟就会这样做。然而，此刻，乌龟正在上蹿下跳，疯狂地抽搐着。系统没有将 Postel 的文件发送到打印机，而是意外地将其发送到了海龟端口，然后机器人尽职尽责地对运动命令进行了解释。

Later that evening, Jon Postel was in the exhibition room sitting at a keyboard, logged on to the host at UCLA. His team had designed a demonstration in which someone in Washington could pull up a file in Boston via the host computer in Los Angeles. The idea was to then print out the file in the exhibition room at the Hilton. When Postel shipped the file to the printer sitting beside him, nothing happened. He looked around the room. There were a lot of other demonstrations, one of which was a small robotic turtle built at MIT. The turtle was built to demonstrate how a computer program could be written to direct the motion of a machine. Kids could write their own programs in the LOGO language that said, “go left, go right, go forward, back up, move sideways,” and when the program was run, the turtle would do that. At the moment, however, the turtle was jumping up and down, twitching and jerking crazily. Instead of sending Postel’s file to the printer, the system had accidentally sent it to the turtle port, and the robot dutifully offered its interpretation of what it took to be motion commands.

作为一名热情的研究生，鲍勃·梅特卡夫承担了编写一本小册子的任务，以配合演示。它描述了使用 ARPANET 的 19 种场景，列出了各个站点的资源，并展示了如何登录远程主机、如何访问其中一个应用程序以及如何控制程序或通过网络进行某种交互式通信。其中有几款国际象棋游戏、一个关于南美洲地理的交互式测验、一种通过网络阅读美联社新闻的方式，以及许多其他游戏、工具和演示。其中一个更实际的应用程序模拟了空中交通管制场景，其中监控飞机飞行的责任会自动从一台计算机移交给另一台计算机，代表不同的空中交通管制中心，因为飞机跨越了地理边界。梅特卡夫的场景书旨在引导参与者逐步完成每个演示，其中大多数人对 ARPANET 知之甚少。

As an enthusiastic graduate student, Bob Metcalfe had undertaken the task of writing a booklet to accompany the demonstrations. It described nineteen scenarios for using theARPANET, listed resources at various sites, and showed how to log on to a remote host, how to gain access to one of the applications, and how to control a program or engage in some kind of interactive communication over the network. There were several chess games, an interactive quiz about the geography of South America, a way of reading the Associated Press news wire over the network, and many other games, tools, and demonstrations. One of the more practical applications simulated an air traffic control scenario in which responsibility for monitoring an airplane flight is automatically handed off from one computer to another, representing different air traffic control centers, as the plane crosses geographic boundaries. Metcalfe’s scenarios book was designed to walk participants, most of whom knew little about theARPANET, through each demonstration step by step.

星期一早上，ARPANET 的计算机科学家们热切地等待着他们的公众。当好奇的与会者走近时，网络专家们就像分发《守望台》的耶和华见证人一样，把梅特卡夫的情景书塞到他们手中，并把他们带进房间。虽然可以按照说明操作，但对于除了入门者之外的其他人来说，情景书相当难以理解，而且很容易搞砸系统。一个人坐在终端前，输入了书中的一条指令。不知出于什么原因，他试图连接的主机没有运行，或者他错误地指示了主机。返回的消息是：“主机已死。”

On Monday morning, theARPANETcomputer scientists eagerly awaited their public. When curious conference-goers approached, the network guys, like Jehovah’s Witnesses handing out copies ofThe Watchtower, thrust Metcalfe’s scenarios book into their hands and ushered them into the room. Although it was possible to follow the instructions, to all but the initiated the scenarios book was fairly incomprehensible, and it was easy to foul up the system. One man sat down in front of a terminal and typed in an instruction from the book. For some reason or other, the host he was trying to reach wasn’t functioning, or he miscued the thing. The message came back: “HOST DEAD.”

“哦，天哪。我把它搞定了！”他惊呼道。从那以后，他就再也没有碰过任何终端。

还发生了一些有趣的事情。有两个人登录了犹他大学。其中一个人看到另一个他认识但从未见过的人登录了。他们处于通话模式，于是他输入了“你在哪里？”另一个人回答说：“嗯，我在华盛顿。”“华盛顿哪里？”“在希尔顿酒店。”“嗯，我也在希尔顿酒店。”结果发现这两个人之间只有几英尺的距离。

Other funny things happened. Two people had logged in to the University of Utah. One saw that somebody else he knew but had never met was logged in. They were in talk mode, and so he typed, “Where are you?” The other replied, “Well, I’m in Washington,” “Where in Washington?” “At the Hilton.” “Well, I’m at the Hilton, too.” The two turned out to be only a few feet from each other.

有些事情并不那么好笑。作为情景书的作者，梅特卡夫被选中带领 10 名 AT&T 高管虚拟参观 ARPANET。这是一个奇怪的场景：年轻的梅特卡夫留着大红胡子，带领 10 名 AT&T 穿条纹衣服的商人参观网络。在演示过程中，计算机崩溃了。这是计算机第一次也是唯一一次崩溃。电话公司高管的第一反应是大笑。

Some things weren’t so funny. As the author of the scenarios book, Metcalfe was chosen to take ten AT&T executives on a virtual tour of theARPANET.It was an odd sight: Young Metcalfe, with his big red beard, showing ten AT&T pinstriped businessmen around the network. In the middle of the demonstration the computers crashed. It was the first and only time the computers went down. The phone company executives’first reaction was to laugh.

“我痛苦地抬起头，”梅特卡夫说，“我看到他们面带微笑，很高兴看到分组交换技术并不可靠。我永远不会忘记这一点。这让他们确信电路交换技术将继续存在，而这种分组交换技术只是一种不可靠的玩具，永远不会对商业世界产生太大影响，现在他们可以回新泽西了。我很清楚，他们被过去所困扰。”

如果他们不去想倒霉的梅特卡夫和失败的演示，AT&T 高管们就会看到房间其他角落的兴奋。分组交换技术不仅有效，而且还使奇妙的事情成为可能。

“I looked up in pain,” said Metcalfe, “and I caught them smiling, delighted that packetswitching was flaky. This I will never forget. It confirmed for them that circuit-switching technology was here to stay, and this packet-switching stuff was an unreliable toy that would never have much impact in the commercial world, and now they could go home to New Jersey. It was clear to me they were tangled up in the past.”

Had they looked beyond the luckless Metcalfe and the failed demo, the AT&T executives would have seen the exuberance in other corners of the room. Not only did packetswitching work but it made wondrous things possible.

一些最巧妙的演示涉及英语对话程序。这些程序经过精心设计，旨在让用户与机器进行口头对话。展出了四个程序，其中两个程序特别引人入胜地展示了交互式计算。

Some of the most ingenious demonstrations involved English-language conversational programs. These were elaborate programs constructed to engage a user in a verbal dialogue with a machine. There were four programs on display, two of which offered an especially fascinating glimpse into interactive computing.

PARRY 是这些虚拟对话者中的第一个，它模仿了偏执型精神病患者的信仰系统。他会通过对自己认为理解的陈述提供预设的回应来结束对话。否则，他的回应是模棱两可的。PARRY 是斯坦福大学的肯尼斯·科尔比博士的创意。

PARRY, the first of these virtual conversationalists, mimicked the belief system of a paranoid psychotic. He held up his end of a conversation by offering canned responses to statements he thought he understood. Otherwise, his response was noncommittal. PARRY was the brainchild of Dr. Kenneth Colby at Stanford University.

Doctor 是另一个对话程序，基于麻省理工学院的 Joseph Weizenbaum 编写的自然语言程序 ELIZA。Doctor 模仿精神病医生的行为，比 PARRY 更羞怯。Doctor 接受陈述，然后尝试根据其他对话者的单词和语法产生新句子。虽然最终的对话完全是平淡无奇的，但用户经常对他们与 Doctor 的对话质量如此逼真感到震惊。“人们会坐下来与这个东西互动，”Cerf 观察道。“有时他们会要求其他人离开房间，因为他们认为他们在进行私人谈话。”

The Doctor was another conversational program, based on ELIZA, a natural-language program written by MIT’s Joseph Weizenbaum. The Doctor, which mimicked the behavior of a psychiatrist, was rather more diffident than PARRY. The Doctor accepted statements, then tried to produce new sentences based on the words and syntax of the other conversant. While the resulting conversation was altogether banal, users were often struck by how lifelike the quality of their conversations with the Doctor actually seemed. “People would sit down and interact with this thing,” observed Cerf. “And sometimes they’d ask other people to leave the room, because they thought they were having a private conversation.”

瑟夫和其他人曾考虑过让科尔比的偏执狂与精神科医生进行一次“会谈”。就在 ICCC 演示的几周前，PARRY 确实在 UCLA 精心策划的一项实验中通过 ARPANET 与博士进行了一次不同寻常的对话。这或许标志着所有计算机聊天的真正起源。对话中没有人工干预。PARRY 在斯坦福的人工智能实验室运行，博士在 BBN 的一台机器上运行，在 UCLA，他们的输入和输出通过 ARPANET 交叉连接，而操作员则坐在后面观看。

Cerf and others had toyed with the idea of setting up Colby’s paranoid to have a “session” with the psychiatrist. Just a few weeks before the ICCC demonstration, PARRY indeed met the Doctor for an unusual conversation over theARPANET, in an experiment orchestrated at UCLA. It perhaps marked the origin, in the truest sense, of all computer chat. There was no human intervention in the dialogue. PARRY was running at Stanford’s artificial-intelligence lab, the Doctor was running on a machine at BBN, and at UCLA their input and output were cross-connected through theARPANET, while the operators sat back and watched.

“晚上好，”医生说，“告诉我你的问题。请用句号或问号结束输入。”

 

 

“ 有时候人们会让我心烦意乱， ”帕里回答道。

“我不确定我是否理解了你。”“你应该多注意点。 ”“我想你应该多注意点。”“你有权表达自己的意见。 ”

“I am not sure I understand you.” “You should pay more attention.” “Suppose you should pay more attention.” ”You’re entitled to your own opinion.”

“是什么让你认为我有权表达自己的看法？”“和其他人在一起让我很不舒服。 ”“请继续说。”“不久前我去了 Bay Meadows 的赛道。 ”“你为什么刚才这么说？”“那里有很多不正当的赌博行为。 ”“请继续说。”

“What makes you think I am entitled to my own opinion?” “It bothers me just to be around people in general.” “Please go on.” “I went to the track at Bay Meadows a while back.” “Why do you say that just now?” ”There’s a lot of crooked gambling going on there.” “Please go on.”

“我赌马。 ” “这对你来说意味着什么？” “我去看了赛马。 ” “你还想讨论什么？” “赌博对我来说只会带来麻烦。 ” “你为什么现在这么说？” “我曾经和赛马场上的赌博骗子打过交道。 ” “我不确定我是否完全理解你的意思。”

“ I gamble on horses.” “What does that suggest to you?” “I went to the races.” “What else would you like to discuss?” “Gambling has been nothing but trouble for me.” “Why do you say that just now?” ”I’ve had experience with crooks gambling at the track.” “I am not sure I understand you fully.”

“你对庄家了解多少？ ”“你怎么认为我对庄家了解多少？”“庄家一次都没付钱给我。”“这说明什么？”

“ Do you know anything about bookies?” “What makes you think I know anything about bookies?” “A bookie didn’t pay me off once.” “What does that suggest to you?”

“ 我痛打了那个不给钱的赌徒，我想他可能会利用他在黑社会的朋友来报复我。 ”

“你到底在谈论谁？” “你真的想过黑手党吗？ ” “假设你真的想过黑手党。” “我们谈点别的吧。 ”

“Who are you really talking about?” “Have you ever really thought about the MAFIA?” “Suppose you ever really thought about the MAFIA.” ”Let’s talk about something else.”

“我不确定我是否完全理解了你的意思。”

“你总是问我同样的问题，为什么不换个话题呢？ ”“你为什么总是想着这样的问题？”“我想我告诉过你，人们让我很烦。 ”“你烦吗？”“我宁愿不再讨论这个了。 ”“你愿意讨论你的烦吗？”“我想是的。 ”

“ You keep asking me the same things, why not change the topic?” “Why are such questions on your mind? “I thought I told you, people get on my nerves.” “Your nerves?” “I would rather not discuss that anymore.” “Would you like to discuss your nerves?” “I guess so.”

“我不确定我是否完全理解你。”“你总是重复同样的问题。 ”“这种相似性对你意味着什么？”“我不明白你的意思。 ”“你希望你不明白我的意思吗？”“是时候你对我的感受表现出一些兴趣了。 ”“哦？我对你的感受表现出一些兴趣？”“如果我相信你，我就会帮助你。 ”

“I am not sure I understand you fully.” “You harp on the same questions too much.” “What does that similarity suggest to you?” “I don’t get you.” “Do you wish that you didn’t get I?” ”It’s about time you showed some interest in my feelings.” “Oh? I showed some interest in your feelings?” “I will help you if I trust you.”

“你希望相信我吗？”“也许是，也许不是。 ”“你似乎不太确定。”“在我看来，你是一个一根筋的人。 ”“是什么让你认为我是一个一根筋的人？”“我以前每周都去跑马场。 ”“你还想讨论什么？”“那是我不想说的。 ”

“Do you wish that you trust I?” “Maybe yes, maybe no.” “You don’t seem quite certain.” “In my opinion you have a one-track mind.” “What makes you think I have a one-track mind?” “I used to go to the track every week.” “What else would you like to discuss? “That’s something I don’t want to go into.”

“你刚才为什么这么说？”“不关你的事。 ”“你关心我的事干什么？”

“Why do you say that just now?” “It’s none of your business.” “Why are you concerned over my business?”

“我不信任陌生人。 ” “难道你真的不信任陌生人吗？” “ 我们换个话题吧。 ” “ 我不确定我是否完全理解你。” “你怎么了，为什么一直缠着我？ ”
