“ I don’t confide in strangers.” “Don’t you really confide in strangers?” “Let’s change the subject.” “I’m not sure I understand you fully.” “What’s wrong with you that you keep on bugging me about this?”

“请继续说。”“你真是个唠叨的人。 ”“你愿意相信我是个唠叨的人吗？”“我受够了。 ”“这对你意味着什么？”“再见。 ”

“Please go on.” “You are a real nag.” “Does it please you to believe I am a real nag?” “I have had enough of this.” “What does that suggest to you?” “Goodbye.”

“这是我的荣幸。”“恐惧 = 4.2223001“愤怒 = 10“不信任 = 12.650703“一共 399.29 美元。”

“It’s been my pleasure. “Fear = 4.2223001 “Anger = 10 “Mistrust = 12.650703 “That’s $399.29 please.”

在为期两天半的 ICCC 演示中，数百人参与其中。电信和计算机行业的高管、工程师和技术人员中有相当一部分人进入会议室时对 ARPANET 和分组交换持怀疑态度。许多人离开时相信这项技术可能终究是真实的。在大多数情况下，四十多个终端运行正常，资源引人入胜，TIP 运行良好，ARPANET 栩栩如生。“这几乎就像铁路行业不相信飞机真的能飞，直到他们亲眼看到飞机在飞行一样，”卡恩说。

Hundreds of people participated in the ICCC demonstration over its two and a half days. Executives, engineers, and technicians from the telecommunications and computer industries, a good number of them, entered the room skeptical of theARPANETand packet-switching. Many left believing the technology might be real after all. For the most part, the forty-odd terminals worked, the resources were engaging, the TIP ran spectacularly, and theARPANETcame alive. “It was almost like the rail industry disbelieving that airplanes could really fly until they actually saw one in flight,” said Kahn.

ICCC 的演示比以往任何演示都更能证明分组交换的可行性。因此，ARPANET 社区对自己、其技术和可支配的资源有了更深刻的认识。对于计算机制造商来说，他们意识到市场可能会出现。“房间里的气氛不是恐惧或担忧，”Len Kleinrock 说。“而是兴奋。我的意思是，在这里我们可以展示它，我们知道它会成功。即使它失败了，这些东西也是可以修复的。这是一次非常令人兴奋的经历。”罗伯茨表现出坚定的信心。他得到了他想要的东西，一个更加坚实的努力，一个社区的基础，一个他可以在此基础上继续发展的东西。活动前的紧急努力和恐慌得到了回报。而在这一天，甚至连 BBN 和霍尼韦尔都相处得很好。

The ICCC demonstration did more to establish the viability of packet-switching than anything else before it. As a result, theARPANETcommunity gained a much larger sense of itself, its technology, and the resources at its disposal. For computer makers, there was the realization that a market might emerge. “The sense in that room was not one of fear, or concern,” said Len Kleinrock. “It was excitement. I mean, here we could show it off, we knew it would work. Even if it fumbled, these things were fixable. It was a wonderfully exciting experience.” Roberts had shown steady confidence. He had gotten what he wanted, a more solidified effort, the foundation for a community, something he could build on. The crash efforts and panic that preceded the event had paid off. And on this day, even BBN and Honeywell were getting along.

鲍勃·卡恩刚刚花了一年时间证明通过网络共享资源确实可行。但在活动进行过程中的某个时刻，他转向一位同事说道：“你知道，每个人都真的用这个东西来收发电子邮件。”

Bob Kahn had just devoted a year of his life to demonstrating that resource-sharing over a network could really work. But at some point in the course of the event, he turned to a colleague and remarked, “You know, everyone really uses this thing for electronic mail.”

7 电子邮件

7 E-Mail

1973 年 9 月的一个晚上，Len Kleinrock 正在整理行李，突然发现自己忘了带剃须刀。他刚从英国布莱顿返回洛杉矶，在那里他把剃须刀放在了萨塞克斯大学宿舍的浴室里。这是一把普通的电动剃须刀，丢了也不是什么大事。“但它是我的，”他回忆道，“我想把它找回来。”

One September evening in 1973, Len Kleinrock was unpacking his bags when he discovered that he’d forgotten his razor. He’d just returned home to Los Angeles from Brighton, England, where he’d left the razor in a Sussex University dormitory bathroom. An ordinary electric razor, it was no big loss. “But it was mine,” he recalled, “and I wanted it back.”

克莱因罗克刚刚参加了一个关于计算和通信的会议。这次会议汇集了来自几个国家的科学家，其中一些科学家在本国政府的支持下开始开发数字网络。但美国政府的 ARPANET 是迄今为止世界上规模最大、最先进的网络实验，国际社会对有机会亲眼目睹该项目的演示表示欢迎。会议组织者还决定利用这次机会测试通过卫星传输数据包。为了召开这次会议，美国临时连接了布莱顿。数据包通过卫星链路从弗吉尼亚州传输到康沃尔郡兰兹角附近 Goonhilly Downs 的一个地面站，然后从那里安装了一条专用电话线连接到伦敦大学。从伦敦到布莱顿的最后一跳是连接到布莱顿的，在那里人们有机会使用 ARPANET，就像坐在马萨诸塞州剑桥或加利福尼亚州门洛帕克的办公室里一样。

Kleinrock had just come from a conference on computing and communications. The conference had brought together scientists from several countries, some of whom had begun developing digital networks under the auspices of their own governments. But the U.S. Government’sARPANETwas by far the largest and most sophisticated network experiment in the world, and the international community welcomed the chance to see the project demonstrated. The organizers of the conference had also decided to use the occasion to test the transmission of data packets via satellite. For the conference, a temporary link from the United States had been patched into Brighton. Packets traveled over a satellite link from Virginia to an earth station in Cornwall, at Goonhilly Downs near Land’s End, and from there a dedicated phone line was installed to connect with the University of London. From London a final hop was patched in to Brighton, where people had a chance to use theARPANET just as if they were sitting in an office in Cambridge, Massachusetts, or Menlo Park, California.

克莱因罗克提前一天返回美国，因此当他意识到自己忘了带剃须刀时，他想他可能会找到仍在会议上的人来取它。网络上有一款名为资源共享执行程序（RSEXEC）的便捷软件。如果您输入“某某在哪里”，RSEXEC 会通过搜索每个站点的“谁”列表（登录的所有人名单）来查找某某。如果某人恰好在那个时刻登录，您可以通过这种方式在网络上找到他。“我问过自己，哪个疯子会在凌晨三点登录？”克莱因罗克回忆道。他走到终端前，输入“罗伯茨在哪里”。

Kleinrock had returned to the States a day early, so when he realized he had forgotten his razor, he thought he might find someone still at the conference to retrieve it. There was a handy bit of software on the network called the resource-sharing executive, orRSEXEC. If you typed in “where so-and-so,”RSEXEClooked for so-and-so by searching the “who” list—a roster of everyone logged on—at each site. You could locate a person on the network this way if he happened to be logged on at that moment. “I asked myself what maniac would be logged in at threeA.M.?” Kleinrock remembered. He went to his terminal and typed, “where roberts.”

几分钟后，克莱因罗克的终端显示了答案。拉里·罗伯茨确实还在布莱顿，醒着，此刻正与剑桥的 BBN 主机相连。罗伯茨的电传打字机号码也出现在克莱因罗克的屏幕上，这些信息足以让他从洛杉矶以电子方式拍拍同事的肩膀。“我所要做的就是与 BBN 建立电传打字机连接，”克莱因罗克说。他使用 TALK 连接到罗伯茨，这样他们就可以通过在分屏的一半上打字，同时从另一半读取来进行交谈。这两个朋友互相问候。“我问他能不能把剃须刀拿回来。他说，‘当然，没问题。’”第二天，丹尼·科恩把剃须刀归还给了我们，他是我们共同的朋友，参加过会议，后来回到了洛杉矶

A few minutes later, Kleinrock’s terminal displayed the answer. Larry Roberts was indeed still in Brighton, awake, and at the moment connected to a BBN host in Cambridge. A Teletype number for Roberts also appeared on Kleinrock’s screen, enough information for him to tap his colleague on the shoulder electronically from L.A. “All I had to do was make a Teletype connection to BBN,” said Kleinrock. He linked to Roberts using TALK, which allowed them to converse by typing onto one half of a split screen while reading from the other. The two friends traded greetings. “I asked if he could retrieve the razor. He said, ‘Sure, no problem.’” The next day the razor was returned by Danny Cohen, a mutual friend who had been at the conference and had come back to L.A.

没有任何正式规则限制那些有权限访问 ARPANET 的人。克莱因罗克的取剃须刀事件并不是第一次有人超越官方使用网络的界限。人们发送的私人信息越来越多。有传言说，北加州的一些 IMP 甚至达成了一两笔毒品交易。不过，利用 ARPANET 跨越国际线路取剃须刀有点像偷渡到航空母舰上。

毕竟，ARPANET 是官方的联邦研究机构，不是可以玩弄的东西。克莱因罗克觉得他搞的这个花招有点越界了。“这太刺激了。我感觉我在扩大网络。”

There weren’t any formal rules restricting use of theARPANETby those with authorized access. Kleinrock’s razor retrieval caper wasn’t the first time anyone had pushed past official parameters in using the network. People were sending more and more personal messages. Rumor had it that even a dope deal or two had been made over some of the IMPs in Northern California. Still, tapping into theARPANETto fetch a shaver across international lines was a bit like being a stowaway on an aircraft carrier.

TheARPANETwas an official federal research facility, after all, and not something to be toyed with. Kleinrock had the feeling that the stunt he’d pulled was slightly out of bounds. “It was a thrill. I felt I was stretching the Net.”

ARPANET 并非旨在用作消息系统。在其发明者看来，该网络旨在实现资源共享，仅此而已。事实上，其容量中只有极小部分用于资源共享，这一事实很快被电子邮件的浪潮淹没。1972 年至 80 年代初，数千名早期用户发现了电子邮件或网络邮件。这十年催生了现代数字文化的许多持久特征：火焰、表情符号、@ 符号、关于言论自由和隐私的辩论，以及对技术改进和关于所有这些技术基础的协议的不懈追求。起初，电子邮件很难使用，但到 70 年代末，大问题已经解决。消息流量的大幅增长将成为网络增长和发展的最大早期推动力。电子邮件之于 ARPANET 就像路易斯安那购买案之于年轻的美国。随着网络的发展和技术与人类频繁交谈的习惯的融合，情况只会变得更好。

TheARPANETwas not intended as a message system. In the minds of its inventors, the network was intended for resource-sharing, period. That very little of its capacity was actually ever used for resource-sharing was a fact soon submersed in the tide of electronic mail. Between 1972 and the early 1980s, e-mail, or network mail as it was referred to, was discovered by thousands of early users. The decade gave rise to many of the enduring features of modern digital culture: Flames, emoticons, the @ sign, debates on free speech and privacy, and a sleepless search for technical improvements and agreements about the technical underpinnings of it all. At first, e-mail was difficult to use, but by the end of the 1970s the big problems had been licked. The big rise in message traffic was to become the largest early force in the network’s growth and development. Email was to theARPANETwhat the Louisiana Purchase was to the young United States. Things only got better as the network grew and technology converged with the torrential human tendency to talk.

电子邮件将成为网络空间的长效唱片。就像 LP 是为鉴赏家和发烧友发明的，但却催生了整个行业一样，电子邮件首先在 ARPANET 上的计算机科学家精英社区中发展起来，然后像浮游生物一样在整个互联网上蓬勃发展。就在克莱因罗克拿起剃须刀的时候，禁忌开始消失，互联网上的信息交流开始变得轻松起来。

Electronic mail would become the long-playing record of cyberspace. Just as the LP was invented for connoisseurs and audiophiles but spawned an entire industry, electronic mail grew first among the elite community of computer scientists on theARPANET, then later bloomed like plankton across the Internet. It was about the time Kleinrock was reaching for his razor that taboos were tumbling and the tone of message traffic on the Net started loosening up.

作为文化产物，电子邮件介于偶然发现的艺术和幸运事故之间。ARPANET 的创建者并没有为发明一个环绕地球的信息处理系统而制定宏伟的愿景。但是，一旦安装了最初的几十个节点，早期用户就会将这个联网计算机系统变成个人和专业的通信工具。将 ARPANET 用作复杂的邮件系统只是一种高明的黑客行为。在那些日子里，黑客行为与恶意或破坏性行为无关；高明的黑客行为是一种创造性或灵感的编程。最好的黑客是专业人士。爱管闲事和恶意的网络用户（一开始几乎没有）最初被称为“网络随机用户”或“网络随机用户”或简单的“随机用户”。又过了十年，黑客行为才被冠以恶名。

As cultural artifact, electronic mail belongs in a category somewhere between found art and lucky accidents. TheARPANET’s creators didn’t have a grand vision for the invention of an earth-circling message-handling system. But once the first couple of dozen nodes were installed, early users turned the system of linked computers into a personal as well as a professional communications tool. Using theARPANETas a sophisticated mail system was simply a good hack. In those days hacking had nothing to do with malicious or destructive behavior; a good hack was a creative or inspired bit of programming. The best hackers were professionals. Meddlesome and malicious network users, of which there were virtually none at the outset, were first referred to as “network randoms” or “net randoms” or just plain “randoms.” It would be another decade before hacking was given a bad name.

在阿帕网出现之前的十年里，计算机科学家已经设计出在分时系统中交换电子信息的方法。同一分时系统中的研究人员在中央机器中各自拥有一个指定的文件，就像一个收件箱。同事们可以将简短的电子信息发送到其他人的收件箱，只有收件人才能阅读。信息可以随时发送和接收。考虑到人们的工作时间不固定，这种方式很方便。同一个实验室里的人们会来回发送一长串的单行文字，以及较长的备忘录和论文草稿。

In the decade before theARPANET, computer scientists had devised ways of exchanging electronic messages within a time-sharing system. Researchers on the same time-sharing system each had a designated file, like an in-box, in the central machine. Colleagues could address short electronic messages to someone else’s box, where only the recipient could read them. Messages could be dropped and picked up at any time. It was convenient, given the odd hours people kept. People within a single lab sent parades of one-liners back and forth, as well as longer memoranda and drafts of papers.

第一个这样的程序叫做 MAILBOX，它于 20 世纪 60 年代初安装在麻省理工学院的兼容分时系统上。此后，类似的邮箱成为几乎所有分时系统的标准功能。在人们分散的地方，相隔数百码工作的程序员无需从办公桌前站起来就可以交换信息。但通常，在一台机器或域中交换信息会成为一种多余的活动——就像两个人在一间小屋里用对讲机交谈一样。人们仍然会从办公桌前站起来，走到走廊上交谈。一位用户说：“我永远不会忘记一位同事，他在隔壁办公室工作时，会不断给我发电子邮件，当我站起来走到隔壁回复他时，他总是感到惊讶。”

The first of these programs, calledMAILBOX, was installed in the early 1960s on the Compatible Time-Sharing System at MIT. Similar mailboxes became a standard feature of almost every timesharing system built thereafter. In places where people were spread out, programmers working hundreds of yards apart could exchange messages without having to get up from their desks. But often, exchanging messages in a single machine, or domain, became a superfluous exercise—like two people using walkie-talkies to converse in a one-room cabin. People still got up from their desks and walked down the hall to talk. Said one user, ”I’ll never forget a colleague who, while working in the next office, would constantly send me e-mail and it never failed to surprise him when I got up and walked next door to respond to him.”

凭借其地理覆盖范围，ARPA 网络改变了这一切，将电子邮件从一个有趣的玩具变成了一个有用的工具。ARPANET

社区的倾向是强烈的民主，带有某种无政府主义的倾向。ARPANET 的早期用户不断产生新想法，修补旧想法，推动、拉动或刺激他们的网络做这做那，产生了一种创造性混乱的氛围。计算机编程的艺术为他们提供了无尽的即兴发挥和任何主题的变化空间。其中一个主要主题就是电子邮件。

By virtue of its geographic reach, the ARPA network changed all that, turning electronic mail from an interesting toy into a useful tool. The tendencies of

theARPANETcommunity ran strongly democratic, with something of an anarchic streak. TheARPANET’s earliest users were constantly generating a steady stream of new ideas, tinkering with old ones, pushing, pulling, or prodding their network to do this or that, spawning an atmosphere of creative chaos. The art of computer programming gave them room for endless riffs, and variations on any theme. One of the main themes became electronic mail.

1972 年的一天，BBN 的一位低调工程师 Ray Tomlinson 首次实现了两台机器之间的电子邮件传递。在此之前，Tomlinson 曾为 Tenex 编写过一个邮件程序，Tenex 是 BBN 开发的操作系统，目前已在大多数 ARPANET 的 PDP-10 机器上运行。该邮件程序分为两部分：要发送消息，您需要使用一个名为 SNDMSG 的程序；要接收邮件，您需要使用名为 READMAIL 的另一部分。他实际上并没有打算在 ARPANET 上使用这个程序。与当时的其他邮箱程序一样，它是为分时系统创建的，仅设计用于在单个 PDP-10 内本地处理邮件，而不是跨 PDP-10 处理邮件。

The first electronic-mail delivery engaging two machines was done one day in 1972 by a quiet engineer, Ray Tomlinson at BBN. Sometime earlier, Tomlinson had written a mail program for Tenex, the BBN-grown operating system that, by now, was running on most of theARPANET’s PDP-10 machines. The mail program was written in two parts: To send messages, you’d use a program calledSNDMSG ; to receive mail, you’d use the other part calledREADMAIL.He hadn’t actually intended for the program to be used on theARPANET. Like other mailbox programs of the day, it was created for time-sharing systems and designed only to handle mail locally, within individual PDP-10s, not across them.

但汤姆林森，一个资深的实验者，决定利用剑桥办公室里安装的两台 PDP-10 计算机；事实上，BBN 就是用这两台机器连接 ARPANET 的。几周前，汤姆林森编写了一个名为 CPYNET 的实验性文件传输协议。现在他修改了这个程序，使它可以将邮件信息从一台机器传输到另一台机器的文件中。当他尝试将邮件从一台 PDP-10 发送到另一台 PDP-10 时，这个小技巧成功了，尽管他的邮件实际上并没有进入开放网络，但它已经跨越了重要的历史分界线。汤姆林森的 CPYNET 技巧是一个突破；现在没有什么可以阻止电子邮件跨越更广泛的网络。虽然从技术角度来说，汤姆林森的程序微不足道，但在文化上它却是革命性的。“SENDMSG 打开了大门，”电子邮件先驱史蒂夫·克罗克的弟弟戴夫·克罗克说。“它创造了第一个互联互通，然后每个人都从那里开始。”

But Tomlinson, an inveterate experimenter, decided to take advantage of having two PDP-10 computers set up in the Cambridge office; in fact, they were the same machines BBN was using to connect to theARPANET.Weeks earlier, Tomlinson had written an experimental file-transfer protocol calledCPYNET.Now he modified the program so that it could carry a mail message from one machine and drop it into a file on another. When he tried it, and sent mail from one PDP-10 to the other, the little hack worked, and even though his mail hadn’t actually gone out onto the open network, it had crossed an important historical divide. Tomlinson’sCPYNEThack was a breakthrough; now there was nothing holding e-mail back from crossing the wider Net. Although in technical terms Tomlinson’s program was trivial, culturally it was revolutionary. “SENDMSGopened the door,” said Dave Crocker, the younger brother of Steve Crocker and an e-mail pioneer. “It created the first interconnectivity, then everyone took it from there.”

但是如何让这项发明在网络上发挥作用呢？答案在于文件传输协议。1972 年 7 月的一个晚上，在麻省理工学院的科技广场，当 Abhay Bhushan 正在为 ARPANET 文件传输协议编写最终规范时，有人建议将 Tomlinson 的电子邮件程序搭载到最终产品上。为什么不呢？如果电子邮件可以在 CPYNET 上传输，那么它们也可以在文件传输协议上传输。Bhushan 和其他人制定了一些修改方案。8 月，当 Jon Postel 收到一份概述电子邮件功能的 RFC 时，他心想：“现在有一个不错的破解方法。”ARPANET 的第一个电子邮件处理孪生兄弟 MAIL 和 MLFL 诞生了。

But how to get this invention running out on the network? The answer lay in the filetransfer protocol. In July 1972, one evening at Tech Square at MIT, as Abhay Bhushan was writing the final specifications for theARPANETfile-transfer protocol, someone suggested piggybacking Tomlinson’s e-mail programs onto the end product. Why not? If electronic messages could ride onCPYNET , they might just as well ride on the filetransfer protocol. Bhushan and others worked out some modifications. In August, when Jon Postel received an RFC outlining the e-mail feature, he thought to himself, “Now there’s a nice hack.” TheARPANET’s first electronic mail-handling twins, named MAIL and MLFL, came to life.

汤姆林森因 SNDMSG 和 CPYNET 而出名。但他更出名的还是他在编写这些程序时做出的一个聪明（他称其为显而易见）的决定。他需要一种方法来在电子邮件地址中将用户名与用户所在的机器区分开来。应该如何表示呢？他想要一个在任何可能的情况下都不会出现在用户名中的字符。他低头看着他正在使用的键盘，这是一台 33 型电传打字机，网络上的几乎所有其他人也都在使用这种键盘。除了字母和数字外，还有大约十几个标点符号。“我先到了那里，所以我可以选择任何我想要的标点符号，”汤姆林森说。“我选择了 @ 符号。”这个字符还有一个好处，即表示“在”指定机构。他不知道自己正在为有线世界创造一个图标。

Tomlinson became well known forSNDMSGandCPYNET.But he became better known for a brilliant (he called it obvious) decision he made while writing those programs. He needed a way to separate, in the e-mail address, the name of the user from the machine the user was on. How should that be denoted? He wanted a character that would not, under any conceivable circumstances, be found in the user’s name. He looked down at the keyboard he was using, a Model 33 Teletype, which almost everyone else on the Net used, too. In addition to the letters and numerals there were about a dozen punctuation marks. “I got there first, so I got to choose any punctuation I wanted,” Tomlinson said. “I chose the @ sign.” The character also had the advantage of meaning “at” the designated institution. He had no idea he was creating an icon for the wired world.

斯蒂芬·卢卡西克是一位物理学家，他于 1971 年至 1975 年担任 ARPA 主任，是网络邮件的首批用户和大力倡导者之一。事实上，他最喜欢的 ARPA 部门是拉里·罗伯茨的信息处理技术办公室。卢卡西克的职业生涯始于 20 世纪 50 年代，当时他还是 BBN 和麻省理工学院的一名研究生。他于 1966 年加入 ARPA，从事核试验检测工作，并亲眼见证了 ARPANET 的创建。在晋升为主任期间，卢卡西克特别努力地保护计算机科学界的资金。ARPA 面临着从事国防相关工作的压力。他认为计算是一项更基础但更重要的技术，并在国会面前为它辩护。

Stephen Lukasik, a physicist who directed ARPA from 1971 to 1975, was among the first users and great advocates of network mail. His favorite part of ARPA, in fact, was Larry Roberts’s Information Processing Techniques Office. Lukasik had begun his career in the 1950s working for BBN and MIT as a graduate student. He joined ARPA in 1966 to work on nuclear test detection, and he had watched the creation of theARPANET.During his rise to the directorship, Lukasik had fought especially hard to protect the computer science community’s funding. ARPA was under pressure to do defense-related work. He saw computing as a more fundamental but important technology and defended it as such before Congress.

但有时事情会变得有点过分。作为主任，他经常四处走动，到办公室拜访人们。有一天，他在 IPT 办公室时，注意到文件柜顶部放着一个文件夹。它的橙色封面（“不是我最喜欢的颜色”）引起了他的注意。文件夹上标着“计算机辅助编舞”。它包含一个项目的进度报告，该项目利用舞者的动作通过计算机绘制人体动作。“我非常愤怒，”他说。他可以想象出标题：五角大楼资助舞蹈研究。

But sometimes things went a bit too far. As director, he walked around a lot, dropping in on people in their offices. One day he was in the IPT Office when he noticed a folder lying on top of a file cabinet. Its orange cover (“not my favorite color”) caught his eye. The folder was labeled “Computer-Assisted Choreography.” It contained progress reports on a project that used dancers’ movements to map human motions by computer. “I went ballistic,” he said. He could picture the headline:PENTAGON FUNDS DANCE RESEARCH.

卢卡西克让他的员工转告科学家，如果“你们要做的某件事看起来与国防相差无几，请不要在上面写上我们的名字。”他了解这项研究，不在乎他们是否做了，但不希望他们吹嘘。史蒂夫·克罗克现在是罗伯茨手下的 IPTO 项目经理，他很高兴自己不是负责监督舞蹈自动化项目的人。但他自己也对他资助的斯坦福人工智能实验室的研究人员有点不满。“在随机的突击访问中，他们会自豪地向我展示实验室对嗡嗡作响的苍蝇的四声道模拟——这耗费了那里 25% 的计算资源，”克罗克说。

Lukasik told his staff to tell the scientists, if ”you’re going to do something that looks like it’s forty thousand miles away from defense, please leave our name off of it.” He understood the research and didn’t care if they did it, but didn’t want them bragging about it. Steve Crocker, now an IPTO program manager working under Roberts, was glad he wasn’t the one overseeing the dance automation project. But he did have a small problem of his own with researchers he was funding at Stanford’s Artificial Intelligence Lab. “On random unannounced visits, they would show me proudly the lab’s quadraphonic simulation of a buzzing fly—which ate up twenty-five percent of the computing resources there,” Crocker said.

卢卡西克被任命为该机构负责人后做的第一件事就是让罗伯茨给他一个电子邮件地址和 ARPANET 的访问权限。对于一个非计算机科学家来说，对使用网络邮件感兴趣是很不寻常的，而像卢卡西克这样依赖网络邮件的人则更加不寻常。

One of the first things Lukasik had done upon being named head of the agency was get Roberts to give him an e-mail address and access to theARPANET.It was unusual for someone who wasn’t a computer scientist to be interested in using network mail, and more unusual for anyone to grow as reliant on it as Lukasik did.

卢卡西克经常坐飞机，他每次上飞机时都会随身携带一台 30 磅重的德州仪器“便携式”终端，该终端配有声学耦合器，这样他就可以拨号上网，在路上查看信息。卢卡西克回忆道：“我确实用它来管理 ARPA。我会在开会时，每小时拨号上网查看邮件。我鼓励所有人使用它。”他把这个功能推广给所有办公室主任，他们又把这个功能推广给其他人。ARPA 经理们注意到，电子邮件是与老板沟通的最简单方式，也是获得老板快速批准的最快方式。

A frequent flier, Lukasik seldom boarded a plane without lugging aboard his thirty-pound “portable” Texas Instruments terminal with an acoustic coupler, so he could dial in and check his messages from the road. “I really used it to manage ARPA,” Lukasik recalled. “I would be at a meeting, and every hour I would dial up my mail. I encouraged everybody in sight to use it.” He pushed it on all his office directors and they pushed it on others. ARPA managers noticed that e-mail was the easiest way to communicate with the boss, and the fastest way to get his quick approval on things.

卢卡西克和罗伯茨的关系非常好，部分原因是他们都是分析型思维者，部分原因是罗伯茨总是能迅速回答卢卡西克关于他的项目的任何问题。“如果我们在周二下午开会，我让拉里回答一些问题，他第二天会回来参加另一次会议，不仅仅是回答问题。他会有趋势、预测和比较。”

Lukasik and Roberts had an excellent relationship, partly because they were both analytical thinkers, and partly because Roberts was always quick to answer any questions Lukasik had about his projects. “If we had a meeting on Tuesday afternoon and I sent Larry away with some questions to answer, he’d come back the next day for another meeting with more than just answers. He’d have trends and projections and comparisons.”

随后卢卡西克发现了正在发生的事情，电子邮件的实用性变得比以往任何时候都更加清晰。通常，罗伯茨会离开卢卡西克的办公室，回到自己的办公室，向手头上相关主题的专家发送消息，专家们再将问题反馈给他们的研究生。经过 24 小时和大量电子邮件，问题通常已经得到多次解决。“拉里的工作方式是支持计算机网络的典型论据，”卢卡西克说。在卢卡西克任职期间，罗伯茨的年度预算几乎翻了一番，从 2700 万美元增加到 4400 万美元。

Then Lukasik discovered what was happening, and the utility of e-mail became clearer than ever. Typically, Roberts would leave Lukasik’s office, return to his own office and fire off messages to the experts on the topic at hand, who in turn bounced the questions off their graduate students. Twenty-four hours and a flurry of e-mail later, the problem had usually been solved several times over. “The way Larry worked was the quintessential argument in favor of a computer network,” Lukasik said. During Lukasik’s tenure, Roberts’s annual budget nearly doubled, from $27 million to $44 million.

1973 年，卢卡西克委托 ARPA 开展了一项研究，研究发现 ARPANET 上四分之三的流量都是电子邮件。那时，发送电子邮件已经是一个简单的过程，几乎没有任何麻烦。但是，阅读或回复电子邮件却又是另一回事：虽然可行，但一点也不容易。文本只是涌入屏幕或从打印机中输出，消息之间没有任何分隔符。要想看到最后一条消息，您必须重新浏览一遍。对于许多用户来说，阅读邮件的唯一方法是打开电传打字机并打印出文本流。撰写邮件确实很麻烦，因为文本编辑工具还很原始。而且电子邮件没有“回复”功能；要回复，您必须从头开始撰写新邮件。

In 1973, Lukasik commissioned an ARPA study that found that three quarters of all traffic on theARPANETwas e-mail. By then, sending e-mail was a simple and nearly trouble-free process. However, trying to read or respond to it was something else: functional but not at all easy. Text just poured onto the screen or out of the printer, and nothing separated the messages. To get to the last one, you had to run through them all again. For many users, the only way to read mail was to turn on the Teletype and print out streams of text. Composing messages was truly an annoyance, because tools for text editing were primitive. And there was no “reply” function for e-mail; to respond, you had to start a new message from scratch.

卢卡西克讨厌扔掉任何东西，他开始对收件箱里堆积如山的电子邮件感到沮丧。他找到了罗伯茨。“我说，‘拉里，这封电子邮件很棒，但太乱了！’”卢卡西克回忆道。“第二天，他以典型的拉里风格来找我，说，‘史蒂夫，我为你写了一些代码，可能会对你有帮助。’他还向我展示了如何获取邮件菜单、归档邮件或删除邮件。”罗伯茨刚刚编写了第一个邮件管理软件。

Lukasik, who hated throwing anything away, was beginning to get frustrated by the volume of e-mail piling up in his in-box. He went to Roberts. “I said, ‘Larry, this e-mail is great, but it’s a mess!’” Lukasik recalled. “In typical Larry fashion, he came in the next day, and said, ‘Steve, I wrote some code for you that may help.’And he showed me how to get a menu of messages, or file them, or delete them.” Roberts had just written the first mail manager software.

罗伯茨将他的程序命名为 RD，即“read”。ARPANET 上的每个人都很喜欢它，几乎每个人都对 RD 做了一些改动 — 这里做些调整，那里做些改动。基于 Tenex 操作系统的一系列新邮件处理程序纷纷涌入网络：NRD、WRD、BANANARD（“banana” 是程序员的俚语，意为“酷”或“时髦”）、HG、MAILSYS、XMAIL……这些程序层出不穷。很快，网络的主要操作员就开始紧张起来。他们就像杂耍演员一样，把太多东西抛向空中。他们需要这些程序更加统一。难道没有人关注标准吗？

Roberts called his programRD, for “read.” Everyone on theARPANET loved it, and almost everyone came up with variations toRD —a tweak here and a pinch there. A cascade of new mail-handling programs based on the Tenex operating system flowed into the network:NRD,WRD ,BANANARD (“banana” was programmer’s slang for “cool” or “hip”),HG,MAILSYS ,XMAIL. . . and they kept coming. Pretty soon, the network’s main operators were beginning to sweat. They were like jugglers who had thrown too much up in the air. They needed more uniformity in these programs. Wasn’t anyone paying attention to the standards?

由于与电子邮件无关但每天使用网络的所有人都清楚的原因，网络偶尔会变得异常。或者，正如某人所说，它变得“皱巴巴的”。一台机器出现故障可能会引发全系统的多米诺骨牌效应。例如：1973 年圣诞节的死机。哈佛 IMP 出现硬件故障，导致路由表中全为零，从而通知全国其他 IMP，哈佛已成为通往 ARPANET 上任何目的地的最短路线（零跳）。大量数据包涌向哈佛，令人叹为观止。

For reasons unrelated to e-mail but apparent to all who used the network daily, occasionally the network simply went berserk. Or, as one person said, it became “wrinkled.” Trouble in one machine could trip a systemwide domino effect. Case in point: the Christmas Day, 1973, lockup. The Harvard IMP developed a hardware fault that had the bizarre effect of reading out all zeros into the routing tables, thereby informing other IMPs across the country that Harvard had just become the shortest route—zero hops—to any destination on theARPANET. The rush of packets toward Harvard was breathtaking.

用户会注意到这样的崩溃。一切都停止了。“哈佛变成了一个黑洞，”当时还是哈佛研究生的约翰·麦奎兰说。“所有的流量都流向哈佛，就像一个黑洞，没有任何信息流出。”麦奎兰是由本·巴克介绍进入网络运营领域的，并帮助连接哈佛的 PDP1。在完成博士学位期间，麦奎兰被聘请来改进 BBN 网络控制中心的软件。圣诞节那天，当来自哈佛的零被发送到全国各地的路由表时，甚至连 BBN 用于诊断和调试系统的控制流量也被吸入了哈佛故障 IMP 的“引力轨道”中。BBN 操作员必须“烧灼”——切断网络的那部分，对其进行调试，然后将其恢复。

Users would notice a crash like that. Everything came to a halt. “Harvard became a black hole,” said John McQuillan, then a Harvard graduate student. “All the traffic went to Harvard, and like a black hole, no information came out.” McQuillan had been introduced to network operations by Ben Barker and had helped connect Harvard’s PDP1. While finishing his doctorate, McQuillan was hired to improve the software for BBN’s Network Control Center. On Christmas Day, as the zeros from Harvard were sent to routing tables across the country, even the control traffic used by BBN to diagnose and debug the system got sucked into the “gravitational orbit” of Harvard’s faulty IMP. The BBN operators had to “cauterize”—cut off that part of—the network, debug it, and then bring it back up.

就像一家公用事业公司一样，BBN 正在迅速开发应对此类事件的方法。网络崩溃的次数相对较少，持续时间也并不长。

星期二是 BBN 让 ARPANET 做家务的日子，McQuillan 早上六点就上班了。Crowther 和 Walden 已经停止编写 IMP。1972 年至 1974 年间，McQuillan 承担了修订代码和设计发布程序的主要责任。他领导的团队编写了所有新的 IMP 软件，并将这些软件发布到网络中。他在 BBN 实验室建立了“相当复杂”的测试网络，在那里他模拟了故障场景，迫使测试网络发生故障，以便他能够学习如何使 ARPANET 更加安全。

On Tuesdays, the days that BBN had theARPANETreserved for housekeeping chores, McQuillan got in by sixA.M. Crowther and Walden had stopped programming the IMPs. Between 1972 and 1974 McQuillan picked up primary responsibility for revising the codes and designing the release procedures. He led the team that wrote all the new IMP software and made the releases into the network. He built “fairly elaborate” test networks in the BBN laboratory, where he simulated failure scenarios, forcing the test network to fail so he could learn to make theARPANETmore fail-safe.

“你知道，计算机会遭遇雷暴、断电、软件错误和硬件错误，看门人会被电源线绊倒，你能想到的任何情况都有可能发生，”麦奎兰说。但在所有潜在问题中，路由算法问题被认为是最糟糕的。

“You just know that the computers are going to encounter lightning storms, and power failures, and software bugs, and hardware bugs, and the janitor’s going to trip over the power cord, and just anything you can think of could happen,” said McQuillan. But of all the potential problems, trouble in the routing algorithm was deemed the worst.

尽管 Crowther 编写的原始路由算法优雅而简单，但存在缺陷，因为尽管该算法很精简，但从某种意义上说，该方案对于高流量来说过于原始。这是一个众所周知的问题，但直到网络达到高使用率和大量节点开始给路由方案带来压力的程度时，它才变得重要。“直到网络变大，这种情况才开始发生，”McQuillan 说。“当网络非常小时，基本协议都有效。但当网络很小的时候，几乎任何东西都可以工作。”他们知道，当系统达到五六十个节点时，旧算法将无法足够快地提供路由更新，他们将面临真正的大麻烦。McQuillan 的使命是“完全防弹”计算，以便它“在面对‘不可能’的问题时继续工作。”

For all of its elegance and simplicity, the original routing algorithm written by Crowther was flawed, for although it was lean, in a sense the scheme was too primitive for heavy traffic. It was a known problem, but it didn’t matter until the network reached a point when heavy use and a large number of nodes began to strain the routing scheme. “This didn’t start to happen until the network got big,” said McQuillan. “When it was real small, the basic protocols all worked. But when it’s small, almost anything will work.” They knew that when the system reached fifty or sixty nodes, the old algorithm wouldn’t be able to provide routing updates fast enough, and they’d have a real big mess on their hands. McQuillan made it his mission to “completely bullet-proof” the calculation so that it would “keep working in the face of ‘impossible’problems.”

在两年内，随着大量版本的发布，McQuillan 取代了路由算法、确认的工作方式，并最终取代了整个 IMP 操作程序。他构建了一种完全不同的算法，用于快速向所有 IMP 发送有关网络变化的信息，这样它们就不会做出错误的路由决策。他还消除了死锁场景，部分原因是从方程中消除了臭名昭著的 RFNM。

In two years, with a lot of releases, McQuillan replaced the routing algorithms, the way acknowledgments worked, and eventually the whole IMP operating program. He built a completely different algorithm for flooding information about changes in the network very quickly to all the IMPs so they wouldn’t make bad routing decisions. And he eliminated deadlock scenarios, partly by eliminating the infamous RFNM’s from the equation.

“我了解网络上的所有计算机，”麦奎兰说，“我知道它们在哪里，它们的号码是多少，谁在那里，而且我知道它们所有人的名字。”现在，ARPANET 上已经有近 50 个 IMP。

“I knew all the computers on the network,” McQuillan said. “I knew where they were and what their numbers were and who was there and I knew them all by name.” By now there were nearly fifty IMPs on theARPANET.

• • •

邮件系统（无论是数字系统还是其他系统）的某些方面对那些具有某种不墨守成规的人很有吸引力。也许因为必须有规则，有些人总是试图打破规则。例如，有一个聪明的人利用美国邮政服务将砖块一块一块地邮寄到阿拉斯加，直到他在那里积攒了足够的砖块来建造自己的房子；这是从美国本土 48 个州运送砖块最便宜的方式。或者有一位叫艾姆婶婶的女士，她用奇特的插图装饰她寄给远方侄子侄女的包裹，这很可能让邮局工作人员感到有趣而不是惊慌。在一本厚厚的细则中，有关于美国邮件的官方邮政法规——什么可以寄送，什么不能寄送，以及如何寄送。但在一定范围内，各种包裹都会被送达，因为人类邮局工作人员可以适应相当大的不墨守成规范围。

Something about a mail system, digital or otherwise, is inviting to those with a certain nonconformist temperament. Perhaps because there must be rules, some people will always try bending them. There was the clever fellow, for instance, who got away with using the U.S. Postal Service to mail bricks, one by one, to Alaska, until he had enough there to build himself a house; it was the cheapest way to ship them from the lower fortyeight states. Or there’s Auntie Em, who embellishes her packages to her far-flung nieces and nephews with fanciful illustrations, to the probable amusement rather than consternation of the postal clerks. Somewhere in a thick book of fine print are the official postal regulations regarding U.S. mail—what can be sent, what can’t, and how. But within limits, all manner of packages get delivered, because human mail clerks can adjust to a fairly wide latitude of nonconformity.

但想象一下，某个地方的一家邮局决定独自行动，制定自己的地址、包装、盖章和邮件分类规则。想象一下，如果这家不守规矩的邮局决定发明自己的邮政编码。想象一下，许多邮局都自作主张地制定新规则。想象一下，这将造成广泛的混乱。邮件处理需要一定程度的一致性，而由于计算机的容错能力不如人类，电子邮件的要求就更高了。

But imagine a local post office somewhere that decided to go it alone, making up its own rules for addressing, packaging, stamping, and sorting mail. Imagine if that rogue post office decided to invent its own set of ZIP codes. Imagine any number of post offices taking it upon themselves to invent new rules. Imagine widespread confusion. Mail handling begs for a certain amount of conformity, and because computers are less faulttolerant than human beings, e-mail begs loudly.

早期在 ARPANET 上就强制推行标准消息头而发生的争论是后来计算机行业标准争论的典型代表。但由于电子邮件标准的争论是社区中真正紧张的最初根源之一，因此它显得格外突出。

The early wrangling on theARPANETover attempts to impose standard message headers was typical of other debates over computer industry standards that came later. But because the struggle over e-mail standards was one of the first sources of real tension in the community, it stood out.

1973 年，麻省理工学院的 Bhushan 领导的一个特别委员会试图对新电子邮件程序的实施进行一些整理。每个人都知道，从长远来看，需要一个独立于 FTP 的单独邮件传输协议。网络邮件正在走向自己的生命。它有自己的技术问题。它不能永远粘在 FTP 上。但就目前而言，仅仅标准化邮件标题就已经够让人头疼的了。

In 1973 an ad hoc committee led by MIT’s Bhushan tried bringing some order to the implementation of new e-mail programs. Everyone knew that in the long run a separate mail-transmission protocol—independent of the FTP—was needed. Network mail was taking on a life of its own. It had its own technical problems. And it couldn’t stay glued to FTP forever. But for now, just standardizing mail headers was enough of a headache.

ARPANET 上的数据包已经有一种称为报头的东西，但它们与电子邮件报头完全不同。数据包上的报头是 IMP 严格读取的编码位，告诉它们如何处理每个数据包。然而，在电子邮件中，报头是指每封电子邮件顶部的大量信息。这个想法是，某些信息应该始终以指定的格式出现在邮件的顶部，实际上只是一个复杂的时间和日期定位器，包括邮件发送和传递的时间、传输的路线、发送给的其他收件人等信息。Bhushan 的委员会还提出了一种语法，使阅读报头变得更容易，而无需大量特殊的邮件处理。

Data packets on theARPANETalready had something called headers, but they were entirely different from e-mail headers. The headers on data packets were coded bits read strictly by the IMPs, telling them how to handle each packet as it came along. In the context of electronic mail, however, the header refers to a larger raft of information at the top of every e-mail message. The idea was that certain information should always appear at the top of messages in a specified format, really just an elaborate time and date locator, including information such as the time a message was sent and delivered, the route it traveled, other recipients to whom it was sent, and more. Bhushan’s committee also suggested a syntax that would make it easier to read headers without the aid of a lot of special message processing.

标头并不总是只有用户才能看到。一些标头字段由接收系统处理，这些系统被编程为处理保留含义和非常严格定义的语法。如果接收程序以某种方式误解了发送者的标头，结果可能会非常令人沮丧。阅读器程序可能会停止运行或吐出错误消息。例如，日期以特定方式指定，偏差可能难以理解。或者，如果您将逗号放在错误的位置，您的邮件程序处理消息的能力可能会出错。当一个邮件处理程序无法解析其他人发送的标头时，就好像威斯康星州基诺沙的邮局职员被要求递送用梵文和阿拉伯语写的信件一样。

Headers weren’t always something seen only by the user. Some header fields were processed by receiving systems, programmed to deal with reserved meanings and very tightly defined syntax. If the recipient program somehow misinterpreted the sender’s header, the results could be exceedingly frustrating. The reader program might stop dead in its tracks or spit out an error message. Dates, for example, were specified in a particular way, and deviations might be unintelligible. Or if you put a comma in the wrong place, your mail program’s ability to process messages might go awry. When one mail handler couldn’t parse headers sent by others, it was as if a postal clerk in Kenosha, Wisconsin, were being asked to deliver letters addressed in Sanskrit and Arabic.

ARPANET 上的机器经常遇到这种计算机语言障碍，随着邮件程序数量和网络上节点数量的增长，问题也成倍增加。根据人们用来发送邮件的邮件系统类型，接收端不兼容的程序或操作系统会“搞砸”邮件头，正如一位观察者所说。即使邮件成功发送，接收者可能仍要处理乱码翻译或乱码格式。收件人会抱怨发件人。如果有时间，发件人可能会同意使用破解或临时解决方案（一种定义是“临时解决方案是能用的垃圾”）来解决问题。或者，如果他很喜欢自己的邮件程序，他可能会抱怨收件人的邮件程序。

Machines on theARPANETencountered computer-language barriers of this kind regularly, and the problems multiplied with the growth in both the number of mail programs and the number of nodes on the Net. Depending on the kind of mail system one might use to send a message, an incompatible program or operating system at the receiving end would “barf up” the headers, as one observer put it. If the message got through, the person who received it still might have to deal with a garbled translation or screwed-up formatting. Recipients would complain about the sender. A sender might agree to fix the problem with a hack or kludge (“a kludge is a crock that works,” went one definition), if he had the time. Or, if he liked his own mail program well enough, he might simply complain about the recipient’s.

建立电子邮件交流就像约人出去约会一样。“电子邮件被视为成年人之间自愿交流的事物，”正在卡内基梅隆大学攻读博士学位的计算机科学家 Brian Reid 说。这需要一定的成熟理解。“我有一个电子邮件程序，我想给你发邮件，你想收到它，”他继续说，“只要我们同意标准，就可以了。”许多早期传真机的用户都经历了同样的繁琐程序，以确保发件人的机器可以与收件人的传真机通信。

Setting up an e-mail exchange was like asking someone out on a date. “E-mail was seen as something between consenting adults,” said Brian Reid, a computer scientist who was working on his Ph.D. at Carnegie-Mellon. A certain mature understanding was required. “I have an e-mail program, I want to send you mail, and you want to receive it,” he continued, “and as long as we agree on the standard, it’s fine.” Many users of early fax machines went through the same kind of rigmarole making sure the sender’s machine could communicate with the recipient’s fax machine.

这个问题在 Tenex 和非 Tenex 机器之间大规模出现。一些非 Tenex 站点的程序员（例如那些使用基于 Multics 操作系统的机器的程序员）继续以他们自己的操作系统的语法引入电子邮件程序和功能，并继续通过网络发送消息。然而，Tenex 机器无法处理某些站点使用的其他格式的语法，因此再次导致冲突和混乱。

The problem occurred on a massive scale between Tenex and non-Tenex machines. Programmers at a few non-Tenex sites, like those working with machines based on the Multics operating system, continued introducing e-mail programs and features in the syntax of their own operating systems, and continued sending their messages out over the Net. Tenex machines, however, couldn’t handle the syntax of other formats used at some sites, so again, conflict and confusion would result.

网络上非标准系统的多样性甚至给汤姆林森的 @ 符号这样看似微不足道的东西带来了问题。@ 符号之争由来已久，涉及各方。对于符号左侧和右侧的内容存在分歧。但在此之前，人们一直在争论它是否应该用作地址中用户名和主机名之间的分隔符。

The diversity of nonstandard systems on the Net caused problems even with something as apparently trivial as Tomlinson’s @ sign. The @ sign dispute was long-running, and there were many sides to it. There was disagreement over what should go on the left hand side of the sign and what should go on the right. But before that, there was the debate over whether it should even be used at all as the delimiter between the user and host names in the address.

Multics 员工在第一次使用 @ 符号时强烈反对，这是可以理解的。Tenex 黑客 Tomlinson 选择了 @ 符号，但他可能没有意识到，在 Multics 系统中，它是用于发送“行删除”命令的字符。任何试图向“Tomlinson@bbn-tenex”发送邮件的 Multics 用户都会很快陷入麻烦。Multics 会开始读取地址，遇到 @ 符号，并丢弃之前输入的行上的所有内容。

The Multics folks objected vehemently when it was first used, understandably so. Tomlinson, a Tenex hacker, had chosen the @ sign without realizing, perhaps, that in the Multics system it was the character used to send a “line kill” command. Any Multics user who tried to send mail to “Tomlinson@bbn-tenex” would quickly get into trouble. Multics would start reading the address, encounter the @ sign, and throw away everything on the line that had been typed previously.

BBN Tenex 小组的 Ted Myer 和 Austin Henderson 决定尝试解决这些兼容性问题之一，即报头问题。1975 年 4 月，他们发布了新的“标准”报头列表。他们给这份文件取名为“消息传输协议”，并以 RFC 680 的形式出现。

Ted Myer and Austin Henderson, from the BBN Tenex group, decided to try their hand at solving one of these compatibility issues, the header problem. In April 1975 they issued a new list of “standard” headers. The document, which they gave the title, “Message Transmission Protocol,” appeared as RFC 680.

但 RFC 680 立刻在那些认为这项努力过于以 Tenex 为导向的人中引起了骚动。RFC 的保管人 Postel 挥舞着木槌，他的悄悄话往往是最终决定。他说，RFC 680 是邮件有史以来最标准的东西。“许多邮件阅读程序会接受不符合标准的邮件，这很好，”他说，“但这并不能成为邮件发送程序违反标准的理由。”他补充说，如果标准不够充分，欢迎提出任何修改建议。

But RFC 680 immediately created a ruckus among those who thought the effort too Tenex-oriented. Postel, keeper of the RFCs, whose quiet word was often final, wielded the gavel. RFC 680, he said, was as standard as mail ever got. “It is nice that many mailreading programs will accept mail that does not conform to the standard,” he said, “but that does not justify mail-sending programs’ violation of the standard.” If the standard is inadequate, he added, any proposals to change it are welcome.

这场争执表明，以 BBN 为首的 Tenex 网站在网络上形成了主流文化，而“少数”网站凭借其多样化的操作系统构成​​了潜在的反叛运动。由此埋下了一场旷日持久的冲突的根源，这场冲突持续了接下来的十年，并在社区中被称为标题战争。其中许多战斗都是在一个新的计算机对话者群体——“Msg-Group”的竞技场上进行的。

The tiff made clear that Tenex sites, led by BBN, formed a dominant culture on the network, while the “minority” sites, with their diverse operating systems, posed a potentially rebellious countermovement. Thus were planted the roots of a protracted conflict that continued into the ensuing decade and became known in the community as the header wars. Many of those battles were fought in the arena of a new group of computer conversationalists—the “Msg-Group.”

MsgGroup

The MsgGroup

1975 年 6 月 7 日，IPTO 的 ARPA 项目经理 Steve Walker 起草了一份消息，宣布成立一个新组织——电子讨论组。他写道，网络社区需要“了解在消息服务中什么是必须的、什么是好的、什么是不可取的。我们在很多服务方面都有丰富的经验，应该能够就此事收集我们的想法。他欢迎任何愿意提出意见的人，甚至为启动它提供了一些 ARPA 资金。“这整个事情都是一次新的尝试，”他继续说道。“我希望从这一切中制定出一个长期战略，确定消息服务在 ARPANET 和国防部中应该走向何方。让我们开始吧。”

On June 7, 1975, Steve Walker, an ARPA program manager at IPTO, drafted a message to announce the formation of something new—an electronic discussion group. The network community, he wrote, needs “to develop a sense of what is mandatory, what is nice, and what is not desirable in message services. We have had a lot of experience with lots of services and should be able to collect our thoughts on the matter. He welcomed opinions from anyone willing to toss them in and even provided a bit of ARPA funding to launch it. “This whole thing is a new attempt,” he continued. “I hope from all this to develop a long-term strategy for where message services should go on theARPANETand indeed in the DOD. Let’s have at it.”

在贯穿计算机文化的简洁语言风格中，消息服务组被称为 MsgGroup。

加州大学欧文分校的戴夫·法伯自愿担任 MsgGroup 档案管理员；法伯自愿寻求同事、顾问埃纳尔·斯特弗鲁德的帮助。不久之后，大部分日常琐事就落到了斯特弗鲁德的身上，他开始负责管理 MsgGroup 参与者名单、注册新成员、劝说他们发布自己的简介以及整理退回的邮件。斯特弗鲁德将成为 MsgGroup 的主持人和幕后操纵者。作为中间人，他接收要发布的消息并手动将其重新发送给名单上的每个人。这是一个艰巨的过程，后来变成了自动化过程。

Dave Farber at UC Irvine volunteered to be the MsgGroup file clerk; and Farber volunteered the help of a colleague, a consultant named Einar Stefferud. Before long, the bulk of the daily housekeeping chores fell to Stefferud, who began in the job by keeping the list of MsgGroup participants, signing up newcomers, cajoling them into posting introductory biographies of themselves, and sorting out bounced mail. Stefferud would become the MsgGroup’s moderator and man behind the curtain. Serving as the gobetween, he received messages for posting and manually remailed them to everyone on the list. It was an arduous process that became automated later on.

并非每个人都在 MsgGroup 这个露天市场中开展业务；程序员之间的私人电子邮件交流同样多，甚至更多。但世界上所有参与实施邮件系统的人最终都参与其中，或者至少知道小组中发生的事情。讨论持续了十年。随着时间的推移，大约一百名 MsgGroup 参与者交换了数千条消息和数十万个单词。

Not everyone conducted his business in the open-air market of the MsgGroup; there was just as much or more private e-mail traffic among programmers. But everyone in the world involved in implementing mail systems eventually participated or at least knew what transpired in the group. The discussion was to last ten years. In time, thousands of messages, and hundreds of thousands of words, were exchanged by the hundred or so MsgGroup participants.

MsgGroup 是第一批网络邮件列表之一。教育网站周围还有其他邮件列表，其中大多数未经批准。第一个广受欢迎的非官方列表名为 SF-Lovers，专门面向科幻小说爱好者。

The MsgGroup was among the first network mailing lists. There were other mailing lists, most of them unsanctioned, around the educational sites. The first widely popular unofficial list, called SF-Lovers, was devoted to science-fiction fans.

邮件头之争暴露了程序员的顽固和意志。机器之间的操作冲突只是其中的一半。邮件头问题还源于人们对于邮件顶部应该显示多少信息和显示什么类型的信息存在分歧。人们对于在查看邮件时愿意处理多少邮件头信息存在很大分歧。

The header wars brought out the stubborn and strong-willed traits of the programmers. Operating conflicts between machines were only the half of it. Header troubles were also rooted in human disagreement over how much and what kind of information should be presented at the tops of the messages. People differed widely over how much header information they cared to deal with when looking at their mail.

有些程序员和邮件程序在标题字段中包含的内容比其他程序多得多。他们用字符数、关键词和各种深奥的东西来锦上添花。与此同时，批评者则极力主张节约，反对信息过载。他们看到太多又粗又无聊的标题——这相当于在电子版上标注一张信纸上的棉布内容。带有繁琐标题的短信总是显得头重脚轻，不平衡，强调标题而不是消息。卡内基梅隆大学的 Brian Reid 经常在 MsgGroup 中发出理性的声音，他属于短标题阵营。有一天，他收到一位同事发来的讽刺消息，并将其发布到 MsgGroup：

Some programmers and mail programs included a lot more in their header fields than others did. They iced the cake with character counts, key words, and various esoterica. Critics meanwhile argued strenuously for economy, opposing an information overload. They saw too many fat and frivolous headers—the electronic equivalent of noting the cotton-rag content of a sheet of stationery. Short messages with cumbersome headers always appeared top-heavy, out of balance, emphasizing the header rather than the message. Brian Reid at Carnegie-Mellon, who often sounded the voice of reason in the MsgGroup, was in the short-header camp. One day he received a sarcastic message from a colleague and posted it to the MsgGroup:

日期：1977 年 4 月 7 日 1712-EST 发件人：CMU-10A 的 Bob Chansler 回复至：CMU-10A 的 Cheese Coop 主题：回复：差一点，但还不够 收件人：CMU-10A 的 BRIAN. REID

Date: 7 Apr 1977 1712-EST From: Bob Chansler at CMU-10A Reply-To: Cheese Coop at CMU-10A Subject: Re: Close, but no cigar To: BRIAN. REID at CMU-10A

抄送：Chansler@CMU-10A 发件人：CMU-10A 的 BOB.CHANSLER 消息 ID：[CMU-10A] 1977 年 4 月 7 日 17:12:49 Bob Chansler 回复：您 1977 年 4 月 6 日的消息 我的序列号：39492094 年份序列号：4992488 类别：A 子类：MCMXLVII

CC: Chansler@CMU-10A Sender: BOB.CHANSLER at CMU-10A Message-ID: [CMU-10A] 7 Apr 1977 17:12:49 Bob Chansler In-ReplyTo: Your message of April 6, 1977 My-Seq-#: 39492094 Yr-Seq-#: 4992488 Class: A Subclass: MCMXLVII

作者：RC12 打字员：Fred 终端：TTY88 FE-L#：44 原因：哥斯拉需要理由吗？ 有效期：不早于 1977 年 4 月 12 日 1321Z 暂停：1977 年 4 月 19 日 0000Z 之后 拼写错误：0

Author: RC12 Typist: Fred Terminal: TTY88 FE-L#: 44 Reason: Did Godzilla need a reason? Valid: Not before 12 Apr 1977 1321Z Suspend: After 19 Apr 1977 0000Z Spelling-errors-this-message: 0

迄今为止的拼写错误：23 天气：小雨，有雾 预报：早晨转晴 发件人的心理评估：略不稳定 安全级别：公共 安全子级别：0 发送权限：一般 接收权限：一般

Spelling-errors-to-date: 23 Weather: Light rain, fog Forecast: Clearing by morning Psych-evaluation-of-sender: Slightly unstable Security-level: Public Security-sublevel: 0 Authority-to-send: General Authority-to-rcv: General

终端室内人数：12 XGP：UP 切割器不工作 Ht/Wt 发送器：76/205 机器：M&Ms 可用但杏仁机器是空的 M&Ms-Last Nickel：17 HDR 校验和：032114567101

----------------------------------------------------------Brian，

#-people-in-terminal-room: 12 XGP: UP-cutter not working Ht/Wt-sender: 76/205 Machines: M&Ms available but almond machine is empty M&Ms-Last Nickel: 17 HDR-chksum: 032114567101

----------------------------------------------------------Brian,

我不明白您对邮件头大小的担心。

 

 

鲍勃。

为什么我们不能配置邮件头，只打印我们选择阅读的邮件头部分？里德问道。“继续吧，输入 34 个不同的邮件头字段，”他说。“我真正想看的只是‘发件人’和‘日期’。”其他人也同意。理想的程序应该允许用户设计自己的邮件头。至少有一个精心设计的邮件系统，Doug Engelbart 的 NLS JOURNAL MAIL，提供了“不可见信息”功能，允许选择性查看大量邮件头数据。

Why can’t we configure headers to print only the pieces of the header we choose to read? Reid asked. “Go ahead and put in thirty-four different header fields,” he said. “All I ever really want to look at is ‘from’and ‘date.’” Others agreed. The ideal program would allow users to design their own headers. At least one elaborate mail system, Doug Engelbart’sNLS JOURNAL MAIL, offered an “invisible information” feature that allowed selective viewing of a great deal of header data.

1977 年 5 月 12 日，肯·波格兰 (Ken Pogran)、约翰·维塔尔 (John Vittal)、戴夫·克罗克 (Dave Crocker) 和奥斯汀·亨德森 (Austin Henderson) 发起了一场计算机邮件政变。他们宣布“终于”完成了一项新的邮件标准，即 RFC 724，“ARPA 网络消息格式的拟议官方标准”。他们提出的标准包含超过 20 页的规范——语法、语义和词汇形式。RFC 解释说，消息的接收者可以对消息的外观进行极大的控制，这取决于邮件阅读系统的功能。

On May 12, 1977, Ken Pogran, John Vittal, Dave Crocker, and Austin Henderson launched a computer mail putsch. They announced “at last” the completion of a new mail standard, RFC 724, “A Proposed Official Standard for the Format of ARPA Network Messages.” The standard they were proposing contained more than twenty pages of specifications—syntactical, semantic, and lexical formalities. The RFC explained that the receiver of a message could exercise an extraordinary amount of control over the message’s appearance, depending on the capabilities of one’s mail-reading system.

在 RFC 724 发布后的几天里，计算机界对新协议的反应充其量只是冷淡。BBN 的 Alex McKenzie 尤其直言不讳。Postel 曾是旧 RFC 680 的捍卫者，他对新提案印象最深刻。他强烈反对将新协议作为 ARPA 官方标准的说法。“据我所知，任何级别的 ARPANET 协议都没有被 ARPA 标记为官方协议，”他说。“官员到底是谁？这群计算机研究组织为什么要听从任何人的命令？”官方主义太过突出，而对系统的合作和完善关注不够。“我更愿意将这种情况视为一种逐步演变的过程，”他说，“其中 RFC 561、680 和 724 等文档记录了这些步骤。如果对某一步骤过分强调官方性，可能会使下一步变得非常困难。”

In the days after the publication of RFC 724, the computing community’s response was at best cool to the new protocol. Alex McKenzie of BBN was particularly outspoken. Postel, who had been a defender of the old RFC 680, was the least impressed by the new proposal. He came down hard on the assertion that this was to be an official ARPA standard. “To my knowledge noARPANETprotocol at any level has been stamped as official by ARPA,” he said. “Who are the officials anyway? Why should this collection of computer research organizations take orders from anybody?” There was too much emphasis on officialism and not enough on cooperation and perfection of the system. “I prefer to view the situation as a kind of step-by-step evolution,” he said, “where documents such as RFCs 561, 680, and 724 record the steps. To make a big point of officialness about one step may make it very hard to take the next step.”

RFC 724 团队吸收了这些批评意见。六个月后，在 Dave Crocker 和 JohnVittal 的领导下，RFC 724 的最终修订版发布为 RFC 733。该规范旨在“严格定义”在 ARPANET 主机之间传递的内容。他们无意规定消息程序的外观和感觉，或它们可以支持的功能。他们说，要求比标准允许的要少，所以就在这里。它就在那里。

The RFC 724 team absorbed the criticism. Six months later, under Dave Crocker’s and JohnVittal’s leadership, a final revised edition of RFC 724 was published as RFC 733. This specification was intended “strictly as a definition” of what was to be passed betweenARPANEThosts. They didn’t intend to dictate the look and feel of message programs or the features they could support. Less wasrequiredthanallowed by the standard, they said, so here it was. And there it sat.

许多开发人员编写或修改了邮件程序以符合新准则，但在 RFC 733 发布后一年内，持续的冲突再次出现。特别令人担忧的是，RFC 733 标头与名为 MSG 的邮件程序不兼容（尽管其作者 JohnVittal 曾帮助编写 RFC 733）。MSG 是 ARPANET 上最受欢迎的邮件程序。

A number of developers wrote or revised mail programs to conform with the new guidelines, but within a year of RFC 733’s publication the persistent conflict picked up again. Of particular concern, RFC 733 headers were incompatible with a mail program calledMSG(in spite of the fact that its author, JohnVittal, had helped write RFC 733).MSGwas far and away the most popular mail program on theARPANET .

维塔尔是一名黑客中的黑客，他于 1975 年出于对工作的热爱编写了 MSG 程序。MSG 从未获得过正式的资金或支持，“除了我利用业余时间，”他解释道。但很快，MSG 就拥有了超过一千人的用户社区，这在当时意味着有线世界的很大一部分。维塔尔曾使用过罗伯茨的 RDmail 程序，该程序非常适合一次处理两三条消息，甚至可以处理短消息堆栈，但维塔尔现在每天收到二十条消息，他想要一个程序来更轻松地管理它们。“MSG 所做的就是关闭循环，”他说，“这样你就可以将消息打包到各种其他文件（称为文件夹）中，最终进行答复和转发。”

A hacker’s hacker,Vittal had written theMSGprogram in 1975 out of sheer love for the work.MSGwas never formally funded or supported, “other than by me in my spare time,” he explained. But soon,MSG had a user community of more than a thousand people, which in those days meant a huge portion of the wired world. Vittal had used Roberts’sRDmail program, which was great for handling two or three messages at a time, or even a short message stack, but Vittal was getting twenty messages a day now and wanted a program to manage them with greater ease. “WhatMSGdid was close the loop,” he said, “so that you could parcel messages out to various other files, called folders, and ultimately answer and forward.”

事实上，维塔尔因将“回答”一词纳入电子邮件词汇而广为人知。他发明了 ANSWER 命令，这使得回复消息变得轻而易举。维塔尔回忆道：“当时我在想，‘嘿，有了回答命令，我就不必重新输入——或者输错！——回复地址了！’”

Vittal, in fact, became widely known for putting the word “answer” into the lexicon of email. He invented theANSWERcommand, which made replying to messages a cinch. Recalled Vittal, “I was thinking, ‘Hey, with an answer command I don’t have to retype— or mistype!—a return address or addresses.’”

MSG 是一个鼓舞人心的模型，它催生了新一代邮件系统，包括 MH、MM、MS，以及由五角大楼资助的 BBN 项目 HERMES。MSG 是最初的“杀手级应用”——一款风靡全球的软件应用程序。尽管 MSG 从未得到官方认可，但它显然拥有最广泛的草根支持。它遍布整个网络；甚至五角大楼 ARPA 的高层也使用它。如果说有什么是最广泛接受的标准，那就是 MSG，它统治了很长一段时间。（BBN 的一些人在 1990 年代仍在使用 MSG。）

An inspiring model,MSGspawned a whole new generation of mail systems includingMH,MM ,MS, and a heavily funded, Pentagon-sponsored project at BBN calledHERMES.MSGwas the original “killer app”—a software application that took the world by storm. Although there was never anything official about it,MSGclearly had the broadest grassroots support. It was all over the network; even ARPA’s top folks in the Pentagon used it. If anything was the most widely accepted standard, it wasMSG, which reigned for a long while. (A few people at BBN were still usingMSGin the 1990s.)

Vittal 的 MSG 和 ANSWER 命令使他成为电子邮件圈的传奇人物。“正是因为 Vittal，我们才将网络邮件融入我们的脊髓，”Brian Reid 回忆道。“多年后当我见到他时，我记得自己很失望——就像人们遇到一位活着的传奇人物时经常会感到的一样——看到他有两只胳膊和两条腿，背上没有火箭背包。”

Vittal’sMSGand hisANSWERcommand made him a legendary figure in e-mail circles. “It was because ofVittal that we all assimilated network mail into our spinal cords,” recalled Brian Reid. “When I met him years later, I remember being disappointed—as one often is when one meets a living legend—to see that he had two arms and two legs and no rocket pack on his back.”

MSG 不仅仅是一次伟大的黑客攻击，它还是迄今为止最好的证据，证明了在 ARPANET 上可能会制定规则，但这些规则肯定不会成功。官方声明并没有推动互联网的发展，而是将技术投入到互联网上，看看哪种技术有效。当某样东西有效时，它就会被采用。

More than just a great hack,MSGwas the best proof to date that on theARPANETrules might get made, but they certainly didn’t prevail. Proclamations of officialness didn’t further the Net nearly so much as throwing technology out onto the Net to see what worked. And when something worked, it was adopted.

冒险与类星体：开放网络与言论自由

Adventure and Quasar: The Open Net and Free Speech

人们使用 ARPANET 发送电子邮件的次数越多，他们说话就越放松。有人发出反战信息，在水门事件最严重的时候，一名学生在 ARPANET 上支持弹劾尼克松。

The more that people used theARPANETfor e-mail, the more relaxed they became about what they said. There were antiwar messages and, during the height of the Watergate crisis, a student on theARPANET advocated Nixon’s impeachment.

网络不仅在扩展，还向新用途开放，并在人们之间建立新的联系。这就是纯粹的利克莱德。最令人震惊的例子之一始于最初的 IMP 成员之一——威尔·克劳瑟。

Not only was the network expanding, it was opening wider to new uses and creating new connections among people. And that was pure Licklider. One of the most stunning examples of this began with one of the original IMP Guys—Will Crowther.

BBN 的一小群朋友迷上了《龙与地下城》，这是一款精心设计的奇幻角色扮演游戏，玩家可以创造一个场景，并在其中设置怪物和谜题，然后其他玩家可以探索该场景。整个游戏只存在于纸上和玩家的脑海中。

A small circle of friends at BBN had gotten hooked on Dungeons and Dragons, an elaborate fantasy role-playing game in which one player invents a setting and populates it with monsters and puzzles, and the other players then make their way through that setting. The entire game exists only on paper and in the minds of the players.

1975 年的一个晚上，戴夫·沃尔登 (Dave Walden) 第一次接触到这款游戏，当时他在哈佛教授的一个班的学生埃里克·罗伯茨 (Eric Roberts) 带他参加了一场 D&D 课程。沃尔登立即召集了一群来自 ARPANET 团队的朋友继续进行课程。罗伯茨创作了《幽暗密林传说》，这是 JRR 托尔金 (JRR Tolkien) 的《中土世界》中《龙与地下城》的精巧版本。这款游戏持续了一年多的时间，大部分时间都是在沃尔登的客厅地板上玩的。其中一位常客是威尔·克劳瑟 (Will Crowther)。其他十几位玩家都为自己的角色选择了像 Zandar、Klarf 或 Groan 这样的名字，而克劳瑟只给自己的角色起了威利 (Willie)，一个鬼鬼祟祟的小偷。

Dave Walden got his introduction to the game one night in 1975, when Eric Roberts, a student from a class he was teaching at Harvard, took him to a D&D session. Walden immediately rounded up a group of friends from theARPANETteam for continued sessions. Roberts created the Mirkwood Tales, an elaborate version of Dungeons and Dragons set in J. R. R. Tolkien’s Middle Earth. The game stretched on for the better part of a year and was played mostly on Walden’s living room floor. One of the regulars was Will Crowther. Where the other dozen players chose names like Zandar, Klarf, or Groan for their characters, Crowther’s was simply Willie, a stealthy thief.

克劳瑟还是一位热心的洞穴探险家。他的妻子帕特因参与发现肯塔基州猛犸山洞和弗林特岭洞穴之间首个已知连接而成为洞穴探险家的名人。这两个洞穴系统总长 144 英里，是世界上已知最长的洞穴。克劳瑟是洞穴研究基金会的制图师。他利用业余时间在 BBN 计算机上绘制复杂的地下地图。

Crowther was also an ardent cave explorer. And his wife Pat had achieved renown among cavers for having been part of a small group that discovered the first known link between the Mammoth and Flint Ridge caves in Kentucky. The combined 144-mile system was the longest known cave in the world. Crowther was the cartographer for the Cave Research Foundation. He used his off-hours to plot intricate subterranean maps on a BBN computer.

1976 年初，威尔和帕特离婚。他想找点事情和两个孩子一起做，于是他想出了一个主意，将程序员威尔和虚构的小偷威利联系在一起：一款简化的龙与地下城电脑版游戏，名为《冒险》。尽管这款游戏没有使用肯塔基州洞穴的实际地图，但克劳瑟根据这些地下室的鲜明心理图像设计了《冒险》的几何图形。游戏开始时玩家要穿过的铁栅栏是以公园管理局在弗林特岭系统入口处安装的铁栅栏为原型的。他甚至还开了一两个洞穴探险的玩笑；游戏中一块岩石上刻着的“Y2”是洞穴探险者对次要入口的简称。

In early 1976 Will and Pat divorced. Looking for something he could do with his two children, he hit upon an idea that united Will the programmer with Willie the imaginary thief: a simplified, computer version of Dungeons and Dragons called Adventure. Although the game did not use actual maps of the Kentucky caves, Crowther based the geometry of Adventure on stark mental images of those underground chambers. The iron grate through which players passed at the start of the game was modeled on those installed by the Park Service at entrances to the Flint Ridge system. He even included a caving in-joke or two; the “Y2” inscribed on a rock at one point in the game is caver shorthand for a secondary entrance.

克劳瑟在三四个周末内完成了这个项目。他的孩子（一个 7 岁，一个 5 岁）非常喜欢这个项目，克劳瑟开始向朋友们展示。但婚姻破裂削弱了克劳瑟的精神，他再也没有时间完善这项运动。

Crowther finished the program over the course of three or four weekends. His kids—ages seven and five—loved it, and Crowther began showing it to friends. But the breakup of his marriage had sapped Crowther’s spirit, and he never got around to refining the game.

鲍勃·泰勒 (Bob Taylor) 现任施乐公司帕洛阿尔托研究中心计算机科学实验室主任，他先后说服塞韦罗·奥恩斯坦 (Severo Ornstein) 和威尔·克劳瑟 (Will Crowther) 加入他。克劳瑟于 1976 年搬到加利福尼亚后，将 Adventure 程序留在了 BBN 计算机的一个文件中。尽管这款游戏尚未完善，但 Adventure 的口碑已传遍网络社区。

Bob Taylor, now director of the Computer Science Lab at Xerox Corporation’s Palo Alto Research Center, persuaded first Severo Ornstein, then Will Crowther, to join him, and when Crowther moved to California in 1976 he left the Adventure program behind in a file on a BBN computer. Unpolished though the game was, word of Adventure had filtered through the network community.

斯坦福大学的研究生唐·伍兹 (Don Woods) 从一位朋友那里听说了 Adventure，这位朋友在斯坦福医学院的电脑上看到了这款游戏的副本，于是他就从那里下载了这款游戏。但伍兹一开始很难运行 Adventure，当他运行起来时，他发现它充满了错误。尽管如此，他还是迷上了这款游戏。“Adventure 让用户感觉他们与计算机有更多的互动，”伍兹说。“它似乎对你输入的内容有更多反应，而不仅仅是像一个沉默的对手一样自己行动。我认为这吸引了许多玩家，否则他们可能会对与计算机‘对抗’的想法感到厌烦。这是在与计算机‘一起’玩游戏。”

A Stanford graduate student named Don Woods heard about Adventure from a friend who had run across a copy on the Stanford Medical School computer, and he downloaded the game from there. But Woods had difficulty getting Adventure to run at first, and when he did he found it riddled with bugs. Still, he was hooked. “Adventure made users feel like they were interacting more with the computer,” said Woods. “It seemed to be responding more to what you typed, rather than just making its own moves like a silent opponent. I think this attracted a lot of players who might otherwise have been turned off by the idea of playing ‘against’ a computer. This was playing ‘with’a computer.”

游戏的作者是威尔·克劳瑟，伍兹决定找到克劳瑟，获取源代码，以便开始修复这个简陋的小程序。他给网络上的每一台主机发电子邮件寻找克劳瑟，最后在 PARC 找到了他。克劳瑟高兴地交出了代码。重新修改花了几个月的时间，在此期间，这个简单的程序的大小增加了一倍。伍兹创造了新的障碍，增加了一个海盗，进一步扭曲了迷宫，并增加了几个需要解决一些问题才能找到的宝藏。

The game listed Will Crowther as the author, and Woods decided to track down Crowther to get the source code so he could start making repairs to the rudimentary little program. He sent e-mail to every host on the network looking for Crowther, and finally he found him at PARC. Crowther happily handed over the code. It took several months to rework, during which the simple program doubled in size. Woods created new obstacles, added a pirate, twisted the mazes further, and added several treasures that required some problem solving before they were found.

Adventure 完成后，Woods 在斯坦福人工智能实验室的计算机上创建了一个访客帐户，供人们玩，于是大批访客登录。随着人们通过网络互相发送程序，Adventure 像呼啦圈一样传播开来。由于 Crowther 用 FORTRAN 编写了该程序，因此它可以相对轻松地适应许多不同的计算机。Crowther 和 Woods 都鼓励程序员盗版该游戏，并将他们的电子邮件地址提供给任何需要帮助安装、玩或复制该游戏的人。

When Adventure was done, Woods created a guest account on the computer at the Stanford AI Lab to let people play, and swarms of guests logged in. Adventure spread like hula hoops, as people sent the program to one another over the network. Because Crowther had written it in FORTRAN, it could be adapted to many different computers with relative ease. Both Crowther and Woods encouraged programmers to pirate the game and included their e-mail addresses for anyone looking for help installing, playing, or copying the game.

人们睡眼惺忪地搜寻宝藏，直到凌晨。“很久以前，我就数不清有多少程序员告诉我，他们开始使用电脑的经历就是玩冒险游戏，”伍兹说。这款游戏启发了数百款仿制品，最终催生了整个行业。

People grew bleary-eyed searching for treasure into the small hours of the morning. ”I’ve long ago lost count of the programmers who’ve told me that the experience that got them started using computers was playing Adventure,” Woods said. The game inspired hundreds of knockoffs, which eventually spawned an entire industry.

冒险证明了开放网络文化的吸引力。随着时间的推移，对开放性的重视程度不断提高。网络上几乎没有封闭的大门，自由精神在人们的态度中占主导地位，人们可以自由地进出网络，也可以出于什么目的。任何试图限制研究生自由使用网络的人都会严重误解计算机科学界的思维方式。ARPANET 是联邦政府的官方财产，但网络邮件被用于各种日常对话。

Adventure demonstrated the appeal of an open networking culture. And the emphasis on openness grew with time. There were few closed doors on the network, and a free spirit prevailed in people’s attitudes about who could come and go through them, and for what purposes. Anyone trying to restrict the graduate student population from freely using the network would have grossly misunderstood the mind-set of the computer science community. TheARPANET was official federal government property, but network mail was being used for all manner of daily conversation.

随后，在 1977 年春天，Quasar 问世了。它的问世标志着网络空间言论自由的首次辩论的开始。这场争论的焦点是 Quasar Industries 制造的一款不同寻常的设备，并演变成一场关于使用纳税人资助的 ARPANET 公开批评一家私营公司的争论。

Then, in the spring of 1977, Quasar rolled in the door. Its arrival marked the beginning of the first debate over free speech in cyberspace. The controversy centered on an unusual device made by Quasar Industries and blew up into an argument over using the taxpayerfundedARPANETto speak, in openly critical terms, about a private company.

该设备是 Quasar Industries 的创意，高 5 英尺 4 英寸，重 240 磅。它被称为家用安卓机器人，是一个可编程的助手，可以执行十几种基本的家务，例如拖地、修剪草坪、洗碗和端上鸡尾酒。它配备了个性和语言，因此可以“在任何人类情况下互动”。它可以“教孩子们法语”，并且“在他们睡觉时继续教他们”。广告上说它的价格是 4,000 美元，这似乎很划算。

The brainchild of Quasar Industries, the device stood five feet four inches and weighed two hundred forty pounds. It was called the Domestic Android robot, a programmable helper that could perform a dozen basic household tasks such as mopping the floor, mowing the lawn, washing dishes, and serving cocktails. It came equipped with a personality and speech, so that it could “interact in any human situation.” It could “teach the kids French” and “continue teaching them, while they sleep.” At the advertised price of $4,000, the thing seemed a steal.

1977 年 5 月 26 日，卡内基梅隆大学的 Phil Karlton 率先向 Msg-Group 发出了警告。他在 ARPANET 上的站点大量涉及人工智能、语音识别和相关研究问题的探索，因此他对机器人略知一二。机器人及其发明者吸引了全国媒体的大量关注，其中大部分都是正面的。Quasar 的销售宣传也引起了《消费者报告》的注意，该杂志在 6 月刊上刊登了一篇对其持怀疑态度的文章。

Phil Karlton of Carnegie-Mellon was the first to alert the Msg-Group, on May 26, 1977. His site on theARPANETwas heavily involved in exploring artificial intelligence, speech recognition, and related research problems, so he knew a thing or two about robots. The android and its inventor had attracted a fair amount of national press attention, most of it favorable. Quasar’s sales pitch had also caught the attention ofConsumer Reports,which ran a skeptical item on it in the June issue, just out.

起初，Quasar 似乎只是 MsgGroup 主营业务的一个有趣的消遣。小组中的每个人都知道这是个骗局，而且有一段时间，这似乎已经足够了。但后来，一种公民责任感油然而生。Dave Farber 讲述了他在佛罗里达州博卡拉顿时在收音机上听到戴德县警察局正在考虑为他们的县监狱购买一台 Quasar 警卫机器人，价格为 7,000 美元。3 月，《波士顿环球报》刊登了一篇引用麻省理工学院的 Marvin Minsky 和其他持怀疑态度的人工智能专家的报道。但 MsgGroup 的一名成员表示，这篇文章的整体态度是“它只是向你表明，那些院士无法做任何实际的事情，你所需要的只是一个在车库后面工作的人来让他们感到羞愧。”这个故事在人工智能研究界留下了一片怀疑的痕迹。

At first Quasar seemed nothing but an amusing diversion from the MsgGroup’s main business. Everyone in the group knew the thing was a hoax, and for a while that seemed enough. But then a sense of civic duty arose. Dave Farber told of being in Boca Raton, Florida, and hearing on the radio that the Dade County police department was considering purchasing a Quasar guard robot for their county jail, for $7,000. In March theBoston Globeran a story quoting MIT’s Marvin Minsky and other skeptical AI experts. But the article took the overall attitude, said a MsgGroup member, that it “just goes to show you, those academicians can’t do anything practical, and all you need is some guy working in the back of a garage to put them to shame.” The saga left a trail of disbelief in the artificial intelligence research community.

卡内基梅隆大学人工智能实验室的 Brian Reid 和同事 Mark Fox 向 MsgGroup 的所有人发布了一份另类的报告，介绍了他们在匹兹堡市中心一家大型百货商店检查家用机器人“Sam Strugglegear”的个人经历。研究界人士知道卡内基梅隆大学的开创性人工智能工作，他们一直打电话给实验室询问 Quasar 的机器人在语音识别方面为何比卡内基梅隆大学生产的任何产品都要好得多。卡内基梅隆大学的一个四人小组接受了挑战，进行了实地调查。

Brian Reid and a colleague, Mark Fox, from the Carnegie-Mellon Artificial Intelligence Lab, posted an offbeat report to everyone in the MsgGroup, giving them a personal account of their inspection of the domestic robot, “Sam Strugglegear,” at a large department store in downtown Pittsburgh. People in the research community, knowing of CMU’s pioneering AI work, had been calling the Lab to ask how it was possible for Quasar’s robot to be so much better at speech recognition than anything CMU had produced. Rising to the challenge, a four-member team from CMU had done the fieldwork.

“他们发现了令人恐惧的一幕，”里德和福克斯报道说。在男装部，在三件套西装中间，有一个五英尺二英寸的“带轮子的喷雾罐，正在向人群生动地讲话”。电动马达和齿轮系统驱动着设备的手臂。这个机器人似乎对任何话题都很熟悉，能识别顾客的体貌特征，并能自由地向任何方向移动。人群被迷住了。

“They found a frightening sight,” reported Reid and Fox. In the men’s department, among the three-piece suits, was a five-feet-two-inch “aerosol can on wheels, talking animatedly” to a crowd. Electric motors and a system of gears moved the device’s arms. The robot seemed conversant on any subject, recognized the physical features of customers, and moved freely in any direction. The crowd was charmed.

但科学家们对此表示怀疑。他们四处寻找遥控器的证据。“瞧，在距离机器人约十英尺的地方，我们发现一个穿着蓝色西装的男人站在人群中，他用手捂住嘴，若有所思，就像亚里士多德在凝视着伦勃朗名画中荷马的半身像一样。”里德和其他人观察了一会儿，发现每当机器人说话时，穿着蓝色西装的男人也会说话——对着他的手喃喃自语。这名男子腰间挂着一根可疑的电线。

But the scientists were skeptical. They looked around for some evidence of a remote controller. “Lo and behold, about ten feet from the robot, standing in the crowd, we found a man in a blue suit with his hand held contemplatively to his mouth like Aristotle contemplating the bust of Homer in the famous Rembrandt painting.” Reid and the others watched for awhile and noticed that whenever the robot was talking, so was the man in the blue suit—muttering into his hand. The man had a wire dangling suspiciously from his waist.

关于 Quasar 机器人的讨论断断续续持续了几年，直到 1979 年初，MsgGroup 的主持人 Einar Stefferud 和一直潜伏在评论之外的 Dave Farber 向 MsgGroup 发出了警告。他们警告说：“当我们批评 Quasar 机器人时，我们是在自找麻烦。”他们说，利用美国政府设施诽谤一家公司可能会对 ARPA 研究界产生不利影响。他们敦促同行们实施严格的自我审查，只向社区报告技术上感兴趣的事实。但并非所有人都同意，MsgGroup 也因此陷入了一场深刻的反省。

The discussion about the Quasar robot continued on and off for a couple of years until in early 1979, Einar Stefferud, the MsgGroup’s moderator, and Dave Farber, who had been lurking on the sidelines of the commentary, sent a note of caution to the MsgGroup. “We are asking for potential problems,” they warned, “when we criticize the Quasar robot.” Using U.S. Government facilities to cast aspersions on a corporation, they said, could backfire on the ARPA research community. They urged their peers to impose careful self-censorship, to report only facts of technical interest to the community. Not everyone agreed, and with that the MsgGroup got embroiled in a soul-searching exchange.

斯坦福大学人工智能实验室的约翰·麦卡锡 (John McCarthy) 是被 Quasar 的言论激怒最多的人之一。他告诉小组，他不会因为 Quasar 可能起诉的猜测而退缩。“我认为似乎有人害怕自己的影子，”麦卡锡说。“起诉批评者从来都不是嘉年华江湖骗子的习惯。”明斯基和里德还明确表示，他们会告诉任何记者，他们认为这个机器人是个笑话，他们已经向十几位记者表达了这一观点。

John McCarthy, who worked at Stanford’s Artificial Intelligence Lab, was among those most offended by Quasar’s claims. He told the group that he would not be deterred by speculation that Quasar might sue. “I think someone seems to be frightened of his shadow,” McCarthy said. “It has never been the custom of carnival snake-oil salesmen to sue their critics.” Minsky and Reid also made it clear that they would tell any reporter who asked that they believed the robot was a joke, and they’d already expressed that opinion to more than a dozen journalists.

“我并不担心被起诉，”法伯回答道。“但是，我们使用的是一种名为 ARPANET 的公共工具。因此，当我们使用该工具发布可能具有诽谤性的材料时，ARPA、DOD 以及我们未来对该网络的访问和使用将面临某些危险。”法伯再次敦促克制。

“I have no fear of being sued,” replied Farber. “However, we are using a public vehicle called theARPANET. We thereby expose ARPA, DOD, and our future access and use of the network to certain dangers when we use that vehicle for potentially libelous material.” Farber again urged restraint.

里德插话说：“MsgGroup 是我们最接近全国计算机科学社区论坛的地方。”里德开始注意到消息组就像一个社交俱乐部。他们之间争论太多，以至于成为了朋友。限制讨论是不自然的。此外，里德对言论自由持更自由的看法，他认为如果话题受到限制，通信实验就会受到影响。“除非人们开始建议推翻我们的政府，”他说，“否则我认为任何明智的话题都不应该被禁止。”

Reid chimed in, saying, “[the] MsgGroup is the closest that we have to a nationwide computer science community forum.” Reid had begun to notice that the Message Group was like a social club. They had argued with each other so much that they had become friends. To restrict discussion would be unnatural. Besides, Reid took a more liberal view of free speech, reasoning that the experiment in communications would suffer if topics were restricted. “Until such time as people start suggesting the overthrow of our government,” he said, “I don’t think any sensible topic should be off limits.”

有人建议在 ARPANET 上的个人通信中附加免责声明，这样个人意见就不会被误认为是公务。另一个人承认，“谁没有使用网络邮件进行个人通信？谁没有花时间在网上玩一些新游戏？说实话。”捍卫言论自由的热情与同样强烈的自我保护意愿相匹配；保护网络本身的方法是不吸引政府不必要的监督。几天后，争论没有解决，MsgGroup 照常开展业务。

Someone suggested attaching a disclaimer to personal communications on theARPANETso that personal opinions wouldn’t be mistaken for official business. Admitted someone else, “Who hasn’t used Net mail for personal communication? Who hasn’t spent time playing some new game over the Net? Be honest.” The passion in defense of free speech was matched by an equally strong will to self-protection; the way to protect the network itself was not to attract unwanted supervision by the government. After a few days the argument wore itself out without resolution and the MsgGroup carried on with business as usual.

这场辩论得出的有力证据表明，网络社区对网络的创建有着深切的利害关系，无论有没有 ARPA 资助，他们都在竭尽全力捍卫自己决定未来的权利。在某种意义上，个人身份完全由人们选择的词语来定义，言论自由似乎仅次于对网络本身生存的关注。

What emerged from the debate was strong evidence that the networking community felt a deep stake in the creation of the Net, ARPA funding or no ARPA funding, and was trying jealously to guard its right to determine its future. In a realm where, in a sense, personal identity is defined entirely by the words people choose, free speech seemed second only to concern for the survival of the realm itself.

铜脐带缆

Copper Umbilicals

1976 年第一季度的流量报告显示，ARPANET 邮件量与美国普通邮件量相比，只是大象群足迹中的蚂蚁足迹。例如，麻省理工学院的人工智能实验室在此期间传递了大约 9,925 条消息。（相比之下，到 1996 年，一些站点每天处理 150,000 封电子邮件。）麻省理工学院是一个典型的站点，通过推断，如果一台机器每天处理大约一百封电子邮件，乘以 98 倍左右（当时网络上的主机数量），电子邮件似乎还没有对美国邮政系统构成威胁。邮局每年处理超过 500 亿封一等邮件。但电子邮件的急剧增长曲线并没有被忽视。

For the first quarter of 1976, traffic reports showed that the volume ofARPANETmail, compared to the volume of regular U.S. mail, was a mere ant trail in the tracks of an elephant herd. MIT’s Artificial Intelligence Lab, for example, passed some 9,925 messages during the period. (By 1996, by comparison, some sites were processing 150,000 e-mail messages every day.) MIT was a typical site, and by extrapolation, if one machine processed about a hundred pieces of e-mail a day, multiplied by a factor of 98 or so (the number of hosts then on the Net) electronic mail didn’t yet appear to pose a threat to the U.S. postal system. The post office handled more than 50 billion pieces of firstclass mail a year. But e-mail’s steep growth curve wasn’t going unnoticed.

在私营部门，各公司都已做好迎接电子邮件服务概念的准备。美国计算机公司很快开始销售首批商用电子邮件软件包之一，即一款名为 COMET 的产品，售价 40,000 美元，专为 PDP-11 小型计算机设计。另一款名为 MESSENGER 的程序是为 IBM 360 和 370 计算机开发的，很快由一家名为 On-Line Software International 的公司以 18,000 美元的价格出售。成本正在下降，一些分析师预测这将对美国邮政局的一流业务产生“毁灭性”影响。

In the private sector, companies were poised for the concept of electronic-mail service to take off. The Computer Corporation of America soon began selling one of the first commercially available e-mail software packages, a $40,000 product calledCOMET, designed for the PDP-11 minicomputer. Another program calledMESSENGER, developed for IBM 360 and 370 computers, was soon available from a company called On-Line Software International, for $18,000. Costs were heading down, and some analysts projected a “devastating” impact on the U.S. Postal Service’s first-class business.

1976 年初，美国邮政局长助理报告称：“我们在技术上被超越了。”新技术的增长趋势和明显的潜力确实相当惊人。一些更复杂的 ARPANET 电子邮件程序（如 MSG、HERMES 和 SRI 的 NLS JOURNAL MAIL）的版本正在进入非研究人员的手中。包括美国地质调查局、商务部、国家安全局和海湾石油公司在内的几家大型组织都已开始在局域网上使用电子邮件。

“We are being bypassed technologically,” reported an assistant U.S. postmaster general at the beginning of 1976. The new technology’s growth trend and obvious potential were indeed quite dramatic. A few versions of the more sophisticatedARPANETmail programs such asMSG,HERMES , and SRI’sNLS JOURNAL MAIL, were coming into the hands of nonresearchers. Several large organizations including the U.S. Geological Survey, Department of Commerce, National Security Agency, and Gulf Oil had all started using e-mail over local area networks.

政府正在密切关注电子邮件服务的未来。咨询公司 Arthur D. Little 为白宫电信政策办公室撰写的一份报告估计，几年内所有一等邮件的 30% 可能会以电子方式发送。邮政局对这一预测作出了反应，授予 RCA 一份价值 220 万美元的合同，以评估提供电子​​邮件服务的技术和经济可行性。RCA 在其报告中主张将电子邮件添加到邮局的服务中。USPS 顾问小组也进行了仔细研究。他们建议对电子邮件做出“坚定而持续的承诺”，与 NASA 的载人航天计划相媲美。1976 年秋天，吉米·卡特的总统竞选团队每天使用电子邮件数次。他们使用的系统是一个基本的邮箱程序，这项技术已经有十多年的历史了。但对于政治竞选来说，这是通信领域的一次革命性举措。基于此，卡特被称为“计算机驱动的候选人”。

The government was looking closely at the future of e-mail service. A report for the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy by the consulting firm Arthur D. Little estimated that 30 percent of all first-class mail was likely to be sent electronically within a few years. The postal service reacted to that prediction by awarding RCA a $2.2 million contract to evaluate the technical and economic feasibility of providing e-mail service. In its report, RCA argued for adding e-mail to the post office’s services. A USPS advisory panel also took a close look. They recommended making a “firm and continuing commitment” to electronic mail, on a par with NASA’s manned space program. Jimmy Carter’s presidential campaign used e-mail several times a day in the autumn of 1976. The system they were using was a basic mailbox program, a technology already more than a decade old. But for a political campaign this was a revolutionary stroke in communications. On that basis, Carter was labeled the “computer-driven candidate.”

1979 年，卡特总统支持邮局提出的一项提案，即向全国提供一种有限的电子信息服务。这种混合方案的工作方式更像是电报服务，而不是最先进的电子通信系统。信息将在夜间以电子方式在邮局之间传输，然后于第二天送到收件人的家门口。这项提案之所以引人注目，主要是因为它在技术可能性方面显得非常谨慎。

By 1979, President Carter was supporting a post office proposal to offer a limited kind of electronic message service to the nation. The hybrid scheme worked more like a telegram service than a state-of-the-art electronic communications system. Messages would be transmitted electronically between post offices overnight, then delivered to recipients’doorsteps the next day. The proposal was remarkable mainly for how cautious it seemed in view of the technological possibilities.

Stefferud 和 MsgGroup（电子邮件领域最有经验的社区）的其他成员立即发现了美国邮政服务计划的缺陷，该计划涉及将信息从数字电子媒体转换为纸质文件，然后像普通邮件一样通过人工投递。这种方法不仅比电子邮件成本更高，而且只要依靠 USPS 传统的人工力量完成最后几步，它就永远无法与电子邮件竞争。Stefferud 预测，台式计算机“将成为完美的邮箱”，并将完全绕过邮局。可以将其与曾经荒谬的自动垃圾收集概念进行类比，在“电猪”发明之前，这是不可想象的，电猪是水槽内垃圾处理器的早期名称。“关键不在于实现袋子/罐子/卡车/人员机制的自动化，”Stefferud 说。“关键在于完全绕过它们。”

Stefferud and others in the MsgGroup—the community with the most experience with email—immediately saw the flaws in the U.S. Postal Service’s plan, which involved converting messages from digital electronic media to paper and then delivering them by hand as you would ordinary mail. Not only would this approach cost more than e-mail, but it would never be fast enough to compete with e-mail as long as it depended on USPS’s traditional foot power for those final steps to the mailbox. Desktop computers “will make the perfect mailbox,” Stefferud predicted, and would bypass the post office entirely. An analogy could be drawn to the once farcical notion of automated garbage collection, which was unthinkable until the invention of the “electric pig,” the early name given to the in-sink disposal. “The key is not in automating the bag/can/truck/ person mechanism,” Stefferud said. “It is in bypassing them altogether.”

美国邮政服务公司和早先的 AT&T 公司一样，从未真正摆脱保护传统业务的思维模式，可能是因为两者都是垄断实体。最终，美国司法部、联邦通信委员会甚至邮政费率委员会都反对政府在电子邮件服务中扮演任何重要角色，宁愿将其留给自由市场。

The USPS, like AT&T earlier, never really broke free of the mindset guarding its traditional business, probably because both were monopolistic entities. Eventually the U.S. Justice Department, the FCC, and even the Postal Rate Commission opposed any significant government role in e-mail services, preferring to leave them to the free market.

在 MsgGroup 中，任何话题都无需长时间讨论。这种媒介的速度和便捷性为人们带来了随意、自发的对话。到 20 世纪 90 年代末，利克莱德和巴兰等人意识到，他们参与发起的一场革命已经开始。

No issue was ever too small for long discussion in the MsgGroup. The speed and ease of the medium opened vistas of casual and spontaneous conversation. It was apparent by the end of the decade to people like Licklider and Baran that a revolution they had helped start was now under way.

“明天，计算机通信系统将成为作者之间远程协作的规则”，巴兰和加州大学欧文分校的戴夫·法伯写道。这些评论出现在一篇通过电子邮件共同撰写的论文中，两人相隔五百英里。该论文于 1977 年在 MsgGroup 上以电子版形式“发表”。他们继续说道：“随着计算机通信系统变得更加强大、更加人性化、更加宽容，最重要的是更加便宜，它们将变得无处不在。”自动酒店预订、信用检查、实时金融交易、保险和医疗记录访问、一般信息检索以及企业的实时库存控制都将实现。

“Tomorrow, computer communications systems will be the rule for remote collaboration” between authors, wrote Baran and UC Irvine’s Dave Farber. The comments appeared in a paper written jointly, using e-mail, with five hundred miles between them. It was “published” electronically in the MsgGroup in 1977. They went on: “As computer communication systems become more powerful, more humane, more forgiving and above all, cheaper, they will become ubiquitous.” Automated hotel reservations, credit checking, real-time financial transactions, access to insurance and medical records, general information retrieval, and real-time inventory control in businesses would all come.

20 世纪 70 年代末，信息处理技术办公室向 ARPA 管理层提交的关于 ARPANET 研究项目完成情况的最终报告得出了类似的结论：“ARPANET 项目最大的惊喜是网络邮件的惊人普及和成功。毫无疑问，与 ARPANET 项目相关的网络邮件技术将席卷全国，并彻底改变公共和私营部门的相互通信技术。”

In the late 1970s, the Information Processing Techniques Office’s final report to ARPA management on the completion of theARPANETresearch program concluded similarly: “The largest single surprise of theARPANETprogram has been the incredible popularity and success of network mail. There is little doubt that the techniques of network mail developed in connection with theARPANETprogram are going to sweep the country and drastically change the techniques used for intercommunication in the public and private sectors.”

对于 MsgGroup 的成员来说，电子邮件就像是放在灯光下的钻石一样令人着迷。MsgGroup 的成员会探究每一个细节。他们是这项技术的狂热爱好者。例如，时间和日期戳的问题就是典型问题。“我老板的老板的老板抱怨那些熬夜的人胡言乱语，”有人说。“他可以从时间戳（和发件人的习惯）看出对信息的重视程度。”

To members of the MsgGroup, electronic mail was as engrossing as a diamond held to the light. MsgGroup members probed every detail. They were junkies for the technology.
