The issue of time and date stamps, for example, was classic. “My boss’s boss’s boss complains of the ravings of the late-nighters,” someone said. “He can tell from the time stamp (and the sender’s habits) how seriously to take the message.”

另一位用户说：“也许除了日期和时间之外，我们还应该用月相来标记时间。”（不久之后，有人编写了一个电子邮件程序来实现这个功能。）

 

 

“我真的很喜欢看到准确的时间戳，”另一个人说道。“能够解开收到的乱七八糟的评论顺序真是太好了。”

 

 

“有些人明目张胆地利用这一点来显示自己胜人一筹。‘我工作的时间比你长。’”

MsgGroup 成员可以就任何事情进行争论。有时你会发誓你刚刚加入了一群激烈的律师、语法学家或拉比的讨论。陌生人会随意地加入对话，或者有人称之为“多方对话”。随着常客彼此熟悉，他们之间的友谊迅速加深，有时甚至在他们真正见面之前就已经建立了多年友谊。在许多方面，ARPANET 社区的基本价值观都是传统的——言论自由、平等使用权、个人隐私。然而，电子邮件也不受约束，创造了完全属于自己的参考点，这是一个虚拟社会，其礼仪、价值观和可接受的行为——例如“火上浇油”的做法——对世界其他地方来说都是陌生的。

MsgGroup members could argue about anything. There were times when you’d swear you had just dropped in on a heated group of lawyers, or grammarians, or rabbis. Strangers fell casually into the dialogue or, as someone called it, the “polylogue.” As the regulars became familiar to one another, fast friendships were cemented, sometimes years before people actually met. In many ways theARPANET community’s basic values were traditional—free speech, equal access, personal privacy. However, e-mail also was uninhibiting, creating reference points entirely its own, a virtual society, with manners, values, and acceptable behaviors—the practice of “flaming,” for example—strange to the rest of the world.

MsgGroup 中的熟悉偶尔会滋生出轻蔑的语言。ARPANET 上第一次真正的“争吵”（一种激烈的、通常带有辱骂性的对话形式）爆发于 20 世纪 70 年代中期。这种争吵引发了鲁莽的反驳和言语争吵。然而，MsgGroup 中的激烈争吵相对得到了控制，因为他们认为自己是文明的。当事情变得特别喧闹和有争议时，Stefferud 几乎凭一己之力冷静地将这个小组团结在一起。他努力保持 MsgGroup 的正常运转，在必要时解析困难的标头或消除误解，确保小组的情绪和流量不会变得太糟糕。当遇到技术问题时，他说过最糟糕的话就是一些标头有“口臭”。

Familiarity in the MsgGroup occasionally bred the language of contempt. The first real “flaming” (a fiery, often abusive form of dialogue) on theARPANEThad flared up in the mid-1970s. The medium engendered rash rejoiners and verbal tussles. Yet heavy flaming was kept relatively in check in the MsgGroup, which considered itself civilized. Stefferud almost single-handedly and cool-headedly kept the group together when things got particularly raucous and contentious. He slaved to keep the MsgGroup functioning, parsing difficult headers when necessary or smoothing out misunderstandings, making sure the group’s mood and its traffic never got too snarly. About the worst he ever said, when beset by technical problems, was that some headers had “bad breath.”

相比之下，隔壁有一个讨论组（打个比方），叫做 Header People，据说是地狱。“我们通常穿着石棉内衣，”一位参与者说。Header People 位于麻省理工学院，由 Ken Harrenstien 于 1976 年创立。该小组是非官方的，但更重要的是，它没有主持人（这意味着它没有 Stefferud 那样的人性过滤器）。Harrenstien 打算从 ARPANET 上的每种系统中招募至少一名开发人员，很快 Header People 中的冲突就将关于 header 的争论提升到了圣战的水平，然后爆发了冲突。“一群精神抖擞的猛击手，”Harrenstien 说，“把一匹马的尸体打得粉碎。”这两个以邮件为导向的小组有很多重叠之处；即使在文明的 Msg-Group 公司，脾气也会定期爆发。讽刺性攻击和恶语攻击是网络通信所特有的，在任何其他情况下都是不可接受的反社会行为，但在 ARPANET 上却很常见。任何时间都可能因为任何事情而爆发争吵，争吵可能持续一条消息，也可能持续一百条消息。

By comparison, there was a discussion group next door (metaphorically speaking), called Header People, reputed to be an inferno. “We normally wear asbestos underwear,” said one participant. Based at MIT, Header People had been started by Ken Harrenstien in 1976. The group was unofficial, but more important, it was unmoderated (meaning it had no Stefferud-like human filter). Harrenstien had set out to recruit at least one developer from every kind of system on theARPANET,and in no time the conflicts in Header People raised the debate over headers to the level of a holy war before flaming out. “A bunch of spirited sluggers,” said Harrenstien, “pounding an equine cadaver to smithereens.” The two mail-oriented groups overlapped considerably; even in civilized Msg-Group company, tempers flared periodically. The acidic attacks and level of haranguing unique to on-line communication, unacceptably asocial in any other context, was oddly normative on theARPANET. Flames could start up at any time over anything, and they could last for one message or one hundred.

FINGER 争议是一场关于网络隐私的辩论，它发生在 1979 年初，引发了 MsgGroup 历史上最严重的争吵。这场争吵的起因是卡内基梅隆大学推出了一种电子小工具，它允许用户窥探网络上其他用户的上网习惯。FINGER 命令是 20 世纪 70 年代初由斯坦福人工智能实验室的计算机科学家 Les Earnest 创建的。“人们通常在那里工作很长时间，而且日程安排常常难以预测，”Earnest 说。“当你想和某个小组会面时，重要的是要知道谁在那里，其他人什么时候可能再次出现。当您想打排球时，能够找到潜在的排球运动员；当您想吃饭时，能够找到中餐爱好者；当系统出现异常情况时，能够找到反社会的计算机用户，这些也很重要。”FINGER 不允许您阅读其他人的消息，但您可以知道此人上次登录的日期和时间，以及他或她上次阅读邮件的时间。有些人对此有意见。

TheFINGERcontroversy, a debate over privacy on the Net, occurred in early 1979 and involved some of the worst flaming in the MsgGroup’s experience. The fight was over the introduction, at Carnegie-Mellon, of an electronic widget that allowed users to peek into the on-line habits of other users on the Net. TheFINGERcommand had been created in the early 1970s by a computer scientist named Les Earnest at Stanford’s Artificial Intelligence Lab. “People generally worked long hours there, often with unpredictable schedules,” Earnest said. “When you wanted to meet with some group, it was important to know who was there and when the others would likely reappear. It also was important to be able to locate potential volleyball players when you wanted to play, Chinese-food freaks when you wanted to eat, and antisocial computer users when it appeared that something strange was happening on the system.”FINGER didn’t allow you to read someone else’s messages, but you could tell the date and time of the person’s last log-on and when last he or she had read mail. Some people had a problem with that.

为了尊重隐私，卡内基梅隆大学的 Ivor Durham 更改了 FINGER 的默认设置；他添加了一些可以打开或关闭的位，这样除非用户选择显示，否则信息就可以被隐藏。Durham 遭到了无情的抨击。人们骂他没骨气、不负责任、小气的政客，甚至更糟——但他没有因为保护隐私而受到批评。人们批评他破坏了网络的开放性。

In an effort to respect privacy, Ivor Durham at CMU changed theFINGER default setting; he added a couple of bits that could be turned on or off, so the information could be concealed unless a user chose to reveal it. Durham was flamed without mercy. He was called everything from spineless to socially irresponsible to a petty politician, and worse—but not for protecting privacy. He was criticized for monkeying with the openness of the network.

这场辩论最初是卡内基梅隆大学的内部对话，但被戴夫·法伯泄露到了阿帕网上，他想看看如果向外界透露的话会发生什么。随后的激烈争论消耗了 400 多条信息。

The debate began as an internal dialogue at CMU but was leaked out onto theARPANETby Dave Farber, who wanted to see what would happen if he revealed it to the outer world. The ensuing flame-fest consumed more than 400 messages.

在 FINGER 争论达到顶峰时，有个人因厌恶这种激烈的争论而退出了 Msg-Group。与 Quasar 争论一样，FINGER 争论也无果而终。但这两场争论都让用户对他们所使用的媒介有了更深刻的认识。有人说，电子邮件的速度促进了激烈的争论；任何热情的人都可以当场反驳，而不需要直视对方的眼睛来调节气氛。

At the height of theFINGERdebate, one person quit the Msg-Group in disgust over the flaming. As with the Quasar debate, theFINGER controversy ended inconclusively. But both debates taught users greater lessons about the medium they were using. The speed of electronic mail promoted flaming, some said; anyone hot could shoot off a retort on the spot, and without the moderating factor of having to look the target in the eye.

到 20 世纪末，MsgGroup 的气氛从一开始的僵硬变成了开放的自由。Stefferud 总是试图让新人加入时通过电子方式介绍自己；离开时，有些人会告别，但后来又出现在其他站点；只有一两个人会非常隆重地离开，因为会有人大吵大闹或做出其他令人不快的行为。

By the end of the decade, the MsgGroup’s tone, which had begun stiffly, was an expansive free-for-all. Stefferud always tried to get newcomers to introduce themselves electronically when they joined the group; when leaving, some bid farewell only to turn up again later at other sites; only one or two people huffed off, quite ceremoniously, over a flame-fest or some other perceived indignity.

MsgGroup 的一位杰出政治家 Dave Crocker 有时会以社会学家的好奇心探索互联网。例如，有一天晚上五点左右，他给全国大约 130 人发了一条消息，只是想看看人们收到消息并回复的速度有多快。他说，回复统计“有点吓人”。七个人在九十分钟内做出了回应。在二十四小时内，他收到了二十八条回复。在一个对信息技术的速度、便捷性和普及性期望不断提高的文化中，这种程度的回复时间和数字似乎并不值得一提。但在 20 世纪 70 年代，“这绝对是一种令人惊讶的经历”，Crocker 说，能如此迅速、如此轻松地收到如此多的回复。

One of the MsgGroup’s eminent statesmen, Dave Crocker, sometimes probed the Net with a sociologist’s curiosity. One day, for example, he sent a note to approximately 130 people around the country at about five o’clock in the evening, just to see how fast people would get the message and reply. The response statistics, he reported, were “a little scary.” Seven people responded within ninety minutes. Within twenty-four hours he had received twenty-eight replies. Response times and numbers on that order may seem hardly noteworthy in a culture that has since squared and cubed its expectations about the speed, ease, and reach of information technology. But in the 1970s “it was an absolutely astonishing experience,” Crocker said, to have gotten so many replies, so quickly, so easily, as that.

1979 年 4 月 12 日，MsgGroup 的一位新人 Kevin MacKenzie 公开表示，这种电子文本媒介“失去了意义”。毫无疑问，电子邮件可以实现自发的口头交流，但他对它无法传达人类的手势、面部表情和语调感到困扰——所有这些都是交谈时自然而然出现的，可以表达言语和思想中的一系列细微差别，包括讽刺和挖苦。也许，他说，我们可以扩展电子邮件中的标点符号。为了表明某个句子是开玩笑的，他建议在句子末尾插入连字符和括号，例如：-)。

On April 12, 1979, a rank newcomer to the MsgGroup named Kevin MacKenzie anguished openly about the “loss of meaning” in this electronic, textually bound medium. Unquestionably, e-mail allowed a spontaneous verbal exchange, but he was troubled by its inability to convey human gestures, facial expressions, and tone of voice—all of which come naturally when talking and express a whole vocabulary of nuances in speech and thought, including irony and sarcasm. Perhaps, he said, we could extend the set of punctuation in e-mail messages. In order to indicate that a particular sentence is meant to be tongue-in-cheek, he proposed inserting a hyphen and parenthesis at the end of the sentence, thus: -).

麦肯齐承认这个想法并非完全是他自己想出来的；灵感来自他在一本旧版《读者文摘》上读到的关于不同主题的内容。大约一小时后，他被批评了，或者说被烧焦了。他被告知他的建议“天真但不愚蠢”。他被简短地讲解了莎士比亚对没有辅助符号的语言的掌握。“那些不愿意学会使用这种工具的人无法通过扩大字母表来拯救他们；他们只会用扩大的胡言乱语来折磨我们。”莎士比亚知道什么？;-) 表情符号和笑脸符号 :-)，毫无疑问，是平民百姓使用的，在电子邮件中逐渐发展成为我们这个时代的肖像符号。

MacKenzie confessed that the idea wasn’t entirely his; it had been sparked by something he had read on a different subject in an old copy ofReader’s Digest.About an hour later, he was flamed, or rather, singed. He was told his suggestion was “naive but not stupid.” He was given a short lecture on Shakespeare’s mastery of the language without auxiliary notation. “Those who will not learn to use this instrument well cannot be saved by an expanded alphabet; they will only afflict us with expanded gibberish.” What did Shakespeare know? ;-) Emoticons and smileys :-), hoisted by the hoi polloi no doubt, grew in e-mail and out into the iconography of our time.

很难确定是什么时候，为什么——也许是因为疲惫，也许是 MsgGroup 中加入了太多新成员——但到了 20 世纪 80 年代初，这个演奏出色、在过去十年中共同创作电子邮件的管弦乐队开始逐渐放弃乐谱，起初几乎是不可察觉的。一个关键的声音在这里消失，另一个声音在那里消失。MsgGroup 似乎不再是和弦，而是白噪音。

It’s a bit difficult to pinpoint when or why—perhaps it was exhaustion, perhaps there were now too many new players in the MsgGroup—but by the early 1980s, note by note, the orchestra that had been performing magnificently and that had collectively created email over a decade, began abandoning the score, almost imperceptibly at first. One key voice would fade here, another would drift off there. Instead of chords, white noise seemed to gradually overtake the MsgGroup.

从某种意义上说，这并不重要。Msg-Group 中的对话本身一直比结果更重要。当然，创建电子邮件机制很重要，但 MsgGroup 还创造了完全不同的东西——一个平等的社区，其中许多人从未见过面，但他们相处得就像他们一生都认识一样。这是他们自 ARPANET 出现以来第一次找到他们一直在寻找的东西的地方。MsgGroup 也许是第一个虚拟社区。

In some sense it didn’t matter. The dialogue itself in the Msg-Group had always been more important than the results. Creating the mechanisms of e-mail mattered, of course, but the MsgGroup also created something else entirely—a community of equals, many of whom had never met each other yet who carried on as if they had known each other all their lives. It was the first place they had found something they’d been looking for since theARPANETcame into existence. The MsgGroup was perhaps the first virtual community.

网络的浪漫并非源自其构建方式或运作方式，而是源自其使用方式。到 1980 年，网络已不再只是计算机和租用线路的集合。它是一个分享工作成果、建立友谊和更开放的沟通方式的地方。类似地，美国人对高速公路系统的浪漫并非由第一个想出如何修整道路、铺设柏油路或在中间画一条线的人创造，而是由第一个发现你可以像詹姆斯·迪恩那样开着敞篷车沿着 66 号公路行驶、大声播放收音机并享受美好时光的人创造。

The romance of the Net came not from how it was built or how it worked but from how it was used. By 1980 the Net was far more than a collection of computers and leased lines. It was a place to share work and build friendships and a more open method of communication. America’s romance with the highway system, by analogy, was created not so much by the first person who figured out how to grade a road or make blacktop or paint a stripe down the middle but by the first person who discovered you could drive a convertible down Route 66 like James Dean and play your radio loud and have a great time.

8 我们手上的火箭

8 A Rocket on Our Hands

1972 年，鲍勃·卡恩离开 BBN，转而为拉里·罗伯茨工作。他推迟了一年才抵达华盛顿，留在剑桥策划 ICCC 演示。在连续六年专注于计算机网络之后，他现在准备彻底脱离这个行业。他不想管理网络项目。因此，他和罗伯茨同意卡恩将设立一个自动化制造技术的新项目。但国会在卡恩到来之前就取消了这个项目。到那时，ARPA 已更名为 DARPA——国防高级研究计划局。正如卡恩曾经说过的那样，D一直在那里，但现在它不再沉默了。ARPANET 这个

名字保留了下来。

Bob Kahn left BBN and went to work for Larry Roberts in 1972. He had deferred his arrival in Washington for a year to stay in Cambridge and plan the ICCC demonstration. Having spent six uninterrupted years focused on computer networking, he was now ready to make a clean break. He did not want to run a network project. So he and Roberts agreed that Kahn would set up a new program in automated manufacturing techniques. But Congress canceled the project before Kahn arrived. By now, ARPA had been changed to DARPA—the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. As Kahn once put it, theDhad always been there, but now it was no longer silent. The

nameARPANETremained.

制造项目结束后，卡恩被召回他已精通的领域。但他想从事最新的实验。

20 世纪 70 年代初，计算机网络实验如火如荼。一些人开始考虑新型分组网络。分组交换的基本原理不太可能得到显著改进。而用于处理消息的协议、接口和路由算法也越来越完善。然而，还有一个领域有待探索，那就是数据传输的媒介。现有的 AT&T 电话线网络显然是首选。但为什么不通过无线电波“空中”传输数据包来构建无线网络呢？

The early 1970s were a time of intense experimentation with computer networking. A few people were beginning to think about new kinds of packet networks. The basic principles of packet-switching were unlikely to be improved upon dramatically. And the protocols, interfaces, and routing algorithms for handling messages were growing more refined. One area still to explore, however, was the medium over which data traveled. The existing AT&T web of telephone lines had been the obvious first choice. But why not make a wireless network by transmitting data packets “on the air” as radio waves?

1969 年，鲍勃·泰勒 (Bob Taylor) 离开 ARPA 之前，他为夏威夷大学建立固定站点无线电网络筹集了资金。它由一位名叫诺姆·艾布拉姆森 (Norm Abramson) 的教授和几位同事设计。他们构建了一个简单的系统，使用无线电在四个岛屿上的七台计算机之间来回广播数据。艾布拉姆森称之为 ALOHA。

In 1969, before Bob Taylor had left ARPA, he set up funding for a fixed-site radio network to be built at the University of Hawaii. It was designed by a professor named Norm Abramson and several colleagues. They constructed a simple system using radios to broadcast data back and forth among seven computers stationed over four islands. Abramson called itALOHA.

ALOHANET 使用的小型无线电与出租车使用的无线电相同，它们共享公共频率而不是单独的信道。该系统采用非常宽松的协议。核心思想是让每个终端在它选择的时间传输数据。但是，如果数据与其他人的传输发生冲突（当流量很大时会发生这种情况），接收器将无法正确解码任何传输。因此，如果源无线电没有收到确认，它会认为数据包已被混淆；它会在稍后以随机间隔重新传输数据包。ALOHA 系统就像电话服务一样，在您尝试讲话后才告诉您线路繁忙，直到那时才通知您。

TheALOHANETused small radios, identical to those used by taxicabs, sharing common frequency instead of separate channels. The system employed a very relaxed protocol. The central idea was to have each terminal transmit whenever it chose to. But if the data collided with somebody else’s transmission (which happened when there was a lot of traffic), the receivers wouldn’t be able to decode either transmission properly. So if the source radio didn’t get an acknowledgment, it assumed the packet had gotten garbled; it retransmitted the packet later at a random interval. TheALOHAsystem was like a telephone service that told you, after you tried to speak, and not until then, that the line was busy.

罗伯茨和卡恩喜欢计算机之间无线电连接的总体思路。为什么不做更具挑战性的事情：设计小型便携式计算机“站点”，放在车上或随身携带，通过分组交换网络连接在一起？1972 年，罗伯茨概述了这一方案。他设想了一个网络，其中位于强大无线电台的中央微型计算机将与较小的移动计算机站点进行通信。罗伯茨要求 SRI 研究这个问题并制定一个实用的系统。

Roberts and Kahn liked the general idea of radio links between computers. Why not do something still more challenging: devise small portable computer “sites” carried around in vehicles or even by hand, linked together in a packet-switching network? In 1972 Roberts outlined the scheme. He envisioned a network in which a central minicomputer situated in a powerful radio station would communicate with smaller mobile computer sites. Roberts asked SRI to study the problem and work out a practical system.

移动计算机站点的概念对陆军具有明显的吸引力。安装在车辆或飞机上的战场计算机（移动目标）比固定装置更不易受到攻击，也更有用。然而，如果毁坏最关键的元素（集中式系统中的固定主计算机），整个网络就会被摧毁。防御这种危险的需要是 Paul Baran 最初设计分布式网络的原因。因此，从生存能力和易于部署的角度来看，分组无线电网络被认为是 ARPANET 的无线版本，是分布式的，而不是集中式的。多年来，分组无线电计划已在少数军事站点部署，但由于技术问题，成本高昂，最终被逐步淘汰。

The concept of mobile computer sites held obvious appeal to the Army. Battlefield computers installed in vehicles or aircraft—moving targets—would be less vulnerable and more useful than fixed installations. Still, destruction of the single most crucial element—the stationary master computer in a centralized system—would take out a whole network. The need to defend against that danger was what had led Paul Baran to devise distributed networks in the first place. So from the standpoint of survivability and easy deployment, the packet radio network was conceived as a wireless version of theARPANET, distributed rather than centralized. Over the years, the packet radio program was deployed at a handful of military sites, but technical problems made it expensive, and it was eventually phased out.

由于无线电信号范围有限，分组无线电网络必须使用相距不超过几十英里的中继站。但地球上方的链路则没有这样的限制。这样的中继站几乎可以“看到”整个地球半球。在监督分组无线电项目期间，卡恩开始考虑通过卫星连接网络，这些网络可以在广阔的领域内访问——往返于海上船只、偏远的陆基站和几乎在世界任何地方飞行的飞机之间。

The limited range of radio signals made it necessary for packet-radio networks to use relay sites no more than a few dozen miles apart. But a link above the earth would have no such constraints. Such a relay would “see” almost an entire hemisphere of the earth. While overseeing the packet-radio projects, Kahn began to think about networks linked by satellites accessible over broad domains—to and from ships at sea, remote land-based stations, and aircraft flying almost anywhere in the world.

到 20 世纪 70 年代初，许多通信卫星（其中大部分是军用卫星）已进入轨道。如果装备得当，这样的卫星可以充当通信中继。由于卫星通信距离遥远，信号会延迟。数据包到达目的地的平均行程大约需要三分之一秒，比 ARPANET 上的主机到主机延迟时间长几倍。因此，数据包卫星网络会很慢。

By the early 1970s, many communications satellites—most of them military—were in orbit. Appropriately equipped, such a satellite could serve as a relay for communication. With the huge distances involved in satellite communications, signals would be delayed. The average trip for a packet to its destination would take about one third of a second, several times longer than host-to-host delays on theARPANET. As a result, packetsatellite networks would be slow.

尽管如此，分组交换网络及其附属计算机可以通过卫星反射的无线电波连接起来的想法不仅对美国政府有吸引力，而且对欧洲人也有吸引力，因为当时跨大西洋的地面电路成本高昂，而且容易出错。卫星网络被称为 SATNET 。美国研究人员与英国和挪威的计算机科学家一起加入进来，不久之后，意大利和德国也建立了卫星链路。一段时间内，SATNET 表现良好。然而，随着时间的推移，电话公司将其跨大西洋线路从铜线升级为高速光纤电缆，从此不再需要更复杂的 SATNET 链路。

Still, the idea that packet-switched networks and their attached computers could be linked by radio waves bounced from a satellite was appealing, not only to the American government but also to Europeans, because transatlantic terrestrial circuits at the time were expensive and prone to error. The satellite network was dubbedSATNET . Researchers in the United States were joined by British and Norwegian computer scientists, and before long satellite links were established to Italy and Germany as well. For a while,SATNETdid well. In time, however, the phone company upgraded its transatlantic lines from copper to high-speed fiber-optic cable, eliminating the need for the more complicatedSATNETlink.

无线电和卫星实验的技术教训并不比它们所启发的更广泛的网络理念更重要。显然会有更多的网络。一些外国政府正在建立数据系统，越来越多的大公司开始开发自己的网络理念。卡恩开始思考将不同的网络连接在一起的可能性。

The technical lessons of radio and satellite experiments were less significant than the broader networking ideas they inspired. It was obvious there would be more networks. Several foreign governments were building data systems, and a growing number of large corporations were starting to develop networking ideas of their own. Kahn began wondering about the possibility of linking the different networks together.

1972 年，他在从事分组无线电项目时第一次想到了这个问题。“我的第一个问题是，‘我该如何将这个分组无线电系统连接到任何感兴趣的计算资源？’”卡恩说。“好吧，我的答案是，‘让我们将它连接到 ARPANET 吧，’只不过这两个网络在很多方面都是完全不同的。”第二年，ARPA 的另一项工作，即 Internetting 项目诞生了。

The problem first occurred to him as he was working on the packet-radio project in 1972. “My first question was, ‘How am I going to link this packet-radio system to any computational resources of interest?’” Kahn said. “Well, my answer was, ‘Let’s link it to theARPANET ,’ except that these were two radically different networks in many ways.” The following year, another ARPA effort, called the Internetting Project, was born.

到 1972 年在华盛顿举行 ICCC 演示时，几个国家网络项目的领导人已经成立了一个国际网络工作组 (INWG)，由 Vint Cerf 负责。法国和英国的分组交换网络项目取得了良好的成果。Donald Davies 在英国国家物理实验室的工作进展顺利。在法国，一位名叫 Louis Pouzin 的计算机科学家正在构建 Cyclades，这是 ARPANET 的法国版本。Pouzin 和 Davies 都参加了在华盛顿举行的 ICCC 演示。BBN 在 INWG 的代表 Alex McKenzie 说：“ICCC 之后的精神是，‘我们已经证明了分组交换在国家范围内确实有效。让我们带头创建一个国际网络。’”

By the time of the 1972 ICCC demonstration in Washington, the leaders of several national networking projects had formed an International Network Working Group (INWG), with Vint Cerf in charge. Packet-switching network projects in France and England were producing favorable results. Donald Davies’s work at the U.K.’s National Physical Laboratory was coming along splendidly. In France, a computer scientist named Louis Pouzin was building Cyclades, a French version of theARPANET. Both Pouzin and Davies had attended the ICCC demonstration in Washington. “The spirit after ICCC,” said Alex McKenzie, BBN’s representative to the INWG, “was, ‘We’ve shown that packet-switching really works nationally. Let’s take the lead in creating an international network of networks.’”

拉里·罗伯茨对 INWG 充满热情，因为他希望将 ARPANET 的覆盖范围扩展到 DARPA 资助的世界之外。英国和法国也同样对扩大其国家研究网络的覆盖范围感到兴奋。麦肯齐说：“开发网络互连技术是实现这一目标的一种方式。”INWG 开始追求他们所谓的“级联网络”，简称 CATENET，即不同技术和速度的网络的透明互连。

Larry Roberts was enthusiastic about INWG because he wanted to extend the reach of theARPANETbeyond the DARPA-funded world. The British and the French were equally excited about expanding the reach of their national research networks as well. “Developing network-interconnection technology was a way to realize that,” said McKenzie. The INWG began pursuing what they called a “Concatenated Network,” orCATENETfor short, a transparent interconnection of networks of disparate technologies and speeds.

互联网

An Internet

鲍勃·卡恩多年后将这次合作描述为他职业生涯中最令人满意的一次，这次合作发生在 1973 年的几个月里。1970 年初，卡恩和文特·瑟夫在加州大学洛杉矶分校的测试期间首次见面，当时他们通过使 IMP 超载测试流量，迫使新生的 ARPANET 陷入紧张状态。他们一直是亲密的同事，现在两人都在深入思考如何在不同的网络之间建立无缝连接。瑟夫回忆道：“大约在这个时候，鲍勃开始说，‘听着，我的问题是如何让卫星网络上的计算机、无线电网络上的计算机和 ARPANET 上的计算机以统一的方式相互通信，而不必意识到它们之间发生了什么？’”瑟夫对这个问题很感兴趣。

The collaboration that Bob Kahn would characterize years later as the most satisfying of his professional career took place over several months in 1973. Kahn and Vint Cerf had first met during the weeks of testing at UCLA in early 1970, when they had forced the newbornARPANETinto catatonia by overloading the IMPs with test traffic. They had remained close colleagues, and now both were thinking extensively about what it would take to create a seamless connection among different networks. “Around this time,” Cerf recalled, “Bob started saying, ‘Look, my problem is how I get a computer that’s on a satellite net and a computer on a radio net and a computer on theARPANETto communicate uniformly with each other without realizing what’s going on in between?’” Cerf was intrigued by the problem.

1973 年春天的某个时候，瑟夫正在旧金山一家酒店参加会议，他坐在大厅里等待会议开始，这时他开始胡思乱想。此时，他和卡恩已经讨论了几个月如何构建一个网络网络，他们两人都与国际网络工作组的其他成员交换了想法。瑟夫和卡恩突然想到，他们需要一个“网关”，即位于各个网络之间的路由计算机，用于将消息从一个系统传递到另一个系统。但这说起来容易做起来难。“我们知道我们无法改变任何分组网络本身，”瑟夫说。“它们所做的一切都是因为它们针对该环境进行了优化。”对于每个网络而言，网关必须看起来像一个普通主机。

Sometime during the spring of 1973, Cerf was attending a conference at a San Francisco hotel, sitting in the lobby waiting for a session to start when he began doodling out some ideas. By now he and Kahn had been talking for several months about what it would take to build a network of networks, and they had both been exchanging ideas with other members of the International Network Working Group. It occurred to Cerf and Kahn that what they needed was a “gateway,” a routing computer standing between each of these various networks to hand off messages from one system to the other. But this was easier said than done. “We knew we couldn’t change any of the packet nets themselves,” Cerf said. “They did whatever they did because they were optimized for that environment.” As far as each net was concerned, the gateway had to look like an ordinary host.

在大厅等候的时候，他画了这张图：

 

 

重现早期互联网设计理念

“我们的想法是，显然，每个网关都必须知道如何与它所连接的每个网络进行通信，”瑟夫说。“假设您正在将分组无线电网络与 ARPANET 连接起来。网关机器中装有软件，使其看起来像 ARPANETIMP 的主机。但它也看起来像分组无线电网络上的主机。”

“Our thought was that, clearly, each gateway had to know how to talk to each network that it was connected to,” Cerf said. “Say you’re connecting the packet-radio net with theARPANET. The gateway machine has software in it that makes it look like a host to theARPANETIMPs. But it also looks like a host on the packet-radio network.”

网关的概念已经定义好了，下一个难题就是数据包传输。与 ARPANET 一样，数据包在互联网中传输的实际路径应该无关紧要。最重要的是数据包完好无损地到达。但有一个棘手的问题：所有这些网络（分组无线电、SATNET 和 ARPANET）都有不同的接口、不同的最大数据包大小和不同的传输速率。如何标准化所有这些差异以便在网络之间传输数据包？第二个问题涉及网络的可靠性。无线电和卫星传输的动态性无法实现 ARPANET 中费力构建的可靠性。美国人向法国的 Pouzin 求助，他为 Cyclades 特意选择了一种方法，要求主机而不是网络节点从传输错误中恢复，将可靠性的负担转移到主机上。

With the notion of a gateway now defined, the next puzzle was packet transmission. As with theARPANET, the actual path the packets traveled in an internet should be immaterial. What mattered most was that the packets arrive intact. But there was a vexing problem: All these networks—packet radio,SATNET, and theARPANET—had different interfaces, different maximum packet sizes, and different transmission rates. How could all those differences be standardized in order to shuttle packets among networks? A second question concerned the reliability of the networks. The dynamics of radio and satellite transmission wouldn’t permit reliability that was so laboriously built into theARPANET. The Americans looked to Pouzin in France, who had deliberately chosen an approach for Cyclades that required the hosts rather than the network nodes to recover from transmission errors, shifting the burden of reliability on to the hosts.

显然，主机到主机网络控制协议（该协议旨在符合 ARPANET 的规范）必须被更独立的协议取代。国际网络工作组面临的挑战是设计出能够应对按照自己的规则运行的自治网络的协议，同时还要建立允许不同网络上的主机相互通信的标准。例如，CATENET 仍将是一个独立管理的网络系统，每个网络都由自己的人员按照自己的规则运行。但是，当一个网络需要与 ARPANET 交换数据时，网络间协议就会运行。处理传输的网关计算机不必关心每个网络内部隐藏的本地复杂性。它们唯一的任务是将数据包通过网络发送到另一端的目标主机，从而形成所谓的端到端链接。

在概念框架建立之后，瑟夫和卡恩在 1973 年春夏期间制定了细节。瑟夫向斯坦福大学的研究生介绍了这个问题，他和卡恩也加入了他们的攻克。他们举办了一场研讨会，重点讨论了如何将主机到主机协议发展为允许数据流量在网络中流动的标准。斯坦福研讨会帮助确定了关键问题，并为几年后出现的解决方案奠定了基础。

It was clear that the host-to-host Network Control Protocol, which was designed to match the specifications of theARPANET, would have to be replaced by a more independent protocol. The challenge for the International Network Working Group was to devise protocols that could cope with autonomous networks operating under their own rules, while still establishing standards that would allow hosts on the different networks to talk to each other. For example,CATENETwould remain a system of independently administered networks, each run by its own people with its own rules. But when time came for one network to exchange data with, say, theARPANET , the internetworking protocols would operate. The gateway computers handling the transmission couldn’t care about the local complexity buried inside each network. Their only task would be to get packets through the network to the destination host on the other side, making a so-called end-to-end link.

Once the conceptual framework was established, Cerf and Kahn spent the spring and summer of 1973 working out the details. Cerf presented the problem to his Stanford graduate students, and he and Kahn joined them in attacking it. They held a seminar that concentrated on the details of developing the host-to-host protocol into a standard allowing data traffic to flow across networks. The Stanford seminar helped frame key issues, and laid the foundation for solutions that would emerge several years later.

瑟夫经常前往弗吉尼亚州阿灵顿的 DARPA 办公室，在那里他和卡恩连续几个小时讨论这个问题。在一次马拉松式的会议中，两人整晚不眠，一边在卡恩的黑板上写写画画，一边在荒无人烟的郊区街道上踱步，最后在当地的万豪酒店吃早餐。他们开始合作撰写论文，并在瑟夫的社区进行了下一次马拉松式的会议，在帕洛阿尔托的凯悦酒店通宵工作。

Cerf frequently visited the DARPA offices in Arlington, Virginia, where he and Kahn discussed the problem for hours on end. During one marathon session, the two stayed up all night, alternately scribbling on Kahn’s chalkboard and pacing through the deserted suburban streets, before ending up at the local Marriott for breakfast. They began collaborating on a paper and conducted their next marathon session in Cerf’s neighborhood, working straight through the night at the Hyatt in Palo Alto.

同年 9 月，卡恩和瑟夫向国际网络工作组提交了他们的论文以及关于新协议的想法，同时在布莱顿的萨塞克斯大学举行了一次通信会议。瑟夫来英国的时间很晚，因为他的第一个孩子刚刚出生。“我到的时候正好是会议进行到一半，大家就鼓掌欢迎我，因为我通过电子邮件提前得知了孩子出生的消息，”瑟夫回忆道。在萨塞克斯的会议上，瑟夫概述了他和卡恩以及斯坦福研讨会产生的想法。在萨塞克斯，经过与戴维斯和普津实验室的研究人员的长时间讨论，这些想法得到了进一步完善。

That September, Kahn and Cerf presented their paper along with their ideas about the new protocol to the International Network Working Group, meeting concurrently with a communications conference at the University of Sussex in Brighton. Cerf was late arriving in England because his first child had just been born. “I arrived in midsession and was greeted by applause because word of the birth had preceded me by e-mail,” Cerf recalled. During the Sussex meeting, Cerf outlined the ideas he and Kahn and the Stanford seminar had generated. The ideas were refined further in Sussex, in long discussions with researchers from Davies’and Pouzin’s laboratories.

卡恩和瑟夫从英国回来后，他们修改了论文。两人都有固执的一面。“我们会陷入这种争论状态，然后退后一步说，‘让我们看看我们到底在争论什么。’”瑟夫喜欢在开始写作之前把所有东西都整理好；卡恩则喜欢坐下来，按照他自己的逻辑顺序写下他能想到的一切；重新整理是后来的事。合作写作过程非常紧张。瑟夫回忆道：“我们其中一个人打字，另一个人紧跟在他身后，一边打字一边写作，就像两只手握着一支笔一样。”

When Kahn and Cerf returned from England, they refined their paper. Both men had a stubborn side. ”We’d get into this argumentative state, then step back and say, ‘Let’s find out what it is we’re actually arguing about.’ ” Cerf liked to have everything organized before starting to write; Kahn preferred to sit down and write down everything he could think of, in his own logical order; reorganization came later. The collaborative writing process was intense. Recalled Cerf: “It was one of us typing and the other one breathing down his neck, composing as we’d go along, almost like two hands on a pen.”

1973 年底，瑟夫和卡恩完成了论文《分组网络互通协议》。他们通过掷硬币来决定谁的名字应该排在第一位，结果瑟夫赢了。第二年春天，这篇论文发表在一本广为阅读的工程学杂志上。

By the end of 1973, Cerf and Kahn had completed their paper, “A Protocol for Packet Network Intercommunication.” They flipped a coin to determine whose name should appear first, and Cerf won the toss. The paper appeared in a widely read engineering journal the following spring.

就像七年前罗伯茨的第一篇概述拟议的 ARPANET 的论文一样，瑟夫卡恩在 1974 年 5 月发表的论文描述了一些革命性的东西。在论文中描述的框架下，消息应该被封装和解封装在“数据报”中，就像一封信被放入信封并从信封中取出一样，并以端到端数据包的形式发送。这些消息将被称为传输控制协议 (TCP) 消息。该论文还引入了网关的概念，网关只会读取信封，这样只有接收主机才能读取内容。

Like Roberts’s first paper outlining the proposedARPANETseven years earlier, the CerfKahn paper of May 1974 described something revolutionary. Under the framework described in the paper, messages should be encapsulated and decapsulated in “datagrams,” much as a letter is put into and taken out of an envelope, and sent as end-to-end packets. These messages would be called transmission-control protocol, or TCP, messages. The paper also introduced the notion of gateways, which would read only the envelope so that only the receiving hosts would read the contents.

TCP 协议还解决了网络可靠性问题。在 ARPANET 中，目标 IMP 负责在消息到达时重组消息的所有数据包。IMP 努力确保消息的所有数据包都通过网络，使用逐跳确认和重新传输。IMP 还确保单独的消息保持有序。由于 IMP 所做的所有这些工作，旧的网络控制协议是建立在底层网络完全可靠的假设之上的。

The TCP protocol also tackled the network reliability issues. In theARPANET, the destination IMP was responsible for reassembling all the packets of a message when it arrived. The IMPs worked hard making sure all the packets of a message got through the network, using hop-by-hop acknowledgments and retransmission. The IMPs also made sure separate messages were kept in order. Because of all this work done by the IMPs, the old Network Control Protocol was built around the assumption that the underlying network was completely reliable.

新的传输控制协议借鉴了 Cyclades 的思想，认为 CATENET 完全不可靠。信息单元可能会丢失，其他信息单元可能会重复。如果数据包未能到达或在传输过程中出现混乱，并且发送主机未收到确认，则将传输一个完全相同的数据包。

The new transmission-control protocol, with a bow to Cyclades, assumed that theCATENETwas completely unreliable. Units of information could be lost, others might be duplicated. If a packet failed to arrive or was garbled during transmission, and the sending host received no acknowledgment, an identical twin was transmitted.

新协议背后的总体思路是将可靠性从网络转移到目标主机。“我们专注于端到端可靠性，”瑟夫回忆道。“不要依赖网络内的任何东西。我们要求网络做的唯一一件事就是接收这块比特并将其传遍网络。这就是我们所要求的。只需接收这个数据报并尽力传递它。”

The overall idea behind the new protocol was to shift the reliability from the network to the destination hosts. “We focused on end-to-end reliability,” Cerf recalled. ”Don’t rely on anything inside those nets. The only thing that we ask the net to do is to take this chunk of bits and get it across the network. That’s all we ask. Just take this datagram and do your best to deliver it.”

新方案的运作方式与用集装箱运输货物的方式非常相似。这些箱子具有标准的尺寸和形状。它们可以装任何东西，从电视机到内衣再到汽车——内容并不重要。它们通过轮船、铁路或卡车运输。一个典型的货物集装箱在不同阶段通过这三种运输方式到达目的地。确保交叉兼容性唯一需要的是用于将集装箱从一种运输方式转移到另一种运输方式的专用设备。货物本身在到达目的地之前不会离开集装箱。

The new scheme worked in much the same way that shipping containers are used to transfer goods. The boxes have a standard size and shape. They can be filled with anything from televisions to underwear to automobiles—content doesn’t matter. They move by ship, rail, or truck. A typical container of freight travels by all three modes at various stages to reach its destination. The only thing necessary to ensure crosscompatibility is the specialized equipment used to transfer the containers from one mode of transport to the next. The cargo itself doesn’t leave the container until it reaches its destination.

TCP 的发明对于网络而言绝对至关重要。没有 TCP，网络间通信就无法实现。如果 TCP 能够完善，任何人都可以构建任何规模或形式的网络，只要该网络拥有能够解释和路由数据包的网关计算机，它就可以与任何其他网络通信。随着 TCP 的出现，现在很明显，网络的未来将远远超出实验性的 ARPANET。人们开始意识到，不仅是 Cerf 和 Kahn，还有法国的 Louis Pouzin 等人正在发明的东西的潜在威力和影响力。如果他们能够解决所有细节问题，TCP 可能就是打开世界的机制。

The invention of TCP would be absolutely crucial to networking. Without TCP, communication across networks couldn’t happen. If TCP could be perfected, anyone could build a network of any size or form, and as long as that network had a gateway computer that could interpret and route packets, it could communicate with any other network. With TCP on the horizon, it was now obvious that networking had a future well beyond the experimentalARPANET. The potential power and reach of what not only Cerf and Kahn, but Louis Pouzin in France and others, were inventing was beginning to occur to people. If they could work out all the details, TCP might be the mechanism that would open up worlds.

随着 ARPANET 上可用的资源越来越多，以及越来越多的人熟悉这些网站，网络使用率也逐渐上升。为了了解世界新闻，早期的网络常客会定期登录 SRI 的一台机器，该机器与美联社新闻专线相连。在高峰时段，麻省理工学院的学生会登录网络上的其他计算机来完成他们的工作。加州大学圣巴巴拉分校制作的声学和全息图像在南加州大学的机器上数字化，并通过网络传送回加州大学圣巴巴拉分校的图像处理器，在那里可以进一步处理。加州大学圣巴巴拉分校的实验室配备了定制的图像处理设备，加州大学圣巴巴拉分校的研究人员将高级数学转化为其他网站的图形输出。到 1973 年 8 月，当 TCP 仍处于设计阶段时，流量已增长到平均每天 320 万个数据包。

从 1973 年到 1975 年，网络以每月一个新节点的速度扩展。增长正按照拉里·罗伯茨最初的设想进行，即故意在网络中装载大型资源提供商。在这方面，DARPA 取得了巨大的成功。但结果却是供需失衡；资源提供商太多，而客户不够。终端 IMP 的引入帮助平衡了平衡，首先是在 Mitre，然后是 NASA 的艾姆斯研究中心和国家标准局，每个中心最多有 63 个终端。主机站点本身的访问正在放松。例如，UCSB 的主机与政治学、物理学和化学系的小型计算机相连。类似的模式正在整个网络地图上展开。

As more resources became available over theARPANETand as more people at the sites became familiar with them, Net usage crept upward. For news of the world, early Net regulars regularly logged on to a machine at SRI, which was connected to the Associated Press news wire. During peak times, MIT students logged on at some other computer on the Net to get their work done. Acoustic and holographic images produced at UC Santa Barbara were digitized on machines at USC and brought back over the Net to an image processor at UCSB, where they could be manipulated further. The lab at UCSB was outfitted with custom-built image-processing equipment, and UCSB researchers translated high-level mathematics into graphical output for other sites. By August 1973, while TCP was still in the design phase, traffic had grown to a daily average of 3.2 million packets.

From 1973 to 1975, the Net expanded at the rate of about one new node each month. Growth was proceeding in line with Larry Roberts’s original vision, in which the network was deliberately laden with large resource providers. In this respect, DARPA had succeeded wonderfully. But the effect was an imbalance of supply and demand; there were too many resource providers, and not enough customers. The introduction of terminal IMPs, first at Mitre, then at NASA’s Ames Research Center and the National Bureau of Standards with up to sixty-three terminals each, helped right the balance. Access at the host sites themselves was loosening up. The host machine at UCSB, for example, was linked to minicomputers in the political science, physics, and chemistry departments. Similar patterns were unfolding across the network map.

与大多数早期的 ARPANET 主机站点一样，伊利诺伊大学高级计算中心之所以被选中，主要是因为它能够为其他网络用户提供资源。在罗伯茨规划网络时，伊利诺伊州计划成为强大的新型 ILLIAC IV 的所在地，这是一台巨大的、独一无二的高速计算机，正在宾夕法尼亚州保利的 Burroughs 公司建造中。这台机器肯定会吸引来自全国各地的研究人员。

Like most of the earlyARPANEThost sites, the Center for Advanced Computation at the University of Illinois was chosen primarily for the resources it would be able to offer other Net users. At the time Roberts was mapping out the network, Illinois was slated to become home to the powerful new ILLIAC IV, a massive, one-of-a-kind high-speed computer under construction at the Burroughs Corporation in Paoli, Pennsylvania. The machine was guaranteed to attract researchers from around the country.

然而，意想不到的情况导致伊利诺伊大学成为该网络的第一个大规模消费者，而不是资源供应商。厄巴纳校区的学生确信 ILLIAC IV 将用于模拟越南战争的轰炸场景，并在校园内进行绝密研究。随着校园对即将安装的 ILLIAC IV 的抗议爆发，大学官员开始担心他们保护 ILLIAC IV 的能力。当 Burroughs 完成机器的建造后，它被送往 NASA 管理的一个更安全的设施。

An unexpected twist of circumstances, however, led the University of Illinois to become the network’s first large-scale consumer instead of a resource supplier. Students on the Urbana campus were convinced the ILLIAC IV was going to be used to simulate bombing scenarios for the Vietnam War and to perform top-secret research on campus. As campus protests erupted over the impending installation, university officials grew concerned about their ability to protect the ILLIAC IV. When Burroughs finished construction of the machine, it was sent to a more secure facility run by NASA.

但高级计算中心已经拥有了自己的 IMP 并完全访问了网络。那里的研究人员很快就掌握了利用远程计算资源的新能力 — — 事实上，他们反应非常迅速，以至于该中心终止了每月 4 万美元的高性能 Burroughs B6700 租赁合同。取而代之的是，该大学开始通过 ARPANET 签订计算机服务合同。通过这种方式，计算中心将其计算机费用削减了近一半。这就是罗伯茨设想的规模经济，其水平超出了任何人的预期。很快，该中心就通过网络获得了 90% 以上的计算机资源。

But the Center for Advanced Computation already had its IMP and full access to the network. Researchers there took quickly to the newfound ability to exploit remote computing resources—so quickly, in fact, that the Center terminated the $40,000 monthly lease on its own high-powered Burroughs B6700. In its place, the university began contracting for computer services over theARPANET . By doing this, the computation center cut its computer bill nearly in half. This was the economy of scale envisioned by Roberts, taken to a level beyond anyone’s expectations. Soon, the Center was obtaining more than 90 percent of its computer resources through the network.

遍布网络的大型数据库越来越受欢迎。美国计算机公司有一台称为数据计算机的机器，它本质上是一个信息仓库，全天候将天气和地震数据输入到机器中。每周都有数百人登录，使其成为网络上几年来最繁忙的站点。

Large databases scattered across the Net were growing in popularity. The Computer Corporation of America had a machine called the Datacomputer that was essentially an information warehouse, with weather and seismic data fed into the machine around the clock. Hundreds of people logged in every week, making it the busiest site on the network for several years.

在新数据的支持下，ARPANET 开始吸引来自各个领域的计算机研究人员的关注。互联网的访问仍然仅限于与 DARPA 签约的站点，但这些站点的用户多样性仍然创造了一个与构建 ARPANET 的工程师和计算机科学家不同的用户社区。帮助设计医学研究的程序员可以与美国国家医学图书馆丰富的 MEDLINE 数据库相结合。加州大学洛杉矶分校公共卫生学院建立了一个心理健康项目评估实验数据库。

Abetted by the new troves of data, theARPANETwas beginning to attract the attention of computer researchers from a variety of fields. Access to the Net was still limited to sites with DARPA contracts, but the diversity of users at those sites was nonetheless creating a community of users distinct from the engineers and computer scientists who built theARPANET. Programmers helping to design medical studies could tie in to the National Library of Medicine’s rich MEDLINE database. The UCLA School of Public Health set up an experimental database of mental health program evaluations.

为了服务日益壮大的用户社区，SRI 的研究人员于 1973 年 3 月建立了一个名为ARPANETNews的独特资源。该期刊以纸质印刷形式每月发行一次，也可在网上获取。该通讯包含会议列表、站点更新和技术论文摘要，读起来就像充斥着计算机术语的小镇八卦。ARPANETNews 中最重要的项目之一是“特色站点”系列，其中来自不断增长的主机列表的系统管理员描述了他们所提供的内容。1973 年 5 月，凯斯西储大学向网络用户出售计算机服务，其 PDP-10 的描述听起来就像是来自个人版块的广告：“凯斯西储大学愿意接受合作提议，涉及与其他站点交换与此处兴趣相关的工作的时间，以及将时间作为服务出售。”

To serve the growing user community, SRI researchers established a unique resource called theARPANETNewsin March 1973. Distributed monthly in ink-on-paper form, the journal was also available over the Net. A mix of conference listings, site updates, and abstracts of technical papers, the newsletter read like small-town gossip riddled with computer jargon. One of the more important items in theARPANETNewswas the “Featured Site” series, in which system managers from the growing list of host computers described what they had to offer. In May 1973 Case Western Reserve University, which was selling computer services to network users, described its PDP-10 in terms that sounded altogether like an ad from the Personals section: “Case is open to collaborative propositions involving barters of time with other sites for work related to interests here, and sales of time as a service.”

通过计算机进行通信和使用远程资源仍然是繁琐的过程。在大多数情况下，网络仍然是一个对用户不友好的环境，需要相对复杂的编程知识和对主机上运行的各种系统的理解。用户对“高级”应用程序的需求日益增长，这些应用程序旨在帮助用户利用现在可用的各种资源。文件传输和 Telnet 程序已经存在，但用户社区需要更多工具，例如通用编辑器和会计方案。

Communicating by computer and using remote resources were still cumbersome processes. For the most part, the Net remained a user-hostile environment, requiring relatively sophisticated programming knowledge and an understanding of the diverse systems running on the hosts. Demand was growing among users for “higher-level” application programs aimed at helping users tap into the variety of resources now available. The file-transfer and Telnet programs existed, but the user community wanted more tools, such as common editors and accounting schemes.

SRI 的网络信息中心估计用户数量约为 2000 人。但一个新成立的用户利益团体 USING 确信，网络资源的设计与试图使用这些资源的人们的需求之间存在差距。USING 把自己设想为一个游说团体，甚至是一个消费者联盟，它立即开始制定计划和建议，以改善 ARPANET 上计算机服务的提供。

SRI’s Network Information Center estimated the number of users at about two thousand. But a newly formed users’ interest group, calledUSING, was convinced there was a gap between the design of the network resources and the needs of the people trying to use those resources. Envisioning itself as a lobby group, a consumers’union even,USINGbegan immediately to draw up plans and recommendations for improving the delivery of computer services over theARPANET.

但 DARPA 认为没有必要与一个小型自封的监督组织分享权力，该组织由该机构视为实验飞行器乘客的人员组成。该计划在大约 9 个月后夭折，DARPA 项目经理 Craig Fields 发出一份简短的备忘录，警告该组织它已经超越了权限。由于没有资金或官方支持，成员们将 USING 置于停滞状态，从未恢复。

But DARPA saw no need to share authority with a tiny self-appointed watchdog group made up of people the agency viewed as passengers on its experimental vehicle. The initiative died after about nine months with a terse memo from a DARPA program manager named Craig Fields, warning the group that it had overstepped its bounds. With neither funding nor official support for their effort forthcoming, members putUSINGinto a state of suspended animation from which it never emerged.

随着网络的知名度不断提高，DARPA 也遇到了其他问题。与 USING 叛乱一样，大多数问题都是相对较小的。但它们共同说明了 DARPA 对网络的管理权存在持续的紧张关系。其中一个紧张领域与 DARPA 的五角大楼主管有关。IPTO 尤其设法避开了最明显的军事研究。但是，尽管伊利诺伊大学的学生认为 ILLIAC IV 是用于模拟轰炸北越的任务，但他们计划将其用于对苏联进行核攻击。同样，各种研究人员都使用存储在美国计算机公司 (CCA) 数据库服务器上的地震信息，这些信息被收集起来用于支持五角大楼涉及地下原子试验的项目。20

世纪 60 年代末，日益加剧的政治动荡（包括暴力和非暴力）让美国军方措手不及。陆军情报部门对布拉格、柏林和莫斯科了如指掌，但现在五角大楼正在考虑纽瓦克、底特律和芝加哥。陆军从美国几十个城市收集了警察局、消防局、医院等地点的信息。五角大楼有人认为，追踪当地的闹事者也是个好主意。

Other problems developed for DARPA as the profile of the network began to rise. Like theUSINGinsurgency, most were relatively minor affairs. But together they illustrated the ongoing tensions related to DARPA’s stewardship of the network. One area of tension had to do with DARPA’s Pentagon masters. IPTO in particular managed to steer clear of the most blatantly military research. But while the Illinois students were wrong about the ILLIAC IV being used for simulated bombing missions against North Vietnam, therewereplans to use it for nuclear attack scenarios against the Soviet Union. Similarly, researchers of all sorts used seismic information stored on the Computer Corporation of America (CCA) database server, information that was being collected to support Pentagon projects involving underground atomic testing.

In the late 1960s, growing political unrest—both violent and nonviolent—caught the U.S. military by surprise. Army intelligence knew all about Prague, Berlin, and Moscow, but now the Pentagon was contemplating Newark, Detroit, and Chicago. The Army gathered information from dozens of U.S. cities on the location of police and fire stations, hospitals, and so forth. Someone in the Pentagon thought it would be a good idea to keep track of local troublemakers as well.

1972 年，公众对陆军的信息收集行为表示强烈抗议，并下令立即销毁这些文件。但三年后，有指控称，陆军情报人员利用 ARPANET 将文件转移到新位置。当这个故事被曝光时，大多数美国人都不知道 ARPANET 之类的东西的存在。这个故事以最严厉、最隐秘的措辞报道，这只会加剧人们的强烈反应。结果是参议院展开了调查，要求 DARPA 解释其如何使用 ARPANET。

In 1972 public outcry erupted over the Army’s information gathering, and the order went out for the files to be destroyed immediately. But three years later, allegations surfaced that Army intelligence officers had instead used theARPANETto move the files to a new location. When the story broke, the fact that something like theARPANETexisted was news to most Americans. That the story was reported in the most draconian, cloak-anddagger terms only added to the stormy reaction. The result was a Senate investigation in which DARPA was called upon to explain how it was using theARPANET .

DARPA 最终通过审查数百卷存放在 BBN 尘土飞扬的爬行空间中的电传打字机打印件，证明了陆军文件没有在 ARPANET 上移动。DARPA 被证明是正确的，但 ARPANET 最不希望看到的是与陆军秘密行动的纠缠。

DARPA eventually proved that the Army files had not moved on theARPANETby reviewing hundreds of rolls of Teletype printouts that had been stored in a dusty crawl space at BBN. DARPA was vindicated, but a perceived entanglement with the Army’s clandestine operations was the last thing theARPANETneeded.

DARPA 的变化

Changes at DARPA

关于 DARPA 最终将如何剥离网络运营责任的讨论早在 1971 年左右就已开始。DARPA 已着手将美国顶级计算机科学研究中心的核心处理能力连接起来，就该机构而言，它已经实现了这一目标。它的使命是研究。它不应该从事网络运营业务。现在系统已经启动并运行，它正在成为其他优先事项的负担。现在是 DARPA 摆脱服务提供商角色的时候了。

Discussions about how DARPA would ultimately divest operational responsibility for the network had already begun around 1971. DARPA had set out to link the core processing capabilities in America’s top computer science research centers, and as far as the agency was now concerned, it had accomplished that. Its mission was research. It wasn’t supposed to be in the business of operating a network. Now that the system was up and running, it was becoming a drain on other priorities. It was time for DARPA to shed the service provider’s role.

处理好这种转变是一件棘手的事情。ARPANET 现在是一个有价值的工具，而罗伯茨的目标是确保它继续发展。他委托进行了几项研究，以帮助确定最佳选择。看来，最好的办法是保留网络研究工作，但将网络本身出售给私人承包商。但卖给谁呢？数据通信网络市场在很大程度上仍是未知的，大型通信公司仍然像以往一样对 DARPA 技术持怀疑态度。

Handling the transition was a touchy matter. TheARPANETwas now a valuable tool, and Roberts’s goal was to ensure its continued development. He commissioned several studies to help determine the best option. The best route, it seemed, was to maintain a networking research effort, but sell off the network itself to a private contractor. But sell to whom? The market for data-communications networks was still largely uncharted, and the big communications companies remained as skeptical as ever about the DARPA technology.

当罗伯茨联系 AT&T，询问其是否想接管 ARPANET 时，AT&T 成立了一个由公司和贝尔实验室员工组成的委员会，并花了数月时间研究这个想法。AT&T 本可以以垄断服务的形式拥有该网络，但最终还是拒绝了。“他们最终得出结论，分组技术与 AT&T 网络不兼容，”罗伯茨说。

When Roberts contacted AT&T to see if it wanted to take over theARPANET , AT&T formed a committee of corporate and Bell Labs staff and studied the idea for months. AT&T could have owned the network as a monopoly service, but in the end declined. “They finally concluded that the packet technology was incompatible with the AT&T network,” Roberts said.

其他人对计算机网络的前景并不那么盲目。1972 年 7 月，三名工程师离开 BBN，成立了一家名为 Packet Communications Incorporated 的公司，负责营销商业网络。BBN 本身也曾与罗伯茨讨论过购买该网络并成立一家子公司来运营它。像这样的小型、专业化的商业运营商显然是解决 DARPA 问题的良方。

Others were not so blind to the prospects of computer networking. In July 1972 three engineers left BBN to form a company that would market a commercial network called Packet Communications Incorporated. And BBN itself had spoken to Roberts about buying the network and setting up a subsidiary company to operate it. Small, specialized, commercial carriers like these were the obvious solution to DARPA’s problem.

但很快罗伯茨就遇到了新问题。1973 年初，BBN 招募他经营一家名为 TELENET（不要将其与远程登录程序 Telnet 混淆）的新子公司，该公司将销售一项私人分组交换服务。由于无法建议政府将 ARPANET 出售给 TELENET，罗伯茨安排将

ARPANET 暂时转让给国防通信局——十年前巴兰拒绝让该机构建立他的网络。将军、少校和上尉对分组交换网络的想法仍然比 AT&T 稍微接受一点，但罗伯茨预计这只是一个临时安排。

But soon Roberts had a new problem. In early 1973, BBN recruited him to run a new subsidiary calledTELENET(not to be confused with Telnet, the program for remote logins), which would market a private packet-switching service. Now unable to recommend a sale by the government toTELENET, Roberts arranged to have

theARPANETtransferred temporarily to the Defense Communications Agency—the same agency that Baran had refused to let build his network ten years earlier. The generals and majors and captains were still only slightly more receptive to the idea of a packet-switched network than AT&T, but Roberts expected this to be only an interim arrangement.

决定接受 TELENET 的职位后，罗伯茨现在的任务是寻找继任者。然而，DARPA 的信息处理技术办公室对学术界人士的吸引力已不复当初。罗伯茨联系了几位大学里的首席研究员，但那些正在从事研究项目的人并不想离开。其他人则担心，如果要到 DARPA 办公室工作，他们将不得不接受减薪。

Having decided to accept the post atTELENET, Roberts now had the job of finding a successor. DARPA’s Information Processing Techniques Office, however, no longer held the appeal it once had for those in academe. Roberts approached a couple of his principal investigators at universities, but people who had active research programs did not want to leave them. Others were concerned about the salary cuts they would have to take to come to the DARPA office.

当利克莱德听说罗伯茨遇到的麻烦时，他表示如果罗伯茨需要他，他愿意回来。罗伯茨知道这只是利克莱德的一种姿态。利克莱德现在很高兴地回到了麻省理工学院。但经过六个月的寻找，罗伯茨决定他别无选择。当罗伯茨打电话给麻省理工学院利克莱德的办公室时，他被告知利克莱德正在英格兰徒步旅行。罗伯茨在威尔士中部找到了他，并问他是否认真考虑接受这份工作。利克莱德说是的。“我从未见过拉里像他终于找到继任者时那样欣喜若狂，因为他已经准备好了，”罗伯茨的一位同事回忆道。“我认为他的高兴还在于利克莱德会接受这份工作，因为他喜欢他。每个人都喜欢他。”

When Licklider heard of the trouble Roberts was having, he offered to return if Roberts needed him. Roberts knew it was just a gesture on Licklider’s part. Lick was now happily entrenched back at MIT. But after six months of searching, Roberts decided he didn’t have a choice. When Roberts called Lick’s office at MIT, he was told that Lick was on a walking tour in England. Roberts tracked him down in the middle of Wales and asked him if he was serious about taking the job. Licklider said yes. “I never saw Larry so overjoyed as when he finally got his replacement, because he was ready to go,” recalled a colleague of Roberts. “I think some of his delight was also the fact that Lick was going to take it, because he liked him. Everybody did.”

利克回国后面临的第一个问题就是与他曾经的雇主 BBN 有关的棘手问题。BBN 拒绝发布 IMP 源代码——即 IMP 团队五年前编写的原始操作程序。

One of the first problems Lick faced upon his return was an awkward one involving BBN, his onetime employer. BBN was refusing to release the IMP source code—the original operating program written by the IMP Guys five years earlier.

BBN 显然想要控制网络的各个方面，这从一开始就造成了一定的紧张局势。加州大学洛杉矶分校网络测量中心的 Len Kleinrock 和他的团队对此感到特别沮丧。该中心的工作是查找网络中的问题，但当他们找到问题时，BBN 却拒绝提供帮助。“每当我们发现软件错误或效率低下时，我们都会专门通知 Heart，而我们得到的回应通常几乎是无动于衷，”Kleinrock 说。“他会说，‘看，网络正在运行，我要让网络保持正常运行，我们会将您的评论放入队列中。’我们无法自己修复它，因为我们没有源代码。”

BBN’s apparent impulse to control every aspect of the network created a certain tension from the beginning. Len Kleinrock and his group at UCLA’s Network Measurement Center had found it particularly frustrating. The center’s job was to find problems in the network, but when they did, BBN refused to help. “Whenever we found a software bug or inefficiency, we’d alert Heart specifically, and the response we got was typically almost a stiff arm,” said Kleinrock. “He’d say, ‘Look, the network is working, I’ve got a network to keep up and running and we’ll put your comment in the queue.’ We couldn’t fix it ourselves because we didn’t have the source code.”

当离开 BBN 创办自己公司的工程师们明确要求他们的前雇主交出 IMP 源代码时，知识产权问题终于爆发了。当 BBN 拒绝时，他们向 DARPA 上诉。虽然保持源代码专有通常是开发它的公司的特权，但 IMP 源代码却不同，因为它是由 BBN 使用联邦资金开发的。此外，BBN 正在启动 TELENET 子公司，它将与工程师创办的公司竞争。DARPA 担心，如果国会或新闻界有人抓住 BBN 的子公司和其他任何人都无法使用国防部资助的 IMP 技术这一事实，该机构可能会面临大麻烦。

The intellectual property issue finally boiled over when the engineers who left BBN to start their own company made a pointed request for their former employer to turn over the IMP source code. When BBN refused, they appealed to DARPA. While keeping source code proprietary is usually the prerogative of the company that develops it, the IMP source code was different, for it had been developed by BBN with federal funds. Moreover, BBN was in the midst of starting up theTELENETsubsidiary, which would be competing with the company started by the engineers. There was some concern at DARPA that if anyone in Congress or the press corps latched onto the fact that BBN’s subsidiary and no one else had access to the Defense Department–sponsored IMP technology, the agency could have a major problem on its hands.

BBN 的 Frank Heart 和 Dave Walden 认为，由于源代码经常被更改以提高性能或修复错误，因此公司不愿意分发过时的软件。该公司坚持自己的立场。

Frank Heart and Dave Walden at BBN argued that since the source code was changed frequently to improve performance or fix bugs, the company was uncomfortable with distributing software that would become obsolete. The company held its ground.

史蒂夫·克罗克当时是 DARPA 的项目经理，负责 BBN 的大部分合同，他掌控着局面。他每年负责 BBN 价值约 600 万美元的工作，约占该公司总收入的四分之一。“我认真考虑过将我们在 BBN 支持的所有工作转移到其他地方，因为我们无法与他们就 IMP 代码的数据权达成一致，”他说。他让 BBN 知道了他的想法。

Steve Crocker, by then a DARPA program manager who oversaw most of BBN’s contracts, took charge of the situation. He had control of about $6 million worth of work a year at BBN, about a quarter of the firm’s gross revenues. “I seriously considered moving all of the work we were supporting at BBN to other places because we couldn’t reach closure with them on the data rights to the IMP code,” he said. And he let BBN know what he was thinking.

利克与 BBN 有着长期的合作，他非常尊重那里的人，但他对他们的态度感到失望。整个计算机社区的反应大致相同。最后，作为对克罗克威胁的直接回应，BBN 同意向任何需要的人提供代码，并收取象征性的手续费。“这只是未来几十年整个行业出现的更严重的知识产权问题的早期版本，”克罗克说。

Lick had had a long association with BBN, and he had high regard for people there, but he was dismayed by their posture. Reaction throughout the computer community was much the same. Finally, in direct response to Crocker’s threat, BBN agreed to provide the code to whoever asked for it, charging a nominal handling fee. “This was just an early version of much more serious intellectual property rights issues that emerged across the industry over the next few decades,” Crocker said.

在鲍勃·卡恩的帮助下，利克莱德还完成了将网络剥离给国防通信局的工作。尽管罗伯茨早些时候曾对出售网络进行过调查，但联邦法规要求，像阿帕网这样丰富的资源不能出售给外部方，直到国防部确定是否需要网络用于国防。该机构最终决定需要。1975 年夏天，DCA 从 DARPA 手中接管了网络管理工作。现在，DCA 为网络制定了运营政策。DCA 决定在何时何地安装新节点以及数据线路的配置。而 BBN 保留了网络运营的合同，这意味着该公司执行 DCA 做出的决定。移交后不久，利克回到了麻省理工学院，在那里度过了他的余生。

With Bob Kahn’s help, Licklider also finished the job of spinning off the network to the Defense Communications Agency. Roberts’s earlier probes into selling off the network notwithstanding, federal rules required that a resource as rich as theARPANETcouldn’t just be sold to an outside party until the Defense Department determined whether it had a need for the Net in Defense. The agency eventually decided it did. In the summer of 1975,DCA took over the network management job from DARPA. Now DCA set operational policy for the network. DCA decided such things as where and when new nodes would be installed and what the configuration of data lines should be. And BBN retained the contract for network operations, which meant the company carried out the decisions made by DCA. Shortly after the transition had been made, Lick returned to MIT, where he would spend the remainder of his career.

很快，BBN 的每个人都注意到，即使最小的工作也需要填写越来越多的表格。DCA 的官僚作风也让许多大学人员感到不安。“该机构从上校和将军那里获得了大量关于你可以做什么和不可以做的事情的备忘录，”布莱恩·里德回忆道。DCA 接管 ARPANET 几个月后，斯坦福大学计算机科学系的几名研究生打扮成上校参加了万圣节派对。

Soon everyone at BBN noticed an increasing number of forms that had to be filled out, even for the smallest of jobs. The DCA bureaucracy rattled many of the university people, too. “The agency generated a blizzard of memoranda from colonels and generals about things you were and weren’t allowed to do,” recalled Brian Reid. A few months after DCA took over theARPANET, several of the graduate students in Stanford’s computer science department came to a Halloween party dressed as colonels.

摆脱了日常管理琐事后，DARPA 现在可以专心开发新的 CATENET 协议。到 1975 年，斯坦福大学研究生 Yogen Dalal 将 Cerf 和 Kahn 1974 年论文中的传输控制协议完善为一套具体的规范。TCP 规范被发送到三个不同的地方同时实施：BBN、斯坦福大学的 Cerf 计算机实验室和伦敦大学学院。

Relieved of the day-to-day management chores, DARPA was now able to concentrate on developing the newCATENETprotocols. By 1975, Yogen Dalal, a Stanford graduate student, had polished the Transmission-Control Protocol from Cerf and Kahn’s 1974 paper into a set of concrete specifications. The TCP specification was sent to three separate places for concurrent implementation: BBN, Cerf’s computer lab at Stanford, and University College, London.

大约在同一时间，卡恩和史蒂夫·克罗克开始与瑟夫商谈在华盛顿担任 DARPA 项目经理一职。“我飞到那里，降落时遇到了一场大雪，当时我就想，我不想住在这个地区，”瑟夫回忆道。“所以我拒绝了。但真正的原因是我担心自己做不好。我觉得这个职位很显眼，如果我搞砸了，每个人都会知道。”

At about the same time, Kahn and Steve Crocker began talking to Cerf about taking a job as a DARPA program manager in Washington. “I flew there and landed in a big snowstorm and thought, I don’t want to live in this part of the country,” Cerf recalled. “So I said no. But the real reason was I was afraid I wouldn’t do a very good job. I thought it would be a very visible position and if I screwed up, everybody would know.”

一年后，卡恩和克罗克再次尝试。这次瑟夫接受了。“我对斯坦福的碎片化感到有些厌倦。我无法完成任何研究。所以我想，为什么不去 DARPA 做更大的贡献呢？因为在斯坦福，我的工作预算很少，在 DARPA，我有机会花更多的钱做更大的贡献。”

A year later, Kahn and Crocker tried again. This time Cerf accepted. “I was getting a little tired of being so fragmented at Stanford. I couldn’t get any research done. So I thought, Why not go to DARPA and have a bigger impact, because instead of the small little budgets I got at Stanford for my work, at DARPA I’d have an opportunity to have a bigger impact with more money to spend.”

作为一名项目经理，瑟夫负责分组无线电、分组卫星和研究项目，现在简称为 ARPA 互联网。瑟夫还继续致力于完善 TCP 规范。1977 年 10 月，瑟夫和卡恩以及其他十几个人展示了第一个三网系统，其中分组无线电、ARPANET 和 SATNET 协同工作，这是一个里程碑。信息从旧金山湾区通过分组无线电网络、ARPANET 和专用卫星链路传输到伦敦，再通过分组卫星网络返回，再次通过 ARPANET，最后到达位于玛丽安德尔湾的南加州大学信息科学研究所 (ISI)。数据包传输了 94,000 英里，没有丢失一个比特。

As a program manager, Cerf was given responsibility for the packet radio, packet satellite, and research programs in what was now simply called the ARPA Internet. Cerf also continued working intensively on refining the TCP specification. A milestone occurred in October 1977, when Cerf and Kahn and a dozen or so others demonstrated the first threenetwork system with packet radio, theARPANET , andSATNET, all functioning in concert. Messages traveled from the San Francisco Bay area through a packet-radio net, then theARPANET, and then a dedicated satellite link to London, back across the packetsatellite network and across theARPANETagain, and finally to the University of Southern California’s Information Sciences Institute (ISI) in Marina del Rey. The packets traveled 94,000 miles without dropping a single bit.

1978 年初，瑟夫主持了一次 ISI 会议，讨论 TCP。在会议间隙，瑟夫、波斯特尔和波斯特尔在 ISI 的同事丹尼·科恩 (Danny Cohen) 在走廊里展开了讨论。“我们在走廊墙上靠着一块大纸板画图，”波斯特尔回忆道。会议恢复后，三人向小组提出了一个想法：将传输控制协议中处理路由数据包的部分拆分出来，形成一个单独的互联网协议 (IP)。

During a break from a meeting Cerf chaired at ISI to discuss TCP in early 1978, Cerf, Postel, and Danny Cohen, a colleague of Postel’s at ISI, got into a discussion in a hallway. “We were drawing diagrams on a big piece of cardboard that we leaned up against the wall in the hallway,” Postel recalled. When the meeting resumed, the trio presented an idea to the group: break off the piece of the Transmission-Control Protocol that deals with routing packets and form a separate Internet Protocol, or IP.

拆分后，TCP 将负责将消息拆分成数据报，在另一端重新组装，检测错误，重新发送丢失的内容，并将数据包重新按正确顺序排列。互联网协议 (IP) 将负责路由单个数据报。

After the split, TCP would be responsible for breaking up messages into datagrams, reassembling them at the other end, detecting errors, resending anything that got lost, and putting packets back in the right order. The Internet Protocol, or IP, would be responsible for routing individual datagrams.

Postel 回忆道：“我记得当时有一个关于 IP 和 TCP 内容的一般指导原则。规则是‘网关是否需要这些信息来传输数据包？’如果不需要，那么这些信息就不会进入 IP。” 这项协议的改进受到施乐公司帕洛阿尔托研究中心参加斯坦福研讨会的一组工程师的启发。施乐团队通过定义一组称为 PARC 通用数据包 (PUP) 的协议解决了较小规模的专有类似问题。Postel 决定创建单独的协议是正确的做法后，便着手确保完成这项工作。通过彻底分离协议，现在可以构建快速且相对便宜的网关，这反过来又会促进互联网的发展。到 1978 年，TCP 已正式成为 TCP/IP。

“I remember having a general guideline about what went into IP versus what was in TCP,” Postel recalled. “The rule was ‘Do the gateways need this information in order to move the packet?’If not, then that information does not go in IP.” This twist on the protocol was inspired by a group of engineers from the Xerox Corporation’s Palo Alto Research Center who had attended the Stanford seminar. The Xerox team had solved similar issues on a smaller, proprietary scale by defining a family of protocols called the PARC Universal Packet, or PUP. Once Postel decided that creating a separate protocol was the right thing to do, he set about making sure it got done. With a clean separation of the protocols, it was now possible to build fast and relatively inexpensive gateways, which would in turn fuel the growth of internetworking. By 1978, TCP had officially become TCP/IP.

以太网

ETHERNET

1973 年，就在瑟夫和卡恩开始合作研究网络互联概念时，施乐帕洛阿尔托研究中心的鲍勃·梅特卡夫正在发明一种新型网络的技术基础。梅特卡夫的网络被称为短距离或局域网，它连接的不是不同城市，而是不同房间的计算机。

In 1973, just when Cerf and Kahn had begun collaborating on the concept of internetworking, Bob Metcalfe at Xerox PARC was inventing the technological underpinnings for a new kind of network. Called a short-distance, or local-area, network, Metcalfe’s network would connect computers not in different cities but in different rooms.

梅特卡夫在麻省理工学院获得了电气工程和管理学学士学位，后来进入哈佛大学攻读研究生。但他很快就讨厌哈佛大学。“哈佛大学里都是有钱人，”他说。“麻省理工学院里都是没钱人。这是阶级问题。”

Metcalfe had received his undergraduate degrees in electrical engineering and management from MIT and enrolled at Harvard for graduate school. But he hated Harvard immediately. “Harvard is full of old-money people,” he said. “MIT is full of no money. It was a class thing.”

梅特卡夫在麻省理工学院找到了一份工作，在那里他感觉更自在。该学院即将加入 ARPANET，他被指派负责构建麻省理工学院 PDP-10 和 IMP 之间的接口。哈佛大学也有一台 PDP-10，梅特卡夫愿意制作一个复制的接口送给哈佛大学。但哈佛大学的网络人员拒绝了这一提议。“他们说不可能让研究生做这么重要的事情，”梅特卡夫说。哈佛大学官员决定让 BBN 来做这件事。BBN 又把这项工作交给了其驻校研究生本·巴克，巴克招募了哈佛大学研究生同学约翰·麦奎兰来帮忙。

Metcalfe took a job at MIT, where he felt more comfortable. The Institute was about to join theARPANET, and he was assigned to build the interface between MIT’s PDP-10 and its IMP. Harvard had a PDP-10, too, and Metcalfe offered to make a duplicate interface to give to Harvard. But the networking people at Harvard declined the offer. “They said they couldn’t possibly let a graduate student do something that important,” said Metcalfe. Harvard officials decided to have BBN do it. BBN in turn gave the job to its graduate student in residence, Ben Barker, who recruited John McQuillan, a fellow Harvard graduate student, to help him.

尽管就读于哈佛大学，梅特卡夫仍留在麻省理工学院撰写他的毕业论文，即对阿帕网的研究。当梅特卡夫提交论文时，哈佛大学拒绝了他的论文，理由是理论性不足（他被告知工程学太多，科学性不足）。这次拒绝让梅特卡夫感到尴尬，因为他刚刚说服妻子辞职和他一起在施乐公司的帕洛阿尔托研究中心找到了一份工作。他还是去了施乐帕洛阿尔托研究中心，开始为他的论文寻找一个更理论性的主题。

Although enrolled at Harvard, Metcalfe stayed at MIT to work on his dissertation, an examination of theARPANET. When Metcalfe submitted the work, Harvard rejected the finished dissertation as insufficiently theoretical (too much engineering and not enough science, he was told). The rejection was embarrassing for Metcalfe, who had just taken a job at Xerox Corporation’s Palo Alto Research Center after persuading his wife to leave her job to join him. He went to Xerox PARC anyway and began looking for a more theoretical topic for his thesis.

1972 年，梅特卡夫在 PARC 从事与 DARPA 相关的业务时，住在他的朋友史蒂夫·克罗克位于华盛顿的家中。克罗克召集了早期站点的一些最优秀的技术人员来协助新站点，并称这些人为“网络协调员”。梅特卡夫就是其中之一，他当时已成为麻省理工学院的 ARPANET 专家。

Then in 1972, while on DARPA-related business for PARC, Metcalfe stayed at the Washington home of his friend Steve Crocker. Crocker had gathered together some of the best technical people from the early sites to assist new sites and called these people “network facilitators.” Metcalfe, who had become something of anARPANET expert at MIT, was one of them.

当时，夏威夷大学 ALOHA 网络的主要设计者诺姆·艾布拉姆森刚刚拜访了克罗克。梅特卡夫来访的那天晚上，克罗克把艾布拉姆森的一篇关于 ALOHA 网络的论文留在了外面。梅特卡夫拿起它，在睡觉前读了一遍。这篇论文让他整晚都睡不着觉。“论文中的数学不仅熟悉，而且令人恼火，”他说，“因为他们做出了人们为了让他们的模型奏效而做出的典型不准确假设。”

Crocker had just been visited by Norm Abramson, the primary architect of theALOHAnetwork at the University of Hawaii. On the night of Metcalfe’s visit, Crocker left one of Abramson’s papers about theALOHAnetwork out. Metcalfe picked it up and read it before going to sleep. The paper kept him up much of the night. “The math in the paper was not only familiar but infuriating,” he said, “because they made the typical inaccurate assumptions that people make so that their models work.”

梅特卡夫偶然读到艾布拉姆森的论文，从此改变了他的一生。“我决定为 ALOHA 系统建立一个新模型。”几周后，他参加了由施乐公司资助的夏威夷大学之旅。他在那里待了一个月，回国前在论文中加入了对 ALOHA 系统的广泛分析。这正是论文所需要的理论支持。当他重新提交论文时，论文被接受了。

Metcalfe’s chance encounter with Abramson’s paper was to change his life. “I set out to make a new model for theALOHAsystem.” Within a few weeks, he was on a Xeroxfunded trip to the University of Hawaii. He stayed a month, and before coming home had added an extensive analysis of theALOHAsystem to his thesis. It was just the theoretical boost the dissertation needed. When he resubmitted the work, it was accepted.

但 ALOHA 系统给梅特卡夫带来的远不止一个博士学位。施乐 PARC 当时正在开发第一台个人电脑 Alto。该公司发现客户希望连接这些机器，因此常驻网络专家之一的梅特卡夫被指派负责将 Altos 连接在一起。如果没有存储转发模型，就不可能防止数据包发生冲突。但仅仅通过构建一个 IMP 类存储转发计算机子网来缩小 ARPANET 的规模，对于设计用于办公楼的系统来说，成本将高得令人望而却步。

But theALOHAsystem gave Metcalfe far more than a doctorate. Xerox PARC was in the process of developing one of the first personal computers, called the Alto. The company saw that customers would want to connect the machines, so Metcalfe, one of the resident networking experts, was assigned the task of tying the Altos together. Without a storeand-forward model, preventing data packets from colliding was impossible. But simply scaling down theARPANET by building a subnet of IMP-like store-and-forward computers would have been prohibitively expensive for a system designed to work in an office building.

梅特卡夫有一个想法，直接借鉴了 ALOHANET——事实上，他称之为 Alto Aloha 网络：让数据包发生碰撞，然后在随机时间重新传输。但梅特卡夫的想法在几个方面与夏威夷系统不同。首先，他的网络比 ALOHANET 快一千倍。它还包括碰撞检测。但也许最重要的是，梅特卡夫的网络是硬连线的，不是通过无线电波运行，而是通过连接不同房间或建筑物群之间计算机的电缆运行。

Metcalfe had an idea, borrowed directly from theALOHANET—in fact, he would call it the Alto Aloha Network: Let the data packets collide, then retransmit at a random time. But Metcalfe’s idea differed in several respects from the Hawaiian system. For one thing, his network would be a thousand times faster thanALOHANET. It would also include collision detection. But perhaps most important, Metcalfe’s network would be hardwired, running not by radio waves but on cables connecting computers in different rooms, or among clusters of buildings.

一台计算机想要将数据包发送到另一台机器（例如，台式工作站发送到打印机），它会监听电缆上的通信。如果计算机检测到冲突的传输，它会等待，通常要等待几千分之一秒。当电缆安静时，计算机开始传输数据包。如果在传输过程中检测到冲突，它会停止并等待，然后再试一次——通常要等几百微秒。在这两种情况下，计算机都会随机选择延迟，以最大限度地减少在发送导致冲突的信号的设备选择的同一时刻重试的可能性。随着网络变得越来越繁忙，计算机会退出并在更长的随机间隔内重试。这可以保持流程高效，通道完好无损。

One computer wishing to send a data packet to another machine—say, a desktop workstation sending to a printer—listens for traffic on the cable. If the computer detects conflicting transmissions, it waits, usually for a few thousandths of a second. When the cable is quiet, the computer begins transmitting its packet. If, during the transmission, it detects a collision, it stops and waits before trying again—usually a few hundred microseconds. In both instances, the computer chooses the delay randomly, minimizing the possibility of retrying at the same instant selected by whatever device sent the signal that caused the collision. As the network gets busier, computers back off and retry over longer random intervals. This keeps the process efficient and the channel intact.

“想象一下你在一个聚会上，几个人站在一起聊天，”帮助梅特卡夫开发这个想法的巴特勒·兰普森在描述这个系统时说。“一个人停止说话，另一个人想说话。好吧，不能保证只有一个人想说话；也许有几个人想说话。两个人同时开始说话并不罕见。但通常会发生什么？通常他们都会停下来，犹豫一会儿，然后一个人又开始说话了。”

“Imagine you’re at a party and several people are standing around having a conversation,” said Butler Lampson, who helped Metcalfe develop the idea, describing the system. “One person stops talking and somebody else wants to talk. Well, there’s no guarantee that only one person wants to talk; perhaps several do. It’s not uncommon for two people to start talking at once. But what typically happens? Usually they both stop, there’s a bit of hesitation, and then one starts up again.”

梅特卡夫和兰普森与施乐研究人员戴维·博格斯和查克·萨克尔一起，在施乐帕洛阿尔托研究中心鲍勃·泰勒的实验室中建立了他们的第一个 Alto Aloha 系统。令他们欣喜的是，该系统成功运行。1973 年 5 月，梅特卡夫提出了一个名字，他回忆起 19 世纪物理学家发明的假想发光介质，用于解释光如何穿过真空。他将该系统重新命名为以太网。

Metcalfe and Lampson, along with Xerox researchers David Boggs and Chuck Thacker, built their first Alto Aloha system in Bob Taylor’s lab at Xerox PARC. To their great delight, it worked. In May 1973 Metcalfe suggested a name, recalling the hypothetical luminiferous medium invented by nineteenth-century physicists to explain how light passes through empty space. He rechristened the system Ethernet.

中国科学院网络

CSNET

国防部研究与开发局（DCA）是 ARPANET 的管理机构，但并不是华盛顿唯一一个官僚主义严重的研发机构。在华盛顿，再也没有哪个机构像你走进老板的办公室，带着一个绝妙的项目创意，二十分钟后就带着一百万美元的资金走出办公室。在 20 世纪 70 年代中期，唯一一个与旧 ARPA 有相似之处的组织是美国国家科学基金会。该基金会成立于 1950 年，旨在通过资助基础研究和加强科学教育来促进科学进步。到 20 世纪 70 年代末，NSF 在计算领域崛起。

DCA, theARPANET’s caretaker, wasn’t the only R&D agency in Washington to have grown bureaucratic. Nowhere in Washington could you walk into your boss’s office anymore with a bright idea for a project and walk out twenty minutes later with a million dollars in support. In the mid-1970s, the only organization that bore any resemblance to the ARPA of old was the National Science Foundation. The foundation was created in 1950 to promote progress in science by funding basic research and strengthening education in science. By the late 1970s, NSF was on the rise in the computing field.

NSF 不仅是一个可能的充足资金来源，而且是唯一一个官员可以代表整个科学界的组织。DARPA 提供了研究基础和新技术。现在 NSF 将把它推广给更大的科学界。

Not only was NSF a new likely source of sufficient funds, it was also the only organization whose officials could act on behalf of the entire scientific community. DARPA had provided the research base and new technology. Now NSF would carry it forward to a larger community.

一段时间以来，NSF 的官员一直对为学术计算机科学界创建一个网络感兴趣。在 1974 年的一份报告中，NSF 的一个咨询委员会得出结论，这种服务“将创造一个前沿环境，为地理上分散或孤立的研究人员提供先进的通信、协作和资源共享。”当时，NSF 主要关注的是推动这一尚处于起步阶段的学科的发展。也许是因为计算机科学在大多数校园里仍然是一个新兴领域，所以这个想法并没有取得多大进展。

Officials at NSF had been interested in creating a network for the academic computer science community for some time. In a 1974 report, an NSF advisory committee concluded that such a service “would create a frontier environment which would offer advanced communication, collaboration, and the sharing of resources among geographically separated or isolated researchers.” At that point, NSF was mostly concerned with spurring the development of what was still a fledgling discipline. Perhaps because computer science was still an emerging field on most campuses, nothing much came of the notion.

到 20 世纪 70 年代末，计算机科学系如雨后春笋般涌现。ARPANET 的优势现在显而易见。与同事之间快速的电子通信和轻松的资源共享意味着通常需要数周才能完成的任务现在可以在数小时内完成。电子邮件创造了一个快速地下出版物的新世界，取代了缓慢的邮政服务和不频繁的会议。网络对计算机科学研究的重要性不亚于望远镜对天文学家的重要性。

By the late 1970s, computer science departments had mushroomed. The advantages of theARPANETwere now clear. Rapid electronic communication with colleagues and easy resource-sharing meant tasks that usually took weeks could now be finished in hours. Electronic mail created a new world of fast samizdat, replacing the slow postal services and infrequent conferences. The network had become as essential to computer science research as telescopes were to astronomers.

但阿帕网却威胁着将计算机研究人员群体分裂为富人和穷人。1979 年，全国大约有 120 个学术计算机科学系，但 61 个阿帕网站点中只有 15 个位于大学。教职候选人和研究生都开始根据学校是否可以访问网络来接受或拒绝录用，这使得没有阿帕网节点的研究机构在争夺顶尖学者和随之而来的研究经费的竞争中处于劣势。

But theARPANETwas threatening to split the community of computer researchers into haves and have-nots. In 1979 there were about 120 academic computer science departments around the country, but just fifteen of the sixty-oneARPANETsites were located at universities. Faculty candidates and graduate students alike were starting to accept or decline offers based on whether or not a school had access to the Net, putting research institutions without anARPANET node at a disadvantage in the race to land top scholars and the research grants that followed them.

更重要的是，计算机人才从学术界流向工业界，这在全国范围内引起了担忧，人们担心美国将无法培养下一代计算机科学家。私营部门的薪酬诱惑是问题的一部分。但科学家不仅被吸引到工业界，他们还被推着走。许多大学的计算机设备陈旧或动力不足，使得校园里的人们很难跟上快速变化的计算机领域的步伐。

More important, an exodus of computing talent from academia to industry had caused a nationwide fear that the United States would not be able to train its next generation of computer scientists. The lure of private sector salaries was part of the problem. But scientists weren’t just being pulled into industry; they were also being pushed. Computer facilities at many universities were obsolete or underpowered, making it hard for people on campuses to stay abreast of the rapidly changing computer field.

学术界和工业界之间的薪资差距几乎无能为力。但资源问题本质上与 DARPA 十年前面临的问题相同。计算机科学家网络将减少重复劳动的需要。如果这个网络对私人研究机构开放，研究人员离开大学以跟上其学科发展的压力就会减小。

Little could be done about the salary discrepancies between academia and industry. But the resource problem was essentially the same one that DARPA had faced a decade earlier. A network for computer scientists would reduce the need for duplicative efforts. And if this network was open to private research sites, there would be less pressure on researchers to leave the universities in order to keep up with their discipline.

虽然解决方案看起来很清晰，但实施起来却又是另一回事。将计算机科学系连接到 ARPANET 是不可能的。要获得一个站点，大学必须参与特定类型的政府资助研究，通常是与国防相关的研究。即便如此，分配新

站点的成本也很高。ARPANET 连接只有一种尺寸：超大。该系统使用昂贵的租用电话线，每个节点必须维护两个或更多与其他站点的链接。因此，维护 ARPANET 站点每年的成本超过 100,000 美元，无论它产生的流量是多少。

Clear though the solution seemed, implementing it proved another matter. Linking the computer science departments to theARPANET was out of the question. To be assigned a site, universities had to be involved in specific kinds of government-funded research, typically defense-related. Even then, it was costly to allocate new

sites.ARPANETconnections came in one size only: extra large. The system used costly leased telephone lines, and each node had to maintain two or more links to other sites. As a result, maintaining anARPANETsite cost more than $100,000 each year, regardless of the traffic it generated.

计算机科学家不得不另辟蹊径。1979 年 5 月，威斯康星大学计算机科学系主任 Larry Landweber 邀请六所大学的代表来到麦迪逊，讨论建立一个新的计算机科学研究网络（称为 CSNET）的可能性。尽管 DARPA 无法提供资金支持，但该机构还是派 Bob Kahn 作为顾问参加了会议。NSF 早在五年前就提出了学术网络问题，并派其计算机研究部门负责人 Kent Curtis 参加了会议。会后，Landweber 花了整个夏天与普渡大学的 Peter Denning、特拉华大学的 Dave Farber 以及刚离开犹他大学加入兰德公司的 Tony Hearn 一起制定了新网络的详细提案。

The computer scientists had to invent another way. In May 1979, Larry Landweber, head of the computer science department at the University of Wisconsin, invited representatives of six universities to Madison to discuss the possibility of building a new Computer Science Research Network, to be calledCSNET. Although DARPA couldn’t provide financial support, the agency sent Bob Kahn to the meeting as an advisor. NSF, which had raised the academic network issue five years earlier, sent Kent Curtis, the head of its computer research division. After the meeting, Landweber spent the summer working with Peter Denning from Purdue, Dave Farber from the University of Delaware, and Tony Hearn who had recently left the University of Utah for the RAND Corporation, to flesh out a detailed proposal for the new network.

他们的提案呼吁建立一个向学术界、政府和工业界的计算机科学研究人员开放的网络。底层介质将是像 TELENET 这样的商业服务提供商。由于 CSNET 使用的链接比 ARPANET 使用的链接慢，并且不坚持冗余链接，因此系统的成本将低得多。该网络将由 11 所大学组成的联盟运营，预计五年成本为 300 万美元。由于 DCA 政策

限制 ARPANET 仅供国防部承包商访问，因此该提案不包含两个网络之间的网关。该小组分发的提案草案获得了热烈的赞扬。他们于 1979 年 11 月将最终版本提交给了 NSF。

Their proposal called for a network open to computer science researchers in academia, government, and industry. The underlying medium would be a commercial service provider likeTELENET. BecauseCSNETwould be using slower links than those used by theARPANET , and did not insist on redundant linkages, the system would be far less expensive. The network would be run by a consortium of eleven universities, at an estimated five-year cost of $3 million. Because of the DCA policy

restrictingARPANETaccess to DOD contractors only, the proposal contained no gateway between the two networks. A draft of the proposal circulated by the group received enthusiastic praise. They sent the final version to NSF in November 1979.

但经过近四个月的同行评审后，NSF 拒绝了该提案，尽管它仍然对 CSNET 的想法充满热情。因此 NSF 赞助了一个研讨会来克服 NSF 评审员在提案草案中发现的缺陷。Landweber 和公司又回到了他们的绘图板上。

But after nearly four months of peer review, NSF rejected the proposal, although it remained enthusiastic about theCSNETidea. So NSF sponsored a workshop to overcome the deficiencies that NSF’s reviewers found in the draft proposal. Landweber and company returned to their drawing boards.

1980 年夏天，兰德韦伯的委员会提出了一种定制 CSNET 架构的方法，以便为最小的实验室提供经济实惠的接入服务。他们提出了一个三层结构，包括 ARPANET、基于 TELENET 的系统和仅提供电子邮件的服务（称为 PhoneNet）。网关将把各层连接成一个无缝整体。

In the summer of 1980, Landweber’s committee came back with a way to tailor the architecture ofCSNETto provide affordable access to even the smallest lab. They proposed a three-tiered structure involvingARPANET, aTELENET-based system, and an e-mail-only service called PhoneNet. Gateways would connect the tiers into a seamless whole.

根据新方案，NSF 将为 CSNET 提供五年的启动资金，之后将完全由用户付费。一所大学的年度费用（会费和连接费）从 PhoneNet 服务的几千美元（主要用于长途电话连接）到 TELENET 站点的 21,000 美元不等。至于如何管理网络（NSF 的管理机构国家科学委员会关心的问题），该计划采取了一种新颖的方法。在头两年，NSF 本身将扮演大学联盟管理者的角色。此后，责任将移交给大学大气研究公司。UCAR 熟悉高级计算工作，并拥有处理涉及如此多学术机构的项目的专业知识。更重要的是，科学委员会了解 UCAR 并信任其管理技能。委员会同意为 CSNET 项目提供近 500 万美元。

Under the new proposal, NSF would supportCSNETfor a five-year startup period, after which it was to be fully funded by user fees. A university’s annual costs, a combination of dues and connection charges, ranged from a few thousand dollars for PhoneNet service (mostly for the long-distance phone connections) to $21,000 for aTELENETsite. As to how the network would be managed—a concern of the National Science Board, the NSF’s governing body—the plan took a novel approach. For the first two years, the NSF itself would play the role of manager for the university consortium. After that, responsibility would be handed off to the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research. UCAR was familiar with advanced computing work and had the expertise to handle a project involving so many academic institutions. More important, the Science Board knew UCAR and trusted its management skills. The Board agreed to provide nearly $5 million for theCSNETproject.

到 1983 年 6 月，已有 70 多个站点上线，获得全面服务并缴纳年费。1986 年 NSF 资助期结束时，几乎所有国家的计算机科学系以及大量私人计算机研究站点都已联网。该网络财务稳定，资金自给自足。
