By June 1983, more than seventy sites were on-line, obtaining full services and paying annual dues. At the end of the five-year period of NSF support in 1986, nearly all the country’s computer science departments, as well as a large number of private computer research sites, were connected. The network was financially stable and financially selfsufficient.

NSF 在启动 CSNET 过程中获得的经验为 NSF 在计算机网络领域开展更多活动铺平了道路。

20 世纪 80 年代中期，随着 CSNET 的成功，更多的网络开始涌现。其中一个网络名为 BITNET（Because It's Time Network），是 IBM 系统之间的合作网络，对成员资格没有任何限制。另一个网络名为 UUCP，由贝尔实验室建立，用于文件传输和远程命令执行。USENET 始于 1980 年，是两台机器（一台在北卡罗来纳大学，另一台在杜克大学）之间的一种通信方式，后来发展成为使用 UUCP 的分布式新闻网络。NASA 有自己的网络，称为空间物理分析网络 (SPAN)。由于这个不断增长的网络集合能够使用 TCP/IP 协议进行通信，因此这个网络集合逐渐被称为“互联网”，借用了“互联网协议”的第一个词。

In the mid-1980s, on the heels ofCSNET’s success, more networks began to emerge. One, calledBITNET(the Because It’s Time Network), was a cooperative network among IBM systems with no restrictions on membership. Another, called UUCP, was built at Bell Laboratories for file transfer and remote-command execution.USENET , which began in 1980 as a means of communication between two machines (one at the University of North Carolina and one at Duke University), blossomed into a distributed news network using UUCP. NASA had its own network called the Space Physics Analysis Network, or SPAN. Because this growing conglomeration of networks was able to communicate using the TCP/IP protocols, the collection of networks gradually came to be called the “Internet,” borrowing the first word of “Internet Protocol.”

到目前为止，小写的“internet”和大写的“Internet”之间已经出现了区别。正式的区别很简单：“internet”是指任何使用 TCP/IP 的网络，而“Internet”是指由许多运行 TCP/IP 协议的链接网络组成的公共、联邦政府补贴的网络。粗略地说，“internet”是私有的，“Internet”是公共的。直到 20 世纪 80 年代中期，路由器供应商开始销售构建私有互联网的设备时，这种区别才真正重要。但随着私有互联网建立起通往公共互联网的网关，这种区别很快就变得模糊了。

By now, a distinction had emerged between ”internet” with a small i,and “Internet” with a capitalI.Officially, the distinction was simple: “internet” meant any network using TCP/IP while “Internet” meant the public, federally subsidized network that was made up of many linked networks all running the TCP/IP protocols. Roughly speaking, an “internet” is private and the “Internet” is public. The distinction didn’t really matter until the mid-1980s when router vendors began to sell equipment to construct private internets. But the distinction quickly blurred as the private internets built gateways to the public Internet.

大约在同一时间，私营公司和研究机构正在构建使用 TCP/IP 的网络。路由器市场开始开放。网关是 IMP 的互联网变体，而路由器是网关的量产版本，将局域网连接到 ARPANET。20 世纪 80 年代初的某个时候，Alex McKenzie 和另一位 BBN 工程师找到了 BBN 的营销副总裁，他们认为该公司应该涉足路由器制造业务。这是有道理的。BBN 已经构建了 IMP 和 TIP，甚至作为分组无线电计划的一部分构建了第一个互联网网关。但这位营销人员在脑子里快速计算了一下后，认为路由器没有多大前景。他错了。

At around the same time, private corporations and research institutions were building networks that used TCP/IP. The market opened up for routers. Gateways were the internetworking variation on IMPs, while routers were the mass-produced version of gateways, hooking local area networks to theARPANET. Sometime in the early 1980s a marketing vice president at BBN was approached by Alex McKenzie and another BBN engineer who thought the company should get into the business of building routers. It made sense. BBN had built the IMPs and the TIPs, and even the first gateway for the Internet as part of the packet radio program. But the marketing man, after doing some quick calculations in his head, decided there wasn’t much promise in routers. He was wrong.

同样在 20 世纪 80 年代中期，欧洲出现了几个学术研究网络。加拿大有 CDNet。然而，逐渐地，每个网络都建立了通往美国政府资助的互联网的网关，边界开始消失。互联网逐渐变成了全球范围内相互连接的 TCP/IP 网络的松散矩阵。

Also in the middle of the 1980s several academic research networks in Europe sprang to life. In Canada there was CDNet. Gradually, however, each network built a gateway to the U.S. Government–sponsored Internet and borders began to dissolve. And gradually the Internet came to mean the loose matrix of interconnected TCP/IP networks worldwide.

到目前为止，所有获得 NSF 支持的研究科学家（不仅是计算机科学家，还有海洋学家、天文学家、化学家等）都开始相信，除非他们能够访问网络，否则他们将处于竞争劣势。而 CSNET 原本仅供学术计算机科学部门使用，并不是答案。但 CSNET 是 NSF 的主要成就 NSFNET 的垫脚石。

By now, all research scientists with NSF support—not just computer scientists, but oceanographers, astronomers, chemists, and others—came to believe they were at a competitive disadvantage unless they had network access. AndCSNET, which was to be used only by academic computer science departments, wasn’t the answer. ButCSNETwas the stepping stone to NSF’s major accomplishment,NSFNET.

CSNET 的模式让 NSF 认识到网络对科学界的重要性。与同行交流的能力所带来的专业优势是无法估量的。而且由于该机构一直与计算机科学家密切合作，因此其内部有许多了解网络并能够帮助管理项目的人员。但 NSF 没有能力建立全国性的网络。仅维护 ARPANET 每年就需要花费数百万美元。

The model ofCSNETconvinced NSF of the importance of networking to the scientific community. The professional advantages to be gained from the ability to communicate with one’s peers was incalculable. And since the agency had been working so closely with the computer scientists, it had a number of people internally who understood networking and were able to help manage programs. But NSF didn’t have the means to build a national network. Maintaining theARPANETalone cost millions of dollars a year.

1985 年，五个超级计算机中心在美国各地建立，这为解决这一问题提供了解决方案。物理学家和其他人士正在推动建立一条“主干网”来连接超级计算机中心。NSF 同意建立主干网，称为 NSFNET。同时，NSF 提出，如果某个地理区域内的学术机构组建社区网络，该机构将允许社区网络访问主干网。这个想法不仅提供访问权限，还允许区域网络相互访问。通过这种安排，任何计算机都可以通过一系列链接与其他计算机通信。

The creation in 1985 of five supercomputer centers scattered around the United States offered a solution. Physicists and others were agitating for a “backbone” to interconnect the supercomputer centers. The NSF agreed to build the backbone network, to be calledNSFNET . At the same time, the NSF offered that if the academic institutions in a geographic region put together a community network, the agency would give the community network access to the backbone network. The idea was not only to offer access but also to give the regional networks access to each other. With this arrangement, any computer could communicate with any other through a series of links.

作为回应，全国成立了十几个区域网络。每个网络都拥有该地区连接 NSFNET 主干网的独家经营权。在纽约州北部，成立了 NYSERNET（纽约州教育研究网络）。在圣地亚哥，成立了加州教育研究网络，简称 CERFnet（尽管 Vint Cerf 与该网络没有任何关系，但 CERFnet 创始人邀请他参加了网络成立仪式）。区域网络的资金将来自成员公司本身。NSF 为学术界提供主干网，本质上是一种“免费产品”，因为区域网络无需支付使用费用。另一方面，NSF 为大学提供将其校园连接到区域网络的资助始终是两年期的、严格不可续期的资助。这意味着两年后，大学将自掏腰包支付区域连接的费用。高速连接的典型费用为每年 20,000 至 50,000 美元。

In response, a dozen or so regional networks were formed around the country. Each had the exclusive franchise in that region to connect to theNSFNETbackbone. In Upstate New York,NYSERNET(for New York State Educational Research Network) was formed. In San Diego there was the California Educational Research Network, or CERFnet (althoughVint Cerf had no relationship to the network, the CERFnet founders invited him to its inauguration). The funding for the regional networks would come from the member companies themselves. The NSF provided the backbone as essentially a “free good” to the academic community in the sense that the regional networks didn’t pay to use it. On the other hand, NSF grants to universities to connect their campuses to the regional network were always two-year, strictly nonrenewable grants. This meant that after two years, universities were paying the cost of the regional connection out of their own pockets. Typical charges were between $20,000 and $50,000 per year for a high-speed connection.

TCP/IP 与 OSI

TCP/IP versus OSI

1982 年，文特·瑟夫宣布他将离开 ARPA 并加入 MCI。当年早些时候，他遇到了一位 MCI 高管，他的工作是让 MCI 进军数据业务。“他的想法是建立一个数字邮局，”瑟夫回忆道。“我立刻被这个想法所吸引。”瑟夫离职后，大家的反应是震惊。一位同事哭了。“文特是我们见过的最接近将军的人，”另一位说。

In 1982 Vint Cerf announced that he was going to leave ARPA to take a job at MCI. Earlier that year he had met an MCI executive whose job was to get MCI into the data business. “His idea was to build a digital post office,” Cerf recalled. “I was immediately grabbed by the idea.” The reaction to Cerf’s leaving was shock. One colleague cried. “Vint was as close to a general as we had,” said another.

瑟夫的离职正值网络的关键时刻。ARPANET 即将正式过渡到 TCP/IP，但没有人确切知道美国政府是否真的愿意接受它。国防部已经批准了 TCP/IP，但政府的民事部门却没有。而且人们越来越担心国家标准局会决定支持一种新兴的网络互连竞争标准，即 OSI 参考模型。

Cerf was leaving at a critical time for the network. TheARPANETwas about to make its official transition to TCP/IP, but no one knew for certain whether the U.S. Government was serious about embracing it. The Defense Department had endorsed TCP/IP, but the civilian branch of the government had not. And there was mounting concern that the National Bureau of Standards would decide to support an emergent rival standard for network interconnection called the OSI Reference Model.

几年前，国际标准化组织 ISO 开始开发自己的网络互联“参考”模型，即 OSI，即开放系统互连。自 20 世纪 40 年代以来，ISO 已为从品酒杯到信用卡、从胶卷到计算机等各种事物制定了全球标准。他们希望他们的 OSI 模型能够像双 A 电池之于便携式收音机一样，成为计算机的普遍标准。

Several years earlier, the International Organization for Standardization, ISO, had begun to develop its own internetworking “reference” model, called OSI, or open-systems interconnection. Since the 1940s, ISO had specified worldwide standards for things ranging from wine-tasting glasses to credit cards to photographic film to computers. They hoped their OSI model would become as ubiquitous to computers as double-A batteries were to portable radios.

一场类似战争正在形成，让人想起 AT&T 与 ARPANET 诞生之初分组交换的发明者之间的对抗。OSI 一方是根深蒂固的官僚机构，他们有着强烈的“我们知道最好的”态度，居高临下，有时甚至轻蔑。“OSI 社区的某些部分有一种态度，他们传递的信息是‘是时候卷起你的玩具学术网络了’，”一位热心的 TCP/IP 爱好者回忆道。“他们认为 TCP/IP 和互联网就是学术玩具。”没有人声称从网络工作组开始并在整个学术界持续多年的事情不是临时性的。天哪，有人在浴室里写了第一个 RFC。不仅 RFC 系列从未被 ARPA 正式委托，而且其中一些 RFC 简直就是笑话。

A battle of sorts was forming along familiar lines, recalling the confrontation between AT&T and the inventors of packet-switching during the birth ofARPANET. On the OSI side stood entrenched bureaucracy, with a strong we-know best attitude, patronizing and occasionally contemptuous. “There was a certain attitude among certain parts of the OSI community whose message was, ‘Time to roll up your toy academic network,’” recalled one ardent TCP/IP devotee. “They thought TCP/IP and Internet were just that—an academic toy.” No one ever claimed that what had started with the Network Working Group and continued throughout the academic community for years had been anything but ad hoc. Someone had written the first RFC in a bathroom, for heaven’s sake. Not only had the RFC series never been officially commissioned by ARPA, but some of the RFCs were, quite literally, jokes.

但互联网社区（包括瑟夫、卡恩和波斯特尔等人，他们多年来一直致力于 TCP/IP）从一开始就反对 OSI 模型。首先是技术上的差异，其中最主要的是 OSI 的设计更为复杂和分区化。而且这种设计从未被尝试过。就互联网人群而言，他们实际上已经多次实施了 TCP/IP，而 OSI 模型从未经过日常使用和反复试验的检验。

But the Internet community—people like Cerf and Kahn and Postel, who had spent years working on TCP/IP—opposed the OSI model from the start. First there were the technical differences, chief among them that OSI had a more complicated and compartmentalized design. And it was adesign,never tried. As far as the Internet crowd was concerned, they had actually implemented TCP/IP several times over, whereas the OSI model had never been put to the tests of daily use, and trial and error.

事实上，对于互联网社区来说，OSI 模型不过是一些抽象概念的集合。“OSI 的所有内容都以一种非常抽象、学术的方式描述，”瑟夫说。“他们使用的语言令人难以置信地浮夸。即使你的生命依赖于 OSI 文档，你也不会读懂它。”

In fact, as far as the Internet community was concerned, the OSI model was nothing but a collection of abstractions. “Everything about OSI was described in a very abstract, academic way,” Cerf said. “The language they used was turgid beyond belief. You couldn’t read an OSI document if your life depended on it.”

另一方面，TCP/IP 则体现了经验。它已在实际网络上投入运行。“我们可以尝试各种方法，”瑟夫说。“事实上，我们觉得有必要尝试各种方法，因为最终如果不打算构建某项技术，那么指定它就毫无意义。我们不断收到务实的反馈，了解它是否有效。”

TCP/IP, on the other hand, reflected experience. It was up and running on an actual network. “We could try things out,” Cerf said. “In fact we felt compelled to try things out, because in the end there was no point in specifying something if you weren’t going to build it. We had this constant pragmatic feedback about whether things worked or didn’t.”

瑟夫和其他人认为，TCP/IP 只能在合作研究领域发明，而这正是它如此成功的原因，而 OSI 这样的“骆驼”只能在数千个委员会中发明。也许最重要的是，国防部已经宣布选择 TCP 和 IP 作为军用计算机上运行的协议。

Cerf and others argued that TCP/IP couldn’t have been invented anywhere but in the collaborative research world, which was precisely what made it so successful, while a camel like OSI couldn’t have been invented anywhere but in a thousand committees. Perhaps most important, the Defense Department had already announced its choice of TCP and IP as the protocols that would run on military computers.

20 世纪 80 年代，ISO 会议经常在海外举行，对于瑟夫和波斯特尔这样的人来说，参加会议有时是痛苦的经历。他们参加会议时，感觉就像卡努特国王对着涨潮的潮水大喊大叫。“我总是那个写反驳文件的人，”瑟夫回忆道。

ISO meetings, which were often held overseas in the 1980s, were occasionally painful experiences for people like Cerf and Postel. They attended them only to feel like King Canute yelling at the incoming tide. “I was the guy who was forever writing the counterpaper,” Cerf recalled.

如果说有谁能为推动 TCP/IP 的推广做出不懈努力，那一定就是瑟夫了。互联网的魔力在于，计算机使用了一种非常简单的通信协议。他的一位同事曾说，文特·瑟夫的魔力在于，他劝说、谈判并敦促用户社区采用它。

If anyone could claim credit for having worked tirelessly to promote TCP/IP, it was Cerf. The magic of the Internet was that its computers used a very simple communications protocol. And the magic of Vint Cerf, a colleague once remarked, was that he cajoled and negotiated and urged user communities into adopting it.

1983 年，瑟夫在 MCI 开发 MCI Mail 时，曾试图让 IBM、Digital 和惠普支持 TCP/IP，但他们拒绝了，转而采用了 OSI。尤其是 Digital，它在其基于 OSI 的 DECNET 网络上投入了大量资金。他们认为 TCP/IP 是“研究的东西”。瑟夫感到失望，也有点恼火。“他们说他们不会用它制造产品。所以我不得不用一堆乱七八糟的协议来开发 MCI Mail。”瑟夫将 Digital 和 IBM 内部使用的现有协议拼凑起来，为 MCI Mail 开发了一些更特别的协议。“我理解他们为什么采取这种立场，但它仍然让我很恼火。”

While at MCI in 1983, building what was to become MCI Mail, Cerf tried to get IBM, Digital, and Hewlett-Packard to support TCP/IP, but they refused and adopted OSI instead. Digital, in particular, had invested a great deal of money in itsDECNETnetwork, based on OSI. TCP/IP, they argued, was “a research thing.” Cerf was disappointed and a little irked. “They said they weren’t gonna make products out of it. So I had to build MCI Mail out of a dog’s breakfast of protocols.” Cerf patched together MCI Mail from existing protocols that were being used internally by Digital and IBM, and developed a few more specifically for MCI Mail. “I understood why they took the position they did, but it still bugged me.”

开关

The Switch

1983 年 1 月 1 日，ARPANET 将正式过渡到 TCP/IP。每个 ARPANET 用户都应该从网络控制协议切换到 TCP/IP。当天，管理 ARPANET 的协议将被封存，这样只有运行新协议的机器才能通过网络通信。一些尚未完成转换的站点向 Postel 或其同事 Dan Lynch 或负责监督转换的 Bob Kahn 提出自己的请求，并通常会获得一个宽限期。但到 1983 年春天，要么您已经完成转换，要么您的机器将脱离网络。

On January 1, 1983, theARPANETwas to make its official transition to TCP/IP. EveryARPANETuser was supposed to have made the switch from the Network Control Protocol to TCP/IP. On that day, the protocol that had governed theARPANETwould be mothballed, so that only those machines running the new protocols could communicate over the network. Some sites that hadn’t made the transition yet pleaded their case to Postel or his colleague Dan Lynch, or, to Bob Kahn, who was overseeing the transition, and usually won a grace period. But by the spring of 1983, either you had made the conversion or your machine fell off the network.

作为里程碑，向 TCP/IP 的过渡可能是未来几年互联网发展中最重要的事件。安装 TCP/IP 后，网络可以分支到任何地方；协议使从一个网络到另一个网络的数据传输变得轻而易举。“借用一句话，”瑟夫说，“现在它可以到达以前没有网络到达的地方。”现在有一系列令人印象深刻的网络——从 ARPANET 到 TELENET 再到基克拉泽斯群岛。事实上，为了建立某种秩序，乔恩·波斯特尔 (Jon Postel) 发布了一份 RFC 为这些网络分配编号。

As milestones go, the transition to TCP/IP was perhaps the most important event that would take place in the development of the Internet for years to come. After TCP/IP was installed, the network could branch anywhere; the protocols made the transmission of data from one network to another a trivial task. “To borrow a phrase,” Cerf said, “now it could go where no network had gone before.” An impressive array of networks now existed—from theARPANET toTELENETto Cyclades. There were so many, in fact, that in an attempt to impose some order, Jon Postel issued an RFC assigning numbers to the networks.

1983 年，国防通信局认为 ARPANET 已经发展到足够大的规模，安全问题已成为一个问题。该机构将网络分成两部分：MILNET，用于承载非机密军事信息的站点；ARPANET，用于计算机研究界。在拆分之前，合并后的网络中有 113 个节点。拆分之后，45 个节点仍留在 ARPANET，其余节点则转到 MILNET。在管理和操作上，有两个不同的网络，但通过网关连接，用户无法分辨。旧的 ARPANET 已成为成熟的互联网。

In 1983 the Defense Communications Agency decided that theARPANET had grown large enough that security was now a concern. The agency split the network into two parts: theMILNET, for sites carrying nonclassified military information, and theARPANETfor the computer research community. Before the split, there were 113 nodes in the combined network. Afterward, 45 nodes remained with theARPANET, and the rest went toMILNET. Administratively and operationally there were two different networks, but with gateways connecting them users couldn’t tell. The oldARPANEThad become a full-fledged Internet.

1988 年，即 1983 年 ARPANET 过渡到 TCP/IP 的五年后，ISO 终于制定了开放系统互连标准，美国政府立即采用了竞争对手 OSI 协议作为其官方标准。OSI 似乎可能胜过 TCP/IP。在欧洲，各国政府颁布标准，OSI 似乎是解决方案的必由之路。

In 1988, five years after the 1983ARPANETtransition to TCP/IP, the ISO finally produced standards for Open Systems Interconnection, and the U.S. Government immediately adopted the rival OSI protocols as its official standard. It appeared that OSI might prevail over TCP/IP. In Europe, where national governments decree the standards, it seemed an article of faith that OSI was the solution.

另一方面，美国的互联网文化正在呈指数级增长，其基础是 TCP/IP。当欧洲各国政府都在推行 OSI 时，欧洲大学中出现了一些地下运动，旨在实施 TCP/IP。

On the other hand, an American culture of the Internet was growing exponentially, and its foundation was TCP/IP. And while governments throughout Europe were anointing OSI, something of an underground movement sprang up at European universities to implement TCP/IP.

决定 TCP/IP 和 OSI 结果的一个关键发展是 UNIX 操作系统的流行，该系统由 AT&T 的贝尔实验室于 1969 年开发。

One key development in determining the outcome between TCP/IP and OSI turned out to be the popularity of theUNIXoperating system, which had been developed at AT&T’s Bell Laboratories in 1969.

程序员喜欢 UNIX 主要有两个原因：它的灵活性使他们可以根据自己正在开发的任何程序进行调整，而且它是“可移植的”，这意味着它可以在许多不同的计算机上工作。20 世纪 70 年代末，伯克利的程序员开发了自己的 UNIX 品牌，并以此在计算机科学界播下了种子。BerkeleyUNIX 最终成为世界各地大学和研究机构的固定产品。1981 年左右，伯克利的 UNIX 黑客 Bill Joy 获得 ARPA 资助，将 TCP/IP 写入 BerkeleyUNIX 的一个版本。BBN 已经编写了一个带有 TCP/IP 的 UNIX 版本，但 Joy 不喜欢它，并决定按照自己的方式进行。

Programmers likedUNIXfor two primary reasons: Its flexibility let them tailor it to whatever program they were working on, and it was “portable,” meaning it could be made to work on many different computers. In the late 1970s, programmers at Berkeley developed their own brand ofUNIX, and seeded the computer science community with it. BerkeleyUNIXeventually became a fixture at universities and research institutions all over the world. Around 1981, Bill Joy, aUNIXhacker at Berkeley, got ARPA funding to write TCP/IP into a version of BerkeleyUNIX. BBN had already written a version ofUNIXwith TCP/IP, but Joy didn’t like it and decided to do it his own way.

1982 年，乔伊加入了斯坦福商学院的几位毕业生的行列，他们成立了一家新公司，制造和销售功能强大的“工作站”，这种计算机比个人计算机强大一个数量级。乔伊以 UNIX 专家的身份加入公司。他们将公司命名为 Sun（斯坦福大学网络）微系统公司。第一台 Sun 机器搭载的是伯克利版 UNIX，并配有 TCP/IP。带有 TCP/IP 的伯克利 UNIX 对互联网的发展至关重要。当 Sun 将网络软件作为其销售的每台机器的一部分，并且不单独收费时，网络便开始蓬勃发展。

Then, in 1982, Joy joined a couple of Stanford Business School graduates who were starting a new company to build and sell powerful “workstations,” computers that were of an order of magnitude more powerful than personal computers. Joy was brought in as theUNIX expert. They called their company Sun (for Stanford University Network) Microsystems. The first Sun machines were shipped with the Berkeley version ofUNIX, complete with TCP/IP. BerkeleyUNIXwith TCP/IP would be crucial to the growth of the Internet. When Sun included network software as part of every machine it sold and didn’t charge separately for it, networking exploded.

由于以太网的存在，以太网进一步发展壮大。虽然分组无线电和卫星网络激发了人们对互联网概念框架的思考，但它们在很大程度上只是实验性的。以太网是鲍勃·梅特卡夫和他在施乐帕洛阿尔托研究中心的同事于 1973 年设计的局域网络，它为解决如何将校园或公司内的计算机连接在一起的问题提供了一个实用的解决方案。施乐于 1980 年开始将以太网作为商业产品销售。大约在同一时间，鲍勃·泰勒在施乐帕洛阿尔托研究中心的部门向主要研究型大学提供了以太网设备、功能强大的计算机和激光打印机等资助。这些硬件价值数百万美元。然后，一家名为 Ungermann-Bass 的小型网络公司将以太网作为终端和主机之间的连接出售。梅特卡夫创办了自己的公司 3Com，销售用于商业计算机（包括 Sun 机器）的以太网。

It further mushroomed because of Ethernet. While packet radio andSATNETsparked the thinking about a conceptual framework for internetworking, they were largely experimental. Ethernet—the local area network designed by Bob Metcalfe and his colleagues at Xerox PARC back in 1973—was a practical solution to the problem of how to tie computers together, either on a campus or at a company. Xerox began selling Ethernet as a commercial product in 1980. At around the same time, Bob Taylor’s division at Xerox PARC gave a grant to major research universities in the form of Ethernet equipment, powerful computers, and laser printers. It amounted to millions of dollars worth of hardware. Then a small networking company called Ungermann-Bass sold Ethernet as a connection between terminals and host computers. And Metcalfe started his own company, 3Com, to sell Ethernet for commercial computers, including Sun machines.

整个 20 世纪 80 年代初期，局域网风靡一时。每所大学都将其工作站连接到局域网。大学不想连接到一台大型计算机，而是希望将其整个局域网（或 LAN）连接到 ARPANET。

Throughout the early 1980s, local area networks were the rage. Every university hooked its workstations to local area networks. Rather than connect to a single large computer, universities wanted to connect their entire local area network—or LAN—to theARPANET.

以太网使这一切成为可能。以太网很简单，与 ARPANET 的 50 千比特线路相比，它的功能非常强大。它们在大学和研究界的快速发展推动了对网络互连的需求。如果你的整个大学没有连接到 ARPANET，CSNET 可以让你把你大学的一台计算机连接到 ARPANET。但正是以太网创造了一个巨大的网络群体。

Ethernet made this possible. Ethernets were simple and, compared to the 50-kilobit lines of theARPANET, they were tremendously powerful. Their rapid growth in the university and research community pushed the demand for network interconnection. If your whole university was not connected to theARPANET,CSNET gave you a way to connect one computer at your university to theARPANET. But it was Ethernet that created a huge networking constituency.

在主要的研究型大学，会有一个由数百台计算机组成的网络，这些计算机都可以通过以太网相互通信。要将流量从圣地亚哥的以太网发送到布法罗的另一个以太网，需要通过 ARPANEThub 发送。这样，ARPANET 就成了 ARPA 互联网的核心。在 20 世纪 80 年代上半叶，ARPA 互联网就像一颗恒星，各种网络围绕着 ARPANET 的中心。

At major research universities there would be a network of hundreds of computers that could all talk to each other over an Ethernet network. To send traffic from an Ethernet in say, San Diego, to another Ethernet in Buffalo, you sent it through theARPANEThub. In this way, theARPANETwas the centerpiece of what was called the ARPA Internet. And through the first half of the 1980s, the ARPA Internet resembled a star, with various networks surrounding theARPANET at the center.

TCP/IP 最值得称道的地方或许在于它绝对“开放”。它的整个设计都是一个开放的过程，遵循了史蒂夫·克罗克和网络工作组率先开辟的道路，并延续到了互联网。ARPANET 以及后来的互联网，都从免费软件和文档的可用性和其他任何东西中发展起来。（相比之下，数字设备公司的 DECNET 是一个专有网络。）互联网还支持广泛的网络技术。尽管卫星和分组无线电网络的寿命有限，但它们帮助开发人员认识到处理多种不同网络的必要性。

Perhaps what TCP/IP had to recommend it most was the fact that it was unerringly “open.” Its entire design was an open process, following a path first blazed by Steve Crocker and the Network Working Group and continuing into the Internet. TheARPANET, and later the Internet, grew as much from the free availability of software and documentation as from anything else. (By contrast, Digital Equipment’sDECNETwas a proprietary network.) The Internet also supported a wide range of network technologies. Although the satellite and packet-radio networks had finite lifetimes, they helped open developers’ eyes to the need to handle a multitude of different networks.

改革电子邮件

Reforming e-mail

TCP 和 IP 标准并不是 20 世纪 80 年代初期网络领域唯一的重大革新。多年来，每个为 ARPANET 编写的电子邮件程序都依赖于原始的文件传输协议作为来回传输邮件的媒介。最初将邮件命令附加到文件传输协议可能是一个巧妙的办法，但电子邮件的处理变得越来越复杂。1982 年 8 月下旬的一天，Postel 在给 MsgGroup 邮件列表中的同事的一封邮件中说：“如果你认真研究一下 FTP 规范，就会发现邮件命令其实是某种缺陷。”Postel 和许多其他人都认为是时候为邮件构建一个完全独立的传输机制了。

The TCP and IP standards weren’t the only major renovation to networking in the early 1980s. For years, every e-mail program written for theARPANEThad depended on the original file-transfer protocol to serve as its barge for schlepping the mail back and forth. It may have been a neat hack to attach the mail commands to the file-transfer protocol at first, but the processing of e-mail had grown more complicated. In a message to his colleagues in the MsgGroup mailing list one day in late August 1982, Postel said, “If you really go look at the FTP spec, you will see that the mail commands are really some sort of wart.” Postel and a lot of others felt it was time to build a completely separate transfer mechanism for mail.

由于网络在切换到 TCP/IP 时经历了大规模重组，因此现在似乎是推出新标准的合适时机。Postel 和他的同事将其称为简单邮件传输协议 (SMTP)。它阐明了现有做法，同时添加了一些新的控制功能。

Since the network was undergoing massive rearrangement anyway with the switch to TCP/IP, this seemed an appropriate time to bring out the new standard. Postel and his colleagues called it the simple mail transfer protocol (SMTP). It clarified existing practices, while adding a few new control features.

与此同时，网络的增长也带来了新的问题。BBN 的程序员 Craig Partridge 表示：“当我们拥有大约两千台主机时，事情就开始变得一团糟。我们不再拥有一台大型主机，可以容纳两万人，而是突然被大量个人机器淹没了。”每台主机都有一个给定的名称，“每个人都想被称为 Frodo”，Partridge 回忆道。

At the same time, the growth of the network gave rise to a new problem. “When we got to about two thousand hosts, that’s when things really started to come apart,” said Craig Partridge, a programmer at BBN. “Instead of having one big mainframe with twenty thousand people on it, suddenly we were getting inundated with individual machines.” Every host machine had a given name, “and everyone wanted to be named Frodo,” Partridge recalled.

区分互联网上的弗罗多与区分克利夫兰的琼斯一家或史密斯维尔的史密斯一家没有什么不同。确切地说，一个人住在哪里是区分一个人身份的重要因素。多年来，区分这个问题一直是互联网上最麻烦、最混乱的问题之一，直到最后，一个组织制定出了一个可行的方案，称为域名系统（DNS）。

Sorting out the Frodos of the Internet wasn’t unlike sorting out the Joneses of Cleveland or the Smiths of Smithville. Where one lived, precisely, was important in differentiating who one was. For years, sorting this out was among the most troublesome, messiest issues for the Internet, until at last a group chiseled out a workable scheme, called the domain name system, or DNS.

DNS 团队的核心成员是 ISI 的 Jon Postel 和 Paul Mockapetris，以及 BBN 的 Craig Partridge。他们花了三个月的时间制定新寻址方案的细节，并于 1983 年 11 月提出了两个描述域名系统的 RFC。“DNS 极大地改变了我们对系统组织方式的看法，”Postel 说。“树状分支”是指导性的比喻。每个地址都有一个层次结构。从树干到树枝，再到树叶，每个地址都包含多层信息，这些信息依次代表网络地址中更小、更具体的部分。

The core of the DNS team was Jon Postel and Paul Mockapetris at ISI, and BBN’s Craig Partridge. They spent three months working out the details of the new addressing scheme and in November 1983 came forward with two RFCs describing the domain name system. “DNS was a very significant change in the way we thought about the system being organized,” said Postel. “Tree-branching” was the guiding metaphor. Each address would have a hierarchical structure. From the trunk to the branches, and outward to the leaves, every address would include levels of information representing, in progression, a smaller, more specific part of the network address.

但这引发了关于层次结构顺序的争论；什么应该放在最前面，什么应该放在最后。Postel 和其他人最终决定采用从特定到通用的寻址方案。互联网社区也对域名命名争论不休，导致实施推迟了大约一年。有人断言，域名应该反映具体的资金来源 — — 例如 MIT、DARPA，这种说法并不令人信服。最终，委员会商定了七个“顶级”域名：edu、com、gov、mil、net、org 和 int。现在可能有七个 Frodo：大学 (edu) 中名为 Frodo 的计算机、政府站点 (gov)、公司 (com)、军事站点 (mil)、非营利组织 (org)、网络服务提供商 (net) 或国际条约实体 (int) 中的一台名为 Frodo 的计算机。

But that sparked a debate about the sequence of the hierarchy; what should come first or last. Postel and others finally decided on a specific-to-general addressing scheme. The Internet community also argued back and forth over what to name the domains, delaying any implementation for about a year. It was asserted by some, unconvincingly, that domain names should reflect specific funding sources—MIT, DARPA, for example. Eventually, a committee agreed on seven “top-level” domains: edu, com, gov, mil, net, org, and int. Now there could be seven Frodos: a computer named Frodo at a university (edu), one at a government site (gov), a company (com), a military site (mil), a nonprofit organization (org), a network service provider (net), or an international treaty entity (int).

DARPA 于 1985 年开始向人们施压，要求他们采用 DNS 地址。1986 年 1 月，西海岸举行了一次盛大的峰会，所有主要网络的代表都聚集在一起。峰会结束后，每个人都一致认为，他们确实相信 DNS 概念。“是的，这就是我们要让它发挥作用的方式，”帕特里奇回忆道，“是的，我们拥有让这一切飞起来的技术。”

DARPA began pressuring people to adopt DNS addresses in 1985. In January 1986 a grand summit meeting took place on the West Coast, bringing together representatives of all the major networks. By the time the summit was over, everyone had agreed that yes, they really believed in the DNS concept. “And yes, here was how we were going to make it work,” Partridge recalled, “And yes, we have the technology to make it all fly.”

拔掉插头

Pulling the Plug

瑟夫第一次意识到互联网将受到科学界和学术界以外的世界的欢迎是在 1989 年，当时他走进了 Interop 的展厅。Interop 是 Dan Lynch 于 1986 年创办的贸易展，旨在通过 TCP/IP 促进互联互通。在最初的几年里，Interop 吸引了数百名网络行业的铁杆人士参加。到 1989 年，展会上挤满了身着商务装束的男男女女。“走进 Interop 并看到人们在展览上投入大量资金并进行大型演示，这让我顿悟了，”瑟夫说。“我意识到，天哪，人们真的在为这个东西投入大量资金。”参展商包括 Novell、Synoptics 和 Network General。“我们开始查看网络统计数据，意识到我们手中有火箭。”多年来，瑟夫一直将互联网视为一项成功且令人满意的实验。他偶尔希望互联网能够覆盖更广泛的用户。现在有证据表明它正在实现这一点。

The first hint Cerf got that the Internet was going to be embraced by a world outside the scientific and academic communities came in 1989, when he walked on to the exhibition floor at Interop, a trade show started by Dan Lynch in 1986 to promote interconnectivity through TCP/IP. In its first couple of years, Interop was attended by a few hundred hardcore networking people. By 1989 the show was teeming with men and women in business attire. “It was an epiphany to walk into Interop and see the major money being spent on exhibitions with huge demonstrations set up,” Cerf said. “I realized, oh my God, people are spending serious money on this.” The exhibitors had names like Novell, Synoptics, and Network General. “We started looking at the network statistics and realized we had a rocket on our hands.” For years Cerf had seen the Internet as a successful, satisfying experiment. Occasionally he had hoped the Internet might reach a wider world of users. Now here was evidence that it was doing just that.

此时，几乎每个人都在使用 TCP/IP。欧洲基于 TCP/IP 的基础设施也日益增多。TCP/IP 如此普及，如此多的人依赖它，以至于将其拆除并重新开始似乎是不可想象的。凭借其默默无闻的势头，TCP/IP 已经战胜了官方 OSI 标准。它的成功为技术及其发展提供了实物教训。“标准应该被发现，而不是被规定出来，”TCP/IP 派系的一位计算机科学家说。它很少以其他方式发挥作用。

By this time, virtually everyone was using TCP/IP. And there was an ever-increasing infrastructure built upon TCP/IP in Europe. TCP/IP was so widespread and so many people depended on it, that taking it down and starting over seemed unthinkable. By virtue of its quiet momentum, TCP/IP had prevailed over the official OSI standard. Its success provided an object lesson in technology and how it advances. “Standards should be discovered, not decreed,” said one computer scientist in the TCP/IP faction. Seldom has it worked any other way.

到 20 世纪 80 年代末，互联网不再是以 ARPANET 为中心的星状网络，而是变成了一个网状网络，就像 ARPANET 本身一样。NSFNET 计划实现了网络的民主化，而 CSNET 却未能做到这一点。现在，任何在大学校园中拥有互联网连接的人都可以成为互联网用户。NSFNET 迅速成为互联网的主干，其运行速度比 ARPANET 快 25 倍以上。用户现在可以选择连接到 ARPANET 或 NSFNET 主干。许多人选择后者，不仅因为它的速度快，还因为它连接起来更容易。

By the late 1980s the Internet was no longer a star with theARPANET its center; it was a mesh, much like theARPANETitself. TheNSFNET program had democratized networks as evenCSNEThadn’t. Now anyone on a college campus with an Internet connection could become an Internet user. TheNSFNETwas fast becoming the Internet’s spine, running on lines that were more than twenty-five times faster thanARPANETlines. Users now had a choice between connecting to theARPANETor to theNSFNETbackbone. Many chose the latter, not only for its speed but because it was so much easier to connect to.

20 世纪 90 年代即将到来，世界上通过 NSFNET 相互连接的计算机数量远远超过了通过 ARPANET 相互连接的计算机数量。ARPANET 现在只是数百个 ARPA 互联网网络中的一个，而且已经是一只恐龙，无法像互联网的其他部分那样快速发展。

As the 1990s approached, the number of computers in the world that were connected to one another via theNSFNETfar outstripped the number of computers connected to one another via theARPANET. TheARPANETwas now just one of hundreds of ARPA Internet networks, and a dinosaur, unable to evolve as quickly as the rest of the Internet.

鲍勃·卡恩是 DARPA 仅存的网络倡导者，他于 1985 年离开该机构，成立了国家研究计划公司，这是一家非营利性公司，其宗旨是促进“国家信息基础设施”的研究和开发。现在管理 DARPA 的人对网络并不特别感兴趣。在他们看来，所有有趣的问题都已经解决了。此外，该机构还被罗纳德·里根总统的星球大战计划分散了注意力。ARPANET 本身每年耗资 1400 万美元，与速度更快的 NSFNET 相比显得有些臃肿。DARPA 管理层认为 ARPANET 已经失去了其作用。是时候关闭它了。

Bob Kahn, DARPA’s sole remaining champion of networking, had left the agency in 1985 to form the Corporation for National Research Initiatives, a nonprofit company whose charter was to foster research and development for a “national information infrastructure.” The people now running DARPA weren’t particularly interested in networking. In their view, all the interesting problems had been solved. Moreover, the agency was distracted by President Ronald Reagan’s Star Wars program. TheARPANETitself, which cost ARPA $14 million a year to run, looked arthritic next to the higher-speedNSFNET. DARPA management decided theARPANEThad outlived its usefulness. It was time to shut it down.

马克·普伦是 DARPA 的项目经理，目前负责网络项目，他被赋予了关闭 ARPANET 的任务。究竟是谁从 DARPA 的高层下达了这项命令，这一点从未得到明确。“没有人想成为关闭 ARPANET 的恶魔，”普伦说，“所以我成为了这项政策的制定者。”普伦的计划是将站点从 ARPANET 中移除，并将它们放在 NSFNET 主干网上。

Mark Pullen, a DARPA program manager who now ran the networking project, was given the task of decommissioning theARPANET . Exactly who gave the order from within DARPA’s higher reaches was never made quite clear. “No one wanted to be the ghoul that turned off theARPANET,” Pullen said, “so I became the source of the policy.” Pullen’s plan was to pull sites off theARPANETand put them on theNSFNETbackbone.

告诉鲍勃·卡恩关闭网络的计划很难。卡恩聘请了普伦，现在普伦扮演了刽子手的角色。“我感觉他可能觉得我关闭了他最大的成就，”普伦说。“对他伤害最大的似乎是我关闭旧的卫星网络。”卫星网络速度慢、价格昂贵、陈旧。“毫无疑问，他一定觉得这是他自己的孩子。理由很充分。但经过思考，他同意我做的是正确的事情。”（事实证明，DARPA 通过关闭 ARPANET 节省的资金帮助资助了卡恩的新项目。）

It was hard telling Bob Kahn about the plan to decommission the network. Kahn had hired Pullen, and now Pullen played the executioner. “I had a sense he might feel I was turning off his greatest achievement,” Pullen said. “The one that seemed to hurt him worse was when I turned off the oldSATNET.”SATNET was slow and expensive and antiquated. “No doubt he must have felt it was his very own child. For valid reasons. But after he thought about it, he agreed I was doing the right thing.” (As it turned out, the money DARPA saved by turning off theARPANEThelped fund Kahn’s new project.)

普伦一个接一个地关闭了仍是原始网络核心的 IMP 和 TIP。它的消亡让人感到有些悲伤，让人想起亚瑟·克拉克的《2001：太空漫游》中的场景，虚构的第五代计算机 HAL 威胁到它的任务，必须逐个电路地拆除。随着 HAL 逐渐失去“理智”，它可怜兮兮地向负责拆除的宇航员戴夫求情，希望他能保住自己的“性命”。

One by one, Pullen turned off the IMPs and TIPs that still lay at the heart of the original network. There was a certain sadness in its demise that called to mind the scene from Arthur C. Clarke’s2001:A Space Odysseywhere the fictional fifth-generation computer HAL is threatening its mission and has to be dismantled circuit by circuit. As HAL gradually loses its “mind,” it makes pathetic appeals for its “life” to Dave, the astronaut, who is doing the dismantling.

在 ARPANET 的案例中，网络消失了，但其部分仍然存在。“这与 Ma Bell 的解体并没有什么不同，”Pullen 回忆道。“它涉及定位 ARPANET 站点集群并找到接管它们的人。”在大多数情况下，Pullen 将每个 ARPANET 站点转移到其中一个区域网络，并通过补贴一段时间的成本来缓解过渡。除了两个站点转到 MILNET 之外，所有站点都转到了一个或另一个区域网络。“我从来没有听到过任何人大声反对，”Pullen 说。“我想他们都知道时机已到。”Pullen 一次为一个站点找到了新家。在没有归属的地方，DARPA 和 NSF 帮助创建一个。南加州的几个 ARPANET 站点迅速形成了自己的区域网络，并将其称为 Los Nettos；由 Danny Cohen 和 Jon Postel 运营。IMP 本身被关闭、解开电缆并运走。大多数被简单地丢弃。其他 IMP 则在 MILNET 上投入使用。波士顿的计算机博物馆收藏了一台，Len Klein-rock 将 IMP 一号放在加州大学洛杉矶分校供游客参观。最后一个离开的 IMP 是在马里兰大学。巧合的是，Trusted Information Systems（史蒂夫·克罗克现在就职的马里兰州的一家公司）与那台 IMP 有联系。克罗克在 IMP 诞生时在场，在它去世时也在场。

In the case of theARPANET, the network died but its pieces lived on. “It wasn’t all that different from the breakup of Ma Bell,” Pullen recalled. “It involved locating clusters ofARPANETsites and finding someone to take them over.” In most cases, Pullen transferred eachARPANET site to one of the regional networks, and eased the transition by subsidizing the cost for a while. With the exception of two sites that went on to theMILNET, all the sites went to one or another of the regional networks. “I never had anyone object all that loudly,” Pullen said. “I think they all knew the time had come.” One site at a time, Pullen found new homes for them. Where there wasn’t a home, DARPA and NSF helped create one. SeveralARPANETsites in Southern California quickly formed their own regional network and called it Los Nettos; it was run by Danny Cohen and Jon Postel. The IMPs themselves were powered down, uncabled, and shipped away. Most were simply junked. Others went into service on theMILNET . The Computer Museum in Boston got one, and Len Klein-rock put IMP Number One on display for visitors at UCLA. The last IMP to go was at the University of Maryland. By coincidence, Trusted Information Systems, a company in Maryland where Steve Crocker now worked, was connected to that IMP. Crocker had been there at the birth and he was there at the death.

到 1989 年底，ARPANET 不复存在。NSFNET 及其衍生的区域网络成为主要骨干。那一年，为了纪念 ARPANET 成立 20 周年及其消亡，加州大学洛杉矶分校主办了一场研讨会，称之为“第一幕”。

丹尼·科恩在演讲中找到了灵感来源，他说：

By the end of 1989, theARPANETwas gone. TheNSFNETand the regional networks it had spawned became the principal backbone. That year, to mark both theARPANET’s twentieth anniversary and its passing, UCLA sponsored a symposium and called it “Act One.”

In his speech, Danny Cohen found a source of inspiration, and he said this:

“起初，ARPA 创建了 ARPANET。“当时 ARPANET 是空虚混沌。“深渊之上一片黑暗。

“In the beginning ARPA created theARPANET. “And theARPANETwas without form and void. “And darkness was upon the deep.

“ARPA 的精神在网络层面上得到了体现，ARPA 说，‘让我们制定一个协议’，于是就有了协议。ARPA 认为这很好。”​​“ARPA 说，‘让我们制定更多的协议’，于是就这样做了。ARPA 认为这很好。”

 

 

“ARPA 说，‘要有更多的网络’，然后事情就成了。”

结语

Epilogue

1994 年 9 月

September 1994

这次聚会是 BBN 的主意：召集波士顿的几十位关键人物，庆祝加州大学洛杉矶分校第一个 ARPANET 节点安装 25 周年。到现在，互联网已经远远超出了研究实验的范围。随着越来越多的人发现它的实用性，它逐渐成为家喻户晓的词。网络对 21 世纪的影响，就如同电话对 20 世纪的影响一样。它的存在已经渗透到美国文化的几乎每一个方面——从出版到社交。对许多人来说，电子邮件已经成为日常生活中不可或缺的一部分。足不出户的老年人用它来寻找陪伴；一些远亲家庭用它来作为粘合剂。越来越多的人登录互联网开展业务或寻找娱乐。分析师宣称互联网是下一个巨大的营销机会。

The party was BBN’s idea: gather a couple of dozen key players in Boston and celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the installation of the firstARPANETnode at UCLA. By now, the Internet had grown far beyond a research experiment. As more people discovered its utility, it was becoming a household word. The Net promised to be to the twenty-first century what the telephone had been to the twentieth. Its existence was already reaching into nearly every aspect of American culture—from publishing to socializing. For many, e-mail had become an indispensable part of daily life. Housebound seniors used it to find companionship; some far-flung families used it as their glue. More people by the day were logging-on to conduct business or find entertainment on the Net. Analysts pronounced the Internet the next great marketing opportunity.

腾飞才刚刚开始。1990 年，日内瓦附近的欧洲粒子物理实验室 CERN 的研究人员创建了万维网，这是互联网的一个多媒体分支。利用蒂姆·伯纳斯-李的 HTTP 协议，世界各地的计算机科学家开始使用点击程序使互联网更易于导航。这些浏览器以伯纳斯-李的原创作品为蓝本，通常基于 CERN 代码库。特别是一款名为 Mosaic 的浏览器，由伊利诺伊大学的几名学生于 1993 年创建，它将帮助普及万维网，从而普及互联网，这是任何软件工具都未曾做到的。

The takeoff was just beginning. In 1990, the World Wide Web, a multimedia branch of the Internet, had been created by researchers at CERN, the European Laboratory for Particle Physics near Geneva. Using Tim Berners-Lee’s HTTP protocol, computer scientists around the world began making the Internet easier to navigate with point-andclick programs. These browsers were modeled after Berners-Lee’s original, and usually based on the CERN code library. One browser in particular, called Mosaic, created in 1993 by a couple of students at University of Illinois, would help popularize the Web and therefore the Net as no software tool had yet done.

20 世纪 70 年代的网络早已被某种更复杂、更笨重的东西所取代。然而，在很多方面，1994 年的网络仍然反映了创建它的人的个性和倾向。拉里·罗伯茨 (Larry Roberts) 不断为互联网这个庞大而杂乱无章的大厦奠定基础。弗兰克·哈特 (Frank Heart) 对技术发明的务实态度——建造它，把它扔到网络上，如果它坏了就修复它——在之后的几年里渗透到了网络感性中。协议流程中的开放性始于史蒂夫·克罗克 (Steve Crocker) 为网络工作组编写的第一个 RFC，并延续到互联网。在 DARPA 任职期间，鲍勃·卡恩 (Bob Kahn) 做出了保持开放性的引人注目的选择。文特·瑟夫 (Vint Cerf) 赋予了网络文明。而网络的创造者仍然管理着互联网协会并参加互联网工程任务组的会议。

The Net of the 1970s had long since been supplanted by something at once more sophisticated and more unwieldy. Yet in dozens of ways, the Net of 1994 still reflected the personalities and proclivities of those who built it. Larry Roberts kept laying pieces of the foundation to the great big rambling house that became the Internet. Frank Heart’s pragmatic attitude toward technical invention—build it, throw it out on the Net, and fix it if it breaks—permeated Net sensibility for years afterward. Openness in the protocol process started with Steve Crocker’s first RFC for the Network Working Group, and continued into the Internet. While at DARPA, Bob Kahn made a conspicuous choice to maintain openness. Vint Cerf gave the Net its civility. And the creators of the Net still ran the Internet Society and attended meetings of the Internet Engineering Task Force.

就在派对计划开始实施时，BBN 迎来了一位新首席执行官。乔治·康拉德斯 (George Conrades) 是 IBM 的资深营销人员，他被 BBN 董事长史蒂夫·利维 (Steve Levy) 招募来重塑公司的业务。康拉德斯喜欢这个派对创意。他抓住了这个完美的营销工具。康拉德斯对 BBN 的先锋作用非常着迷。他认为 BBN 是最初的互联网公司，这是该公司尚未利用的声名。把派对办得盛大而奢华。租下科普利广场酒店。庆祝网络先驱者，就像他们是第一批踏上月球表面的人一样。邀请计算机行业的杰出人物。并邀请媒体。

Just as the party plans got under way, BBN got a new chief executive officer. George Conrades, a high-powered marketing veteran from IBM, had been recruited by BBN’s chairman Steve Levy to reshape the company’s businesses. Conrades loved the party idea. He seized on it as a perfect marketing vehicle. Conrades was smitten with BBN’s pioneering role. BBN wastheoriginal Internet company, he decided, a claim to fame the firm had yet to exploit. Make the party big and lavish. Rent out the Copley Plaza Hotel. Celebrate the network pioneers as if they had been the first to tread on the moon’s surface. Invite computer industry luminaries. And invite the press.

BBN 需要提振。整个 20 世纪 80 年代，该公司的命运大多在衰退。随着互联网越来越流行，BBN 一次又一次未能将其研究成果商业化，逐渐变得默默无闻。1993 年，该公司的销售额为 2.33 亿美元，亏损 3200 万美元。第二年情况也好不到哪里去，销售额下降，亏损 800 万美元。

BBN needed the boost. Throughout the 1980s, the company’s fortunes had mostly ebbed. As the Internet had grown more popular, BBN, which time and again had failed to commercialize on its research efforts, had slipped into relative obscurity. In 1993 the company lost $32 million on $233 million in sales. The next year wasn’t much better, with an $8 million loss on lower sales.

该公司未能进入路由器市场（IMP 是路由器的先驱），错失了最大的机会。BBN 未能看到路由器的潜力，就像 AT&T 拒绝承认分组交换一样。任何想要将局域网（目前有数十万个）连接到互联网的人都需要路由器。到 1994 年，路由器业务已成为价值数十亿美元的产业。十多年前，BBN 自己的几名计算机人员曾试图推动公司进军路由器业务，但被营销副总裁拒绝了。

The company had missed its greatest opportunity when it failed to enter the market for routers—of which IMPs were the progenitors. BBN failed to see the potential in routers much as AT&T had refused to acknowledge packet-switching. Anyone wanting to connect a local area network—of which there were now hundreds of thousands—to the Internet needed a router. By 1994, the router business was a multibillion-dollar industry. More than a decade earlier a couple of BBN’s own computer guys had tried to push the company into the router business, and they had been brushed off by a marketing vice president.

BBN 的麻烦不仅仅是失败的市场机会。1980 年，联邦政府指控该公司在 1972 年至 1978 年期间合谋向政府收取过高的费用，并篡改时间表以掩盖超额收费。这一做法是在 20 世纪 70 年代末的一次例行审计中被发现的，当时 BBN 官员对政府审计员并不坦诚。（“BBN 变得非常傲慢，”一位长期雇员说。）联邦调查持续了两年多。审计员搬到了该公司的剑桥总部。BBN 的高级员工被传唤到大陪审团面前。没有一个 IMP 成员受到牵连。但在 1980 年，该公司的两名高级财务官通过认罪协议摆脱了一项一百项指控。他们被判缓刑，每人罚款 2 万美元。该公司同意支付 70 万美元的罚款。

BBN’s troubles went beyond failed market opportunities. In 1980 the federal government accused the company of conspiring to overcharge the government on its contracts during the period from 1972 to 1978, and of altering time sheets to conceal the overcharges. The practice was discovered when, in the course of a routine audit in the late 1970s, BBN officials were less than candid with a government auditor. (“BBN had gotten very arrogant,” said one long-time employee.) A federal investigation lasted more than two years. Auditors moved into the firm’s Cambridge headquarters. Senior BBN employees were called before a grand jury. None of the IMP Guys was implicated. But in 1980 two of the company’s high-ranking financial officers plea-bargained their way out of a onehundred-count charge. They were given suspended sentences and fined $20,000 each. The company agreed to pay a $700,000 fine.

当时，BBN 近 80% 的收入都来自政府合同。如果双方无法达成和解，那么政府授予 BBN 的所有合同肯定会在漫长的法律辩护期间被暂停，这些指控可能会毁掉这家公司。公司员工认为政府对不正确的会计做法反应过度。他们说，BBN 在合同研发上给予联邦政府的钱总是远远超过其价值。

At the time, BBN depended on government contracts for nearly 80 percent of its revenues. Given the certainty that all government contract awards to BBN would have been suspended during the course of any lengthy legal defense, had no settlement been reached, the charges could have ruined the company. People in the company felt that the government had overreacted to incorrect accounting practices. BBN, they said, had always given the federal government much more than its money’s worth on contract R&D.

BBN 的网络小组只参与了政府调查，但他们同时提供了确凿的证据，证明政府资助的科学可以结出丰硕的果实。ARPANET 就是证据 A。该网络完全由 ARPA 资助，其创建者被赋予了相当的自由，证明了美国人曾经普遍信任科学。该网络是在华盛顿提供少量指导和大量信任的时代建立的。

The networking group at BBN, only minimally involved in the government investigation, was simultaneously offering proof positive that government-funded science can bear splendid fruit. TheARPANET was Exhibit A. Funded entirely by ARPA, its creators given reasonably free rein, the network was evidence of a once-pervasive American trust in science. The network was built in an era when Washington provided a little guidance and a lot of faith.

到 1994 年，BBN 与政府审计员的纠葛已被遗忘。不幸的是，该公司在 ARPANET 建设中的作用也被遗忘。只有熟悉历史的内部人士才会将该公司与新近流行的互联网联系起来。当 Conrades 上任时，他决定是时候提升 BBN 的形象了。而 ARPANET 的 25 周年庆典正是绝佳的机会。

By 1994, BBN’s brush with the government auditors was forgotten. Unfortunately, so was the company’s role in building theARPANET . Only those insiders who were acquainted with history associated the company with the newly popular Internet. When Conrades arrived, he decided it was time to polish BBN’s image. And a silveranniversary bash for theARPANETwas the perfect opportunity.

宴会的邀请名单和白宫晚宴的邀请名单一样，经过了严格的审查。当然，有些名字是显而易见的；但是，有许多人都参与了 ARPANET 的建设，来自世界各地的更多人参与了互联网的建设。哈特、沃尔登和其他人都提出了建议。信息高速公路的倡导者、副总统阿尔·戈尔也受到了邀请。马萨诸塞州的民主党众议员埃德·马基也受到了邀请，他也将互联网列入了自己的政治议程；他接受了邀请。比尔·盖茨也受到了邀请，尽管这位微软董事长尚未承认互联网是一个有用的工具。他拒绝了。保罗·巴兰在 BBN 中的作用被降到最低，几乎没有受到邀请。随着时间的推移，邀请名单膨胀到 500 人。

The invitation list for the party was as scrutinized as an invitation list for a White House dinner. Some names were obvious, of course; but scores of people had had a hand in building theARPANET, and even more people, from all over the world, had been involved with the Internet. Heart, Walden, and others submitted suggestions.Vice President Al Gore, an advocate of the information superhighway, was invited. So was Ed Markey, a Democratic congressman from Massachusetts who had also put the Internet on his political agenda; he accepted the invitation. Bill Gates was invited, although the Microsoft chairman had yet to acknowledge the Internet as a useful tool. He declined. Paul Baran, whose role was minimized at BBN, nearly wasn’t invited at all. In time, the list ballooned to five hundred invitees.

康拉德斯希望这既是未来的信号，也是对过去的庆祝。他计划让 BBN 扩大其在互联网相关业务中略微减弱的作用。BBN 已经拥有并运营新英格兰区域网络 NEARnet。他到任后的首要举措之一就是收购旧金山湾区区域网络 BARRnet。他还关注东南部区域网络 SURAnet。

Conrades wanted this to be as much a signal for the future as a celebration of the past. He was planning for BBN to expand its somewhat diminished role in Internet-related businesses. BBN already owned and operated NEARnet, the New England regional network. One of his first moves after arriving was to purchase BARRnet, the regional network in the San Francisco Bay Area. And he had his eye on SURAnet, the regional network for the Southeast.

为了寻找一个崇高的主题，BBN 聘请的一家公关公司为自己的公关部门扩充了内容，他们想出了一个主题：“未来的历史”。这个主题与 Conrades 为 BBN 制定的计划完美契合。Conrades 还聘请了一家制作公司制作了一段精心制作的视频演示，其中包括对一群核心先驱的采访——Larry Roberts、Bob Kahn、Steve Crocker、Len Kleinrock、Frank Heart 和 Vint Cerf。

Seeking a lofty theme, the public relations firm that BBN hired to augment its own PR department came up with one: “History of the Future.” It suited Conrades’s plans for BBN perfectly. Conrades also hired a production company to put together an elaborate video presentation that would include interviews with a core group of pioneers—Larry Roberts, Bob Kahn, Steve Crocker, Len Kleinrock, Frank Heart, and Vint Cerf.

以太网的发明者鲍勃·梅特卡夫现在是计算机行业报纸《信息世界》的出版商。他为即将到来的活动写了一篇专栏文章，题为“互联网 25 周年纪念日，老顽固们争相争功”。梅特卡夫写道：“我会去见老朋友，重温旧怨，并加入争功的行列——其中有很多功劳。”“我首先要确保参加聚会的人意识到，大多数 TCP/IP 流量都是由我发明的以太网承载的……随着聚会的高潮，我会看看我能从文特·瑟夫和鲍勃·卡恩那里抢到多少发明互联网的功劳……如果做不到这一点，我会看看我能否微笑着进入分组交换发明者的合影。”

Bob Metcalfe, the inventor of Ethernet, was now publisher of a computer trade newspaper calledInfoWorld.He wrote an opinion column on the upcoming event that he titled, “Old Fogies to Duke It Out for Credit at Internet’s 25th Anniversary.” “I’ll be there to see old friends, to renew some old animosities, and to join in the jockeying for credit— of which there is plenty to go around,” Metcalfe wrote. “I’ll begin by making sure partygoers realize that most TCP/IP traffic is carried by Ethernet, which I invented . . . As the party peaks, I’ll see how much credit I can grab from Vint Cerf and Bob Kahn for the invention of internetworking . . . Failing that, I’ll see if I can smile my way into the group photo of the inventors of packet-switching.”

活动前数周和数天，BBN 的公关公司就在杂志和报纸上刊登了相关报道。《新闻周刊》刊登了一篇关于阿帕网先驱者的长文，《波士顿环球报》也是如此。BBN制作了一段视频新闻剪辑，在 100 多个地方新闻节目中播出。雷·汤姆林森在恰当的时机查看键盘时，无意中输入了 @ 符号，因此被全国公共广播电台在晚会上播出的一篇报道中誉为民间英雄。

Weeks and days before the event, BBN’s public relations firm placed stories in magazines and newspapers.Newsweekran a lengthy piece on theARPANETpioneers, and so did theBoston Globe.BBN put together a video news clip, which was aired on more than one hundred local newscasts. Ray Tomlinson, whose scrutiny of his keyboard at an opportune moment had produced the @ sign, was celebrated as a folk hero in a story aired on National Public Radio on the evening of the party.

贵宾于 9 月 9 日星期五陆续抵达，并于当天下午在科普利广场举行招待会和新闻发布会。如今在纽约担任顾问的韦斯·克拉克开玩笑地把拉里·罗伯茨的名牌别在了自己的运动外套上。在新闻发布会上，几位 ARPANET 先驱发表了演讲，人数比记者还多。鲍勃·泰勒在演讲中讽刺道，受邀的人派的是他们的祖父。

The guests of honor began arriving on Friday, September 9, and gathered for a reception followed by a press conference at the Copley Plaza that afternoon. As a joke, Wes Clark, now a consultant in New York, pinned Larry Roberts’s name badge to his own sport coat. At the press conference, several of theARPANETpioneers, who outnumbered the journalists, delivered speeches. In his speech, Bob Taylor wryly remarked that the people who had been invited had sent their grandfathers instead.

最引人注目的缺席者是利克莱德，他于 1990 年去世，但他的妻子露易丝接受了邀请。IMP 团队的王牌调试员伯尼·科塞尔 (Bernie Cosell) 现在住在弗吉尼亚农村，养羊（“人太多，羊太少”，科塞尔的电子邮件签名写道），由于费用问题无法前来。其他人也拒绝了。众所周知，威尔·克劳瑟 (Will Crowther) 不喜欢聚会，他拒绝了邀请；IMP 同事多次打电话也没能改变他的想法。

The most notable absence was that of Licklider, who died in 1990, but his wife, Louise, accepted the invitation. Bernie Cosell, the IMP team’s ace debugger, who now lived in ruralVirginia and raised sheep (“Too many people, too few sheep,” read Cosell’s e-mail signature), was unable to come because of the expense. Others refused. Famously averse to parties, Will Crowther declined the invitation; repeated phone calls from fellow IMP Guys could not change his mind.

新闻发布会结束后，大家在墨西哥自助餐厅里交流。有些人几天前或几个月前见过面，但其他人已经好几年甚至几十年没见过面了。新婚、旧婚和过早衰老等话题被悄悄地谈论着。拉里·罗伯茨现在经营着一家生产新一代 Switch 的小公司，他住在加利福尼亚州伍德赛德，那是旧金山半岛的一个富裕社区。罗伯茨现年 58 岁，他每天服用“聪明药”（一种是用于治疗帕金森症的 Deprenyl，另一种是褪黑激素），以恢复他 28 岁时拥有的注意力。他以特有的专注力，沉浸在这个主题中。他阅读了数百份研究报告，甚至制作了一盘“抗衰老”录像带。

At a stand-up Mexican buffet following the press conference, everyone mingled. Some people had seen each other a few days earlier, or a few months earlier, but others hadn’t seen each other for years, or even decades. New spouses, old spouses, and premature aging were quietly remarked upon. Larry Roberts, now running a small company that was building a new generation of switch, lived in Woodside, California, a well-to-do community on the San Francisco peninsula. Now fifty-eight, Roberts was on a daily regimen of “smart drugs” (Deprenyl, used to treat Parkinson’s, was one; melatonin was another) to regain the powers of concentration he possessed at twenty-eight. With characteristic intensity, he steeped himself in the subject. He read hundreds of research reports and had even produced an “anti-aging” videotape.

1983 年，泰勒离开了施乐公司的帕洛阿尔托研究中心。他的离开引发了一大批忠诚的研究人员的辞职，他们跟随他来到数字设备公司，在那里他建立了一个研究实验室，距离施乐帕洛阿尔托研究中心只有几英里。多年来，他住在拉里·罗伯茨家附近，但两人都不知道。有一天，一封寄给劳伦斯·G·罗伯茨的邮件被误送到了泰勒家，两人发现他们住的地方相隔几百码。

In 1983, Taylor had left Xerox’s Palo Alto Research Center. His departure had sparked a rash of resignations from loyal researchers, who followed him to Digital Equipment Corp., where he set up a research lab just a few miles from Xerox PARC. For years he lived around the corner from Larry Roberts and neither man knew it. One day a piece of mail addressed to Lawrence G. Roberts was misdelivered to Taylor’s house, and the two discovered that they lived a few hundred yards apart.

BBN 庆典的第二天，周六上午，拍照环节一个接一个。首先是正式的集体照。这个团体很大，大约有 25 人。当 Len Kleinrock 错过了第一次正式拍照时，不得不安排另一次拍照。为了摆出另一个姿势，IMP Guys 的核心团队被要求摆出与 1969 年拍摄的原始 IMP Guys 照片完全一样的姿势。“你们可以减肥吗？”当摄影师试图将每个人都拍进照片时，Cerf 喊道。

之后，科学家们乘坐巴士前往两个街区之外的基督教科学中心参加《连线》杂志的拍摄。这 19 个人勇敢地挤在了该中心地图馆的一座又短又窄的桥上。作为工程师，他们忍不住给摄影师提了些建议，因为摄影师在将他们全部拍进照片时遇到了一些麻烦：试试不同的角度。试试不同的配置。试试不同的镜头。试试不同的相机。后来，团队中的一些人对拍照时出现的跟风者表示不满，但总体而言，周末的欢乐气氛开始感染他们所有人。

On day two of BBN’s fete, Saturday morning, came photo sessions, one after another. First was the official group shot. The group was large, about twenty-five people. When Len Kleinrock missed the first official photo shoot, another had to be arranged. For another pose, the core group of IMP Guys was asked to pose precisely as in the original IMP Guys photo taken in 1969. “Could you guys lose some weight?” Cerf called out as the photographer tried to place everyone in the shot.

Afterward, the scientists were bused two blocks away to the Christian Science Center for aWiredmagazine shoot. Gamely, the nineteen men squeezed themselves onto a short, narrow bridge at the Center’s Mapparium. Being engineers, they couldn’t help but offer some advice to the photographer, who was having a little trouble fitting them all in the shot: Try a different angle. Try a different configuration. Try a different lens. Try a different camera. Later, a few in the group grumbled about hangers-on having shown up for the photo, but for the most part, the general good cheer of the weekend was beginning to infect them all.

当天下午，在接受美联社的集体采访时，人们最明显地意识到了互联网的多个创始人（不仅每个创始人都是互联网的创始人，而且都做出了不可估量的贡献）。采访是在酒店套房的免提电话上进行的。美联社记者提问时，卡恩、哈特、恩格尔巴特和克莱因罗克都弯腰坐在电话机前。不久，采访就变成了一场信用管理研究。泰勒迟到了，但还来得及与鲍勃·卡恩发生争执，鲍勃·卡恩警告美联社记者一定要区分早期的阿帕网和互联网，而 TCP/IP 的发明才标志着互联网的真正开端。泰勒说，事实并非如此。互联网的根源肯定在于阿帕网。电话机旁的人群变得不自在。“女性呢？”记者问道，也许是为了打破沉默。“有女性先驱吗？”又是一片沉默。

The multiple paternity claims to the Internet (not only had each man been there at the start but each had made a contribution that he considered immeasurable) came out most noticeably that afternoon during a group interview with the Associated Press. The interview was done over a speakerphone in a suite at the hotel. Kahn, Heart, Engelbart, and Kleinrock sat hunched over the phone as the AP reporter asked questions. Before long the interview transformed into a study in credit management. Taylor arrived late, but not too late to engage in something of a dustup with Bob Kahn, who warned the AP reporter to be certain to distinguish between the early days of theARPANETand the Internet, and that it was the invention of TCP/IP that marked the true beginnings of internetworking. Not true, said Taylor. The Internet’s roots most certainly lay with theARPANET. The group around the telephone grew uncomfortable. “How about women?” asked the reporter, perhaps to break the silence. “Are there any female pioneers?” More silence.

这个周末值得关注的一点是，谁缺席了，谁出席了。万维网的发明者蒂姆·伯纳斯·李刚刚从日内瓦搬到波士顿，加入麻省理工学院的计算机科学实验室。他没有受到邀请，Mosaic 的联合程序员马克·安德森也没有受到邀请，后者刚刚离开伊利诺伊州，去开发其 Web 浏览器的商业版本。诚然，他们没有参与 ARPANET 或互联网的诞生（安德森直到 1972 年 ARPANET 第一个节点安装后才出生），严格来说不能算作创始人。但他们是两项发明的幕后推手，而这两项发明已经让互联网在日常生活中发挥了最大的影响力。

The weekend was as noteworthy for who wasn’t present as for who was. Tim BernersLee, the inventor of the World Wide Web, had just moved to Boston from Geneva to join MIT’s Laboratory for Computer Science. He wasn’t invited, nor was Marc Andreessen, the co-programmer of Mosaic, who had just left Illinois to develop a commercial version of his Web browser. Granted, they hadn’t played roles in the birth of either theARPANETor the Internet (Andreessen wasn’t even born until 1972, after the firstARPANETnodes were installed) and couldn’t technically be counted as founders. But they were behind the two inventions that were already giving the Net its biggest reach into everyday life.

三年前，美国国家科学基金会取消了对互联网商业用途的限制，现在你不仅可以通过发明互联网网关来致富，还可以通过将业务本身带入互联网来致富。当记者要求他们对此发表评论时，一些最初的 ARPANET 建设者表示，他们发现互联网的新商业化令人遗憾。其他人对此表示欢迎。

Three years earlier, the NSF had lifted restrictions against commercial use of the Internet, and now you could get rich not just by inventing a gateway to the Net but by taking business itself onto the Net. When reporters asked them to comment on this, some of the originalARPANETbuilders said they found the new commercialization of the Net lamentable. Others welcomed it.

这些先驱者中，只有少数人变得富有。梅特卡夫发明的以太网使他成为千万富翁。在加州大学洛杉矶分校担任计算机科学教授的近三十年中，克莱因罗克指导了大批博士生，其中许多人后来成为计算机网络领域的杰出人物。克莱因罗克仍在加州大学洛杉矶分校任教，同时还经营着一家成功的研讨会业务。但另一方面，网络领域的无名英雄乔恩·波斯特尔却默默地观察着这个庆祝周末，就像他多年来一直担任 RFC 的保管人和无法达成共识的技术问题的最终仲裁者一样。波斯特尔认为，多年来他在工作过程中做出的决定都是为了社区的利益，而创办一家公司从这些活动中获利则等于违背了公众的信任。

Few of the pioneers had become wealthy. Metcalfe’s invention of Ethernet had made him a multimillionaire. In his nearly thirty years as a computer science professor at UCLA, Kleinrock had guided an army of Ph.D. students, many of whom went on to become luminaries in the field of computer networking. Still teaching at UCLA, Kleinrock ran a successful seminar business on the side. But at the other end of the spectrum was Jon Postel, the unsung hero of networking. He observed the weekend of celebration quietly, much as he had worked for years as keeper of the RFCs and final arbiter in technical matters when consensus couldn’t be reached. Postel believed that decisions he had made in the course of his work over the years had been for the good of the community, and that starting a company to profit from those activities would have amounted to a violation of public trust.

大多数 IMP 成员最终都进入了 BBN 的高级管理层。沃尔登后来担任哈特的老板，巴克则负责管理 BBN 的一个部门。最引人注目的例外是克劳瑟，他一直是一名程序员。多年来，哈特一直是克劳瑟的拥护者，游说公司让克劳瑟做回自己，以自己梦幻的方式想出各种巧妙的想法。在 IMP 项目之后的几年里，克劳瑟追求了一些关于自然语言处理的不同寻常的想法，并广泛研究高速分组交换技术。

Most of the IMP Guys had ended up in BBN’s senior management. Walden later served as Heart’s boss, and Barker had gone on to run one of BBN’s divisions. The most conspicuous exception to this was Crowther, who had remained a programmer. For years Heart had been Crowther’s champion, lobbying for the company to let Crowther just be Crowther and think up ingenious ideas in his own dreamy way. In the years following the IMP project, Crowther pursued some unusual ideas about natural language processing, and worked extensively on high-speed packet-switching technology.

塞韦罗·奥恩斯坦于 20 世纪 70 年代离开 BBN，加入施乐 PARC，并在那里创办了社会责任计算机专业人员组织。从施乐退休后，他和妻子搬到了旧金山湾区最偏远的角落之一。奥恩斯坦多年来一直远离互联网，多年来也一直不使用电子邮件。

Severo Ornstein had left BBN in the 1970s for Xerox PARC, and while there he started Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility. When he retired from Xerox, he and his wife moved into one of the remotest corners of the San Francisco Bay Area. For years Ornstein stayed off the Net, and for years he eschewed e-mail.

在所有人中，文特·瑟夫也许是这个周末最受追捧的人。大多数媒体都向他寻求有关互联网起源的引言。1994 年初，他离开卡恩的国家研究计划公司，回到 MCI 担​​任高级副总裁，帮助建立公司的互联网业务。他的名声在整个公司都很有名。在北卡罗来纳州的 MCI 运营中心，有人挂了一块牌子：“文特·瑟夫是互联网之父，但我们是互联网之母，必须让互联网发挥作用！”

Of everyone, Vint Cerf was perhaps the most celebrated this weekend. He was the person most of the press turned to for quotes on the Internet’s origins. In early 1994 he had left Kahn’s Corporation for National Research Initiatives to return to MCI as a senior vice president and help build the company’s Internet businesses. His reputation was well known throughout the company. At an MCI operations center in North Carolina someone had hung a sign: “Vint Cerf is the Father of the Internet, but we’re the mothers that have to make it work!”

随着周六晚宴的临近，大家在最后一刻匆忙安排，以确保晚宴的剧本恰到好处。康拉德斯将担任主宾。任何人都不能因为别人而受到冷遇。这是一项几乎不可能完成的任务。在最后一刻，座位安排再次被打乱。晚宴终于开始时，大约 250 人挤满了大宴会厅。国会议员马基在为一项悬而未决的电信法案进行游说时发表了幽默的演讲。瑟夫颁发了两个奖项，卡恩因其一生的成就而获得表彰。年迈体弱的路易斯·利克莱德代表她已故的丈夫站起来接受长时间的掌声。

As Saturday’s dinner approached, there was a great last-minute rush to make certain that the script for the evening would strike just the right tone. Conrades was to be emcee for the main event. No one should get short shrift at the expense of anyone else. It was a nearly impossible task. At the last minute, seating assignments were shuffled yet again. When the dinner finally commenced, some 250 people packed the Grand Ballroom. Lobbying for a telecommunications bill that was pending, Congressman Markey gave a humorous speech. Cerf presented two awards, and Kahn was singled out for his lifetime of achievement. Louise Licklider, frail and elderly, stood up to receive an extended round of applause on behalf of her late husband.

这次庆祝活动对哈特来说意义非凡。哈特现年 65 岁，最近刚刚从 BBN 系统和技术部门总裁的职位上退休。他在 BBN 工作了 28 年。BBN 主席史蒂夫·利维 (Steve Levy) 将哈特叫到讲台上，哈特发表了演讲，指出了 ARPANET 项目成功的原因。“该项目是一个可以快速完成的典范，需要真正强大而老练的领导、充足的资源，并避免可能影响许多项目的官僚主义愚蠢行为。”罗伯茨做到了这一点。哈特最后说：“只有一小部分受过技术培训的人口有机会乘坐技术火箭，然后看到这场革命改变世界。”哈特说，网络革命将跻身本世纪最重要的技术变革之列。那天晚上，在那间屋子里，他似乎是对的。

The celebration held a special poignancy for Heart, now sixty-five, who had recently retired as president of BBN’s Systems and Technology Division. He had been at BBN for twenty-eight years. Steve Levy, the BBN chairman, called Heart to the podium, and Heart gave a speech in which he pinpointed the reasons theARPANET project had succeeded. “The project was an example of what can be accomplished quickly, with a really strong sophisticated leadership, adequate resources, and an avoidance of the many kinds of bureaucratic foolishness that can affect so many projects.” Roberts had seen to that. Heart ended on a high note. “Only a small fraction of the technically trained population get a shot at riding a technological rocket, and then get to see that revolution change the world.” The networking revolution, Heart said, would rank among a small number of the most important technological changes of the century. And that night, in that room, it looked like he might be right.

第二天早上，ARPANET 的先驱们一个接一个地告别了酒店。每个人都还兴致勃勃，至少有那么一点。这几天过得还不错。

The next morning, one by one, theARPANETpioneers said their goodbyes and checked out of the hotel. Everyone was still riding high, at least a little bit. It hadn’t been a bad couple of days.

章节注释

Chapter Notes

第一章

Chapter One

关于高级研究计划局及其信息处理技术办公室成立过程的描述来自个人采访、艾森豪威尔的科学顾问詹姆斯·基利安撰写的两本书（见参考书目）、杂志文章，以及由 DARPA 委托、理查德·J·巴伯联合公司于 1975 年撰写的关于该机构的出色而详尽的历史。关于利克莱德早年的描述基于为纪念他而发表的演讲、对路易斯·利克莱德和比尔·麦吉尔的采访以及卡尔·D·克里特撰写的讣告。关于利克莱德对计算机的介绍基于对韦斯·克拉克和杰克·鲁伊纳的个人采访、利克莱德对查尔斯·巴贝奇研究所的采访以及巴伯联合公司的报告。

The description of the formation of the Advanced Research Projects Agency and its Information Processing Techniques Office is derived from personal interviews, two books written by Eisenhower’s science advisor James Killian (see bibliography), magazine articles, and from an excellent and thorough history of the agency commissioned by DARPA and written by Richard J. Barber Associates in 1975. The description of Licklider’s early years is based on talks given in his honor, on interviews with Louise Licklider and Bill McGill, and on an obituary written by Karl D. Kryter. The description of Licklider’s introduction to computers is based on personal interviews with Wes Clark and Jack Ruina, and on Licklider’s interview with the Charles Babbage Institute, as well as the Barber Associates report.

第二章

Chapter Two

对保罗·巴兰 (Paul Baran) 在分布式通信方面的工作的描述基于对巴兰的个人采访以及巴贝奇研究所进行的各种采访。对唐纳德·戴维斯 (Donald Davies) 在分组交换方面的早期工作的描述基于对唐纳德·戴维斯的采访和通信，以及马丁·坎贝尔-凯利 (Martin Campbell-Kelly) 的文章和采访。亚瑟·诺伯格 (Arthur Norberg) 和朱迪·奥尼尔 (Judy O'Neill) 的精彩报告“国防高级研究计划局信息处理技术办公室的历史”也引导我们了解了传记材料和 IPTO 的早期岁月。该报告成为他们著作《转变计算机技术：五角大楼的信息处理，1962 - 1986》(约翰霍普金斯大学出版社，1996 年) 的基础。

The description of Paul Baran’s work on distributed communications is based on personal interviews with Baran, as well as various interviews conducted by the Babbage Institute. The description of Donald Davies’s early work on packet-switching is based on interviews and correspondence with Donald Davies, and on Martin Campbell-Kelly’s articles and interviews. Arthur Norberg and Judy O’Neill’s awesome report, “A History of the Information Processing Techniques Office of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency” also guided us through biographical material and through the early years of IPTO. The report served as the basis for their bookTransforming Computer Technology: Information Processing for the Pentagon,1962–1986(Johns Hopkins University Press, 1996).

保罗·巴兰 (Paul Baran) 和曼利·欧文 (Manley Irwin) 教授提供了有关 AT&T 对被认为剥夺 AT&T 收入的各方提起诉讼的信息。

 

 

道格·恩格尔巴特 (Doug Engelbart) 的鼠标专利于 1970 年 11 月 17 日获得。专利号为 3,541,541。

第三章

Chapter Three

Bolt Beranek 和 Newman 的历史基于对 Dick Bolt 和 Leo Beranek 的个人采访。林肯实验室的描述基于对 Wes Clark、Frank Heart、Larry Roberts 和 Len Kleinrock 的采访。接口信息处理器提案请求相关事件的描述基于对 Jerome Elkind、Frank Heart、Dave Walden 和 Severo Ornstein 的采访，以及查尔斯·巴贝奇研究所进行的各种采访。

The history of Bolt Beranek and Newman was based on personal interviews with Dick Bolt and Leo Beranek. The description of Lincoln Laboratory was based on interviews with Wes Clark, Frank Heart, Larry Roberts, and Len Kleinrock. The description of events surrounding the request for proposals for the Interface Message Processor was based on interviews with Jerome Elkind, Frank Heart, Dave Walden, and Severo Ornstein, as well as various interviews conducted by the Charles Babbage Institute.

第四回

Chapter Four

关于接口消息处理器构建的描述基于对 Dave Walden、Ben Barker、Severo Ornstein、Bob Kahn、Frank Heart、Alex McKenzie 和 Will Crowther 的采访。我们还参考了 ARPA 的提案请求和 BBN 的提案。

The description of the building of the Interface Message Processor was based on interviews with Dave Walden, Ben Barker, Severo Ornstein, Bob Kahn, Frank Heart, Alex McKenzie, and Will Crowther. We also relied on ARPA’s request for proposals and on BBN’s proposal.

第五章

Chapter Five

关于 UCLA 为 IMP Number One 所做的准备和接收的描述基于对 Len Kleinrock、Steve Crocker、Mike Wingfield 和 Vint Cerf 的采访。关于网络工作组在分层协议方面的早期工作的描述基于对 Steve Crocker、Jon Postel 和 Vint Cerf 的采访。关于 UCLA 和 SRI 之间第一次登录会话的描述基于对 Len Kleinrock 和 Charley Kline 的采访。关于 1970 年初进行的僵局测试的描述基于对 Bob Kahn、Dave Walden 和 Vint Cerf 的采访。

The description of UCLA’s preparations for and receipt of the IMP Number One is based on interviews with Len Kleinrock, Steve Crocker, Mike Wingfield, andVint Cerf. The description of the Network Working Group’s early work in layered protocols was based on interviews with Steve Crocker, Jon Postel, andVint Cerf. The description of the first log-in session between UCLA and SRI was based on interviews with Len Kleinrock and Charley Kline. The description of the gridlock tests conducted in early 1970 was based on interviews with Bob Kahn, Dave Walden, andVint Cerf.

约翰·梅尔文 (John Melvin) 帮助我们寻找 UCLA 和 SRI 之间初始登录会话另一端的可能人选，但没有成功。现在我们知道那人不是谁。我们仍然迫切想知道那人是谁。

John Melvin helped us in our unsuccessful search for whoever might have been at the other end of the initial log-in session between UCLA and SRI. Now we know who it was not. We are still eager to know who it was.

第六章

Chapter Six

早期 ARPANET 站点的描述基于 BBN 季度技术报告、技术论文以及对 John Melvin 和 John Day 的采访。Alex McKenzie 提供了有关网络运营中心早期的信息。IMP 维护问题和后续解决方案的描述基于对 Ben Barker、Frank Heart、Severo Ornstein 和 Alex McKenzie 的采访。ICCC '72 ARPANET 演示的描述基于对 Al Vezza、Bob Kahn、Steve Crocker、Len Kleinrock、Jon Postel、Alex McKenzie 和 Larry Roberts 的采访。“PARRY Encounters the Doctor”以 RFC 的形式完整发布，并于 1973 年 7 月发表在Datamation杂志上。

The description of the earlyARPANETsites was based on BBN quarterly technical reports, technical papers, and interviews with John Melvin and John Day. Alex McKenzie supplied information on the early days of the Network Operations Center. The description of the IMP’s maintenance problems and subsequent resolution was based on interviews with Ben Barker, Frank Heart, Severo Ornstein, and Alex McKenzie. The description of the ICCC ’72 demonstration of theARPANETwas based on interviews with Al Vezza, Bob Kahn, Steve Crocker, Len Kleinrock, Jon Postel, Alex McKenzie, and Larry Roberts. “PARRY Encounters the Doctor” was published in its entirety as an RFC and appeared inDatamationmagazine, July 1973.

第七章

Chapter Seven

关于雷·汤姆林森 (Ray Tomlinson) 最初的电子邮件黑客行为以及他选择 @ 符号作为分隔符（并因此给 UNIX 用户带来问题）的描述是基于对汤姆林森和约翰·维塔尔 (JohnVittal) 的采访。

The description of Ray Tomlinson’s original e-mail hack and his choice of the @ sign as a separator—and as a problem forUNIXusers—was based on interviews with Tomlinson and JohnVittal.

MsgGroup 档案的部分内容最初由 Ed Vielmetti 发送给我们。Einar Stefferud 将它们全部保存下来并存放在波士顿计算机博物馆。Ken Harrenstien 帮助我们理清了一些早期邮件列表的历史。Ned Freed 为我们提供了电子邮件使用情况的比较数据。

Parts of the MsgGroup archives were first sent to us by Ed Vielmetti. Einar Stefferud saved them all and deposited them at the Boston Computer Museum. Ken Harrenstien helped us straighten out some early mailing-list history. Ned Freed supplied us with comparative figures on e-mail usage.

Adventure 起源的描述基于对 Don Woods、Will Crowther 和 Dave Walden 的采访。Woods 对 Adventure 的回忆也出现在Janice Winsor 所著的《Unix 游戏之书》中，Prentice-Hall Computer Books 出版社，1996 年。第 208 页关于网络上官方声明的观察来自 Paulina Borsook 所著的《无政府主义是如何运作的》（Wired杂志，1995 年 10 月）。finger 程序的历史来自 Les Earnest。

The description of the origins of Adventure was based on interviews with Don Woods, Will Crowther, and Dave Walden. Woods’s recollections of Adventure also appear inThe Unix Book of Games,by Janice Winsor, Prentice-Hall Computer Books, 1996. Observations on page 208 about proclamations of officialness on the Net come from “How Anarchy Works,” by Paulina Borsook,Wiredmagazine, October 1995. The history of the finger program came from Les Earnest.

第八章

Chapter Eight

分组无线电和分组卫星计划的描述基于各种技术论文（见参考书目），以及对 Vint Cerf、Alex McKenzie 和 Bob Kahn 的个人采访。部分材料取自查尔斯·巴贝奇研究所进行的采访。TCP/IP 演变的描述基于对 Vint Cerf、Bob Kahn、John Shoch、Alex McKenzie 和 Jon Postel 的采访。

Descriptions of the packet-radio and packet-satellite programs were based on various technical papers (see bibliography), as well as on personal interviews withVint Cerf, Alex McKenzie, and Bob Kahn. Some material was taken from interviews conducted by the Charles Babbage Institute. The description of the evolution of TCP/IP was based on interviews with Vint Cerf, Bob Kahn, John Shoch, Alex McKenzie, and Jon Postel.

以太网起源的描述基于对 Bob Metcalfe 的采访。Butler Lampson 对以太网的描述取自Douglas Smith 和 Robert C. Alexander 合著的《Fumbling the Future》（William Morrow，1988 年），第 97 页。

The description of the origins of Ethernet was based on interviews with Bob Metcalfe. Butler Lampson’s description of Ethernet is taken fromFumbling the Future,by Douglas Smith and Robert C. Alexander (William Morrow, 1988), p. 97.

Ole Jacobsen 的文章“OSI 的麻烦”（ConneXions，第 6 卷，第 5 期，1992 年 5 月），尤其是对双 AA 电池的提及，帮助引导了 OSI 与 TCP/IP 的比较部分。Peter Salus 的书《Casting the Net》 （Addison-Wesley，1995 年）和他在ConneXions，第 9 卷，第 8 期，1995 年 8 月发表的文章“协议战争：OSI 终于死了吗？”也帮助引导了这场争论。

Ole Jacobsen’s article, “The Trouble with OSI,” ConneXions,volume 6, no. 5, May 1992, particularly the reference to double AA batteries, helped guide the section on OSI vs. TCP/IP. Peter Salus’s bookCasting the Net,(Addison-Wesley, 1995), and his article “Protocol Wars: Is OSI Finally Dead?” inConneXions,volume 9, no. 8, August 1995, also helped frame the debate.

丹尼·科恩 (Danny Cohen) 允许我们对他于 1989 年在加州大学洛杉矶分校 (UCLA) 第一幕研讨会上向与会者朗读的这首诗进行少许编辑并重印。

未发表的论文、二手资料采访及其他文件

Unpublished Papers, Interviews from Secondary Sources, and Other Documents

“第一幕”。1989 年 8 月 17 日，加州大学洛杉矶分校举办的 ARPANET 历史研讨会。文字记录。

ARPA 网络信息中心，斯坦福研究所，门洛帕克，加利福尼亚州。“ARPANET 使用场景”。小册子。为 1972 年 10 月华盛顿特区举行的国际计算机通信会议准备。Baran

，Paul。采访人：Judy O'Neill。查尔斯·巴贝奇研究所，DARPA/IPTO 口述历史收藏，明尼苏达大学信息处理历史中心，明尼阿波利斯，明尼苏达州，1990 年 3 月 5 日。

———.“BBN Proposal No. IMP P69-IST-5: Interface Message Processors for the ARPA Computer Network.” Design proposal. Submitted to the Department of the Army, Defense Supply Service, in response to RFQ No. DAHC15 69 Q 0002. Washington, D.C., 6 September 1968.

———。“BBN 报告编号 1763：ARPA 计算机网络接口消息处理器的初步设计。”设计提案。根据合同编号 DAHC 15-69-C-0179 提交给高级研究计划局。华盛顿特区，1969 年 1 月 6 日。

———. “BBN Report No. 1763: Initial Design for Interface Message Processors for the ARPA Computer Network.” Design proposal. Submitted to the Advanced Research Projects Agency under contract no. DAHC 15-69-C-0179. Washington, D.C., 6 January 1969.

———。“BBN 报告编号 1822：接口消息处理器。”技术报告。马萨诸塞州剑桥，1969 年。

———.“ARPA 计算机网络接口消息处理器”。季度技术报告。根据合同号 DAHC 15-69-C-0179 和合同号 F08606-73-C-0027 提交给高级研究计划局。华盛顿特区，1969-1973 年。

———.“Interface Message Processors for the ARPA Computer Network.” Quarterly technical reports. Submitted to the Advanced Research Projects Agency under contract no. DAHC 15-69-C-0179 and contract no. F08606-73-C-0027. Washington, D.C., 1969– 1973.

———。“接口信息处理器操作手册：516 IMP、316 IMP、TEP。”修订版。根据 ARPA 订单号 1260、合同号 DAHC15-69-C-0179 提交给高级研究计划局。弗吉尼亚州阿灵顿，1973 年 4 月。

———. “Operating Manual for Interface Message Processors: 516 IMP, 316 IMP, TEP.” Revised. Submitted to the Advanced Research Projects Agency under ARPA order no. 1260, contract no. DAHC15-69-C-0179. Arlington,Va., April 1973.

———。“报告编号 4799：ARPANET 的历史：第一个十年。”提交给国防高级研究计划局。弗吉尼亚州阿灵顿，1981 年 4 月。——。“四座城市计划。”波士顿、华盛顿、洛杉矶和旧金山的 IMP 和 TIP 维护草案和成本分析。BBN 第 6 分部文件。马萨诸塞州剑桥，1974 年 4 月。

———. “Report No. 4799: A History of theARPANET:The First Decade.” Submitted to the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. Arlington,Va., April 1981. ———.“The Four Cities Plan.” Draft proposal and cost analysis for maintenance of IMPs and TIPs in Boston, Washington, Los Angeles, and San Francisco. Papers of BBN Division 6. Cambridge, Mass., April 1974.

———。与第 6 分部工作有关的内部备忘录和文件。马萨诸塞州剑桥，1971-1972 年。

Lukasik, Stephen. Interview by Judy O’Neill. Charles Babbage Institute, DARPA/IPTO Oral History Collection, University of Minnesota Center for the History of Information Processing, Minneapolis, Minn., 17 October 1991.

Marill, Thomas 和 Lawrence G. Roberts。“迈向分时计算机合作网络。”1966 年美国信息处理学会联合会秋季联合计算机会议上发表的论文。

Marill, Thomas, and Lawrence G. Roberts. “Toward a Cooperative Network of TimeShared Computers.” Paper presented at the Fall Joint Computer Conference of the American Federation of Information Processing Societies, 1966.

McCarthy, J.、S. Boilen、E. Fredkin 和 JCR Licklider。“小型计算机的分时调试系统”。1963 年美国信息处理学会联合会春季联合计算机会议上发表的论文。

McCarthy, J., S. Boilen, E. Fredkin, and J. C. R. Licklider. “A Time-Sharing Debugging System for a Small Computer.” Paper presented at the Spring Joint Computer Conference of the American Federation of Information Processing Societies, 1963.

McKenzie, Alexander A. “ARPA 网络控制中心”。该论文于 1975 年 10 月在电气和电子工程师协会第四届数据通信研讨会上发表。

McKenzie, Alexander A. “The ARPA Network Control Center.” Paper presented at the Fourth Data Communications Symposium of the Institute for Electrical and Electronics Engineers, October 1975.

麦肯齐，亚历山大 A. 采访者：朱迪·奥尼尔。查尔斯·巴贝奇研究所，DARPA/IPTO 口述历史收藏，明尼苏达大学信息处理历史中心，明尼阿波利斯，明尼苏达州，1990 年 3 月 13 日。

McKenzie, Alexander A. Interview by Judy O’Neill. Charles Babbage Institute, DARPA/IPTO Oral History Collection, University of Minnesota Center for the History of Information Processing, Minneapolis, Minn., 13 March 1990.

信息组。信息组（或 MsgGroup）成员发送的 2,600 多封电子邮件的全文，该组是最早的电子邮件列表之一，与电子邮件的发展有关。计算机博物馆，马萨诸塞州波士顿，1975 年 6 月 - 1986 年 6 月。电子文档。（http://www.tcm.org/msgroup）

Message Group. The full text of more than 2,600 e-mail messages sent by members of the Message Group (or MsgGroup), one of the first electronic mailing lists, relating to the development of e-mail. The Computer Museum, Boston, Mass., June 1975–June 1986. Electronic document. (http://www.tcm.org/msgroup)

Metcalfe, Robert。“网络中的一些历史性时刻。”征求意见稿 89。网络工作组，1971 年 1 月 19 日。

 

 

Myer, TH 和 DA Henderson。“消息传输协议。”征求意见稿 680。斯坦福研究所，门洛帕克，加利福尼亚州，1975 年。

国家研究委员会，工程技术系统委员会。“国防部数据网络传输协议”。1985 年向国防部和国家标准局、电信和计算机应用委员会提交的报告。

National Research Council, Commission on Engineering and Technical Systems. “Transport Protocols for Department of Defense Data Networks.” Report to the Department of Defense and the National Bureau of Standards, Board on Telecommunication and Computer Applications, 1985.

Neigus，新泽西州“文件传输协议”。征求意见稿 542。Bolt Beranek and Newman Inc.，马萨诸塞州剑桥，1973 年 7 月 12 日。

Norberg, Arthur L. 和 Judy E. O'Neill。“国防高级研究计划局信息处理技术办公室的历史。” 明尼苏达大学查尔斯·巴贝奇研究所，明尼苏达州明尼阿波利斯，1992 年。

Norberg, Arthur L., and Judy E. O’Neill. “A History of the Information Processing Techniques Office of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency.” Charles Babbage Institute, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, Minn., 1992.

Ornstein, Severo M.、FE Heart、WR Crowther、HK Rising、SB Russell 和 A. Michel。“ARPA 网络的终端 IMP。”论文发表于 1972 年 5 月美国信息处理学会联合会春季联合计算机会议，新泽西州大西洋城。Ornstein

, Severo。采访人：Judy O'Neill。查尔斯·巴贝奇研究所、DARPA/IPTO 口述历史收藏、明尼苏达大学信息处理历史中心，明尼苏达州明尼阿波利斯，1990 年 3 月 6 日。

Ornstein, Severo M., F. E. Heart, W. R. Crowther, H. K. Rising, S. B. Russell, and A. Michel. “The Terminal IMP for the ARPA Network.” Paper presented at the Spring Joint Computer Conference of the American Federation of Information Processing Societies, Atlantic City, N.J., May 1972.

Ornstein, Severo. Interview by Judy O’Neill. Charles Babbage Institute, DARPA/IPTO Oral History Collection, University of Minnesota Center for the History of Information Processing, Minneapolis, Minn., 6 March 1990.

Pogran, Ken、John Vittal、Dave Crowther 和 Austin Henderson。“ARPA 网络消息格式的拟议官方标准。”征求意见稿 724。麻省理工学院，马萨诸塞州剑桥，1977 年 5 月 12 日。

Pogran, Ken, John Vittal, Dave Crowther, and Austin Henderson. “Proposed Official Standard for the Format of ARPA Network Messages.” Request for Comments 724. MIT, Cambridge, Mass., 12 May 1977.

Postel, Jonathan B. “简单邮件传输协议。”征求意见稿 821。南加州大学信息科学研究所，1982 年 8 月。————。“互联网传输控制协议规范：TCP 版本 4。”南加州大学信息科学研究所，1978 年 9 月。————。“TCP 和 IP 较量。”征求意见稿 1025。网络工作组，1987 年 9 月。

 

 

Pouzin, Louis。“网络协议。”国际网络工作组 50 笔记，1973 年 9 月。

———.“Cyclades 计算机网络的介绍和主要设计方面。” 1973 年 11 月，在 IEEE 第三届数据通信研讨会（数据网络：分析和设计）上发表的论文。

———.“Presentation and Major Design Aspects of the Cyclades Computer Network.” Paper presented at the IEEE Third Data Communications Symposium (Data Networks: Analysis and Design), November 1973.

———。“实验性通信协议：基本消息框架。”国际网络工作组第 48 次会议记录，1974 年 1 月。

 

 

———.“分组交换网络的互连。”国际网络工作组第 42 号记录，1973 年 10 月。

 

 

———。“网络架构和组件。”国际网络工作组第 49 次会议记录，1973 年 8 月。

 

 

兰德公司。“分布式自适应信息块网络的发展。”1965 年 8 月 30 日，向空军参谋部提出的建议。

年”。高级研究计划局研究，合同编号：MDA

903-74-C-0096。华盛顿特区，1975 年 12 月。复印件。

1974.” A study for the Advanced Research Projects Agency under contract no. MDA

903-74-C-0096. Washington, D.C., December 1975. Photocopy.

Roberts, Lawrence G. 和 Barry D. Wessler。“计算机网络开发以实现资源共享。”1970 年美国信息处理学会联合会春季联合计算机会议上发表的论文。

Ruina, Jack. Interview by William Aspray. Charles Babbage Institute, DARPA/IPTO Oral History Collection, University of Minnesota Center for the History of Information Processing, Minneapolis, Minn., 20 April 1989.

Taylor, Robert. Interview by William Aspray. Charles Babbage Institute, DARPA/IPTO Oral History Collection, University of Minnesota Center for the History of Information Processing, Minneapolis, Minn., 28 February 1989.

美国邮政服务。“美国邮政服务电子信息系统”。美国邮政服务支持小组报告，电信委员会，华盛顿特区，1977 年 1 月。

Walden, David C. “Experiences in Building, Operating, and Using the ARPA Network.” Paper presented at the Second USA-Japan Computer Conference, Tokyo, Japan, August 1975.

沃尔登，戴维。采访人：朱迪·奥尼尔。查尔斯·巴贝奇研究所，DARPA/IPTO 口述历史收藏，明尼苏达大学信息处理历史中心，明尼阿波利斯，明尼苏达州，1990 年 2 月 6 日。

Walden, David. Interview by Judy O’Neill. Charles Babbage Institute, DARPA/IPTO Oral History Collection, University of Minnesota Center for the History of Information Processing, Minneapolis, Minn., 6 February 1990.

Walker, Stephen T. “Completion Report: ARPA Network Development.” Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, Information Processing Techniques Office, Washington, D.C., 4 January 1978.
